snippet.title: How to Convert your Quickbooks Desktop File to Quickbooks Online
snippet.description:
How to Convert your Quickbooks Desktop File to Quickbooks Online

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

This is the new way. This is, we've been doing this for five years, join the cloud revolution. There's no reason to have all your QuickBooks information tied up in a single file when it can just be accessed online. QuickBooks Online is so much easier. So let me just tell you how to do this. I'm recording this video because we still get this request quite a bit when we're talking to new prospects. And so basically what you're going to do is you're going to, you log into QuickBooks Desktop and then make sure your file, like your whole QuickBooks Desktop is all up to date. Save that, save the file. A lot of people sometimes are doing this conversion when they don't actually have a QuickBooks Desktop program. 

Like this happens to us quite a bit. Like someone will send us their file. And so for us we have to actually download a trial version of QuickBooks Desktop. So you can just Google QuickBooks Desktop trial version, Intuit has some really good help links on this by the way. Download that trial piece of software, they will actually let you start or convert one account without having to pay for QuickBooks Desktop. So they're very nice about this. They want to incentivize you to get on QuickBooks Online as well. 

I think Kruze, on our website, you can click and we have a discount link you can just click through and I forget what the discount is, it's like 30% or something like that. Feel free to do that. And then you are going to, once you have your QuickBooks Online account set up, you are going to go back to QuickBooks Desktop and there is, in the file menu there is an export option you can do. You are going to click that and then it's going to run you through a series of prompts and ask you what the destination is and where in QuickBooks Online you want to convert it. It's all super easy. It's going to be like, it's easier than easy. It shouldn't take you like two minutes to do this, but it's going to be very obvious when you log in to the QuickBooks Online account, what the destination, what it's called. You're going to click "convert". You're going to give it, you're basically going to do that and then you're going to give it like 10 minutes. It's going to think, it's going to convert over. You'll get a message that says something like: we'll send you an email when your account has been converted over. 

And then you are going to go over to QuickBooks Online and refresh or maybe log out and sign in again. And make sure all your data is there. So you're going to want to kind of do a side-by-side comparison to make sure your income statement and your balance sheet, the general ledger, all match what is inside QuickBooks Desktop. I wouldn't recommend like a super thorough craziness, go through every line item. You're going to be able to tell if things are in there by what the balance sheet income statement look like, the general ledger. If everything matches, everything balances, everything's reconciled still, you should be fine. And then you will go over to "manage my users" with the, there's a little gear icon in the upper right. 

And you are going to manage your users and invite your friendly CPA firm, Kruze Consulting, to your accounts. Very, very easy. You do it as an accountant user. This, people don't know this necessarily, but being an account user gives you some superpowers. We can see all of the clients that we work with in one, you know, one giant console, and we can provision permission for each member of our team through that accountant console. So super important to give your accountant access as an accountant, not just as a normal user, because that'll make it kind of difficult for them, especially if you're doing this to get a quote. 

Like the context of this for us, a lot of times, if someone has been maybe working with like an old school accountant who only knows desktop, or maybe they have been doing it themselves, and they're looking to professionalize their bookkeeping and taxes. And so this whole kind of jump through these hoops is all to get it into a QuickBooks Online version, where we can easily deliver a quote and tell you what's going on in your book. So I hope this helps, again Intuit does have some really good resources, including some videos on this. So I'm not going to really do like a play by play, insert a play by play video here. But this commentary should be very helpful for you. 

Because there's a couple of places where it gets a little sticky and you know, kind of a hard time knowing where to go. So I hope this helps. If you have any questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. We'll help you out and wish you the best of luck, thanks.

name: How to Convert your Quickbooks Desktop File to Quickbooks Online

snippet.title: When is the best time to send out a W9 to a vendor to determine if they need a 1099?
snippet.description:
When is the best time to send out a W9 to a vendor to determine if they need a 1099?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, we're talking about when's the right time to send a W9 to a vendor, so you can figure out if you need to give them a 1099 or not? 

So let's start really slow here. A W9 is a taxpayer information form that's on the IRS website. Technically, you should send this to all of your vendors. But really, you're just worried about the vendors that are independent contractors, sole member LLCs, partnerships, folks like that. You don't have to worry about S corps or C corps. 

So those folks that need a 1099 to basically state what you paid that vendor during the year on a cash basis, so that they can fill out their taxes. The IRS wants them to get a form so they can fill out their taxes. But also, the IRS wants to get that form themselves so they know what that person should be paying in taxes. So there's definitely a giant cross check happening here, where when that contractor fills out their income tax form, the IRS is checking to see what you paid them and what they actually declared. So that's why 1099s are done. 

Now 1099s are due every January 31st. And so if you don't do those, it's a really big deal. You'll get fined, I think it's like $1,000 or $2,000 per 1099 not filed. It may even be $10,000. It's a really big number. So you really wanna do this. So when are the best times of the year to send out that W9 so that you can determine whether the vendor gets a 1099 or not? 

So the first one is, I like to send it out right away when you start working with them. Like when you're signing the contract, it's nice to kinda bundle that into the contract, or right before you pay the vendor, especially contractors. Sometimes contractors are disorganized. They're a little harder to reach throughout the year, and so if you can get that information right away, that's always helpful. Store it in a really safe place. 

But sometimes it's kinda like, that's not really a scalable process to stop what you're doing all the time and send the W9. So the other alternative is to do it at the end of the year or right in January, when you're preparing all your 1099s. So and that, the cool thing about that is that allows you to run a giant batch process. And so it's very, very efficient with your time. And also, you've just determined, you've closed your books for the year. So you know exactly what you paid this person on a cash basis. So it makes filling out the 1099, after you get the W9 a lot easier. 

So I would either do it right away, before you actually pay that vendor. Or do it in January, so you can do it in bulk and handle all of your vendors at the same time. The nice thing is using a tool that kinda hides the social security number is actually really important. You do not want a bunch of social security numbers flying back and forth in your email inbox, or in documents in your email inbox. You wanna really minimize that. That's just kind of a threat and it's liability you don't really wanna take. 

So we really like using web tools like Track1099 to handle that stuff because they mask all the social security numbers. So again remember, you need to fill out 1099s every year for all your contractors, partnerships, sole member LLCs that you paid throughout the year. You're gonna do it on a cash basis. 

And you need to get those filed before January 31st. So it's really important to know the tax status of all those vendors, so that you can send those 1099s out when it's time. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: When is the best time to send out a W9 to a vendor to determine if they need a 1099?

snippet.title: File Taxes on Time: The Single Most Important Reason for a Startup
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn what happens if you don't file taxes on time for a startup or forget to file taxes on time.

00:00 Introduction
00:12 Startup taxes on time
02:14 Please do your taxes on time
03:30 Conclusion

*******************************
Additional Resources

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2ct0qLSyL0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gGcK8MxFlII

*******************************

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

#filetaxesontime #startupbusiness  #taxes 

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about the single best reason for doing your startup's taxes on time. 

And there's many reasons. You take care of your compliance. You don't look like a schmuck when the VCs want to give you a term sheet, or the acquirer comes, you know exactly what your tax obligations are. It's something you check off the list early in the year, instead of late in the year. There's a lot of benefits, but the single best benefit is that, if you file your return on time, you actually get to take advantage of what's called the R&D Tax Credit, which is a payroll tax offset. So a lot of times people come to us, they don't care, this is incorrect thinking, by the way, they don't think they need to worry about their taxes, doing them on time, because they lost money and they don't owe any money. 

Obviously, if you make a profit, you do owe taxes to the IRS, and so you really want to file your taxes on time in that scenario, too. But these are startups that are losing money and then they think, "Ah, who cares, doesn't matter." But what's happening is they're actually losing out on the payroll tax offset from the R&D Tax Credit. Now, if they file their taxes late, they can still get a tax credit, but it's a 20 year carry forward that can only be used against profits. So what's so cool about the payroll tax offset is pretty much everyone who has employees, who's building something, is going to pay payroll taxes. 

And so the IRS and Treasury allow you to deduct the credit against your payroll taxes. Now, you can only do that if it's filed in a timely manner, to quote the wonderful Internal Revenue Service, the IRS. So, all those startups who are blowing their deadlines, not filing extensions, not caring, are probably costing themselves on, for a seed stage company, it might be $20K. For a Series A company, it's probably 50 to $100K. For Series B companies it can be up to $250K in payroll tax offsets that come from the R&D Tax Credit. 

So this is why I bang on the table and say, "Please do your taxes on time." Also make sure, side note, you're working with someone who actually understands startup taxes. There's so many companies that come to us that have the local bookkeeper or CPA, or they hired someone on Craigslist, or they're working with an online accounting firm that outsources everything to third parties, and doesn't actually do any taxes, even though they advertise they do taxes on their website, which I think that, I don't know if that's actually even kosher or legal, but we see it happen. 

And these people are groups. They're small time and they don't actually understand tax credits. They don't understand the importance of doing your tax returns on time. They don't understand the importance of actually doing a good, accurate tax return, and having those tax returns match the financials. The first thing that happens when you're going to get acquired, or a VC fund is going to invest in you, is they open your financials. 

They open your tax return. If those do not match, there's a problem, so please do them on time, and do them with someone reputable who actually really knows what they're doing, and look for that CPA designation. That is the industry accreditation. The government regulates CPA firms. They don't regulate people who use third party tax services, or the local Craigslist bookkeeper. 

And so you can make sure you're getting it done properly if you work with a CPA, kind of like Kruze Consulting. Check us out at kruzeconsulting.com if you have more questions about doing your taxes on time or any tax credits, the payroll tax offsets, anything related to startups, and finance and taxes, we're there. And please subscribe this channel if you don't mind.

name: File Taxes on Time: The Single Most Important Reason for a Startup

snippet.description:

#saasrevenuerecognition #saasrevenue #kruzeconsulting

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, how do SaaS companies recognize revenue on contracts that are annual and billed and collected upfront? This is a very common question. 

The answer is you always want to use accrual GAAP-based accounting and you always want to recognize that revenue on a monthly basis as you provide the service over the year. It doesn't matter if you collected the cash up front. If you booked it that way that would be called cash accounting. That's not accrual. That's not the right way to do things for startups. That's not the way that VCs, that's not the way that corporate development offices, they don't view your financials that way. They don't wanna see your financials that way. 

They want to see 'em on an accrual basis every time. And it's better for management and for the investors. Imagine you're sitting in a board meeting and you haven't been booking your reoccurring revenue stream on a monthly basis and your revenue, 'cause it's on cash, is bouncing all around and the board is freaking out because they invested in a SaaS company, thinking this is gonna be a smooth, long build. 

And you put up a zero this month, right? People are gonna lose their minds. So you're gonna take a lot of grief if your revenue is not booked correctly. And imagine when you go through an M&A, like if the corporate development group or the accounting firm that they hired to do due diligence on you, is looking at this and it's cash accounting, again bouncing all over, not consistent, not SaaS-like, they're gonna be worried that they're working or buying a company that isn't run by a super sophisticated team. They're also gonna be worried that the accounting firm that you're using is not doing their job correctly. 

And the next natural step is, well, what else is wrong? What else do I not know about? What's lurking beneath the surface here in this M&A deal? And it could literally make the deal fall apart. It could make them give you a haircut. There's a lot of bad things that could happen. So do your revenue recognition correctly, work with a CPA firm that knows what they're doing, that will be there for you during diligence, and always book this stuff on a monthly basis as you earn the revenue as you deliver the service. It doesn't matter if you collect the cash up front, although that's really good for mitigating your burn. 

So definitely try to collect upfront if possible. Hope that helps. If you have any questions on revenue recognition, SaaS companies, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and hey, while you're on our YouTube channel if you don't mind clicking the old subscribe button we'd appreciate it. We put a lot of time and energy into these videos and hope you see more of them. Thanks.

name: How Is SAAS Revenue Recognition From Annual Contracts Billed Upfront?

snippet.title: How should you present your startup's financial results to the board?
snippet.description:
How should you present your startup's financial results to the board?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts

The first one is like cash versus accrual accounting. The second one is like any kind of vanity metrics or metrics that make you look good. And then the third one is kind of the order and the presentation. So first we're going to go cash and accrual. So this is a very common question from our startup founders and really everything should basically be on accrual except you do want to include the pure cash burn number. So your revenue, your costs, your costs of goods sold, all that stuff and your net income, all that should be on accrual basis. But I like to show the board the actual cash burn. So I'll give them what we call like accrual burn which is usually taken from like your operating income line or your net income line. But that's an accounting burn rate. And then I also like to show them a cash burn which is like purely the amount of cash you had in the bank account last month, the amount of cash you have right now and the difference. And that is your true cash burn. 

So, I like to show, you know, again, accrual for everything and then show an additional cash burn, that's the pure cash burn. And then for vanity metrics, I like to do things like especially if you're a SaaS company, things like bookings. So that's usually like the total contract value of deals that you've recognized or signed in a given month. And the reason why that's important is bookings tend to be a forward indicator. And so if you're signing a bunch of contracts that are one-year, two-year, three-year contracts, that means your revenue's going to be really good in the future as you recognize those contracts and deliver the service. 

And so the board wants to know that. Some of the other, I wouldn't put this in the summary but other vanity metrics can be like LTV of customer or cost of acquisition and things like that. But I'm really talking about kind of your summary page here. And so, but I do think bookings is a really good way of showing the traction that's happening in the business and it's not going to show up in just your pure revenue recognition right away. So those are kind of the two, the first categories we're going to talk about. 

And the third one is just what does this actually look like? So I love to have a one-page financial summary very early in a board deck. And the reason for that is the board, they don't always know exactly what's going on financially at the company. So sometimes they're a little jittery or they're just a little nervous and they really kind of need some level setting and you want to let them know where you are. 

So I always like to have just a one-page summary. And this is again, there to kind of level set for them. Just get them oriented and give them a framework to think about the company. What milestones it needs to hit and where you are right now. And so that one page should have something like cash, cash burn for like the last month or last three months or last six months, we give our clients all those metrics. And then your total months of runway and then revenue and ideally bookings. 

And, really those five metrics will give them, venture capitalists talk to startups all day long. They're very good at doing the back of the envelope math on all financials very quickly. But that will just give them a foundation to look at the rest of your presentation and know if your business has plenty of cash and you don't need to worry. Or, "Hey, we're getting a little bit low on cash. We need to think about fundraising." And they'll be doing the metrics calculations in their head and thinking like, "Can this company raise another round or do we need to pare back? Whatever we need to do." That will help your board. 

And then the final thing just when you're talking about board meetings I like to have a much fuller, like kind of almost like a section of the presentation late in the board deck with your full profit and loss statement or like a summary but all the big line items, a balance sheet and ideally a cashflow statement. I also really like to show budget to actuals whenever possible on those things. And especially if you're a good management team and you're executing, budget to actuals actually build a ton of confidence in your investors. They know that you're managing the company tightly. It's a little bit of a cheat sheet for them because it actually allows them to ask smart questions, too. They'll see things are out of whack if you're under-hiring or over-hiring or just spending money too much, too fast on marketing, things like that.

name: How should you present your startup's financial results to the board?

snippet.title: What is a 409A Valuation, and why do funded startups need one?
snippet.description:
What is a 409A Valuation, and why do funded startups need one?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today, I'm answering the question, "What is a 409A valuation?" 

And a 409A valuation is a valuation that allows you to accurately and legally price your employee stock options. Typically, it's common stock. So back in the day when people would be working at a startup, they would get common stock options, and the board used to kinda make up whatever the price per share was. The old joke in the industry is that it would always be a penny a share, no matter how many shares outstanding and what percentage of ownership of the company, always a penny a share. 

And then about 15 years ago, the IRS got smart, and they said, you know what? We think 409A valuation, or we think stock options are systematically being underpriced. And so they instituted the rules that led to 409A valuations. So basically, that means a third-party valuation provider, who's accredited, needs to actually do a couple different analyses to figure out what the fair market value of the common stock prices, and therefore what the stock option price is gonna be. And there's a couple ways to do that. 

The back solve method is typically the most popular in the startup world, because the valuation provider can work backwards, hence, back solve, against the valuation that was just recently done by an independent venture capitalist who put money into the company. So typically, the back solve method yields a valuation of 25 to 35% of preferred. It can bounce around a little bit, but that's kind of the area. Another method is the cost to recreate. You can just look at that and say hey, we've built all this technology. We've got maybe all this revenue. What would it take to build this from scratch? And you have to do a pretty thorough job of listing everything out, itemizing everything, and your accountant usually gets involved. 

But that's another way to do the valuation. Other ways are free cashflow analysis, or just discounted cashflow analysis, comparable multiples analysis. There's a bunch of different ways, but in the startup world, it's usually back solve or cost to recreate. But because there's all these parameters now, there's companies that do 409A valuations, Kruze, we do those with a partner, tons of them. And they're really cheap. The pricing has really come down. I think it starts at $2,000 for us. And because a lot of technology and a lot of systems have been put in place to make these scalable, and be able to a lot of 409As, the price has come down. 

So it's a great time if you're needing 409A valuations, 'cause they are affordable, easy to get. It takes usually about two weeks, two business weeks, to get a 409A, but if your startup is gonna issue stock options to your employees, you're gonna need a 409A, because you don't wanna cross the IRS. And some people think oh, the IRS isn't gonna audit me, or something like that. Well, you have audit risk with the IRS, but you also have audit risk with a late-stage audit partner. 

So typically, when companies hit series C or series D, they're gonna start getting audits every month, every year, excuse me, because the late-stage venture capitalists are putting a lot of money in these companies. They wanna make sure everything's audited, and really getting ready for an IPO, something like that. And if that late-stage audit firm, like a Deloitte, KPMG, E and Y, see that you didn't do 409As, or the 409As are, for whatever reason, not done properly or underpriced, they will actually throw a wrench in your audit and make you do a repricing of those options and take basically charges against your financials. 

And they're doing you a favor, 'cause they're keeping you in compliance, they're keeping you clean. The last thing you wanna do is get to the doorstep of an IPO and have a lot of stock option compensation problems. So really, it's kinda like a lot of things in accounting and tax, these rules are set up to kinda protect you, in a way. But it's just best practice. Get a 409A valuation. They're good for a year, or until you have a material change in your valuation. And if you need help, just hit us up at Kruze. Hope that helps, thanks!

name: What is a 409A Valuation, and why do funded startups need one?

snippet.title: How can you tell if your Accountant is doing Cash Accounting vs. Accrual Accounting?
snippet.description:
How can you tell if your Accountant is doing Cash Accounting vs. Accrual Accounting?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

You want to be on accrual accounting. I'm kind of chuckling here, but you really do. That's what you and your investors are gonna need to know how you're spending money. Because accrual accounting basically puts the expenses and revenue in the periods that they were earned or incurred. Cash accounting is just like, it's like the Wild West. It's like whenever the money came into the bank account or left the bank account. And so it's really hard to predictably run your business on a cash accounting basis because you have these like giant bulk payments to suppliers or contractors, or maybe you get a big prepayment in from a customer and so you have like this one lump sum, either a revenue or expense, and you don't actually know when it was earned. You don't have the predictability of knowing what's actually gonna happen in the future. So accrual accounting is super duper important, you definitely wanna be on it. 

Now, I hate to say this, but like kind of the Craigslist special bookkeeper who you found on Craigslist, those are the kind of people who wanna do stuff on a cash accounting basis, or a lot of the, "automated firms" that usually aren't really that automated, they're the ones who wanna do cash accounting because it's so much easier for them. All they do is take, again, those cash entries from your bank account and slam them into QuickBooks and call it a day. It is so much easier than actually accruing things over the correct time periods. But again, to have the visibility, you need that stuff accrued over the right time period. So let me give you a couple examples. One example is revenue. So say you are a SaaS based company and you sell a 12 month deal to a client, and they're gonna pay $120,000 for the year. You want to accrue that revenue and spread it out over each month. You wanna do revenue recognition, which is the foundation of accrual accounting. So each month out of 12, you're gonna give yourself $10,000 of revenue. 

And for the revenue that is not earned yet because you haven't gotten to those time periods where you're actually serving the customer, that's gonna sit on your balance sheet as deferred revenue. Now, a lot of investors look at deferred revenue and they know that's predictable revenue the company is gonna be able to count in the future. So that's a really good way of doing it. Now, if you're doing cash accounting, you would just take that $120,000 deposit. Boom, put it in one month, and then you got zeros the rest of the time. That's gonna look really bumpy and weird, and it's definitely gonna come up at your board meeting. So do it the accrual accounting way. Another example on the expense side is say you have just an amazing graphic designer and they re-did your entire website. 

And you know, you asked them to do that work and they did it in February, of a given month And they got it all done in February, but they invoiced you in March, and then you actually got around to paying them in April. So on a cash accounting basis, that's just gonna look like a really big expense in April, but actually you should be accruing that expense for the time period it was delivered or the service was delivered, which is February. So that's gonna be way more accurate on your financials. You might get to your board meeting in May and someone's like, hey, what's this giant April expense? And you're gonna be looking at it. You're not actually gonna really remember because that graphic designer did the work for you in February. Or heaven forbid, that graphic designer did their work in February and March, two months and you finally paid them in April. 

Again, you're gonna have that big bulk payment in April, but actually that expense should have been spread out over February and March. So you really wanna do things on accrual basis. Again, it just gives you more visibility into your business. It also makes your tax returns more accurate. You really wanna have your tax returns filed on an accrual basis. If there's some, maybe not so great tax accountants and bookkeepers who outsource to those tax accountants, who will always file you on a cash basis because it's easier for them, but then you have to switch over and actually notify the IRS that you're switching to accrual basis eventually. 

And so that's expensive, it takes time, you have to fill out some forms, And the IRS is always inundated with stuff. So sometimes they could actually unintentionally lose something, and you might have to sit there and wait for your tax return to be filed, which could cost you money on your R&D Tax Credit rebate. So there's just a lot of reasons to be on accrual accounting, not just for your financials, but on your tax return.

name: How can you tell if your Accountant is doing Cash Accounting vs. Accrual Accounting?

snippet.title: How should Startups distribute cash to existing shareholders right before an acquisition?
snippet.description:
How should Startups distribute cash to existing shareholders right before an acquisition?

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, how should startups distribute cash to existing investors right before an acquisition? 

So this is a happy scenario here. This is a company, your company is getting bought and odds are, if you're a venture-backed startup you've probably raised a bunch of cash. And so sometimes companies get bought right after they raised a bunch of VC cash or somewhere in the middle and they haven't really run that cash down. And so, right before they get bought, as part of the acquisition or the merger, the seller, the company that's getting bought will negotiate with the acquirer and say like, "Look, we've got 5 or 10 or $20 million of cash on our balance sheet that our investors put into this company. And you know what? We don't wanna just sell a company, give you that money. We want that money back. That's part of the acquisition price in our head." And if you negotiate this with the buyer, they'll understand that. 

Sometimes the buyers do wanna kind of roll that into the acquisition price. If they're paying $100 million and you've got $20 million of cash on your balance sheet. They're really thinking we're buying you for $80 million. That's why it's important to really negotiate this and make sure it's clear to everyone. So you don't have any surprises right before close. But, most acquirers that we deal with are pretty savvy, fortune 500 companies, and so they get this. So, say you've got that extra $20 million on your balance sheet and you're getting bought in a week. Well, the investors want that money back and they should get that money back. 

And so the way you do it is you issue a 1099-DIV. This is a tax form and you will put the dividend amount in box three. If you do a little Googling, you'll see box three is basically a non-dividend distribution. Meaning, like there weren't profits, the company... And again, I should clarify that, this is for startups that weren't generating a profit. Profit would be a different, if you're distributing profits that'd be a different scenario. But, this is for companies that have raised a bunch of money who are burning a bunch of money but have built something of value and so they're getting acquired for their market position, their intellectual property, how awesome the business looks going forward. But they never generated profit. And so therefore, you do put the amount for distributed into box three because that is a non-dividend distribution. 

Now, with the 1099-DIV, you do need to report out to the folks that you actually made this distribution to. Send them the 1099 before January 31st of the following tax year. So say, I'm recording this in early 2021. Say you make this distribution now. In January of 2022, that's when you're gonna send out the 1099-DIV. So it's really important that you actually give your investors, the people you're distributing this capital to their 1099-DIV, because they need that to report on their own taxes. If they don't get that, they may miss it. The IRS will flag it, see it and it could create some tax problems. So be organized, make sure your tax firm like Kruze, who's taking you through this acquisition is actually there for, ready to do this and knows they need to do this. 

But, this is a good thing. I mean, we do see this quite a bit where companies, especially now the market's hot, companies are able to raise quite a bit of capital, but guess what? Acquirers, this is probably the reason the market's hot, acquirers are buying a lot of startups right now. And the acquirers who are savvy kind of understand that this is an incremental amount of money in addition to the purchase price. And so definitely negotiate this, totally normal to do. Don't hesitate and if the person who's buying it, buying you is saying, this is not marker or this is not what happens. They're wrong because this does happen quite a bit. 

So, I hope that helps. 1099-DIV non-dividend distribution, that is the way you do this. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How should Startups distribute cash to existing shareholders right before an acquisition?

snippet.title: How can an angel investor sell their shares?
snippet.description:
How can an angel investor sell their shares?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

But the idea is you're basically getting a better currency than the private shares you own in the startup and ideally cash is the best currency to get. One little thing, if you do get equity and it's like all equity or there's certain thresholds, I think it's 75% of the considerations in equity, then it's actually a tax deferred sale and you don't have to pay taxes on it immediately. Only the part that you actually get in cash, I believe, you pay taxes on. And so the equity you can just roll that over, you don't have to sell. Say, Microsoft buys one of your angel investment companies, oh, you can just own Microsoft stock for as long as you want and you don't have to pay taxes on it until you sell that Microsoft stock. So very, very nice. 

The second situation where you're selling your shares is in an IPO. And the company has done so well that Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JP Morgan, whoever is taking this company public, initial public offering. Now typically in the IPO the company sells kind of 10 to 20% of its total shares outstanding. Typically it creates actually new shares to sell that way. Sometimes there is like a secondary component where the demand for the stock is so strong on Wall Street that some of the insiders will actually be allowed to sell in the IPO. Fairly rare, but that does happen sometimes. So you could sell a little bit in the IPO, like the actual transaction, but just know pretty much any time one of your companies does an IPO, you will be restricted from anywhere, usually it's six months restricted from trading or selling any of your shares. 

And the way the mechanics on this work is typically like a venture capital fund, they want to come in and put a bunch of money in the company, but maybe they can only get 10% ownership or 15% ownership but their targeted ownership level is 20% ownership. If you think about it from the VC's perspective, they're making a bet on this company, they have conviction. They're professional money managers, if they have conviction they want to own as much as possible. And so most VC firms target 20%. And so, a way for them to get up to 20% if there's not enough preferred shares to buy is to buy common shares from the management team and from the angel investors, angels usually own common. 

Please let me know how much you would want to share. The target price is X dollars per share. And so everyone on that email list can basically do the math themselves. Sometimes angels want to get their cost basis back. Maybe they've made 20X on the investment and they feel like it's good for them to just get their money back at least and then let the rest ride. Other times if it's an angel fund or a pre-seed fund, this investment may be big enough to return the whole fund or maybe if they even sell 10 or 20% of that investment, they can return their whole fund. 

And so that's a really big moment for a venture capital fund, early stage venture capital fund or angel fund to return everything. And so they'll sell whatever it takes to get to that threshold and then let the rest ride. But it's really their kind of decision. I remember when I was talking to Jason Calcanis on his podcast, he was talking about how Uber, when SoftBank came into Uber, Uber came in and approached a bunch of the angel investors and said like, "Hey SoftBank's not getting the ownership position they want. Is there anything you can do to let some of your shares go, sell them to SoftBank? We really want SoftBank to be on our side, Uber side, invested in Uber instead of maybe looking around and investing in Lyft or something like that." 

And so Calcanis, it wasn't just he was taking money off the table but strategically it was important to make sure this investor had enough ownership in the company because they were a big dog, they had a lot of money and so they wanted him on Uber's side. And so that was part of the reason why he decided to sell some of his shares of Uber to SoftBank in a secondary. Now there's another kind of way to get liquidity in a secondary, which is through a marketplace. There's a lot of marketplaces that popped up. And what they're doing is kind of matching private buyers. Maybe they don't have an ownership position in the company yet, but they've heard good things about it or their friend's an investor or whatever it is.

name: How can an angel investor sell their shares?

snippet.title: Does an angel Investor pay capital gains taxes on an investment in their IRA?
snippet.description:
Does an angel Investor pay capital gains taxes on an investment in their IRA?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering a question, does an angel investor pay capital gains taxes on a startup investment made through their IRA? And for those who don't know, IRA stands for Individual Retirement Account. 

It's, basically, like the tax deferred or pre-tax contributions, that you make into a retirement account. And the world's gotten pretty cool, it's gotten very open. You can actually use your IRA to make angel investments now, whether you're working through Carta or AngelList, or there's a bunch of ways to do it, Alto. Lot of different platforms that allow you to tap into that 401(k), or excuse me, your IRA, and make the angel investment. 401(k)'s a little different, but if you roll that 401(k) over into an IRA, you can do it. 

So, basically, the answer is no, you will not pay capital gains taxes immediately, right at the second when you sell those shares. So when you use a traditional IRA or 401(k), and you've made those angel investments through there, well guess what, you don't pay taxes until you draw the money out. Typically, people wait as long as possible to draw the money out, because again, it's tax deferred. And the power of this is you can make multiple, you can make many investments on the same dollars over time if you keep it in an IRA for 20 or 30, 40 years, right? There's a famous example of Peter Thiel who invested in PayPal via his IRA, and then took that money, which he made a lot on, and invested in Facebook, which he made even more on, right? 

So his IRA is completely tax-deferred on pretty big numbers. He was able to compound that over multiple angel investments. Now, there is some pending, or talk of legislation, of limiting the tax benefit on IRAs depending on how big. The numbers I saw were anything over 5 or $10 million in your IRA, you're gonna end up paying additional taxes on, or not get the tax deferred nature. That's something for the politicians to work out. 

Also, for most people watching this, you're going to need a couple of humongous wins on those IRA investments, to even have to worry about that. Albeit, Peter Thiel investing in PayPal and Facebook, but for all of us, most of us, that would be a great problem to have. So for most of us, just know if you put it in like a traditional IRA or 401(k), when you take the money out, is when you start paying taxes, not when you've, actually, when you, actually, sell the shares, right, if they're sitting in a traditional IRA. 

So, hope that helps. If you have any questions on this, give us a call or give us a shout at kruzeconsulting.com, thanks.

name: Does an angel Investor pay capital gains taxes on an investment in their IRA?

snippet.title: How to read a Balance Sheet?
snippet.description:
How to read a Balance Sheet?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

A balance sheet is really kind of a snapshot of where you are right in that moment of time. So we'll start with the assets. The three kind of sections on a balance sheet are assets, liabilities, and equities. And we'll start with the assets side. Oftentimes I kind of visualize a balance sheet as like assets on the left and the liabilities and the equity on the right. And they have to balance each other out. So that's always really helpful to know. I don't wanna be cheesy but that's kind of why they call it a balance sheet. 

So let's go assets. So the most important asset in any business is cash. You have to do know what's in the bank account. And oftentimes people have maybe a couple of entries on their balance sheet. They have a checking account and a savings account. Oftentimes they also have like money market accounts where the big chunk of cash is sitting, that they don't need in operating on a daily basis, but they want to get a little higher interest rate. So cash, just always know that number. A little pro tip here, when you go into a board meeting that morning always pull up your bank account online and check and see your exact number of cash. Your exact amount of cash in the bank. Board members love that. They love to just be able to say, how much cash we have, and it's so empowering to say, "Well as of today, "right this moment we have X, Y, and Z amount of cash." So that's the cash side. You're also gonna have accounts receivable. This is money that is owed to you from your customers. 

Now, the other types of short-term assets might be, you might have like other assets like weird deposits or things like that. Or maybe prepays, like you might've prepaid a vendor to get a better deal. That's another asset account. And then as you move down you'll have things like rental security deposits. You know, if you're in a WeWork you're gonna end up paying, one or two, two and a half times your rent in a deposit. Same thing with like a normal landlord. You also are going to typically buy equipment. Now the IRS has a capitalization limit of $2,500. So if you buy something over $2,500 you're gonna capitalize it, which means putting it on your balance sheet and putting it into the equipment or asset section of your balance sheet.  

Another one to think about is credit cards. People don't always think of credit cards, but that is essentially a line of credit or debt and credit cards typically need to be paid back within a 30 day period. So those go in the short-term liability section. And credit cards can get pretty big. Like a lot of startups, I don't really recommend this, but sometimes they have some pretty big charges on their credit card. I always recommend startups. They typically have some cash because they've raised angel or VC money to always pay their credit cards. There's no reason to be paying interest every month. Just pay your credit cards off every month. It's good discipline. 

And now we start sliding down. There's other things like accrued expenses, other types of liabilities that you have to think about. And then you also have to think about short-term and long-term debt. Sometimes startups or small businesses they take loans, like letters of credit or they take venture debt in the case of startups. And part of that debt needs to be paid back in the next 12 months. So that should be accrued on the short-term debt side of the equation. 

And then anything after that's due after 12 months will be long-term debt. Those are the big ones there. You'll see, typically see a much larger balance on long-term debt if you've taken a big venture debt deal. Those are the basics of the liability side of the equation. There's other little things that can pop up. And we actually, sometimes it's a lot easier to track, like if there's a weird liability you might have, instead of just lumping it into other liabilities or something like that, that's kind of generic, we like to create its own liability account so it's very clear. And so when you look at your balance sheet, the balance sheet is all about knowing how much cash and resources you have in the bank and then what you owe people. 

Now, one thing I forgot to cover in the liability section is convertible debt. It's like SAFE notes and convertible debt are basically the same thing, but convertible debt does have a small coupon and typically does need to be paid back if it doesn't convert to equity. So that would be in the liability section.

name: How to read a Balance Sheet?

Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

It's a really good question because people want to know what they're paying for and they want to kind of understand the variables that make their startup accounting more expensive, frankly. So, we always start with the two fundamentals, which are transaction volume and dollar amount spent. So, transaction volume is just simply like how many transactions do you have? And at this point in the analysis we're not really worrying about whether they're like easy stuff like Uber, or more complex stuff like international wires, or international payments, or contractor payments that span many months or things like that, right. 

We're just kind of ballparking the transaction volume. Because every, you know, every, an accountant has to get all those transactions into QuickBooks, right, so there's a certain amount of time for each transaction. The second bucket is dollars spent. This is a quick kind of shortcut to see like how much is the company actually spending every month? And it correlates very nicely with transaction volume. And also gives you, shows you like when you combine those two you might have some outliers in transaction volume that get picked up or are easy to understand with dollar amounts. So, for example, maybe you've got just an extreme amount of transactions, but they're all like $5 Uber rides, right? Well, actually that's pretty easy. 

And I'll get to the reason why that's easier later, for Kruze. But that's much, much simpler than a bunch of more complex, bigger dollar amount transactions. So, we're looking at both those. And then we start thinking about complexity, which I've touched on a little bit here, but like whenever you're paying a bunch of contractors or vendors with multi-month stuff, well when you're doing GAAP accounting like Kruze, which is what startups should do, that's what VCs want, you have to spread or allocate those transactions over the time service is provided and do it on an accrual method. And, so, that's just a very simple example of complexity. 

Other versions of complexity can be, you know, it's prepays or revenue that's collected in advance, so you have deferred revenue and recognized revenue. You have to split that out. You might have some complexity around fixed asset schedules, or, is this, should this be booked as a fixed asset or not? What does GAAP say? So, there's a bunch of kind of judgment calls and things like that that accountants have to make, generally speaking. So, that's the third ingredient. Now, this is where it gets kind of fun, because if you're using good systems you can actually save a lot of money. When our startup clients are using great credit card systems like Brex, and Ramp and Airbase, and very good startup banks like SVB, or First Republic, Mercury, Bridge Bank, Comerica, stuff that has premium systems, great payroll, Rippling, Gusto, Justworks, TriNet, it actually can help automate some of those transactions for us. 

Kruze has his own system too. And, so, if you're using kind of a more old school credit card firm, or old school bank, or things like that, our system actually learns from the text in the bank feed that comes in and can automatically categorize a lot of that stuff. And, so, that's a little bit of our secret sauce. It's a very minimal part of our secret sauce, frankly, because it's all about the accountant's judgment, accountant's training, and frankly, communication with the client. But that helps quite a bit. 

So, doing that monthly call, making sure they're keeping up with all the questions we're asking them, and that we're answering their questions, very, very powerful. Really helps everyone, and helps Kruze deliver a better service to the client. So, you're going to include a higher price in the bookkeeping package if you are actually doing those monthly calls, which again, we really prefer and believe in. The next one is tax compliance. Are you going to include tax compliance in the monthly bookkeeping package? Now, at Kruze, we have an in-house tax team. We don't outsource at all.

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, we're talking about a really new exciting development from the State of California. 

They are coming out with California Business Connect, a revamped, revitalized, awesome online system for filing incorporation documents, tax payments, tons of stuff, everything you basically need to do, they are virtualizing a lot of stuff that you have to do kind of by hand still or at the State of California or things like that. So it's really exciting because it's been a tough couple years for everyone, from the IRS down to all the state tax agencies, to your friendly accountants, your friendly CPA firms, like Kruze, because COVID really threw a lot of wrenches in everything. And with all the PPP Programs and Employee Retention Tax Credits and all the other stimulus programs, all the state agencies have been really, and IRS, have been really underwater, through no fault of their own, it's just been an incredible amount of work. 

And so, it's really exciting to see, despite that, some cool innovation coming out of the State of California, and it's going to make everyone's life a lot easier. Now, the cut over date is March 29th, 2022. And leading up to that date, there's going to be some of the like online filings or online access stuff that exists right now are not going to be accessible, just know that, don't plan on doing anything super important that week because it could be offline or momentarily offline. But the new system will launch on March 29th, it's been tested a lot, it's been vetted. So at Kruze, we're really excited about this. 

Now you might say like, "What are some of the things that I'll be able to do on this website?" So one of the big things is you're going to get online access to the Secretary of State business records, and you'll be able to file stuff online 24/7, right? Like, the website's not going to go down, you're not going to be relying on going actually to like a physical location and filing stuff, which seems like kind of table stakes, but it's actually really important. And a lot of times you have to get like good standing or things like that, or get something fixed when a registration that's gone stale or old, there actually is a lot of physical process and high fees that you have to pay to like a servicer or someone like that right now. 

So this is going to be really nice, being able to do everything online will be fantastic. Save people a lot of money and a lot of time. Now, another thing you're going to be able to do is there's like tons of forms for, we're talking LLCs, S-Corps, C-Corporations, but the new California Business Connect site is going to allow you to access over 70 electronic forms and submit them, submitting is the big part. It's easy to put a PDF online, but being able to submit it electronically is going to be a really, really big deal. You're also going to be able to do image searches on corporations and be able to see like certain documentation, actually be able to look at it on the website, not request a copy to be mailed to you later. That's another big kind of workflow improvement time saver for folks like us, like CPA firms. 

Some of the other like cool things is just being able to do like business name searches in a much easier way. And one of the other cool things they're going to be able to do is multifactor authentication through like Okta, basically being able to sign in through different ways and verify that you are actually the person signing in and not a robot or a hacker somewhere down the road. So I'm super excited about this, kudos to the State of California for actually being innovative in this very tough time. You know, lot of the startups out there watching this video may not realize how much back and forth there is between the accounting firm and the State of California, or how much time we spend on hold, or how many times the poor agents we're talking to can't find a document that we send in, or are overwhelmed themselves because of the call volume.

name: California Business Connect Gives You Online Access To State Agencies!

snippet.title: Why do General Partner Venture Capitalists contribute cash to the funds they manage?
snippet.description:
Why do General Partner Venture Capitalists contribute cash to the funds they manage?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $6 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today, I'm answering the question, why do general partner venture capitalists contribute cash to the funds they manage? It's a great question. 

General partners are like kind of the, they're the people in front. They're the people doing the deals at the VC funds. They're signing the checks, all that kind of stuff. They're the people you read about in the news. They're the people wooing entrepreneurs taking them to coffee, giving them a term sheet. That is the GP role. And the LP role, limited partner, are the money people. Those are institutions like endowments, foundations, pension funds, high net worth individuals. Those are the people who invest in the venture capital funds and give that capital to the general partners or GPs and so circling back to the question, well the reason why GPs invest cash in their own funds are, there's two reasons. 

The first one is that limited partners like it. I mean, if you're putting some extra money into a vehicle for it to be invested, you definitely want the general partner to have some skin in the game, right? You want them thinking about their money when they're spending your money. So, oftentimes, limited partners will require like one to two percent, sometimes more, of a fund be actually cash contributed by the general partners and the goal here is to align incentives and make sure the GPs don't do any crazy deals they wouldn't do with their own money, right? Like, again, everyone wants alignment. Now, if you're someone who hasn't had a ton of success in the venture capital industry, those capital calls are actually pretty painful because you really don't have any money and so oftentimes banks will actually do capital call loans. SVB does this. First Republic does this where they actually will finance some of the capital calls for you to make this a little bit less painful on a cash basis for the GPs, but you're still in alignment because those are recourse loans like you can't just get out of that loan if the venture fund doesn't do well. So number one by far is just LPs want alignment with the GPs. That's number one. 

Number two, if you're running a fund and you're good at it, well wouldn't you want more money in that fund? Venture capitalists are very good at what they do for the most part and it's a very high return potential vehicle industry and so you see a lot of VCs actually putting more than the minimum into their fund and there was actually something that happened pretty recently, which I thought was cool where Homebrew, one of the dominant seed stage funds, actually decided they were just going to start investing their own money. That's it, they weren't even going to invest any other LP capital. They're just investing their own money. 

Obviously, they've done pretty well over the years and are pretty wealthy to be able to do that, but they don't have investors to answer to. It's, you know, limited partners are really the boss of the GP partners in a way, not always. I mean, the power dynamics can be very different like the top tier Sand Hill funds or best New York funds, you know, the LPs feel lucky to be able to invest in those funds, but if you're an up-and-comer or you're a good fund, but not like the number one or number two fund in the industry, you have to listen to what the LPs ask of you and say to you and so Homebrew basically just decided they're just going to invest their own money, which kudos to them. But you do see a lot of GPs putting more than the minimum in just because they know this is a high return vehicle. 

I mean, if you could invest in Sequoia Capital or Andreessen Horowitz you probably would, too, right? They have a really good track record. So that answers the question, hopefully. One other little fun thing is you see this every kind of down cycle. Venture capitalists also like to invest in each other's funds. So oftentimes like the GP of one fund will be an LP in five or 10 other funds. So hope that helps. That's why GPs invest cash in their own funds to make the LPs happy and create alignment and to, hopefully, take advantage of their awesome performance and make a lot of money for themselves. 

Hope that helps. If you have any questions on venture capital or general partners at a VC fund, hit us up at Kruze Consulting and we'd appreciate it if you subscribe to the YouTube channel, too. Thanks so much, talk to you soon, bye.

name: Why do General Partner Venture Capitalists contribute cash to the funds they manage?

snippet.title: What Recent Increase in Inflation Mean for Cash Management Programs
snippet.description:
What Recent Increase in Inflation Mean for Cash Management Programs

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Inflation is becoming something that people are talking about. It's very understandable. I mean, we're not out of COVID yet, but we've, I'm recording this towards the end of 2021 and the government has pumped a lot of stimulus money into the economy, the last year and a half. I mean, that's part of what kept as many people employed as, as were. I mean, there was a lot of job losses, but broadly speaking, a lot of people were able to maintain their jobs and sustain their standard of living. 

And so, that stimulus money, ultimately starts creating inflation. The other thing that's happened is like the economies of the world are improving. And so, things were like a standstill in mid 2020, and now there's a lot more commerce. People are buying stuff, people are traveling, like stuff's happening. And so it's kind of natural from that stop to triggering and getting the economy to run at 100% again, that there's going to be inflation. Like people need timber, they need oil, they need energy. All these things are happening and people want it now because they want to get going. And so that's creating inflationary pressure. Now we'll have to see if this is going to last or not. It all depends on who you talk to. 

And no one really knows. Personally, I think it'll be a little more temporary, maybe than most people. But there is inflation creeping in the economy. And if you're a startup sitting on a good amount of cash, you're asking yourself like, "Well, what can I do?" or "How should I change my cash management policy?" And frankly, I don't think you should do very much to change your cash management policy, because if you were doing things, best practices before. 

So if you had an investment policy, written document that your board had approved and that you were investing in a mix of either like a money market fund with your bank or doing something where you're kind of doing bond ladders, where you're buying corporate and US treasury bonds out until 12 months out kind of thing, and kind of staggering them. If you're doing all those things, you're actually not going to want to do a whole lot because you're doing it the right way and you're safe. 

And if you watch any of the other videos on cash management and startup, safety is actually the number one thing. But ideally you wouldn't be losing some of your cash balance kind of implicitly to inflation. And so you can look to some of those, changing the mix a little bit to corporate bonds. You might be, all in treasuries or all in CDs or things like that at your bank. And maybe mix in some of those like, Google/Starbucks/Microsoft bonds that still are not going to pay very much interest, but will pay you a little bit more than what your bank's paying you on the balance sheet. The other thing that could start happening, if inflation continues, is that the bond market is going to adjust. And what that means is, the bond market is smart. 

They know that if there's inflation happening, they're going to want to get a higher return, a higher interest on the money that the bond markets effectively lend to all the companies or countries across the world. And so interest rates start to go up and the price of bonds goes down. That's kind of how that inverse relationship works. And so the bonds that you are holding, the bonds that you buy in the future as interest rates start to go up, will actually give you a higher return. It's interesting because the bonds you hold right that minute, if interest rates start going up, are actually worth less. So you'll probably just hold them and run them off. That's kind of the concept of a bond ladder. You just have bonds maturing every month for a year. 

But the future bonds you buy are going to have a higher interest rate if this continues and that will help cushion and reduce the impact of inflation. You can see it's a giant cycle, it's a self-fulfilling cycle. The more people talk about inflation, the more people start to see it. The more the bond market gets nervous, the more interest rates start to go up, the price of bonds goes down and it becomes a cycle. I mean, that's how we got into like the hyperinflation of the early 1980s. That and energy prices were a major problem. So it's something to keep an eye on.

name: What Recent Increase in Inflation Mean for Cash Management Programs

snippet.title: Do you know that you can get Outsourced CFO Services for your business?
snippet.description:
Do you know that you can get Outsourced CFO Services for your business?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

As the company gets bigger, it's time to bring in a startup CFO or interim CFO or outsourced CFO services. There's all kinds of different terms that people use to talk about these. And really the job description is, or functions they provide is, you know, firstly, it usually starts with like financial modeling, and budget to actuals. And financial modeling is really you know, a three-year plan at least, looking forward to see where the company's going revenue-wise, where it's going expense-wise how much capital the company is going to need to raise. And are their growth rates sufficient for further VC funding? You know, what milestones do we need to hit before we can raise VC funding? All these things are really important to include in a financial model. I recommend every startup have a financial model. 

At Kruze we believe this so strong, we actually have like a free financial model on our website. It's pretty slimmed down, because the companies that tend to use it tend to be smaller ones, because they don't need something super customized. But it's there if you need it. There's a bunch of financial models on Google. This thing called Google, just search that. But financial models is the first thing. And then the next thing is budget to actuals. This is... I love budget to actuals. Because you get to overlay all the hard work you're doing on the accounting, and put that into the financial model and see where you're spending too much money, where you're underinvesting. Are you tracking above your revenue targets? Are you below? Is something going wrong? It's like your early warning detection system. 

And so doing budget to actuals every month, can be very powerful. It also inspires a lot of confidence in your board. If you can tell them where you are budget to actual wise, because they'll typically approve the financial model, in every January or December for the following year. And so having budget actual visibility, is very, very effective. The other thing a outsourced CFO can do, is really do a lot of your board prep, like the presentation prep, certainly the financial prep that goes into the board meeting. They should be taking care of. And you know, board meetings they sneak up on you. They come every six weeks, every two months. 

And it's a lot of work for the executive team at a startup. And so having someone that you can trust to assemble all the financial data, we do this for a lot of our clients, like our controllers do this. But as the companies get bigger, it becomes a lot more. And so having an outsourced CFO, can be really, really helpful there. The other thing that an outsourced CFO can do, is track other important metrics. Like your customer acquisition costs, and LTV like lifetime value of a customer, or some of the other like Ops stuff, like spend in certain categories, especially like IT/software infrastructure spend, things like that. Those expenses sneak up on people. And sometimes like the CTO is not talking to the CEO, and it helps to have a little bit of intermediary there, to just justify some of that spend. So that's important. Another thing is just managing the controller and accounting team. So, you know, for a lot of companies, Kruze works with obviously we're the controller and staff accounting team. 

And so sometimes for us, it's nice to have someone who really knows our language, and who's diligent and is very incentivized to actually answer all of our questions. That's kind of, one of our biggest issues is just getting our questions answered. And so having that interface with a CFO, who can talk to the founder when appropriate, but really probably most of the time not bother the founder, or the executive team with our questions is really, really valuable for us. And then there are obvious things, that a CFO should do also are help drive the fundraising process. Like when you go on to fundraising, it's very very helpful, to have the CFO on your side. Sit in the presentations, update presentations follow up on all the diligence. Again, Kruze does that as well, but if you're raising a big amount of money that can be helpful. 

And then also doing things like venture debt, after you've completed an equity fundraising, can be very helpful because it can extend your runway. And the lenders are looking for a lot of the same stuff, but some different stuff. And so getting them all the diligence materials helps a lot. And then finally when you get into an M&A situation, and there's huge dollars around, it does help to have a CFO. M&A events are always chaotic. They're also very emotional.
