snippet.title: Is it common to see a convertible note convert a portion into Common Stock and Preferred Equity?
snippet.description:
Is it common to see a convertible note convert a portion into Common Stock and Preferred Equity?

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts

Hey, Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question is it common to see a convertible note or SAFE note converted into partially common stock and partially preferred equity? 

And the answer is yes, this does happen quite a bit, especially at the seed stage level. And I have some examples here. We have some very simple math. I hope you can follow it. If not, just shoot us an email and we'll explain it. But basically, say a seed stage company takes a million dollar investment from the seed stage investor and they're doing it in a SAFE note or convertible debt. Eventually, those two instruments are gonna convert to preferred equity when a bigger round is actually funded. But for right now, the cap or the effective valuation in the convertible note or SAFE note is $5 million. Effectively, the investor's getting 20% of the company. 

Now, along comes the series A firm that says we love this company, there's been a lot of growth and they're gonna lead a  $5 million series A preferred round at a $20 million pre. So $20 million pre, plus five million investment equals a $25 million post-money valuation. And so the seed stage investor and the entrepreneur, but the seed stage investor in our case is really excited. They basically own 20% of a company that's now valued at $25 million. So effectively, they have $5 million worth of value in this company. Now, here's where we start getting into our question. If that initial $1 million was converted all into preferred, the investor would have $5 million of preferred but they only put in $1 million. And so their liquidation preference, basically, the investors get their money back before anyone else. The liquidation preference would be $5 million. 

That's effectively a 5X liquidation preference over what they put in. And this isn't really fair to anyone. The series A preferred investors don't like it because they put in five and their liquidation preference is only getting five. The founders don't like it 'cause all of a sudden, there's a bunch more money sitting in front of them before they can participate. So it's really unfair and so some really smart lawyers came up with the solution to solve this. And what they started doing was giving the seed stage investor their million dollar liquidation preference, the 1X, the money they put in and then the rest of the ownership is split up into common equity. Common equity typically does not have a liquidation preference. 

And so this was a win-win for everybody. The seed stage investor got their large ownership position. They did get to maintain their $1 million liquidation preference. The series A investor, they're happy because they have five million liquidation preference and the other investor only has a million, like it should be. Like what everyone invested. And the founder's happy because now there's only $6 million of liquidation preference sitting in front of them instead of ten. 

So it's fair to everybody, but the bottom line for the seed investor is they took a risk early on, investing in a low valuation and now they have 20% ownership in probably a really fast-growing company that just raised around $25 million. So this is why you would see a convertible note or SAFE note split out when it converts into partial common stock and partial preferred. It's a little technical but I hope this helps. 

It's a question we get quite a bit from founders and so if you have questions, just shoot us an email and we'll answer the super detailed question you probably have. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Is it common to see a convertible note convert a portion into Common Stock and Preferred Equity?

snippet.title: What is a Convertible Note Valuation Cap?
snippet.description:
What is a Convertible Note Valuation Cap?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about what is a convertible note valuation cap? 

And, you know, when people invest money via a convertible note into a startup, it's typically a angel pre-seed, seed rounds. They're really looking for the big upside that comes over time when the company's gonna IPO or get bought for a lot of money, five, 10 years from now. And so no one would give startup founders money if it was just a pure debt return, like a five or 10% return because you wouldn't make enough money as an investor and you'd be out of business really quickly. So they really do it for the equity upside and the way to determine the equity entry point and then thereby the equity upside is by the valuation cap. 

So you've got a bunch of other items that you're negotiating the convertible debt, and I've covered that in other videos, but here we're just talking about essentially the equity, the convertible valuation. And so for example, you might invest in a seed-stage company at a $10,000,000 cap. That's the lingo that people use. That means if another round of capital, usually institutional VC, comes in with a Series A and does the round at 20, 30, $40,000,000 valuation, your cost basis for that equity is $10,000,000, and you can kind of see how it works, like you've given the angel investor a really strong incentive to come in early because they know that even though they're gonna lose some of these, they're gonna get in a lot earlier than some of the institutional VCs. 

And, therefore, their return profile is actually a lot higher. On the ones they invest in early, they can make a lot, a lot of money. And so the convertible cap is heavily negotiated. It's something you're probably gonna do if you're a founder with like your lead investor. It may be a pre-seed or seed fund or maybe it's just a high net worth person who's kind of taking the lead and putting up the bulk of the capital. You'll negotiate this with them. You know, at pre-seed we usually see kind of five, $6,000,000 caps. 

At seed, it's 10, $15,000,000. Maybe 20. That's pretty aggressive. And then if you're doing something kind of before, you know, a Series A is kicking off, just trying to squeeze some money into a company, you might see a 20 or $30,000,000 cap. The cap is negotiable. So you could do a cap at a $50,000,000 valuation or a $100,000,000 valuation. It happens, but that is something that's negotiated between you and the investor. So I hope that helps. You know, angel, seed, you know, startup investing is very difficult, and so getting in at a low entry point for investors is really important and making sure they make enough money on the winners is really important. 

And so that negotiation on the value cap, valuation cap, and what that valuation is gonna effectively be in the future is really, really important. So good luck. Hopefully it's a collegial conversation. If it's not collegial, probably not a good partner for your startup long-term, so hopefully you find someone nice, easy to work with, and who believes in your vision. That is really, really important. If you have any questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thank you so much. Bye.

name: What is a Convertible Note Valuation Cap?

snippet.title: What is a Convertible Note Investment?
snippet.description:
What is a Convertible Note Investment?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm talking about what is a convertible note investment? 

And really convertible notes exist as a mechanism, or security, so that angels and seed and pre-seed investors can put money into startups. So the documentation is clear and clean, everyone knows what terms they're getting, and hey, the startup that's gonna go on and change the world gets capital, they get to build their company. 

And so, there's a couple of different ways of investing in a startup. Sometimes it's preferred stock, very rarely it's common stock. That's usually what the management team owns. Sometimes it's a SAFE note which is a Y Combinator kind of innovation a few years ago. But old, old steady, tried and true is the convertible note. And that's been around for a very long time. 

And it's got very specific terms, it's got the amount, the length of term, the conversion cap. Those are kind of the big ones, interest rate, it's gonna be nominal. But it is a tool to get money into startups and help those founders change the world. 

And so, it's kinda that simple. When you raise money as a startup and you're very early stage, you're either gonna raise it in a convertible note, or you're gonna raise it in a SAFE note. So, if you have any questions on this hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Happy to answer your questions. Take care.

Sample Convertible Note Agreement

Now we're going to provide one here for you, but your law firm will have this too. And I generally believe that you should just work with the law firm's template. They're gonna be the ones who document the deal, use their template. But this is helpful from an informational standpoint, this will actually teach you a lot. 

And, you'll notice, the amount is in there. That's super important. The term when the money basically has to be paid back or the note needs to be extended is a really important one. The valuation cap, super important. We've gone over that in a couple different videos. And then you're also gonna have the portion about whether it's converting to common or preferred. You can have a one or two page, not one probably two to three page convertible note template. That's very easy to document. That's why people like it. It's really cheap and easy to do a convertible note investment. 

And that's good for the startup they're not wasting a lot of money on legal fees. It's good for the investors because it's easy to understand. They can make the investment with confidence. Also, investing in startups a little bit like falling in love, sometimes it's impulsive. So being able to do it quickly and get it documented is very, very helpful for both parties. Enjoy the template, again don't be afraid to reach out to your lawyer. A lot of law firms have really good online presences now, too where, you know, Wilson, Cooley, Orrick, a lot of them have their stuff up on the internet where you can just do that.

snippet.title: Why VC’s Don’t Want to Lead Down Rounds
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're answering the question, why don't VCs like to lead down rounds? 

And the reason why this question is popping up a lot is with COVID and the associated economic fallout, there's a lot of pressure on valuations and raising money has gotten a lot harder than it's been over the last couple of years. And so, some entrepreneurs are being faced with down rounds or maybe just contemplating them, and what does that mean for the company? Well, there's one thing that's super important to know, and that's, VCs actually don't like leading down rounds. 

And there's a couple reasons for that. First of all, and I'm talking about outside VCs, not VCs that are already invested in the company. VCs that are invested in the company, they will typically do a bridge round, they'll help the company get through, that's part of being a good VC and part of being a good board member. But sometimes those VCs are tapped out, and so the entrepreneur has to look to an outside VC to lead a round. And there're some reasons why outside VCs don't like to do it. The first is, it can really make your referral network as a VC mad. 

People generally know this, but VCs refer each other deals. So, a top-tier series A investor, I always like to say has series B and series C investors on their speed dial. They have five funds that they really like to work with. And so if those funds were to kind of come at their companies in an opportunistic way to try to lead down rounds and wash out those series A investors, well, that's ruining the relationship there. So those series B, series C investors are very aware of that. And so they gently gracefully bow out of most down round opportunities. 

The second reason is that the follow-on investors actually know that VC firms force rank their companies. And the VC firms know their top companies. And so they're always gonna support the top companies in the portfolio. So, if you're a later investor and you're getting the opportunity to lead a down round, well, that means it's probably not the greatest situation, it's not in the top 50% of that other VC fund's investment. So, that makes you worried a little bit again. 

And the third reason is, it can be a huge waste of time, because a lot of these times, the internal VCs are just looking for a fairer price. They've been negotiating a down round or inside round with the founder, but no one knows how to price it. And so by getting an outside investor to put a price on the round, you've done the job that everyone's looking for. They can get the term sheet, they know what the price is, but that doesn't mean they have to sign the term sheet and actually take the money. 

Oftentimes what I see is, the internal VCs will just do the round at that price. That means the outside VC has done a ton of due diligence, risks making their referral network mad, and for what do they get out of it? Nothing, they don't even get the deal. 

So those are three reasons why VCs don't like doing down rounds. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Why VC’s Don’t Want to Lead Down Rounds

snippet.title: When is IRS Form 5471 due?
snippet.description:
When is IRS Form 5471 due?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're answering the question: When is IRS form 5471 due? And for those that don't know, 5471 is an informational return that needs to be included in your company's tax return. 

I'm speaking about Delaware C Corps right now that's our main focus at Kruze Consulting. So, your Delaware C Corp return that goes in to the IRS will have, basically, like an extra form on it, 5471, which covers your foreign corporation, which basically means if you have a foreign subsidiary, like maybe you have a development team in Argentina, or a sales team in London, England, or some other entity somewhere across the world, you need to tell the IRS that you have the entity. And you're basically going to supply the IRS with your financial statements from that entity. It helps the IRS track where all this cash is going across the world, helps them kind of root out bad actors. You know, people who might set up a corporation or a subsidiary for some not so great purposes. 

And so, it's a really, it's kind of your civic duty as someone who has incorporated and running a company to do if you have a foreign corporation. The fine for not filing it is really large. It's $20,000 per year, per form, so definitely, definitely file that 5471. Unfortunately, you see sometimes, you know, companies are incorporated by foreign founders who don't actually know about this. So please, please do that. There's a similar form called the 5472, which I'll cover in another video, that applies to foreign owners that needs to be disclosed, too. But the 5471 goes alongside or in your tax returns. So, the kind of headline due date is April 15th give or take a day every year, the typical tax return due date. 

Now, a lot of people know this, but you can actually file a tax extension form with the IRS. And especially when your company is losing money, you file that form, and the tax return and the 5471 become due on October 15th or within a day or so of that depending on if it's a weekend or not every year. Now, I make that distinction about a money-losing company because you don't owe estimated taxes if you're losing money as a company. If you're profitable, you file an extension. You do have to make your estimated tax payments. 

At Kruze, we work with tons of startups. We do have some profitable startups. So, we have clients that do those estimated tax payments, but the vast majority are startups who are losing money still, building their product, haven't achieved cashflow positive or profits, and so it's very easy for them to extend. And we extend everyone really. So, the due date is April 15th for the 5471. But if you file that extension, it will be October 15th. So, and again, in the given year, you may have like a weekend where it lands on October 15th. And so, usually the IRS will kick it to the next Monday. So you might look at like, it might be like October 17th in a given year. So, I hope that helps! Hit us up if you have any questions, 5471s are very, very important. 

Make sure your startup tax preparer actually knows how to fill them out and knows how to do them right. And be diligent! You don't want to get one of those $20,000 fines. Hope that helps! Hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com if you have any other questions. Thanks!

name: When is IRS Form 5471 due?

snippet.title: IRS Form 5472 for Foreign Shareholders
snippet.description:
IRS Form 5472 for Foreign Shareholders

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about IRS Form 5472. And this is for foreign shareholders, specifically, for individuals or corporations that own over 25% of the ownership of a startup. 

And so, you normally see this when like, maybe two founders incorporate and one owns 50%, the other owns 50%, and but one of them is foreign. And so you actually have to file this 5472. The other use case is like maybe a corporation made a 25% investment or spun a technology out into a startup and owns over 25%. Regardless of it, if they own over 25%, they have to file Form 5472 with their regular tax return. So this goes kind of like think about it like stapling on top of an 1120, which is the annual tax return for companies, for corporations. You can't file the 5472 by itself. It needs to go in with the 1120. These days almost everyone files their taxes electronically. So it's just another form that your tax preparer, your friendly CPA, Kruze Consulting, will help you file and do for you. Now, if you don't do it, like say you're not aware of the law or something like that, it's a $20,000 fine per year, per form. 

So it's really, really painful, that I see this sometimes where it's like some founders incorporate late in the year and they're foreign, they don't have good tax advice and they call us in February and we have to give them the bad news that it needs to be done and they probably owe $20,000. Now there is a process for abating this with the IRS, if it's the first year. So you can petition them, you have to do a bunch of calls, it takes a really long time, but it is possible to get abated. It doesn't happen every single time, but that is an option. 

So tell your friendly CPA, Kruze, or whoever else you're using that is an option that can be done. This is like one of those things where people ask us all the time, like why should I work with a professional CPA firm that knows startups really well versus like, you know, the CPA with a shingle down the block on, you know, whatever street in mid America. And this is one of the things, like the average CPA, isn't gonna be very well-versed in things like foreign shareholders or foreign subsidiaries or R&D Tax Credits, but someone like us who focuses on venture-backed startups constantly is gonna pick this up very quickly and know what you need to do. So this is kind of what you're, you know, was one of the reasons why people choose to work with Kruze. The other thing about the 5472, it's gonna have, like, the vital statistics of the firm, a VOC Corp and the foreign person, so like a lot of times, it's like transactions between the two, like payroll, loans, sales, anything like that, that has to be included on the 5472 as well. 

And then it's good to know that, you know, this again, this is due with the 1120 Form that's due on April 15th, but you can file an extension. And we file an extension automatically for every one of our clients, just in case there's a mess up somewhere. And with an extension filed in a regular year, it's October 15th. So I'm recording this September 30th. So we're two weeks away from the tax deadline. But the most important thing is don't forget this, tell your tax preparer, tell your CPA, if you do own more than 25% of a corporation or you have a strategic investor who owns 25% or more than 25%. 

It's a big deal, you don't want that $20,000 fine, and something that's easily avoided if you have a good tax CPA. Hope that helps, thanks!

name: IRS Form 5472 for Foreign Shareholders

snippet.title: Does a Contractor trigger Tax Nexus in a State?
snippet.description:
Does a Contractor trigger Tax Nexus in a State?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, does a contractor trigger tax nexus in a state? 

Now tax nexus is actually two things. It's income tax and sales tax. Now luckily for our purposes on this question, it's the same answer. A contractor does not trigger tax nexus within a state. Now, the things that do are if you have actual employees, employees you need to register to do business in the state, you have to register to do payroll taxes, that does trigger tax nexus. The other things are if you have equipment like capital assets, like things like computers, big heavy production machinery, things like that. 

Also if you have property, if you're leasing or buying property that can trigger tax nexus. And the final thing is income or material amounts of sales. Both of those will trigger tax nexus within a state. Now the sales threshold is different across different states. And there was a really, couple of years ago, a new ruling called Wayfair versus South Dakota, where actually the state of South Dakota won a ruling that said they could start charging sales tax on companies that didn't have a presence in the state, but sold online. 

You can imagine how the states felt. A bunch of their constituents were buying stuff from out-of-state online retailers, and they weren't getting their fair share of the sales tax. So they took that to the Supreme Court, Supreme Court sided with them, and so now when online retailers actually spent or sell a material amount of goods or services into a state, even if they don't have a presence, they do have to collect sales tax. 

So to bring us all the way back, if you have a contractor in the state, that does not trigger tax nexus, but there's a few other things that do, like people and like employees, capital assets, property or material amounts of income or sales. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Does a Contractor trigger Tax Nexus in a State?

snippet.title: State Payroll Tax Registrations - does your startup need to worry about them?
snippet.description:
State Payroll Tax Registrations - does your startup need to worry about them?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

There's really kind of three things that go into state registrations in general. Like you hire someone in another state, you need to register with the governments there. But there's three kind of concepts. The first is a state registration to do business there. Sometimes that's called like a foreign corporation filing. The second one is filing for a state payroll tax account. And the third one is what's called a registered agent. 

And again, people sometimes get confused with this, because, hey, it's not like you, if you're building a technology company, you're not sitting up at night studying like state law. You're sitting up at night studying code or molecular diagnostics or something super interesting. So that's why we're here, to explain this stuff to you. So, the first thing you need to know is when you do hire someone in another state, or start conducting business in another state, over some revenue thresholds or things like that, or of assets. You will have to file to do business in that state. 

And so you essentially in California, you know, it's a very simple filing with covering whatever tax. You pay a couple hundred bucks then every year you pay $800 for your franchise tax filing. But you basically need to let the state know that you are in their state and you are conducting business. And California is the most expensive state annual tax for this. A lot of states are like, you know, 50 bucks, 200 bucks, something like that. They really just want to be able to monitor you and collect some nominal amount of taxes. Remember, the states get revenue in a couple of different ways. And the state registrations or state filings is one of those ways. 

So, no matter where you go, you're gonna have to register in that state. And don't get too cute and not register, but then have people in that state because you're violating tax nexus. You also get tripped up a lot on your annual tax return. Because if you have people in the state, you've registered in that state, you should be filing a state tax return along with the federal tax return. Like the one that goes to the IRS. People get a little bit confused about this, but just do the right thing, register in the state when you start working there. The next thing you're gonna do is you're gonna have to register and create a state payroll tax account. 

Now, a few states, the registration and payroll tax account are joined. But almost all the states besides a couple, you're gonna have to create separate account. It's just like they're governed by different bodies. They care about different things. Still, both are pretty easy. And the state payroll tax account is what you need when you're gonna start hiring people and paying them through payroll. So you are gonna take that special number they give you, which is, you know, attached to your company in the records. You're gonna pop that into your payroll tax software. 

Which is gonna let you take out the appropriate amount of payroll taxes for the employee in that state, you'll find that a lot of payroll systems like, you know, Rippling and Gusto, Justworks, TriNet, less Justworks and TriNet because they're PEOs, they'll handle some of those for you, but Rippling and Gusto, they will sometimes block your payroll for that person until you get that payroll tax number. And the reason why is, they know that person's out of state or in another state, but they don't have a way of remitting the payroll taxes they withheld to the correct state government. They don't have a way or an account. That makes it really complicated for them. And it makes it really expensive for them.

The third thing when I talked about, which is a registered agent, this is typically related, I only bring it up in this category or this video because people get it confused with those other two. But a registered agent is typically applicable to a company that incorporates in Delaware. Delaware's kind of like the home of incorporation, not necessarily where they actually do business, but just they operate under Delaware rules and the reason for that is a venture capitalists and other folks know the case law in Delaware and it's also a business friendly state. 

And there's a bunch of services that do this. They've kind of virtualized the service and it cost like 100 to 150 bucks a year, but the state of Delaware requires you to have this service because they need someone to be responsible for receiving that paperwork. 

Hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com if you have any other questions on state payroll tax and state registrations, happy to help. Thanks.

name: State Payroll Tax Registrations - does your startup need to worry about them?

snippet.title: What is a Professional Employment Organization (PEO)?
snippet.description:
What is a Professional Employment Organization (PEO)?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today's I'm answering the question, what is a PEO, better known as a professional employer organization? 

And PEOs were an innovation, probably like 15, 20 years ago where some very smart folks, including TriNet, figured out that you could actually pool employees and if you pool employees, you actually create a lot of buying power. And so the pooling mechanism is basically, the employees of a startup actually work directly for the professional employer organization, the PEO, and then have kind of like a side relationship with the startup. But because the PEO can roll up thousands and thousands and thousands of employees because they're working with so many different startups and companies, they actually get a lot of buying power and that buying power actually rivals with some of the other big Fortune 500 companies. 

So like I know some of the PEOs say like hey, you can get Fortune 500 benefits and the quality of benefits and the inexpensiveness of benefits by working through a PEO. So PEOs actually become really popular in the COVID times because people are very sensitive about their benefits and really care about that and so providing great benefits is really important. And secondly, PEOs will actually handle some of the local state tax compliance because you're effectively working for them and so they have an incentive to handle that stuff for you. So it's kind nice. It takes it off your plate. This is especially important when like your employee base is maybe moving spreading out from San Francisco to New York, LA, those typical startup places and moving to lots of states in the Midwest or the South because they can have a better lifestyle there or they wanna be next to family, things like that. 

So when people start moving into a lot of other states that work at your company, it starts creating tax nexus problems and you have to start registering it to do business or registering to do payroll taxes in that state. If you're working with a PEO, they actually basically virtualize that and make it super simple for you. So you don't have to worry about it. So it's a pretty great combo. I would say that the only negative is that it's significantly more expensive than just kind of your regular payroll and benefits setup. 

So the PEO does allow for cheaper benefits but the monthly subscription fee per employee is actually substantially higher than the alternatives. So you're kinda, the way I would think about it, I'll probably date myself here but you're paying for a Cadillac service or you're paying for the Neiman Marcus service rather than shopping at Target or something like that. But it's an option that a lot of startups are doing right now in COVID times because again, the complexity of managing your employee base and what states they're in has actually become a lot more difficult. 

And so the PEO virtualizes all that and handles that for you, so I wanted to just do this video so everyone understood what a PEO is, a professional employer organization 'cause I'm getting this question like every day, so I thought I'd help everyone out and record a quick video on it. Hope this helps, thanks.

name: What is a Professional Employment Organization (PEO)?

snippet.title: Should your startup use a convertible note, SAFE, or preferred stock?
snippet.description:
Should your startup use a convertible note, SAFE, or preferred stock?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

The basic trade off you're making when you raise money as a founder is you're giving someone ownership in your company via a lot of expensive legal paperwork and you're getting cash in the door, right? And so, picking the security that you're giving the investors, whether that's the preferred stock, the SAFE note, the convertible debt, is actually important. You want to be thoughtful about this and make a good decision. So I've done videos explaining what convertible debt is, what SAFE notes are, what preferred equity is or are, so check those videos out. But I'm going to give you the CliffNotes reasons why certain parties actually like different types of securities. So for preferred equity, that is a favorite of venture capitalists. 

And so, the price per share in preferred equity is defined. You know you're paying a dollar a share, and when you add up all the shares in the company, you times that by a dollar and that's the valuation of the company, right? Very, very clear. There's no conversion feature to be had later, which is the case with SAFE notes and convertible notes, which I'll talk about in a second. It's plain as day what you're paying and what the valuation of the company is at the time of the deal. It also starts the QSBS clock immediately. QSBS is frankly a tax shelter or a way of mitigating your capital gains taxes down the line if the startup qualifies. And I think there's like kind of five main qualifications. I've done that in another video, you can check that out, but QSBS can save up to $10 million, or I think it's 15X; don't quote me on that, of whatever the investors' base is, shelter that from capital gains taxes. 

But guess what? The IRS hasn't clarified whether that actually works or not. So we're all going to find out in a couple of years, because SAFE notes have been popular for awhile, whether the IRS actually recognizes that as the date of the clock starting. So that'll be a fun little surprise and I'll definitely do videos on that whenever they come out with a ruling. But next up, the reason why investors like preferred stock is there's a liquidation preference, typically 1X, but very clearly defined. And that means that they get their money back, their invested capital back, before the common stock starts to participate. 

Now, preferred equity can always be converted into common later on. And that's what happens when a company does an IPO. The night before the IPO when it starts trading on the NASDAQ or New York Stock Exchange, all the investors typically will convert over, assuming it makes sense economically for them. 

The only big material difference is that convertible debt is redeemable, typically kind of like every 20, 24 months, sometimes even 36 months. SAFE notes are not really typically redeemable. 

And that works for the founders because they got the capital they needed at the time where they probably didn't have a lot to show for it. So the cap is kind of a proxy for valuation. This is all finalized later when another round, typically a preferred round comes in and there's a clear valuation. The cap is probably the most important term in a SAFE note and convertible debt. Again, SAFE notes and convertible debt, much, much, faster and cheaper to negotiate. They're usually like a two or three page document. A preferred document can be significantly longer, 20, 30 pages, something like that.   

This happens quite a bit. The round might start at a $10 million cap. Some other investors put their money at 15, and then someone late puts money at 25. It's hard to keep all those dilution events in sync in your head, and it's also kind of hard to frankly model it out. There are tools like cap table management software that can help you model it. But even those are a little tricky when there's multiple notes or SAFE notes, convertible debt interacting with each other because it's kind of like a circular calculation. If anyone's ever done a lot of Excel, circular calculations can be a little maddening. So SAFE notes, convertible debt are not perfect. 

There's some downsides with them too. Generally, I recommend early stage companies do the SAFE or converts because they're cheap, they're fast and easy. You can kind of get them done quickly. But if you're raising a material amount of money, like a lot of money, I would always go for a preferred round. It's just easier to get it documented correctly.

name: Should your startup use a convertible note, SAFE, or preferred stock?

snippet.title: Do SAFE Notes start the QSBS Holding Period Clock?
snippet.description:
Do SAFE Notes start the QSBS Holding Period Clock?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, do SAFE notes in an investment, in startups start the QSBS holding period clock? And so I'm going to give you a brief summary of QSBS, which is one of the, kind of the last remaining. I don't know, I don't know what to call it, tax shelters out there in the world. 

And basically it says that, if you own stock in a corporation, that's in like a very highly specific engineering technology focused industry, and you hold that stock for five years and there's a few other requirements. You can actually shield $10 million of capital gains or 10X your investment in capital gains, and you don't pay taxes on that shield. So it can be a really material amount of savings for people who have like a $10 million gain, on a huge startup outcome, especially general partners at venture capital firms. They think about this a lot, the normal founders and normal angel investors, yes, everyone cares about QSBS but the VCs are professional investors. It's something they think about quite a bit. And so, but it's important. 

It can actually save you a lot of money. And so there's been a lot of focus lately on this five-year holding period, and whether SAFE notes, which is kind of like a relatively new innovation in startup financing, maybe like five years old, it's kind of like a hybrid between common and convertible debt, if that actually qualifies to start the clock and the punchline is no one actually knows. And the reason is the IRS hasn't really clarified their position, really on QSBS, much at all, qualified small business stock. They haven't really clarified much at all, but they certainly haven't clarified SAFE notes. 

And so what we've seen over kind of last, I'd probably say like nine months, maybe last year, is the big law firms that service startups and some of the big incubators like Y Combinator, are now inserting a clause in the SAFE note documents saying something to the effect of, that for tax purposes, the safe note is to be treated as common stock. And the QSBS clock should start immediately upon execution of this. So basically everyone kind of is asserting that SAFE notes are equivalent to common stock, in which case the five-year holding period of the clock would start. But the reality is no one really knows this. There's been no kind of full ruling on this. And so everyone's playing in this gray area. Now there's especially like the way the stock market and acquisitions and outcomes are happening right now. 

I fully expect the IRS to clarify this or test it in litigation. So we'll probably know relatively soon, I'm recording this in late September 2021, but there isn't as much guidance as you'd like. So for purposes of the advice I would give a startup or a venture capitalist is, everyone should make best efforts, which is kind of like legal language for like doing the best you can, but you're not guaranteeing anything. A startup should always be careful in guaranteeing or what's called repping, representation warranties, that they are 100% QSBS compliant, because you just never know if something could go wrong or there was redemption that violates that. 

And then you open yourself up to litigation. So always stick to best efforts. But, you know, I think it's, I think the law firms and incubators and some of the VCs are doing the right thing by inserting this clarification into the documentation. We just don't know if the IRS is going to recognize that we won't know it probably for a couple of years, but eventually they'll get around to clarifying. So I hope that helps. 

And if you have other questions on this or other stock or SAFE notes or convertible debt questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, we're here to help you. And we actually enjoy helping you. Take care, thanks!

name: Do SAFE Notes start the QSBS Holding Period Clock?

snippet.title: What counts as research and development in R&D Tax Credit?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost/

Video Transcript:

Hi, guys, I'm Vanessa with Kruze Consulting. And today I want to take a little bit more time to talk to you about the R&D tax credits. Specifically, what defines research and development? 

And the answer is it must pass the IRS's four-part test. So, in other words, your R&D must be One: Specific. So, there's no mindless tinkering allowed. 

Second: It must eliminate uncertainty. That means that you must be contributing to real scientific advancement not just proving existing knowledge. 

Third: It must be experimental. Either you have a scientific method or some sort of trial and error process. And last but not least it must be technical. That means that the work needs to be grounded in the sciences like biology or engineering, not the arts or literature. 

Thanks for watching. I'm Vanessa and please feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions.

snippet.title: Best SaaS Accounting Software
snippet.description:
Best SaaS Accounting Software

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

I always say Quickbooks was kind of like the sun in the solar system. Everything rotates around QuickBooks. But there's other really good accounting software so, a competitor to QuickBooks is Xero, which is super popular in Asia, Australia, New Zealand, because it's a New Zealand founded company. In Europe it's very popular, not as popular in the United States, but Xero is really kind of the first scalable cloud accounting software. And I think they kind of put the fear of God into QuickBooks and made QuickBooks invest a lot of money and expertise into QuickBooks Online and make it, get it to parity. 

But Xero is a perfectly fine software for early stage companies. We don't really recommend starting with it because we're gonna probably transition you to QuickBooks anyways, but if you're a three or four person company, Xero's perfectly fine. 

NetSuite is the typical migration path for a company on QuickBooks. As the company gets to 10 or $15 million in revenue or starts consulting international entities like an international subsidiary, it makes the accounting a lot easier for that. NetSuite is very robust, you can be a public company on NetSuite. Does tons of different modules, does a lot of different stuff for you. NetSuite typically competes directly with Intact.

And probably, I'd say most famously is Brex and we've been a partner of Brex for probably four years, since Michael Tannenbaum walked into our office and said, we've got to work together, shout out to Michael. And what Brex does very well is integrate into QuickBooks and automate again, some of that categorization and labeling. It also has no personal guarantee. They will do some pretty aggressive, effectively letting you borrow money on a Brex credit card. But we like it because it's really easy to use, integrates well, no personal guarantee. And they are building a bill pay system inside of Brex because what typically we were seeing was a company would sign up with Brex and then they'd also go to Bill.com. Bill.com is very good for paying invoices, paying vendors, through wires or ACH or electronic payments. Not as much a credit card company, until they bought Divvy a couple of weeks ago, as I'm recording this, which is kind of like a Brex competitor. 

Additional Brex competitors would be Ramp who's like a credit card based system that tries to manage your spend control, having a lot of success, building up their customer base. And then Airbase is a super interesting company in that category because Airbase came at this less as a credit card company, and more as a spend management company. Kind of think like they're the enterprise software solution to this marketplace. They do offer cards and make provisioning and controlling expense levels on cards very easy, but that's not the foundation of their business, like Brex, Divvy, Ramp, right? But all of these categories are converging. And what I think is gonna happen, and we've been saying this for years and talking to all of our partners about this, is this all gonna be in one system? So like a startup will just be on Brex or they'll be on the Bill.com Divvy Combo. Or they'll be on Ramp, or they'll be on Airbase. 

And now Expensify is coming out with a bunch of different stuff. So they're in that exact market, too. So there's kind of like five big competitors who are well-funded. All have actually really upped their game in the software stack and we have relationships with all of them. We do a lot of business with all of them. It's a little bit of fragmented market right now, so it's hard to tell exactly who's gonna win. For me, I love the ease of just setting up a Brex credit card and getting that going. If you're looking for the pure big spend management tool, I would go with Airbase out of the box. They're moving down market. They've had a lot of success with the series C, series D companies. 

And then again, Ramp and Divvy, Bill.com are also excellent tools. So you're not really gonna go wrong with some of the players in this market. We talked about the pure play credit card market players. I expect the Amex's and Chase's of the world will either buy companies, like Chase put a really large investment into FreshBooks, which is an accounting platform I should have probably mentioned in the earlier segment, as kind of their place holder. 

And frankly, riding the cost curves down of these tools, is really exciting, especially if you're on a fixed fee because you just get more and more efficient over time and everybody wins. So those are my favorite SaaS accounting tools. I hope that helps, if you have any other questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. I've probably done videos on almost all those.

snippet.title: Is a SAFE Note Taxable?
snippet.description:
Is a SAFE Note Taxable?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, is a SAFE note taxable? 

And this is the question we get a lot from founders who've been doing their own accounting and kinda the nightmare scenario is we see their books and see their tax return last year and they've taken a million dollars of SAFE notes and they booked it as revenue and they have a bunch of expenses but they sure didn't spend like the full million dollars. And it looks like they're gonna have to pay a lot of taxes and that's what's causing them to reach out to us. No, your safe note is not taxable. That is an investment, that is not revenue. 

And so the SAFE note goes on your balance sheet booked as equity. It does not go on your profit and loss statement. You should not be paying taxes on the proceeds of your SAFE notes, and so the SAFE notes are eventually gonna get converted into common or preferred. 

Again not gonna hit your P&L so, this is a quick one but it's a mistake we see a lot from folks who are doing their own financials and there's nothing wrong with doing your own financials we actually encourage that at the very, very early stage companies, who've raised just a little bit of money but, if you're, you know, raised $500k or a million dollars you're starting to get to the point where you can afford to buy back a little bit your time and make sure your financials and your taxes are done properly and we're always here to answer your questions but this is one that you don't wanna mess up because if you treat those SAFE notes as revenue you're gonna end up paying a lot of taxes that you shouldn't have paid. Hope that helps thanks.

name: Is a SAFE Note Taxable?

snippet.title: The importance of having a bookkeeper who can handle your sales tax
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about the importance of having a bookkeeper who can handle your sales tax. 

Now, you may think this is like a skill across the bookkeeping world, but it's not. There's a lot of not-so-great bookkeepers out there who have no clue on this stuff, so, let's save you some time and some pain here. So if you don't have a bookkeeper who knows how to handle sales tax, it's pretty likely that you're gonna end up paying sales tax out of your own pocket because your company isn't actually collecting it from its customers. So that's like lost cash right there. The other way a bookkeeper can mess this up if they're not sophisticated, is that they could let you collect the sales tax, but then not remit it to the states or local governments, which becomes a really big issue; that's actually a crime. So you do not wanna be committing crimes while you're building your startup, so don't mess around with this stuff. 

Now this has become actually even more important because the Supreme Court ruled in favor of South Dakota v. Wayfair a couple years ago, and basically South Dakota's argument was like, hey, a bunch of our people in South Dakota are transacting with this Wayfair ecommerce site, but Wayfair is not remitting any sales tax to us. And Wayfair's argument was they didn't have nexus. They didn't have people, property, or assets inside of South Dakota, so why pay sales tax? And so what the Supreme Court did is said like, hey, South Dakota is due some of these taxes. 

So after a threshold, like 100K is passed in sales within the state, the state can start taxing it. So this kinda upped the ante and made sales tax even more important on a state-by-state basis. And I think the other thing you gotta remember is there's SaaS sales tax in a lot of states, not all of them, but this is actually becoming... This is, I think, gonna be one of those things, like ecommerce sales tax and SaaS sales tax, which the governments look to help close their budget deficits. We're in the middle of COVID right now. All the governments' budgets are just totally blown, and so they're gonna be looking for incremental revenue opportunities. And so sales tax is actually gonna become a lot more important going forward. 

So don't mess around, work with a firm, ideally like us that has a dedicated sales tax team, and that's embedded in our general tax-dedicated team. If you're working with someone who's outsourcing taxes, be really, really careful. That can have problems with your federal state returns, but on the sales tax side, it's almost guaranteed they're not gonna be able to handle your sales tax correctly. 

So just be careful. Pick a good bookkeeper who understands sales tax. You'll be safe, you won't make these mistakes, and you can just focus on running your startup. Hope that helps!

name: The importance of having a bookkeeper who can handle your sales tax

snippet.title: Economic Nexus & Sales Tax
snippet.description:
Economic Nexus & Sales Tax

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm talking about economic nexus and sales tax. 

Now economic nexus is a fairly new term actually. That's why we're doing a video on it. It used to be the ways to establish nexus, which basically means like the requirement to pay taxes, was you looked in a state and you said, "Does the company have people? Does it have assets? Or does it have property?" If it has any of those three things, the company has tax nexus in that state, but a couple years ago along came a Supreme Court ruling on the Wayfair versus South Dakota case. 

And that established the concept of economic nexus, which basically means like, "Hey, even though the company doesn't have people, doesn't have assets, doesn't have property in that state, they're selling a lot of goods or services to the people of that state. They're doing business in that state, even though they don't have a physical presence." 

And so the Supreme Court ruled that states could actually tax on the basis of economic nexus, which opened up sales tax really kind of for the whole country, especially for like e-commerce companies, especially for retailers, especially for SaaS companies. And economic nexus is kind of like the fancy term that basically says like, "Hey, if you're doing $50,000, $100,000, some material amount of sales in a state, you are creating economic nexus." You have to file sales tax returns. 

You most likely have to file a state tax return along with your federal return for income tax as well. So I hope this helps. Economic nexus is just it's something that maybe accountants talk about, and I'm recording this video because you, as a startup founder, may be talking to your accountant, hopefully you're talking to Kruze, the friendly CPA, and you don't know the definition of that. And so I don't want you to be confused. And so economic nexus just basically means doing business in a state, even though you don't have a physical presence, and surpassing some dollar amount of revenue threshold that the state has set. And the states are all over the place. 

There's 50 states in the union, right? So they all have different thresholds, but 50 to 100K is a really good kind of barometer. At that point, start talking to your CPA firm. Ask Kruze, we have a full sales tax team, in-house tax team, do tons of this kind of stuff. Hit us up, we'll answer your questions. And I hope that helps, thanks.

name: Economic Nexus & Sales Tax

snippet.title: How the stock option pool at the Series A impacts a Founder’s ownership
snippet.description:
How the stock option pool at the Series A impacts a Founder’s ownership

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm covering how the stock option pool at series A, impacts a founder's ownership in their startup. 

So venture capitalists are smart. They want the company to have enough stock options that can be issued for new employees that join the company so that they're incentivized for big, big upside. Venture capitalists are only concerned with huge IPO, giant M&A outcomes. That's all they invest for. That's all they want. And so they've found over the years that it's great to incentivize employees a little piece of ownership so that if something goes big, they make a lot of money and the venture capitalist makes a lot of money. And so everyone's aligned. But for you as a founder, if you're listening to this, you just have to know that any dilution, whether it's raising new money from a VC or dilution in the form of issuing or granting new stock options is really going to impact you. Like, you are the source of that dilution. 

You are losing ownership percentage points. And so it's important to be smart about this. So when you sign a series A term sheet, just know before that term sheet closes and turns into like a deal, there will probably be new issuance or new reserves of stock options. The VCs will insist on it. In fact, it will probably be in the term sheet you signed. It'll say something like founder agrees to increase the stock option pool up to 10% or maybe up to 15% of total shares outstanding. And even though those shares are not granted at the time because you really haven't hired those people and you may not hire those people for years, you've essentially reserved those shares. And so you have taken a hit on your ownership. And so how do you think about this? 

Well, just remember, this is happening before you actually close the investment and so it's negotiable. It's like everything in life, negotiable. And so when you're choosing the term sheet to sign, you're thinking about, you know, the investor's fund and how smart this investor is and how much the rest of the partners of the fund are going to support you and maybe in branding or content marketing support and maybe recruiting support. But this, alongside the valuation that the investors assign you, is a really important financial negotiating point. So don't be afraid to kind of gently push back and say like, "Hey, you know, hypothetically you're asking for 15% stock option pool but I think at this stage we can get by with 10%. And oh, by the way, here's my financial model showing exactly the number of people we are going to hire over the next two years. 

And two years from now, you know, we will raise another round. And yes, we'll probably have to freshen up the option pool then but that's a problem for then, not a problem for now." And so say you take that, you know, you negotiate the term sheet from 15% to 10% stock option pool. You've saved yourself as a founder a tremendous amount of dilution. That is, that's meaningful. And the venture capitalists will understand. And they will listen to a well-reasoned argument, especially if it's based in quantitative fact like the financial model. 

And so having that model ready in those conversations, being willing to understand your cap table and how many of the senior management you've already hired, already given stock options to, and how many, you know, really need to be incentivized in the future when you bring them on in mid-level management is really, really important. But again, I just want to frankly empower the founders out there when you're raising a series A, even the series B this happens. You know, be ready to negotiate. This is a term that you can negotiate. The venture capitalists prefer you to have a bigger option pool because that protects them along the ways. 

It also protects the note holders because they're going to convert at that post-money valuation. But you know, you want to make sure you create enough stock option liquidity to incentivize the team properly but also don't over-allocate it because those are shares you can never get back again. So I hope this helps. 

If you have any other questions on stock options, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Happy to answer them. Thanks.

name: How the stock option pool at the Series A impacts a Founder’s ownership

snippet.title: Employer Benefits Contributions for Employees vs. Dependents at Series A Startups
snippet.description:
Employer Benefits Contributions for Employees vs. Dependents at Series A Startups

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

The idea is your startup goes out and raises a Series A. Maybe 5, 10, 15, $20 million. Heck, Series A's are getting so big these days. It could be a $30 million, a $40 million Series A. But the question becomes how much of an employer contribution should the company make to pay for the employees' health benefits? So this is like health insurance, vision, dental, all that stuff. And the general rule of thumb is for most well-funded startups, they're gonna wanna pay 100% of the employees' benefits. And that's because they're super well-funded, they've got tons of money, and they're usually competing for like the top engineers in any given field. And if you're trying to recruit people from Google to work at your startup, you're probably gonna have to pay 100% of benefits, right? That's a very quick analogy, but that applies to Genentech. 

And any big company you're recruiting people away from, they're gonna want really good benefits. Now there's some companies that elect to pay 80, 90% of the benefit expense. And what they're doing there is hoping that the employees make a little bit more of an educated decision on kind of what tier of benefits they go for. So there's usually, like, Platinum, Gold, Silver, Bronze. And so someone who's like super young and healthy, they might elect for Silver or Gold over a Platinum if they're paying 10 or 20% of those benefit costs, right? 

So for Kruze, for example, we have a 401k matching program, where the employees are actually making more, they're actually getting a bigger benefit than what they would be paying than their contribution on the benefits through the matching program. Not everyone does this, but I do recommend making, you know, you can have commuter benefits. You can have short-term and long-term life insurance. Those are things that Kruze does as well for free for our employees. 

And so there's a lot of different ways that you can kind of make up the money if you are asking employees to make a small contribution to their health benefits. So that's the first part of the answer. The second part of the answer is what do you do about dependents? This is typically spouses, children. And the range there is something between 50, 80, or 100%. Those are the three kind of sticky points that I typically see. 100% is pretty self-explanatory. Again, you are recruiting the top technical talent in the industry, and you really care about getting the best people, and so you might pay 100% of the health benefits of the dependents that are coming along with the employee that you're hiring. 

More frequently, I see 50 to 80% range. Companies typically wanna create, again, a little bit of incentive for the employee to think with their pocketbook a little bit. And if you're hiring the best badass engineer woman, and her husband works at a incredible accounting firm and you want that, before the engineer puts her entire family on your medical benefits plan, which could cost three, four, $5,000 a month extra, you want them to think about what that incremental cost is for them coming out of their pocketbook because maybe the husband at the incredible accounting firm just stays on the accounting firm's benefits because they pay 100% too, right? 

And so this is a trend in healthcare, is having people make copayments, or having people make small nominal contributions to their benefits, especially health, that's the biggest, most expensive benefit, so that everyone kind of becomes aligned, become like a educated, smart shopper for healthcare instead of just accepting, like, the highest plan and maybe spending the most of the company's money. So I hope that helps. I do wanna emphasize, if you are gonna pay a smaller percentage and let the employee pitch in a little bit, you do wanna try to make that money up to them some way. That's my personal opinion. You don't have to do that. 

But I think it signals to the employee that you really care, that you are making them as successful as possible, you're covering their commuting benefits, or the 401k, so they're saving for the long term. All these things are like, little tiny signals that you can send your employee base because at the end of the day, your startup's only gonna be as successful as the team makes it, and you wanna hire the best and brightest, but you also wanna hire people and make sure their basic needs are taken care of and that they're happy and that they enjoy coming to work and they're not stressed about healthcare payments or commuter expenses or that they're not saving enough money in their 401k.

name: Employer Benefits Contributions for Employees vs. Dependents at Series A Startups

snippet.title: Variance analysis of financial results
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're doing a startup bookkeeping best practice. And one of the most important things a startup bookkeeper can do is. Do a variance analysis on the financials. Once the first pass is done. That means that you're going to look at every line item in the chart of accounts. And just make sure it makes sense. Now we have an automated tool that does that at Kruze. So It goes through and pulls out the stuff that has a higher variance than like 20-25 percent. But a bookkeeper can do that themselves. They can actually look at it and eyeball. So for example, if your payroll expenses have gone up 20-25 percent, the CEO needs to know about it. In our messaging, we actually message that out to the CEO and let them know. Hey, by the way, payroll went up. Now, we usually have a pretty good reason for that. It's usually either a bonus or guess what? They hired a few more team members, which is great. But you always want to call out the variance analysis to the startup CEO so they know exactly what's going on. Similar things around rent or benefits, some of the big expenditures, especially travel. Sometimes the CEO doesn't know that people on the team are booking travel. And guess what? Travel is pretty expensive. So you definitely want to call out the variance analysis on that. Another one is Web services. I've seen times. I'm not going to point fingers, but CIOs or CTOs get a little aggressive with their web service spend. They've got every new web service out there to help the development team. Which is great. Productivity enhancers are great. But sometimes the CEO doesn't know exactly how much money is being spent on that; and being made aware of those big increases when the variance really pops, is super important. And finally, the best way to do a variance analysis is to do budget to actuals every month. We have a huge number of Kruze clients who are doing budget actuals now. It makes so much sense. You sit down with someone on our team. You go over what you are projecting for that month and all the different categories and what you actually did. And having that conversation with a real CPA, a real controller, a real V.P. of finance, is incredibly powerful. You learn so much about your business as a CEO. You know, you're spending money, you know where you need it cut. So we are huge fans of variance analysis and startup bookkeeping. Definitely, start doing that. And if you want to go up a level, do budget to actuals. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Variance analysis of financial results

snippet.title: State Tax Compliance when your Employees Change States
snippet.description: We're recording this during COVID, and I don't know about your company, but I know at our company, people are moving all over the country, even the world, just to work in a more comfortable environment working remotely, and so, we're getting this question a ton, and we're dealing with this question a ton at Kruze Consulting, and so, the big thing, if it's a COVID-related move, and someone's just going to another state for three to six months, what we're seeing is the states are actually passing Safe Harbor acts and allowing employees that went to another state, they're not requiring the employer, the company to register in that state and pay payroll taxes. They're treating it as if nothing happened. Now, that's temporary, and we're recording this in the summer of 2020, and so, I kind of expect if COVID, hopefully COVID ends soon, but if it continues to go, I think somewhere around January of the next year, some of the states may come out and say, hey, we want those payroll taxes. We want those annual registration fees, so we're going to start making you register when you have employees living in our state, so definitely keep a careful watch on this. So now we're going, so that's COVID. Now, we're going to cover just kind of the normal playbook so that you know how to do this regardless, and I know for us, we have employees that are moving to New York or Texas permanently, so we need to make these moves here and be in tax compliance, so the first thing you're gonna do is when someone moves into a state, they're essentially creating tax nexus for your company because you have an employee there, and you typically have assets, even if it's just like a laptop. That counts as an asset. Now, the other tax nexus trigger is sales. Like if you have a lot of sales in a state, that can be triggering tax nexus, too, but the big ones to focus on right now are assets and employees, so when you have someone move into another state, you need to register to do business in that state, and you'll typically pay like an annual fee every year. In California, it is the California franchise tax. New York has a franchise tax. Texas has an annual tax. Massachusetts has an annual tax. You'll pay that, and then you will typically register new paid payroll taxes with another entity. This is super important because you can't run payroll through a system like Rippling or Gusto until you get those payroll tax numbers. It can actually block your autopilot payroll. So always remember not just to register to do business, but register and pay payroll taxes. You need to get those tax rates, and have the right accounts set up. Another thing you would need to worry about potentially, especially if you moved to somewhere like New York, that employee is going to trigger a nexus, and you're going to have to do worker's comp. and just a few states are state administrative workers comp., but New York is one of those, so just be aware of that. We have companies, they have employees move to New York. They don't know, and we don't know they actually moved there, and they trigger worker's comp. problems. So just be aware of that. The other thing you're going to have to do, start filing a state annual tax return. Now, this goes alongside your federal tax return, and luckily, a lot of the information flows from the federal return, so it's not that much more work, but just know if you trigger tax nexus, you're going to have to file the annual state tax return in the states that you have these employees. Now, this is super duper important because you don't want to forget to file and then  have like back taxes or not be compliant, and you do have to file tax returns even if you're losing money, both on the federal level and the state level. Both the IRS and the state tax commissions, they just want to know what your company is doing. They want to make sure that you're losing money, you don't owe them taxes, so that's super important too. Now, those are the big ones you have to worry about if an employee goes into another state. There's one more, which is sales tax, and sales tax, it used to be strictly based on having employees, or having assets, or doing a lot of sales in the state, but the Supreme Court three years ago ruled that you may even have to pay sales tax, even if you don't have a presence in that state. So sales tax got a lot more complicated three years ago, but just know that if you do have an employee moving into a state, it kind of brings the threshold down. It makes it more likely that you'll have to pay sales tax in that state on sales generated in that state.

name: State Tax Compliance when your Employees Change States
