Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm talking about changes, in the Employee Retention Tax Credits, that are in the Build Back Better Act. Now, if that is not a tongue twister, I don't know what is. 

But the Biden Administration just signed in a bunch of tax reform and there's some good things and some bad things in there for startups. The good thing is, one of the tax credits, the new Recovery Startup Business Tax Credit, which basically gives up to $50,000 in payroll taxes on a quarterly basis to startups that were formed after February 15th, 2020. So basically, if you were formed after COVID started, you are eligible for a $50,000 tax credit. It's been going on in Q3 already, we've already been doing tons of these, but Q4, it is preserved. You will still be able to get that up to $50,000 tax credit in Q4. 

It's based on, I think it's capped at $5,000 per employee. So you kind of need to have like 10 engineers basically, or 10 people, not just engineers, to be eligible for that. But that is preserved that will go forward in Q4, if you are a relatively new company, and formed after February 15th, you will be in... February 15, 2020, you'll be in good shape and can get that. So talk to your friendly CPA, don't have a CPA, you know where to find them at kruzeconsulting.com, shameless plug there. But, there's some bad news, and, there was another form, like kind of the earliest form of Employee Retention Tax Credit, which was in 2020 and even the first half of 2021. That has been eliminated for Q4. 

Those were based on reductions in revenue, and there's different thresholds every quarter, some quarters it was 50%, some quarters it was 25%. Also, if your company shut down because of COVID, you were eligible, you know, that's like truly shut down, not like, "Hey, we're working from home and deploying code to get up." "We're working remotely" kind of thing. But unfortunately, that one has been eliminated. So that was a substantial tax credit for a lot of companies that were really hurting. But they probably have been taking advantage of those tax credits for at least a year now. So I think Congress probably said, "Hey, we can save a little money here by getting rid of this one. But let's preserve the one that benefits startups that were formed after February 15th, 2020, because hey, that was a really tough time to start a company. 

We want to support those businesses start early, and we want to encourage them to hire." So I think that's the logic around this, but, the headline is, if you are a new recovery startup business, you're still eligible for that $50,000 tax credit Q4. If you were a company that was really struggling and were dependent on a tax credit because, or we're eligible for tax credit because you had a material revenue decrease or had shut down the offices or things like that, then, that one's not going to be available for you in Q4. 

Other interesting stuff in the Build Back Better legislation that I'll cover in some other videos. But this is how it impacts the Employee Retention Tax Credits. Hope that helps. If you have any questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. 

We're very active on the Employee Retention Tax Credits. We're literally filing hundreds of these, so we know how to do it and we can help you out. Hit us up. Thanks!

name: The Build Back Better Act Makes Changes to Employee Retention Tax Credits.

snippet.title: How long does it take to negotiate a term sheet?
snippet.description:
How long does it take to negotiate a term sheet?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

The quick answer is anywhere from an hour to a week. It's actually really, really quick assuming you actually have the term sheet, like it's been issued, it's sitting in your hot little hands. That is very, very important. Do not negotiate hypothetical term sheets. Negotiate the one that is sent to you in a PDF format by the venture capitalist who you've been talking to. Now, of course, the hard part, anything in life, the hard part is getting your first term sheet, but people also know that running a process, if you can get a couple bidders, that's where you usually end up getting a really good deal. 

But if you're one of the people who only gets one bidder, there are tons and tons of startup stories about how a founder could only get one term sheet, and then eight years later, they're a billion dollar IPO startup, so don't feel bad. The most important thing is get one. And if you get one, try to get two, because that's how you can play people off each other a little bit in a friendly way, respectful way, and get better terms. So you want to be patient until you get your first term sheet. Sometimes you'll hear people, they'll throw out these crazy schedules of like, you got to get me a term sheet by X, Y, and Z date. And if you don't have a term sheet already or have a very good feeling you're going to get one, you could actually be shooting yourself in the foot because sometimes that day will come and go and you end up with nothing. 

And it's like, how do you restart the process? It's actually pretty hard. So my advice is to be pretty conservative, actually, until you get that from first term sheet. Answer all the investors' questions, do whatever it takes, appear at the partner's meetings, do demos, whatever you need to do to get one group over the hump. So after you get the first term sheet, you're in great shape, but here are a couple tips to kind of help you get over that proverbial hump here. The first one is know your valuation and desired dollar ask going in. You're definitely going to be asked about it. Pretty much every meeting you'll be asked about, you know, what are you looking for, what valuation, how much money are you looking for? 

And there's some people who give founders advice and say, you know, do not throw out a number. That will only be used against you. Let the venture capitalists start, and hopefully they will start at a very high number and that will benefit you. I take a little bit of a different tactic. I'm kind of like a ask for what you want kind of person. So I would certainly have a target valuation and a dollar amount. Oftentimes, those are driven by the target valuation translates to investor's going to buy 20% of your company. So whatever your target valuation is multiplied by 20%, right? But have something, because you just don't want to waste time. And if you get that number, you're going to be happy. The way to drive that number up over time is to get two bids. 

So I would just recommend being very focused, know what you want. This also helps you on the second point, which is go to investors who specialize in the stage and industry you are in. So the worst thing you can do is go meet with a seed stage investor and ask for a series B style term sheet, right? A seed stage investor is going to invest anything from one to five million, not $25 million, right? So make sure you've done the research ahead of time so that you can understand where they'd like to play in the timeline, you know, series seed, series A, series B, et cetera, and what kind of checks they normally write. You can waste a lot of time going to venture capitals who will never be able to give you a term sheet for what you're looking for, so be smart about that. Knowing what you're looking for going in helps you with that because you just don't waste time. It's not a discovery process for you. 

Now, if you're having a hard time negotiating or getting to that point where the VC will issue the term sheet, ask them what their ownership targets are. That's a good way of kind of cutting to the chase, because sometimes they may be talking around evaluation or talking around a dollar amount or there's something else going on, and just asking that direct question, most investors want a 20% ownership level. Now, they're willing to come down from that oftentimes through a negotiation, but that's usually what they're going to want.

name: How long does it take to negotiate a term sheet?

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Basically the venture capitalists who are giving you a term sheet, they've spent a ton of time, money, political capital to get you a term sheet and they're excited about doing a deal. So they're shifting into sales mode once they give you that term sheet, and the last thing they want is for you to take that term sheet and walk up and down Sand Hill Road or in New York or wherever you're based and get a better deal using that term sheet as leverage. It's social proof. They're giving you a term sheet. There's a lot of money involved and they want you to consummate the deal. They want you to work with them. 

And so often, almost always in a VC term sheet, there will be some type of no-shop provision, and basically what this means is the management team of the startup who's negotiating this term sheet is not able to take this term sheet and actively shop it. Furthermore, if they get inbound interests, whether there's acquisition or just another round, another VC fund, they're supposed to disclose that to the investor syndicate they sign the term sheet with. Now, one of the most important things here is that, for it to be effective, you actually have to sign the term sheet. So what you kind of practically see is founders getting a term sheet, and then aggressively, but discreetly, shopping that term sheet for a week or so with other VC firms to try to get everyone up to whatever deal terms they want, or to get the firm they really want to work with to give them a term sheet. That gets into exploding term sheets. 

Usually venture capitalists give you like a week or so for a term sheet still to be good. Any shorter than that, it looks a little desperate. Any longer than that, it's just kind of asking for the term sheet to be shopped. So that's in another video, called "Exploding Term Sheets". But for our purposes, you usually see like a no-shop period, kind of one to three months. I would highly recommend not agreeing to a long no-shop, because it can actually create some really negative incentives for the VC fund, especially if you're running out of cash. 

So just to kind of play this forward here, say you sign a term sheet, has a long no-shop, has a three-month no-shop. That's a long time. And the VC firm knows you're kind of getting low on cash. Well, guess what. They may try to let the no-shop get all the way to the end and exert a ton of pressure on you and try to re-trade the deal because they know you're almost out of cash. And so you can end up with a really kind of negative, they-have-all-the-leverage type of thing. 

Now you might say, well, hey, I have a lot of cash. I don't have to worry about that. But still, you don't want a long no-shop, because when you go out and create like an auction to generate term sheets from investors, you're fresh, they know you, they know what's going on, and when you elect to sign a term sheet with another firm, you immediately become kind of like, it's a negative signal to all the other VC firms. You didn't pick them. It's like picking someone else to go to the dance, the prom. Well, are the other guys or girls going to want to go with you if that date ditches you? Probably not. 

So what happens is, if that no-shop runs out and it's a long no-shop, your company can be stale. They might just not want to even re-engage with you. Furthermore, you probably spent a lot of time on this fundraise, and oftentimes what we see is, companies, when they're, the founders can only do so many things, there's only so many hours in the day, and so the performance of the company in the very short-term, when they're negotiating these terms sheets and getting everything done, will suffer a little bit. If you just think about it, you're not calling on customers as much. You're not recruiting new people as much. You're spending a lot of time with the venture capitalists.

name: What Does The No Shop Provision In The VC Term Sheet Mean?

snippet.title: What do you do if you raised capital at a huge valuation before the market decline?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, "What do you do if your startup raised capital "at a huge valuation before the market declined?" 

Now this is a tough situation, but the good news is, you can make it work. You have the capital, and now you just need to execute. So the first thing you're gonna do, is you're gonna make sure you extend your cash runway. That way you don't have to raise money for a really long time. There's a couple ways to do that. 

First, really scrutinize your expenses. Make sure you're spending money intelligently. Make sure that money's just not flying out the door for nonessential things, and make sure that the people that are working at the company are all A-players and worthy of their salary. And if they're not A-players and worthy of their salary, there are a lot of fantastic people hitting the market. You can actually make some adjustments and hire some new people at the appropriate salary, and it can really strengthen your company. So looking at your expenses, being smart about that, and then upgrading your team at the appropriate salaries can make a huge difference. 

The next thing you're gonna wanna do is look at opportunistic capital sources. One really popular one right now which I recommend is Venture Debt. Venture Debt looks at really promising companies and makes a loan on top of the equity in the company, and so they're usually kind of doing 25 to 40% of the equity round, and you can negotiate a forward commitment so you can draw it down in the future. You don't have to draw down right now. That should extend your runway, it's really nice. 

The third thing you should do is look and see if you can collect cash upfront from your existing customers. A lot of big enterprises, especially, are happy to pay upfront if they get a discount. That is a really great way to extend your runway, lower your burn by incentivizing your sales team and your customers to collect cash upfront. Now the other thing you're gonna need to do is really focus on the milestones that are required to raise your next round. And this is maybe the hardest part because one of the things that happens in a market decline is the milestones get a lot tougher. 

The venture capitalists at the next stage are much more choosy, and are slightly risk adverse, and so really be realistic about what those milestones are. Maybe it's 100 paying customers instead of 20, like it used to be. Or maybe it's $10 million in ARR instead of six or seven that you could've got away with a couple months ago. Or maybe it's a certain number of million of subscribers if you're a consumer rep. Whatever it is, be super realistic, know what that new milestone is, sanity check that with your board and then message that to your team. 

It's super important to keep your team in the loop, so they know if the goalposts have moved. They'll accept the new reality, and they'll help the company achieve that milestone. 

So these are ways that can really help you if you raise money at a really high valuation, and think you might be in a little bit of trouble on your next round. Again, cut costs where appropriate, level up your team with the appropriate salaries, raise venture debt or alternatively, sources of funds like your clients or customers paying in advance, and then make sure you vet your milestones, make sure you're realistic about them, because they've probably changed, and then communicate that to your team. 

That's the survival guide to surviving when you raise money at a really big valuation. You can do this, you can grow into that valuation. Don't give up, just focus on executing.

name: What do you do if you raised capital at a huge valuation before the market decline?

snippet.title: Stock Option Vesting Cliff
snippet.description:
Stock Option Vesting Cliff

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Today we're explaining stock option vesting cliffs. And essentially stock options, a lot of startup employees get these. It's one of the reasons people work at startups. They typically trade a higher salary for some equity participation in the company. And so that participation typically comes in the form of stock options or restricted shares known as RSUs. We'll just kinda use them as the same today, stock options. And typically they are vested over a four-year period. Meaning, you know, every year you vest 25% of your initial stake, and so it pays to stay for four years at least at a really great company if the valuation's increasing, and you think there's gonna be an exit opportunity. But the first year is a little bit different than the other years in that, there's typically what's called a cliff, and that's what we're talking about. Meaning you have to clear the full one year timeline before you vest any shares at all. This is designed to make sure you're a good fit for the company. They don't wanna give out a bunch of shares to someone, you know, who ends up leaving in a couple months. 

So typically people use the one-year mark as like, "Hey! We like you, you're great, and here's your vesting of a full one year of stock options." And then after that point, you get to vest on a monthly basis. So essentially after the first year, you start vesting 1/48th of your initial grant every month, until you hit the four year period and you're completely vested. Now, it is possible to do what's called retention grants during that time. So sometimes maybe someone's two or three years into their initial vesting. They're making a huge impact. The company really wants to retain them. They'll do what's called a retention grant or give them another grant of options. The retention grant, it all depends. I mean, if you're a total superstar you might get a bigger package than the first one but usually the first kind of bucket of stock options is your biggest bite of the apple. 

Now, does the retention grant have a cliff on it? Sometimes it does, sometimes it doesn't. It's a very negotiable thing in the management team and the board makes that decision. Typically, most of the time we see it not having a cliff meaning you just start vesting, you know 1/ 48th every month of your retention grant. So that's important to look at and it's always great when you do get that retention grant. The final thing we should cover is just like what happens if you're terminated by the company, you know before your, you know before your one-year vesting cliff and you hear these horror stories of someone who was fired or terminated or whatever one, you know, one week or one month before they were going to vest, something that became super valuable. 

Well, in that case, the company does have some discretion and can work something out. It's important, the way the option language is worded they're not obligated to that. So they're never gonna say that they're obligated to work something out or be nice to you or, or vest you even though you didn't clear that one year. But it's something you can ask for. You know, if you're leaving on good terms and maybe it just wasn't a fit or there's some other extenuating circumstances like someone in your family's not doing too well or or things like that. It's very fair to ask for either the one-year cliff vest or you know, some ratio of that maybe 10 months, if you're if you're leaving after 10 months. So don't be afraid to ask it's okay to do that. 

And you know, it is negotiable again the company is not going to feel or let themselves be obligated to it, but they might you know, do your favor and take care of you. So I hope that helps. Remember, the cliff in stock options is typically set at one year. 

And once you clear that one year cliff you vest a full year of options after that you get to vest monthly. Hope that helps. Thanks!

name: Stock Option Vesting Cliff

snippet.title: How do Startups Value Stock Options
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, we're talking about how do startups value stock options? 

Now, this is something that's super important to the startup, but it's also super important to employees. That's one of the reasons they're working at a startup is the equity upside. Now there is a mechanism called a 409A valuation, and that is a valuation done by an accredited valuation shop. And what they do is they measured the valuation or the value of those stock options in three ways. 

The most frequent way is what's called a Back Solve Method. And what they're doing is working backwards. Hence the Back Solve Method from the preferred stock valuation. So when an investor puts $10 million in a company at a $40 million valuation and that's 40 million dollars for the preferred valuation, the Back Solve Method looks at that and discounts back for the common stock, which is what's typically issued to employees in stock options and says, You know what, preferred has a liquidation preference and they have a couple other features. So that's more valuable than common. 

So we're going to discount that. And typically, the discount ends up being that the common is about worth about 30 to 40 percent of whatever the preferred price is. So 40 million dollar preferred valuation. You're probably looking at like a 12 to 16 million dollar common stock valuation. 

Now, the second way that stock options are valued are on a Cost to Recreate basis, meaning if we just tried to build all the technology again, how much would it cost? Now, there's this is a little bit of a subjective way of doing it, but the founder will typically fill out a very detailed worksheet that says how much all this would have cost to build. And that's the valuation for the stock options. Now, of course, you learn some things along the way and probably you could have built things a little bit cheaper, but it's usually about how much was spent in invested capital to get to where you are. That's a good little rule of thumb. 

The third way is called a Discounted Cash Flow Analysis, which is looking at the projected cash flows of the company in the future. And then you discount it back to the present time. Now, this works great for more mature companies, but isn't very good for startups because startups lose tons of money for a really long time and then they do make a lot of money in the future when they turn cash flow positive. If they do. But it's really hard to project that. It's hard to know with any kind of certainty. And the discount rates bump all over the place. And so DCF's are kind of the... they're included, but they're not really relied on for stock option valuations. 

So those are the three ways the Back Solve Method, the Cost to Recreate and a DCF. And the Back Solve Method is used way more than everything else because that preferred valuation is a really good valuation and it's set by a really sophisticated investor. 

So that's why Back Solve Method is used so much to value employee stock options. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How do Startups Value Stock Options

snippet.title: Average Venture Debt Interest Rates
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about the average interest rates in a venture debt deal. 

You know, there are two types of venture debt deals. 

There's a bank term sheet and then there's the fund term sheet. The banks, again, are usually a little bit more restrictive and use investor abandonment clauses so they can be more aggressive on the interest rate; aggressive being lower. So, a typical bank interest rate will be somewhere around five, five and a half, six percent all in. That's the cash interest you're paying every year on the money you borrow. 

Now, funds, they actually let you use the money a little bit more fluidly and so they don't have the MAC or investor abandonment. So, therefore, they need to charge more. So, the average interest rates we're seeing on fund term sheets are somewhere around ten and a half to twelve percent. That's the TriplePoint, WTI, type of deals. All in ten and a half to twelve percent interest rates. 

Sometimes the upfront interest rate is a little bit low like maybe 8 percent. And then there's a final payment that is paid at the end of the loan which brings the total IRR up to that ten and a half percent range. 

So, again, these are the average interest rates you're going to see on a venture debt term sheet. You're going to see five, five and a half, six percent on banks at ten and a half to twelve percent on the fund term sheets. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Average Venture Debt Interest Rates

snippet.title: Average Warrant Coverage on Venture Debt Deal
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we’re talking about the average warrant coverage on a venture debt deal. 

A typical venture debt deal can be kind of two flavors. 

First is the bank, and again banks use investor abandonment, some of the stricter clauses, so they can be more aggressive on warrant coverage. And by aggressive, I mean ask for less work and less ownership in your startup. A typical bank warrant coverage will be somewhere around 1 percent of the deal amount so to a million-dollar loan, 1 percent of that would be ten thousand dollars in a warrant, something around there. 

Now, usually, you can also translate this to fully diluted ownership in the startup and that's usually going to be around .1 percent. So, point .15 percent of the startup. So, again, banks are cheaper because they use more restrictive clauses. Nothing wrong with that. They're upfront about it. Just know that’s going in. 

The second type of lender is a fund lender. Now they're letting you use the money a little bit more flexible and in a more flexible manner. And so, they're going to charge more. They don't have the MAC. They don't have the investor abandonment. Typical warrant coverage for fund lender is anywhere from 6 to 10 percent of the deal. 

So, again, in that million-dollar deal scenario, we're talking from 60,000 dollars to 100,000 dollars of warrant coverage or equity in your company. Now, that usually translates to about 25 to 50 basis points of the entire company. Sometimes, when the fund lender is being very aggressive and giving you a lot of money, that number can actually edge up to 1 percent of the company total value or total ownership. 

Now again, the great thing about venture debt is it’s less dilutive. So, you're getting a lot more cash and you're giving up less ownership. However, you always need to remember that this money needs to be paid back. Investor equity dollars don't necessarily need to be paid back. Or in a downside scenario aren't going to be paid back. So, the lender is trading off a lot of risk for a lower return. And so, again,

 we see on average warrant coverage for a bank is going to be somewhere around 1 percent. And for a fund lender that's going to be six to 10 percent of the deal amount and for the bank that's going to translate to about .1 percent of the company. 

And for the fund lender, it's going to be a point to .25 percent to .5 percent. Those are averages but that's typically what we see at Kruze Consulting when we're negotiating venture debt deals. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Average Warrant Coverage on Venture Debt Deal

snippet.title: Bank Letter of Credit on Venture Debt
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about letters of credit from banks and why startups should know about them.  

The big reason why startups use letters of credit is to give their landlord at their new office space a defacto deposit. It's basically collateral for the landlord. And so, what the startup will do will have their bank issue a letter of credit may be for $100,000 maybe for $200,000. The bank will segregate that cash out of the startup's normal operating account, back the letter of credit with that cash, the startup can't touch it anymore because it's backing that letter of credit, and then the bank hands over the letter of credit to the landlord. 

Now, this is preferred because you're not... You don't necessarily want to transfer a hundred, two hundred thousand dollars to your landlord.  and just hope they'll get it back for you.  Having the bank on your side, having it documented in a letter of credit is much safer for the startup, and it's much easier logistically.  

So that's why startups use a letter of credits. There’re a few other reasons like inventory deposits or things like that, but it's almost always used to secure new office space.  Hope that helps! Thanks!

name: Bank Letter of Credit on Venture Debt

snippet.title: Fintech Equity & Debt Staircase
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn Kruze at Consulting. And today we're talking about Fintech companies. And the equity and debt staircase they have to go through. So for Fintech companies. They're raising money to power operations. And write software and run the business. But they also need debt capital to actually loan money out. And so for them, debt and equity become really intertwined. So the first thing a Fintech company should do is raise. You know, two, three, four million dollar seed round or. You know, a bigger round if they can do it. And then as soon as they get that equity. They need to go find a debt partner. That can give them a couple of million dollars of debt that will fund their loans. Now, the debt partners really want to know who the equity investors are. Because debt partners typically only advance about 75 to 80 percent of a loan amount. So, for example. If you're making a bunch of ten thousand dollar loans. The debt capital really only wants to do like seventy-five hundred - eight thousand dollars. of that ten thousand dollar loan. Equity needs to fill the gap. This gives the debt partners a little bit of, you know. There's some skin in the game for the company. They're not just going to do a bunch of bad loans. And it gives them a little bit of cushion. Now, for the equity investors. This is great because they don't have to fund the entire loan amount themselves. They're only funding 20, 25 percent. So the equity and debt work in conjunction. And they're both gonna want to know each other. And they're both going to want to know each other are committed. Now, as the company evolves and they get to their series A,. Where they're raising probably a five to 10. Maybe 15 million dollar series A. That unlocks a lot more debt capital. You can probably do something on a 10 million dollar series A. Around 5 to 8 million dollars of debt capital. Again, they're working in conjunction. And the loan book, the loans that are outstanding are continually growing. Now, once a company gets to series B and series C. They're raising really big dollar amounts of equity. And that unlocks bigger lenders. Lenders that want to do 25 to 50, even sometimes 100 million dollar commitments. To fund the loan book. At this stage, when you're raising that big of equity and that big a debt. Usually have a really good track record of loan performance. Everyone understands what the faults look like. And people have a lot more confidence. So they really get behind the company. Your cost of capital drops dramatically. You're really looking at bank style loans at that point. And then finally, as the company gets to the late stage. They start being able to tap, you know, big SPV's. Special purpose vehicles. Or even Wall Street offerings where they can get the cost of debt.
Way, way, way down. And this is exciting for equity investors Because now one of the biggest inputs into the company's capital. Structure and cost the debt has gotten a lot cheaper. So the equity investors want to invest money at much bigger valuations and. They can invest a lot more capital. So this is the staircase. You start at seed, you work your way up and every step of the way. You're having your equity and your debt matching each other. Complementing each other until you get to the late stage where you're able to access Wall Street in big debt placements. Hope that helps on the Fintech equity and debt staircase. Thanks.

name: Fintech Equity & Debt Staircase

snippet.title: Extension on Venture Debt Line
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about how to get an extension on your venture debt line. Now, this is a pretty common request from startups. They want to be able to draw the venture debt, but they don't need it quite yet. So they're going to ask the lender whether it's a bank or a fund to extend that drawdown period. Now, if it's a short drawdown, the lenders are usually pretty happy to comply. After all, they want you to draw the money down. That's how they make money on interest. However, it's going to be a lot easier if it's a short term one like one or two months because anything longer than that, they're starting to extend the risk and they don't know what they don't know. So if it's a one or two-month extension, contact your lender ahead of time. Don't do it last minute, in the last couple of weeks before your drawdown period ends. And give them an update on the company how business is going your cash balance, cash burn. Send all your financials. Probably refresh the cap table. And have a really proactive conversation with a lender. They're going to have to take it to their credit committee probably and get it approved. But usually a one or two-month thing, they'll oblige. Now, if you're looking for something like three to six months, or three to nine months, that's a whole different ball game. That's basically treating this deal as a new deal. And oftentimes the lenders will still want to comply because they still want your business, but they're going to underwrite it in the same way they underwrote your first deal. So they're going to do some real in-depth due diligence. They're really going to do a big presentation, their credit committee, and they're going to probably ask for some compensation in the form of maybe a loan extension fee or some more worth in the company. After all, they're taking more risk, thus more risk than they originally thought they're going to take and it's going to be super important that your company is still executing. Now, a lot of times when the company asks for an extension, it means actually the company is executing because they don't really need the money. They're probably hitting plan or overachieving plan. So that makes the lender want to participate and help you out. But if your company is really not doing so well, and you're asking for a couple more months or six months, be prepared for the lender to say no. That's why it's super important for you to get out in front of this. Have this conversation at least two months before the extension, before the original line runs out. That way, you and the lender have plenty of time to work it out. To give them the update. And if the lender says no on a larger extension, then you can go get another deal put in place or go to your investors and ask for more money. I hope that helps with how to get an extension on your venture debt line. Thanks.

name: Extension on Venture Debt Line

snippet.title: StandStill or Cooling off Period in Venture Debt
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about what is a standstill or cooling off period in venture debt? 

Now, this is the legal term but actually it can have a really huge benefit for a startup. 

A cooling off period basically refers to the lender not aggressively foreclosing on the company if they're in default and where this really comes into play it is if the company has given the lender a lien on the intellectual property and all the other assets. 

When that lender has a lien on all assets including actual property they can foreclose very quickly in 10 to 15 days because they don't have to notify the other creditors who benefit from the sale. If the lender doesn't have all the assets like a lien on IP they'll have to notify all the other creditors like the water person or Kruze Consulting or whoever else the company owes money to. That usually takes 60 and 90 days for foreclosure. So, the cooling off period becomes very important. 

If the lender has all the assets Lien on IP with the cooling off period says is something to the effect that the lender will not foreclose and sell the company within something like 90 days or 120 days that's very negotiable as long as the management team is involved and the board is involved and they're helping to sell the company. What the lender really cares about is if the company actually gets sold and the lender knows that if it's sold without management team cooperation and board cooperation then they're going to get ten cents on the dollar. They are going to have a very good recovery. So, what the lender is doing in agreeing to a cooling off here is saying hey as long as you're playing ball and helping us sell the company helping us get our money back we're fine not aggressively foreclosing for 90 or 120 days. So, this is a very important term. If you're giving your lien on IP away to the lender because what you're basically doing is ensuring as long as you're engaged as the management team and board you're not going to get taken advantage of and have a really quick foreclosure. 

Now, of course, say you agree in this term in management and just quits and will not help the lender sell the company. Then, of course, the lender is going to move quickly and this term will be thrown out the window. 

But I do recommend putting this cooling off period language in a term sheet that you're giving all the assets of the company with. Hope that helps. This is we've been talking about cooling off periods or standstills in venture debt. Thanks.

name: StandStill or Cooling off Period in Venture Debt

snippet.title: What Are Prevailing Interest Rate and Warrant Coverage for Venture Debt
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey It's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, what are the prevailing interest rates, and warrant coverage in venture debt? 

And in venture debt you have two types of lenders: banks and then the fund lenders. So let's go through the banks first. Banks tend to be a lot cheaper. So right now it's somewhere between 5 to 7% interest rates. 

And then the warrant coverage is also a lot cheaper. Usually it's like 1% of the deal amount. Maybe 2% of the deal amount. Usually that kind of equals like .25% of the company's total ownership. 

So banks are much cheaper than fund lenders. Those are the prevailing rates but also remember, banks typically use Investor Abandonment clauses, MAC clauses, other covenants that kinda restrict you a little bit, that's how they can get away with having lower interest rates and lower warrant coverage. 

Now fund lenders, they're more flexible. They really let you use the money and typically do bigger deals, but they're more expensive, so fund lenders what I'm seeing these days, is anywhere from 11 to 13% interest rates, that's on the cash side. 

Then the warrant coverage is anywhere from 8 to 12% of the deal amount. So if you're doing a million dollar deal, and the warrant coverage is 12%, which is on the high side. But I'm seeing that quite a bit, then that will be a hundred and twenty thousand dollars of warrants in the company, above and beyond what the interest rate cash payments are. 

So hope that helps. Again, banks somewhere around 5 to 7% interest rates, 1 to 2% warrant coverage. Funds, anywhere from like 11 to 13% interest rates, and warrant coverage from 8 to 12% of the deal amount. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: What Are Prevailing Interest Rate and Warrant Coverage for Venture Debt

snippet.title: Top 6 Mistakes Startups Make When Raising Venture Debt
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

The first mistake is the old, ''Hey, give me as.'' I'll start over. Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're covering the topic. Six mistakes startups make when raising venture debt. And the first mistake is the old, ''Hey, give me as much debt as possible.'' When a founder tells the lender that the alarm bells go off in the lender's head. That means the founder is not really that concerned with the lender. They're trying to make this a binary outcome. They're trying to completely maximize the terms on their side and not worrying about paying the debt back. 

Now the second mistake companies make is they fail to check the background and reputation of a lender. They fall in love with the term sheet and they're not really thinking about the long term, but this lender is gonna be a part of your capital structure. In fact, they're the senior part of your capital structure. You really need to be able to work with them. And what I've found is new entrants into the market typically try to get into the market by giving really cheap term sheets, but they don't have the stomach and the wherewithal to ride out bumps in the road. So be really careful. I always recommend that startups work with the folks who've been in the market for a very long time because they have a massive incentive to protect their reputation. 

Now, the next one is optimizing for cost instead of flexibility. It's really easy to pick the cheapest term sheet, but sometimes the cheapest term sheet is not gonna match what you need to get done in your company. So for example, banks are really great at giving inexpensive term sheets because they're basically lending out their deposit base and there's no cost for that deposit base in this interest rate environment. We all know we barely get anything in our checking account for interest, right? But banks are federally regulated. And so they have to use covenants like material adverse change clauses or investor abandonment clauses to protect them and bring you back to the table if you're not executing, but that's not always the greatest thing for an entrepreneur. 

Now, the next one is negotiating too short of an interest-only in amortization period. Sometimes people say that's the term of the debt, but the whole reason you're doing venture debt is to extend your runway. That extra three to six months. If you don't have a long enough interest-only period, you should shoot for six to 12 months and you don't have a long enough term you should shoot for 30 to 36 months and then add those two together. Then you are gonna be paying the debt back before you can actually use it. And it ends up not providing very much runway extension. Now lenders will often structure deals to be very conservative like that because they wanna get off risk as fast as possible. So your goal should be to extend the runway for as long as possible and negotiate the longest interest-only period and the longest amortization period possible. 

Now another mistake founders make is they treat the venture debt as a bridge loan. Bridge loans are for equity investors. They are coming in and supporting the company in a tough time. It's kind of like a Hail Mary pass sometimes. Going to your venture lender and trying to get a Hail Mary slash bridge loan is not a good thing to do. First of all, that's not the business they're in and they're also not charging enough for those kinds of deals. And so the risk-reward doesn't match up and so they will be forced to use some of their covenants like material adverse change, investor abandonment, or funding max, and really limit the company's use of that money. It is not a solution for tough situations in bridge rounds. When things are going great and you just need a little bit of runway extension, that's when venture debt really shines. 

Now, the final thing that people make mistakes on is they do not stay in touch with the venture lenders and don't give them regular updates. And so venture lenders are fiduciaries just like everyone else in the ecosystem. They have people or funds that give them money or depositors who give them money and they need to keep them up to date. They need to know what's going on with the deal. If you are struggling do not go silent. If you struggle, that's when good clear communication can really help you because the lender will be in the loop and they can actually really help you with restructures or interest-only periods. It's a huge benefit sometimes and trust me, they are very less likely to do restructures or interest-only periods when you're in a tough spot if you have not been keeping in touch with them.

name: Top 6 Mistakes Startups Make When Raising Venture Debt

snippet.title: What Is Negative pledge On IP?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn about negative pledge on ip and its importance to unsecured bondholders.

00:00 Introduction
00:10 Negative pledge on ip explained
01:16 Prohibition from intellectual property
02:30 A huge deal
04:22 Conclusion

*******************************
Additional Resources

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRAKD3CFj20
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=shdQu24uPFc

*******************************

Raising venture capital? Get the finance and accounting due diligence checklist: https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-capital-finance-tax-hr-due-diligence-checklist

#negativepledgeonip #unsecuredbondholders

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

This is related to debt deals like venture debt deals, bank loans that startups might take. So when a lender gives your company money, they're going to take a lean on all the assets of the company, meaning cash, you know, accounts receivable, the office equipment, whatever it is. And there's one asset that's super valuable in startups because they're building intellectual property and it's their intellectual property. And so lenders typically want to get a lien on that which means they get the proceeds when intellectual property is liquidated in a downside scenario. 

If the company doesn't make it, company goes bust, at least they can sell the assets, you know, get the cash, sell their furniture, and sell the intellectual property and get paid back, at least partially paid back. But startups and startup management teams boards, venture capitalists, try not to give away the lien on IP if possible and so another term is often introduced and that is the negative pledge on intellectual property or IP for short. And what that means is the borrower is prohibited from pledging their intellectual property to another lender. 

So the nightmare scenario for the first lender is they give you a loan. There's no intellectual property pledged and some other really crafty lender comes in later and just does a loan against the intellectual property and they would get the proceeds if the company went down and sold intellectual property. So the first lender wants to prohibit that and so they invoke or require the negative pledge on intellectual property in their loan. That keeps any lenders from getting in there and getting weird. 

But they don't get all the proceeds from the sale of intellectual property. When there's no direct lien on it, the negative pledge doesn't count as an actual lien. When there's no lien on it, then the proceeds from intellectual property sale are split amongst all the creditors, like the general creditor bucket. So that's like the water person and the lawyer, and the gardener and the lender and even like your friendly, you know, lawyer accountants, right? We all would participate in those proceeds. 

And so, it's not like a huge deal because you know, those creditors are only going to get a portion of it. There's some loss proceeds, but not having a lien, like a pure lean on intellectual property affects the lender in a different way, which is, they can't foreclose on the company quite as fast. Meaning, I'm a little rusty on how many days exactly. This is bankruptcy law, foreclosure law. But I typically, when you have the lien on all the assets, including intellectual property, there's no other creditors you need to worry about and so you can foreclose. 

I believe it's either 15 or 30 days. It's very fast. If there's other creditors that will benefit from the sale of some of the assets, like in the negative pledge situation, then it takes more like 90 days because you have to notify all the other creditors and actually run through a process. So that's kind of the secret reason that lenders like to have the lien on IP. It basically allows them to foreclose faster. Now what does this mean? 

Practically speaking, even if you are able to get the lender to agree to a negative pledge on IP, if your company's not doing well and it's struggling and probably not going to be able to raise more money and probably will get liquidated, what you'll probably do, maybe three to six months before you're out of cash is go to the lender and say like, hey, I prefer not to make, you know, full amortizing payments or can you restructure the deal a little bit to give me a little more breathing room and a little bit more time to try to sell the company. In exchange for that restructure, I'm willing to actually give you the lien on intellectual property.

name: What Is Negative pledge On IP?

snippet.title: Can you have two venture debt loans?
snippet.description:
Can you have two venture debt loans?

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, can you have two venture debt loans? 

And, the answer is actually yes, it's possible. However, at early stage companies, they're typically only gonna have kinda one loan, because there's still not a ton of traction, there's still not a ton of enterprise value, there's probably not a ton of equity in the company. And so lenders are gonna be pretty careful, they only really wanna be the senior secured lender. But, as a company achieves enterprise value, it starts getting much bigger, more powerful, then lenders will start taking more risk. 

And you'll typically see if there's two venture debt loans in a company, you'll typically see a senior bank loan, because bank's loans are very very cheap, very inexpensive, maybe 4 to 6% interest rates. So it's smart for companies to leverage that cheap bank capital. But they'll typically want a little bit more debt, they wanna extend their runway as much as possible, and have that optionality. So sometimes they will bring in a subordinate lender, which is typically like a fund or a BDC, someone who's set up to be able to take a lot more risk, they'll be more expensive. Remember banks are federally regulated, so they can't take a ton of risk, like they cannot afford to lose money, otherwise the regulators start coming in, and investigating them, and really kinda clamp down on them. 

So you'll see the bank thing senior, but cheap, and then the funds or BDCs, business development corporations, will do much bigger dollar amounts, and be much more subordinate. But the average cost of capital when you factor in the bank and the fund, is much more attractive than just taking all fund money, and so typically companies will do this. It's actually really great to do, usually it's like $10 or $15 million of ARR, that's a great time to take, two venture debt deals essentially. Now, there's a couple things you need to worry about. 

First of all, an intercreditor agreement needs to be worked out between the bank, and the fund lender. And, typically most of the funds and banks, have usually worked together. Venture debt's kind of a small place, and so everyone usually has a relationship, if they've been doing it for a while. And they'll typically have kind of a standard intercreditor agreement, but, there are things like negative covenants, that really get negotiated. For example, like who gets to take money out first, if there's a default, or things like maybe financial covenants. Like if a company has to have a certain amount of EBITDA, or revenue growth, or net income, they can only lose a certain amount of money. If those negative covenants get triggered, then the company goes into default, and the two lenders get to fight over who gets the proceeds. 

And again, typically the senior lender gets the proceeds, and gets kinda made whole first. And so that intercreditor agreement, is really, really important. Typically the senior lender, the bank, will make that subordinate lender sign what's called a subordination agreement, saying yeah like in paper, with a signature saying, "Hey, the bank gets their money out first. " So that's really really important. Remember that, also there's typically a cross-default between the two lenders, so say you somehow trip a covenant with the fund lender, maybe you're sued for a ton of money, or again, you violate like your net income, or revenue growth covenants. That cross-default with the subordinate lender, will mean that you are also in default with the bank, or the senior lender. 

And so you just wanna be really careful. Again, this is why I recommend early stage startups, like series A, series B, they should really only be doing like one venture debt deal. They should have one senior secured lender, but again, as you get to series C, series D, and the company is passing $10 or $15 million of ARR, that's when you can start to look to layer on additional levels of capital, you'll get an average cost capital that's really really attractive. 

And again, the more debt you raise within reason, without being too aggressive, and potentially bankrupting yourself, means you have a much cheaper cost of capital, and you can hold on to your equity. I hope that helps, I know it's kind of a complex topic, but really when you get to a more, a later stage, it's not so difficult. And, there are a ton of great venture debt lawyers out there, who specialize in this. We at Kruze Consulting know a bunch who can direct you. 

And then of course, we understand the interplay of all this stuff, and can help you negotiate the deal if you're interested. Thanks!

name: Can you have two venture debt loans?

It's instructive just to kind of think about, the startup ecosystem often works backwards, off of the public stock markets. And so, you know, venture capital often tracks what's happening in the NASDAQ and some of the other indexes, but usually like a 3 to 6 month lag. And so it's helpful to think like, "What's happening in stock market? How is that going to affect venture financing, especially if my company needs to raise money?" Now, the NASDAQ is down about 35% at the time we're recording, mid-June 2022, from the November peak, but the Bessemer cloud index which tracks SaaS companies, which is a better barometer of a lot of startups, is actually down like 60, 65%, so a huge amount. 

Now what happened in November, 2021? Well, the market started seeing some pretty intense signs of inflation, and stock market investors are really smart and they worry about inflation all the time. And so what happened is, the investors started selling stocks because they thought, "You know what? This inflation is going to make the Federal Reserve have to start raising interest rates, and pretty aggressively." And so it's this really negative feedback cycle. Investors start selling. The stock market starts coming down. The Fed has to react to inflation and so they start raising interest rates, and so it kind of like, compounds. 

Now it's worth mentioning, when rates are going down and there's no inflation, the same compounding benefits the stock market. Like, that's kind of what we experience when the COVID rally happened. Like, interest rates went way down. There wasn't really inflation at all. And so the stock market really, really popped up into those 2021 highs, right? So now, the market's retrenching because inflation has reared its ugly head. Now what does high interest rates mean for stocks? Well, it actually makes the competition for an investment dollar, much more intense. 

Now imagine you're a money manager, and all of a sudden bonds are yielding 5% and it's... Bonds are safe. These are big publicly traded bonds and you don't have to do anything. You just have to own the bond and you get paid, right? Or you put your money in a CD and own a couple, and generate a couple interest percentages, right? So all of a sudden, the money that goes into risky stocks, and especially risky private stock, like venture capital backed startups, has more competition for the investment dollar. 

Another way to think about this, is most tech companies and biotechs are not going to generate profits and cash flow and dividends for a very long time, like 5 to 10 years out. And so when interest rates go up, those cash flows that one will get someday, if things go well, are discounted back to the present value of today by a much higher interest rate. And so when you increase the denominator, the interest rate or the rate of return that you're going to discount those cash flows back on, all of a sudden, those cash flows are worth way less, right? A dollar today is worth more than a dollar 10 years ago, especially when interest rates are really high. And so what we've seen is, the market has reevaluated what valuations, tech stocks and private venture capital backed startups should be trading at. 

Now, venture capitalists, they don't, they can't react quite as fast as the stock market. You know? The hedge fund people who are just lookin' at the numbers all day long, because venture capitalists are like, they have term sheets out, and they're in the middle of documentation and closing a deal. So it takes them a little while. This is that 3 to 6 month lag that I was talking about. And so, eventually, the VCs say, "Whoa, wait a second.

snippet.title: How to categorize Customer Success expenses on the P&L
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're answering the question, how should a bookkeeper categorize customer success expenses in the profit and loss statement? 

And this is a really important question and we get this a fair amount actually because everybody loves a high gross margin company. Entrepreneurs love it. The venture capitalists love it. Public investors love it. Everyone wants to have a high gross margin company, but when you start loading a lot of expenses into cost of goods sold that by nature reduces your gross margin. The equation for gross margin is revenue minus cost of goods sold equals gross margin. 

So, everyone should be very careful about loading expenses into cost of goods sold. Now, of course, you wanna do it on a GAAP basis, and that's how we do things at Kruze and that's why this guidance is so helpful. So, companies look at customer success in two different ways. Some companies treat that as purely a support organization. Others treat it as a sales organization, they're in charge of upgrading or upselling clients and that's how they pay for those people to work at the company. 

So, if your company treats it as purely support, and there are no commissions, there are no revenue targets, then that should be in cost of goods sold. Put those support costs in cost of goods sold because it's part of the cost for delivering your service. Now, if your Customer Success Organization has milestones and commissions and revenue targets, then that is definitely a sales and marketing expense. It should go into sales and marketing in the operating expenses category. 

So it's not gonna impact your gross margin. Now, there's something really important here to point out, which is in early-stage companies, oftentimes the people who are doing support also have like three other jobs. This is the beauty of working at an early stage company. You get a lot of variety. So we see a lot of times where the head of operations is answering questions or the software development team is actually answering support questions. Or maybe there's one support person, but they're doing something completely different half of their time. 

So, in those cases, you really wanna be smart and you really wanna allocate only the portion of the time equivalent to the portion of the salary for that person or those people into COGS. So again, if someone's doing half their time in operations and half their time in customer support, allocate half of their salary into customer support in COGS, you do not wanna fully burden the COGS with people salaries who are doing other things. The danger in that is it could make your gross margin look really low or even negative. 

Sometimes we have companies coming from other accounting firms that sell a SAAS product that should be very high margin. And we look into the cost of goods sold, and we see that they've got tons of salaries and stuff that's not applicable loaded in cost of goods sold, which again, depresses the gross margin. And this is a big deal for investors. When they're looking at your profit and loss statement and thinking about the potential of the company, they are absolutely not going to invest in a company with a negative gross margin. That's the old thing where you're selling $100 bills for $90. You cannot scale that business. You can't make up in volume. It's a bad business. People are not gonna wanna invest in it. 

So that's why we take such care and we really focus on what needs to go in the cost of goods sold and customer success is really one of those big ingredients. So, be careful, be smart, make sure you do it on a GAAP accounting basis, fully load the cost of goods sold where appropriate, but also be careful because if people are revenue producing and have commission structures, they should be going into sales and marketing in the operating expense category. I hope this helps. Thanks so much. Bye. Cool.

name: How to categorize Customer Success expenses on the P&L

snippet.title: How do I account for a convertible note investment?
snippet.description:
How do I account for a convertible note investment?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm going over how to account for a convertible note investment. 

Convertible notes are one of the most popular investing instruments for startups. It's preferred equity, common equity, SAFE notes, and converts, and, you know, SAFE notes are relatively new. Convertible debt was really the angel investment instrument of choice for many, many years, and still has, we still see a lot of that activity. Now, just remember, convertible notes are debt, so they do need to be paid back eventually. 

Most convertible notes have, something like a 12 to 24 month timeframe, where they're basically outstanding until then. And oftentimes, investors will just sign an extension, or restructure the convertible notes, because they kind of know, that startup funding can ebb and flow, and sometimes it takes longer to raise a round. So, there's usually some flexibility with that, but there is a payment date, usually with convertible debt. That is one reason why convertible debt needs to be booked on the liability side of the balance sheet, so it's not equity, it is a liability. Depending on how long until the debt needs to be paid back, it'll be short-term or long-term. So, short-term is anything below 12 months. When a new convertible note is put in place, it's usually like, kind of, usually really it's 18 to 24 months. 

So, it's usually going to be long-term debt, but of course, as that pay off date gets closer and you cross that 12 month barrier, you're probably going to book it as short term liability. Now, in terms of the accounting treatment, the deposit from the investors for the note, is going to increase your cash and increase your liability, so, a debit cash, credit the short term and long term liability. 

Now, eventually, when another round of capital comes in, the convertible debt's kind of like a placeholder, it's the angels or seed stage firms getting into the company, but everyone waiting for a bigger, later stage round to happen, at which point they'll convert at a price determined by the cap, that's negotiated in the note. So, you know, a seed stage company takes a million dollars in convertible notes, and then a year later, it closes a $10 million series A round. 

Well, that convertible note is going to be wiped off the balance sheet and converted into preferred equity. Sometimes there's a mix of preferred and common equity, but it's going to shift from the liability part of the balance sheet, all of the way to the equity balance sheet. So, convertible notes are our investments made with the intention that it will become equity eventually, but it's debt at the moment the investment is made. 

And again, it's all going to convert, once a bigger, later round happens. Now, if the company doesn't make it, and maybe the assets are sold for pennies on the dollar, the convertible note holders can get some, can get a little bit of money back. If the company is sold for a big win, oftentimes what happens, is the convertible notes are just treated as, they convert at the cap. And so, they get to participate in the upside of the exit. 

So, I hope that helps. Convertible notes are still a very important instrument in the startup ecosystem. If you have any questions on how to book these, how to use them to raise money, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks so much, appreciate it.

name: How do I account for a convertible note investment?

snippet.title: Where Should Startups Put Their Cash?
snippet.description:
Where Should Startups Put Their Cash?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

The first is yield, the second is risk and the third is access. And so let's kind of go through that. Yield is a little bit self-explanatory. You kind of just want to get the best interest rate or best return you possibly can without ignoring the other two criteria. So, we all know that risk and return kind of go hand in hand. So you don't want to put your money as a startup into something risky, like the stock market or high yield bonds, or back in the day, people thought auction rate securities were not risky, but they turned out to be super risky and a lot of that money got evaporated in the 2008 crash. So you want to have a yield that's like, you definitely want to get some yield on this. 

Especially like the startups are raising like 20 to 40 million bucks. That's a lot of money if you're able to get like 50 basis points or 1% on it, you're talking like real money, like that's enough to fund a couple of hires throughout the year. But you have to be careful. You do not want to take too much risk, which is our second criteria here because the people who are investing in your company, the venture capitalists, the angel investors, even the people that work there, they're not doing, they're not, working with your company because they want you to be a hedge fund or they want you to like reinvent the wheel on cash management. They want you to put that money to work building the business instead of trying to do crazy financial engineering. So they want you to hire people. They want you to build a great product. They want you to sell it. That's how they're going to make their money investing in you. 

And so taking risks in the bond market or doing something other crazy with your cash is not acceptable to them. It's a very good way of getting fired and getting kicked out of your own startup. I mentioned the auction rate security stuff back, you know, in 2008, people had been kind of sold or tricked into putting their money in these illiquid bond markets and I know at Lighthouse we had a company that has $30 million frozen and the whole management team got fired. And so you just want to be very, very careful. You started this whole startup journey to build something great, to change the world, not to be a financial engineer. 

So watch out for risk. Access is the third most important criteria, which is basically being able to get at that money in a very easy way. And so like a checking account, which usually pays no interest is always going to be available to you. Savings account is kind of the next up the rung of bank account, checking account, savings account, but savings accounts do usually pay a very, very modest interest rate right now. So like I'm recording this in the Summer of 2021. So interest rates are very, very low. So you might get like a 0.1% interest, like 10 basis points on your savings account. Like really not, it's not going to move the needle for you that much unless you've got 20 to 40 million bucks in that savings account, but very easy access, can access that day, can transfer that money into the operating accounts, typically checking account, same day immediately. 

So access on the savings account is very good. It's also usually very convenient because you can, your bank is going to have, of course they're going to have savings accounts, right? So you'll typically set up an operating account, which is checking and then having savings accounts. So super easy, very high access, but relatively low yield. The next step in this would be, that I recommend, especially if you have a lot of cash, is putting it into like a money market type of it's, it's technically a fund, but money markets have really kind of blurred to be very easy access as well. 

And we typically see all the banks we work with, SVB, Bridge Bank, Comerica, Mercury has a treasury management product now. I think Rho has something. All those firms offer something along those lines, like something essentially more sophisticated than a savings account, which will get you a higher interest rate. Not a huge interest rate, but it'll help. Maybe you're looking at 25 basis points up to maybe 40. Like I know JP Morgan has a really nice, fairly sophisticated money market fund that's got like a trillion dollars in assets. Yes, you heard that right, trillion. And there's that much cash floating around in the economy right now.

name: Where Should Startups Put Their Cash?
