Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question "How much cash should a startup keep in its operating bank account?" 

So to begin, it's helpful to know that startups typically have usually two bank accounts. One is like the normal checking account and the other is a savings/money market; some type of cash yielding vehicle account. And the bulk of the company's cash is kept in that money market/savings account, but a portion of it is kept in the operating account. And the operating account is used to pay the bills and the credit card and run payroll. It's kind of like the working capital of the company. And so a very frequent question I get from a cash management perspective is how much cash to keep in the operating account versus how much in the savings/money market account. 

And I tend to think about this in terms of months of burn rate or months of operating expense. So say you're... I'm just going to take a very round number, $500,000. You're spending $500,000 a month as a startup. That's a pretty healthy operating expense. So maybe some of the seed stage companies are spending more like $200,000 or something like that. Well so, I recommend keeping two to three months of cash in the operating account. So if you're spending 500K, then keep a million bucks to 1.5 million bucks in that operating account. Now this is really a personal preference thing. I meet a lot of companies that want to keep as much cash as possible in those interest-bearing accounts, the money market savings. 

And so they'll keep one month of cash in the operating account. Now that means they have to transfer money in more often and they run the risk of forgetting to do the transfer and missing payroll, or not paying their credit card off in time or whatever it is. But they're on the ball and they want to maximize the interest they earn in that money market savings account, so that's what they do. We have other clients that are super focused on building a product or running the business and they just don't want to forget. 

And so they'll keep more like four months of cash in their operating account. Again, very much a personal preference, but those companies that are more conservative and leaving a little bit of interest on the table, just know they're not going to miss a payroll on accident or anything like that. So it's really personal preference. Again, I'm more of like a two to three months of operating burn or expenses in the bank account, but do what feels right for you. 

But remember, interest rates are still pretty low on the yield basis, meaning banks aren't paying a lot of interest for money in those accounts, or money market funds aren't paying a lot of interest, But interest rates are starting to go up, so this is one of those things you may tweak just a little bit. Also super helpful if you have a cash management policy that's approved by the board that kind of irons this stuff out and expresses it. I find that's a really helpful thing for startups to do. Just put it on a piece of paper, get the board to ratify it, and that way you have a policy. But again, no extremely right answer.

name: Startup Cash Flow Management: How Much Capital Should you Keep in your Operating Account?

snippet.title: Benefits of Startups Offering a 401k
snippet.description:
Benefits of Startups Offering a 401k

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today, I'm just kind of spelling out the benefits of a 401k for a startup's employees. 

So this is a good program to put into place if you're a startup, especially is like, kind of farther along and you don't even really need to do matching, like matching is something that usually like more mature companies or cashflow positive companies will do. Like, for example, Kruze Consulting, we match employee 401k contributions, right? But for a startup, if you're venture funded, you don't really need to do that, but it's a good idea to get something in place. 

Like it's a nice perk for the employees and kind of, here's why, the big thing is, when you put money into a 401k, you don't have to pay taxes on it. Like capital gains, income taxes, anything like that while the money's in the 401k. And so this means that you have a bigger balance, like more money to actually grow over time. And if you start a 401k, if like, say you're an early startup employee, say you graduate college and you're working at like age 22. 

Well, by the time you retire, that's going to have like 30 or 40 years in the 401k to work and compounding every month on a tax-free basis will actually make a huge difference in the size of your 401k when you go to retire. Now, of course, as you start pulling money out of that 401k later, it is taxable. But again, you've gotten the benefit of compounding on the bigger base the whole time. Another nice benefit of 401k is your near term taxes are lower, any dollar you put into a 401k is put in on a pre-tax basis, meaning the government didn't tax those dollars. And so, say you make, let's make the math work very easily. You make a hundred thousand dollars, you put $15,000 into your 401k. Well, your addressable income that can be taxed is now $85,000. 

It's gone down by the $15,000 that you contributed to 401k, it's pre-tax money. Again, this is, that money is sheltered from taxes along the way and you paid less taxes today, which is a really nice thing. So I hope, if you're watching this and you're running a startup, you'll consider doing a 401k. We have a bunch of 401k analysis on the kruzeconsulting.com website, but you know, there's a bunch of providers. It's not going to matter a huge amount of who you work with. 

Work with someone who has a nice integration with your payroll system, has nice reporting for your friendly CPA firm, Kruze Consulting, but getting it in place will actually give a really nice benefit to the employees of the startup. And it doesn't really cost much. 

It's very, very cheap for the startup to pay. Hope that will helps and if you have any other questions on 401ks, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, thank you.

snippet.title: What should I do if my 409A valuation is too high?
snippet.description:
What should I do if my 409A valuation is too high?

If you’re a startup issuing equity compensation (Options/NQSO/ISO), you’ll need a 409A for startup purposes. Get started now at https://kruzeconsulting.com/409a_valuation/

- There is a very systemic problem in the startup world with valuations coming in too high, and the reason for that is 409A providers are heavily scrutinized by two groups. The valuation accreditation entities that really audit, and look at their stuff, and make sure they're doing everything in compliance, and then the IRS. The IRS really wants these valuations to be fair, AKA, not too low because if they're too low, a bigger percentage of the taxes come as capital gains taxes, which have a lower tax rate, so the IRS wants these to be accurate. 

In the old days, boards just used to get together and just make up a price, and then the IRS said, hey, you got to start doing a 409A valuation for this, so that's where this all came from. Now, it's really frustrating because this pressure from the IRS and accreditation entities ends up pushing the valuation people to be more conservative, and more conservative in valuations means a higher valuation. It means that your company, on paper, even though you probably haven't accomplished a ton yet because you're still a startup, is going to have a much, much higher valuation, and so, that stinks for all the employees out there who have to exercise their stock at much higher valuations, so it's important to be able to talk to your 409A provider, and really work with them, and point out some of the things that makes your startup unique, and your situation not just something like a math equation on paper. 

- One of the first things you can do is point out those valuation people, say hey, I know I just closed a round. I know you're using the back solve method, which basically means you're working off of my preferred valuation, but that's a preferred evaluation. The VCs are taking a huge bet on me. They have a huge portfolio of companies, and I'm sure they want us to be successful, but it's not guaranteed, and more important, the VCs have liquidation preference and a bunch of other rights that make their shares way more valuable than my common, so just have that conversation, remind them. 

- The second thing you want to do is you want to make sure you give appropriately conservative financials to the valuation folks. One mistake I see all the time is that founders will provide the same financials that they use to woo their venture capitalist and everybody, including the venture capitalists know that those projections are pie in the sky, and are very unlikely to be hit. Not many companies ever hit their projections, and so, you want to give the inside case, the conservative case to the valuation people. If you give financials that say you're going to be doing $100,000,000 in revenue in three years, then you're going to get a really high valuation. Use the conservative. If you can do 10 in three years or 15 in three years, that's more appropriate, and that will be really good. 

- The third thing you want to do is make sure you pick your comparable companies intelligently. So if you're picking Microsoft and Google, and you're a hardware company, or don't have a monopoly-like those companies do, your margin structure is going to be way worse than them, and you're going to trade at much lower valuations. Also, if you're comparing your company to the new hot IPO that just went public a couple of months ago, it's trading at 100 times revenue, that's going to hurt your valuation. That's going to make your valuation so much higher than it really should be, so pick your comparable companies appropriately. Be conservative. Throw in some older stage companies that are more mature that aren't going to trade at crazy valuations, assuming they are a good comp, and just walk the valuation provider through that. It's really important. You want to end up somewhere in the 25 to 35% ratio of common to preferred, meaning if preferred is $1, you want common to be somewhere around 25 cents, 30 cents. 

- As you're getting to 35 cents on a ratio basis, you're getting up there, and again, it's not really the valuation people's faults. They've kind of built this process that's as robotic as it possibly can so that they can scale, and they're trying two appease to different groups. They're trying to appease the IRS / accreditation firms, and then are also trying to appease your startup, but we all know that the IRS comes first, and so, they're going to be very conservative, so you just need to have that conversation and make sure you're looking out for your employees, so that they don't have to pay a valuation on their common stock, on their options. That's just way too high.

name: What should I do if my 409A valuation is too high?

snippet.title: Cost to Recreate 409A Explained
snippet.description:
Cost to Recreate 409A Explained

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm explaining the cost to recreate method for 409A valuations. And let's start with 409A valuations first. 

A few years ago, the IRS decreed that all stock options for employees need to have an actual fair valuation. They were worried that companies were issuing stock options at too low valuation which meant lower tax proceeds for the IRS. So they instituted the 409A valuation requirement. So that's why there's all this hubbub over actually getting a real valuation. 

Now, a lot of valuation providers will use the back-solve method to do a valuation. Which basically means they work backwards from your preferred valuation and apply a bunch of discounts because preferred stock has liquidation preferences and redemption rights and dividend provisions, and you can control the big decisions with a share class vote. So there's a lot of value in preferred stock versus common stock. And so the common stock trades at a significant discount. 

Now, if your company hasn't done, done a round with the valuation, either ever, or in a very long time, or maybe you've done a convertible note or safe note with no implied valuation in the form of a cap, then what do you do? You can't use the back-solve method. And so that's when the cost to recreate comes in. The cost to recreate basically says like how much would this company have to spend to rebuild or recreate all the technology that they have built to date? 

And so it's actually kind of the closest you can get to a perfect valuation here. And so to build the cost to recreate, you're basically gonna go through all your expenses over time and calculate them. You're kinda like essentially capturing the income statement. And so all the salaries, all the contractor payments, all the software tools, anything that went into building your product is gonna need to be itemized and submitted to your valuation partner. 

But don't forget the balance sheet. A lot of times companies will buy big capital expenditures, like big machines or things like that. And that also needs to be included in the cost to recreate. I would even go a step farther on a balance sheet item, which is the prepaid expenses. If your company has signed a bunch of licenses from software providers or tool providers they need, then I would also include those, even though some of them are capitalized on the balance sheet. 

So once you get all these expenses from the life of the company tabulated, hand those over to your valuation partner, you're gonna probably wanna go over them and answer a bunch of questions for them 'cause they don't know your company as well as you do. So once you get that valuation back from your partner, probably take five to 10 days. You will be able to price all your employees stock options. They will be happy, you'll be happy and you'll be all set. 

I hope that explanation on the cost to recreate for 409A valuations was helpful. Thanks.

name: Cost to Recreate 409A Explained

snippet.title: How do I claim the R&D Tax Credit payroll offset?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost/

Video Transcript:

Hi, guys, I'm Vanessa with Kruze Consulting and today I wanted to take a little bit of time to talk to you more about R&D tax credits for startups. 

The big question that we get is, how do I claim the R&D tax credit payroll offset? And the answer is to follow these steps. 

First and foremost, and this is so important, make sure that you work with a startup CPA. I can't even tell you how many companies I've seen that worked with Joe Schmo down the street or someone who didn't specialize in the R&D tax credit and they wound up either with no R&D tax credit study or kind of shoddy work and then they missed out on tens if not hundreds of thousands of dollars in savings. So please make sure that you work with someone who's really familiar with startups and someone who knows R&D tax credits well. 

A quick kind of publicity plug, we here at Kruze, we only work with startups and we do an amazing job on these types of R&D tax credit studies. 

So, second, you're definitely gonna want to file the R&D tax credit with your startup CPA on form 6765. That's known as the credit for increasing research activities and it's actually a form that goes with your annual tax return. It's the big tax return that's actually known as the 1120. So, just know that it's kind of a subset of that major tax return that you file once a year. 

And then finally once you filed your tax return, and it's been accepted with the IRS, you're going to have to go back to your payroll provider and claim the R&D tax credit on payroll tax form 941. We absolutely love Gusto they've made it totally easy but just about every other payroll processor out there should be able to help. 

If you have any questions feel free to reach out to me. I'm Vanessa with Kruze.

name: How do I claim the R&D Tax Credit payroll offset?

SVB is one of our big partners at Kruze Consulting. And so we wanted to just do a video, explaining the strengths of SVB, so people in the startup community, I think people already kind of know it, but we figured we'd help them get the message out a little bit. So a lot of people don't know but SVB is still relatively young. It was founded in 1982, so almost about 40 years old. But from the beginning, they had a really big focus on startup and entrepreneurs. That was like the big bet behind the bank. And you can look at their market cap. It really, really paid off. I think they had about $70 billion worth of assets, like deposits, loans they own things like that at the end of 2019. So, it's not a small bank anymore. It's had huge growth. It's a big institution. And I think the reason why Kruze really likes SVB it's really is kind of three things. First, it has just a complete product suite. 

SVB really offers every product or service a startup or someone in the startup community could want. They provide wire services, bill pay, stuff like that, that startups are gonna need. And then one of their big differentiators is venture debt. 

Across the country there's not many banks that actually want to lend money to startups or companies that are losing money. It's really hard I mean, think about it. A bank, SVB is too, is federally regulated. 

The other thing about SVB is they do a lot of like personal banking things that help entrepreneurs or help team members, or even help venture capitalists. 

And then the final product suite to talk about is just the fact that they serve venture capital funds, too. They have a big fund money management business. They are also known for helping and introducing big LPs. 

The next thing is just a big emphasis on customer support. So if you're a startup working with SVB, you're gonna have an account manager assigned to you. 

And then I think the other thing we like about them on the customer support side is they do think about the accounting firms like Kruze Consulting.  

And so it's really nice that SVB has all that stuff. It just makes their customer support a lot better. Now, the final thing we'll talk about is just, SVB has proven that they are fast movers and they're really good at filling holes in their product line. A good example, we talked about credit cards a little bit, but the old SVB credit card system was just not that great. Support wasn't very good. The rewards were really poor. There were personal guarantees and Brex came into the market. And I think Brex did some damage in the first couple years, but SVB responded with their SVB Innovator's card, which is a tailor-made credit card for startups. There's no personal guarantee. They really increased the rewards. Most importantly, the customer support and integration into the rest of the SVB banking portal is so much better. It used to be such a nightmare trying to connect the old SVB credit card system to QuickBooks, and we'd have a bunch of errors and a bunch of problems. And so the SVB Innovator's card is a really good example of that. 

Another one people don't really realize, but Stripe was founded and runs on SVB's payment rails. I mean, they are responsible for helping one of the biggest payment innovators in all of Silicon Valley in the tech industry, get there. Without that partnership with Stripe, without the partnership with SVB, Stripe would have probably had a really difficult time getting going in early days. And then the final thing on just improving their systems is they've invested a lot of money. They've even done some acquires and bought some small startups to make their portal and all the data connections so much easier to work with if you're an accountant.

name: What is Silicon Valley Bank? A Complete Review of SVB

snippet.title: First Republic Bank
snippet.description:
First Republic Bank.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

First Republic is one of the dominant banks in the startup category that we focus on, and so I thought it'd be helpful for everyone to know First Republic's strengths and why people like working with them, and so the first one and definitely the single most important reason people like First Republic is they have phenomenal customer service like white glove, call you back in 10 minutes, get it done no matter what, type of customer service and that's, as I'm an entrepreneur myself and so as an entrepreneur and someone who works with a ton of entrepreneurs, I really, really value that. 

Now there's some other great things about First Republic, though. They've made a really big investment into their mobile apps. 

The next one is old fashioned, but they have branches. It sounds kind of silly to say in this day and age, but having a branch you can walk into and make a deposit or handle a wire at the last minute, or even if you need to, you shouldn't really be doing this if you're a startup, but withdrawing cash or things like that is actually really helpful. 

Now there's a couple other things in that they do some ancillary services for startups or founders or employees of startups that are really, really helpful. The two being mortgages, and if you're working in the startup ecosystem, odds are, you're not like maximizing your pay. Like you could probably be making more money at a bigger company, but you've chosen to help build something and change the world, and so you typically, there's a little bit of a trade-off on salary and you usually get some equity alongside of that, and so first Republic understands the trade-off that founders make and employees make on salary and so they're very, very flexible on margins. 

Now they're not gonna underwrite a mortgage that you can't afford, but there's just a lot more wiggle room and again, that customer focus really comes into play there. So that's really, really helpful, especially if you're a founder and you've probably been paying yourself under market for three or four years. That is a huge differentiator if you're trying to buy a house. Another thing along those lines is student loan financing. They, First Republic has a really aggressive student loan financing or refinancing program for startup employees, and I know a bunch of Kruze Consulting team members have taken advantage of that. It's really, really low interest rates, and basically they're using the halo of the company that you work with. 

Like they know you're working with a good company or good startup, and so that factors into their underwriting criteria and allows them to be a lot more aggressive on the student loans. So I know we've made numerous announcements at Kruze that the First Republic student loan financing program is something that everyone should investigate, and a bunch of people have taken advantage of that. 

Now there's another aspect of First Republic that startup founders and employees don't always think about, but it's actually very important. They have a huge fund management practice, meaning they manage the capital, the bank accounts, the capital call loans for tons of venture capital funds, and so that creates a really nice synergy in that they know all the fund managers, all the VCs, you're trying to get their attention or trying to get a meeting with them. 

First Republic usually has a one-to-one relationship with them. In fact, they probably did their capital call loan, and they may even have done their mortgage and their fund probably has their cash sitting at First Republic, and so they can go above and beyond and make some really high value intros for you. There's also just a nice little synergy when the VC knows that their companies are banking at First Republic. So I really, it's kind of an under the radar thing, but having that fund management, fund practice at First Republic is really beneficial to really everyone in the startup ecosystem. 

So those are the big things, but I really wanna come back to people as we wrap it up to just that customer centric approach. It is again, above and beyond really anything I've experienced in the banking industry and I would put it up there with the top, Nordstrom's, Neiman Marcus, Southwest Airlines, all the companies that you read about that are really famous for their customer service, First Republic is at that level and should be mentioned in the same breath as those top tier companies across the world that take customer service really, really important. 

So I hope that helps, check out First Republic, we really like them at Kruze and it's just a great bank to work with, thanks.

So they're right in like the startup flow of New York. And they do have a lot of Silicon Valley clients too. but, they just kind of get it, they've lived it. 

Now they've built a really beautiful interface. Like it's just so easy to use. It's almost like feeding your eyes cookies. Like it's just so nice to just look at it and navigate around. Very easy, very different from like your typical bank login experience. So I really like Rho for that. They also have a really great savings interest rate. So they're very generous on this. That number changes a lot, but they're always significantly higher than kind of the old school banks. The other thing I like about them is, they have FDIC insurance over all your deposits. So typically there's a $250,000 limit for each account on FDIC insurance. 

But they basically built a little bit of technology that splits. You don't see this, but it splits your money. You know, you might raise 10, $20 million in a startup. You want all that to be insured. So it splits your money into micro accounts and makes sure everything is insured, which is pretty huge. And then the kind of clincher for me is that they are building basically an accounts payable solution inside of the bank. And so typically our clients use bill.com. But a lot of times bill.com is kind of tough to learn. It's not the most easy interface, it's kind of industrial strength. And so the early stage founders are kind of like, "Do I really need to use bill.com? Do I really need to spend a lot of time using this?" And it's not always super intuitive. 

And so Rho is effectively replacing bill.com in that flow, and making it super easy to pay your vendors, to store the invoices, to label the transactions, and make sure they sync into QuickBooks, which makes our life a lot easier. That invoice aspect of it is really important. We need to be able to check the invoices, to see which months the service from your contractors was provided. Because if we don't know the months, we can't do accrual accounting and gap based accounting correctly. It just becomes like ugly cash accounting, which is not what you want and which makes your financials lumpy. So Rho is really pioneering, like this bill pay aspect inside of the bank. 

And I'm just super excited about it. Like it's a really beautiful, easy to use solution, but it's got some real business applications that can save you time as a founder, make it a little easier, and frankly, save your accountant like us a lot of time. So check out Rho. It's R-H-O.co and it has an app interface as well. So check it out, we really like it. 

And shout out to Rho. Great job team for building a really great solution. I love recommending new things that make everyone's life a lot easier. Thanks.

name: Rho Banking

snippet.title: How does a secondary transaction get reported on ASC 718 Stock Option Expense?
snippet.description:
How does a secondary transaction get reported on ASC 718 Stock Option Expense?

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're answering the question how does a secondary transaction get reported on ASC 718 stock option expense? 

Now, that is a mouthful but it's really, really important for founders who are doing secondary sales. So the quick answer is a secondary transaction should not impact your ASC 718 reporting. That's a negative. It should not impact it. It potentially can impact your 409a going forward. The logic there being if there's a market made in the common stock that's far above what the 409a valuation is, people need to take a hard look at the situation and think well, hey, is that 409a accurate enough? Is it outdated? Should we be getting a new 409a if other people are willing to pay a lot more for that common stock than what the stock option price is determined by the 409a? So that's not always the case. 

Oftentimes, investors who are buying common stock in a secondary transaction and are paying more than the 409a evaluation, which is recent, could have different motives for paying up. Maybe it is a company they were not able to get into via preferred stock transactions, like the VCs just got boxed out. And so they'll kind of like pay whatever it takes, kind of irrationally almost to get into some common at least. 

Also, there are times where this is kind of the negative situation but there's a founder who is just not kind of executing or not getting along with the team or something like that and so there's a premium put on buying that founder's shares so that you can kind of get them out of the way or get them out of the company. And so that way, the founder who may isn't getting along with everyone still walks away with proceeds and a lot of value and then the team can concentrate and not have to really worry about maybe a personality issue or something like that. 

So those are some of the reasons why people would pay more than the 409a valuation and you could rationalize why it shouldn't be impacting the future 409a valuation. But again, this is a good one to talk to your lawyer about, this is a good one to talk to your accountant firm, like Kruze about and a good one to talk to your valuation provider about because there's always extenuating circumstances in these situations but the big takeaway is that a secondary's just not gonna impact your ASC 718 reporting. That's the good news for you. 

You can sleep well at night and if you have any questions on this, feel free to hit Kruze up. kruzeconsulting.com and we have our dedicated tax team and will be happy to help you on this, thanks.

name: How does a secondary transaction get reported on ASC 718 Stock Option Expense?

snippet.title: Steps to shut down a startup
snippet.description:
Steps to shut down a startup

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

I hope that you never have to go through this, but a lot of the best entrepreneurs take a shot, build a company, it doesn't work out, and they live to fight again and create another company and they go on to a lot of success. So if you're watching this video because you're shutting a company down, I'm sorry. A lot of empathy for entrepreneurs at Kruze. We're entrepreneurs ourself. But I also just want to explain to you how to shut down a company appropriately so that you don't have any bad ramifications down the road. I always like to remember that in the bowels of the IRS and the bowels of the state governments or states, those states you're working in with your startup, your social security number is somewhere attached to the EIN and the state numbers for your company. And so doing the final tax returns, dissolving the company, putting it to bed correctly will save you a lot of headache. 

I get a lot of emails, nightmare emails from entrepreneurs where like the state of California is still auto debiting their personal bank account three years later, because the state of California thinks they should be filing a tax return every year and they're not paying their state franchise tax. So this happens a lot, not a ton, but you want to do this correctly, shut down the company correctly, so here's how you do it. First thing you're going to do, file a final tax return. This is a federal and state tax return. Sometimes municipalities like New York City actually require a final municipal tax return, too. They all kind of flow off the federal return, so just make sure your accountant or CPA is actually doing the final tax return. 

Sometimes companies run out of money and don't have enough money to pay for the final tax return. It's sad, but sometimes those situations have to come out of the founder's pocket. You never like to see that. So right before you're about to run out of money, make sure you reserve some money to wind down the company correctly, but you're going to do that final tax return because the IRS and the state governments and maybe municipality. 

The next thing you're going to do is do a Delaware certificate of dissolution. So you actually have to fill this out, mail it in. Your lawyer will probably do this for you, but you can do it too, it's not too hard. There's some samples on Delaware's website, pretty easy to do. You're also going to file your final Delaware franchise tax report. And so for this, you need your cap table, your up-to-date financials, because you're going to need the asset value on your balance sheet. You're also going to need the shares outstanding. That's why you need your cap table. 

And you're going to go into the Delaware franchise tax website. You're going to fill in all that material, and then you're going to click final filing. And so there's like a little button there, very easy to do. Pro tip, when you fill all that information in and you click the recalculate button, give it a couple of seconds. Sometimes people freak out. They email us or call us because Delaware's website says they owe like $40,000 or $100,000, but it's just they didn't hit the recalculate button. Sounds so simple until you're the person calling me with the complaint about the $40,000 franchise tax fine. If you're a tiny startup, it's going to be like $400, just to give some context if you're watching this video. You're also going to do... So, that's Delaware. 

You're also going to need to do state dissolution. So for example, say you're operating in the state of California, New York, Texas, wherever you're operating. And quite possible these days, you're operating in a bunch of different states. You're going to need to file, again, the final tax return we talked about, but you're usually going to have to file like a form dissolution. So in California, there's a certificate of surrender you have to fill out. New York, Texas, all the other big states have something similar. So don't forget the other states though. You don't want them expecting a tax return every year and doing that auto debit thing on your bank account. You're also going to fill out an IRS dissolution application. It's form 966. So you can just actually type in IRS form 966, you'll see it. Not too complicated. Something, typically, your accountant will fill that out for you, but if you need to do it yourself, you can do it. 

And then the final thing you're going to need to do is compute and prepare the liquidating distribution if there's anything to liquidate in the form 1099-DIV. So you're going to want to get that out. This is like, say, you're shutting down with another million dollars in cash or even $100,000 in cash, whatever it is, you're going to redistribute that back out to investors to make them as whole as possible. Always a good thing to do.

name: Steps to shut down a startup

snippet.title: Can you backdate payroll?
snippet.description:
Can you backdate payroll?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, should your startup backdate payroll? 

And my emphatic answer is no. Please do not do this. Please do not backdate any payrolls for any reason. And the reason is you do not wanna run into compliance problems with the IRS. I know it seems so simple just to run those payrolls on a, you know, historical date and everyone gets paid and you're catching up with money you owed people and things like that. But, the IRS takes payroll taxes very seriously. That's one of the main revenue drivers of our country of any state, of any municipality. 

And so if you start backdating payroll, you're gonna run to a problem because all the payroll providers file payroll tax quarterly reports with the federal government and the States. For the federal, I think it's a 941 is the form. And basically any time you are going in and backdating payroll after that 941 form is filed with the federal government, you are sending contradictory information to your payroll provider and to the IRS and the payroll provider is gonna report it. Like the payroll provider is not gonna get in trouble with the IRS on your behalf because you want to run payroll historically. 

So please do not do that. Please, it's gonna create a ton of problems. People don't know, but payroll penalties, payroll tax penalties create a lot of problems for companies and it's a lot of paperwork. It's a lot of like time spent on hold with the IRS or trying to catch up or paying a specialist to handle those payroll tax re-filings. So please don't do this. Now, one thing... The use case I see this most with startup founders is they don't wanna take payroll until they raise capital, which makes sense. There's no money in the bank really anyways, to pay them. And so what they do, the logic is like, well, hey, I've been spending three to six months raising money. So I raised money and now I'm gonna pay myself for those three to six months in the past. 

And again, I totally get the logic and it makes perfect sense, but again, backdating the payroll is gonna cause problems with IRS. So what I would recommend on the front end, right when you start working with a company and you know you're gonna do this, put it into your contract that you're gonna get a bonus when you raise the capital. So instead of like running a back payroll you're actually gonna be in compliance with the IRS because you're collecting that bonus payment that's in your contract. 

It's very important to have this in your contract as, you know or an agreement with the board or something like that, that's documented ahead of time so that you can show the IRS that you weren't just playing around and ran a bonus payroll for six months of retroactive payroll. You wanna have this all documented properly. But if that's in your contract you have the agreement with the board, you do raise the cash, then it's perfectly fine to run a bonus payment for the successful raising of capital. And now you're gonna be running your normal payroll. 

So that scenario addresses the most frequent use case of why people are trying to run payroll retroactively. There's probably some other reasons that I can't really think of right now, or aren't super common but I think the big takeaway needs to be just please don't run retroactive payrolls. It's gonna get you in compliance problems. You're gonna spend less time building your startup and more time dealing with IRS or you gonna have to pay someone like Kruze to fix this stuff. 

And we don't really like fixing this stuff because it's a real pain and it's very intense for us. So please do it the right way. If you have any questions shoot us an email at kruzeconsulting.com. Always happy to answer payroll, payroll tax questions. And we can give you a little friendly advice if you need it. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Can you backdate payroll?

snippet.title: Why Would a Founder or CEO of a VC backed startup get fired?
snippet.description:
Why Would a Founder or CEO of a VC backed startup get fired?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

And I think it's really important to just state this upfront that no venture capitalist slash board member ever wants to fire the founder from a startup. You remember like those VCs went to their partnership and said, we have to invest in this person, their vision what they're creating is so amazing. We want to be a part of this and we can get a really great financial return on it. Right? So the people who are pulling the trigger on a termination of a founder, are doing it, not because they really want to, but because they kind of feel like they have to. And remember venture capitalists or board members are fiduciaries of the company. Like no matter how much they like the founder they have to look out for the company and for the shareholder value. And that's the definition of being a fiduciary. And so they're doing it. Not, they're not happy to be doing it. They don't want to do it. And frankly, anytime you're firing a founder, the odds of you as a VC making money on the company or the company having a good outcome are probably pretty low. 

So the VCs know that. So this is only stuff that... it's like their hand has been forced. They feel like they have to make a change. And so the first and definitely the biggest is just like negative surprises in cash management. And this can be a couple of different things. This can be spending way too much money, way too fast. This could be misinforming the board about how long your cash runway actually is Or maybe you're so disorganized as a founder, unfortunately, that you actually don't know how much money you're spending. And so you're not just like surprising the VCs but you're surprising yourself. And so this is definitely the biggest thing. Like the venture capitalists are financial people, they're writing a check. 

Now, if you're increasing your burn rate because the opportunity is so attractive or you missed a couple of quarters, but you're communicating with the VCs and the board members, that's different. Like that's not a surprise. The surprise is when they start questioning whether they can actually trust you as the founder or not. Another issue is recruiting. 

And, you know, venture capitalists or board members they will, if, executive team members leave they're going to call that executive team member up and get the scoop. Like they are not shy about getting that person's side of the, of the story. And so. If you're losing... You know, there's obviously always churn in employee ranks and executive ranks, but if there is a clear pattern of you losing your top executives at your company and it happens a couple of different times for the same positions the venture capitalists are going to ask what's going on and what's wrong. So that's another reason that could lead to termination. Falling short of milestones is another really, really big one. And just venture capitals have a lot of boards they sit on, they make a lot of investments. That's part of like, their business. That's part of their daily life. So they really depend on like the shorthand milestones that companies tell them. 

And achieving those milestones is really important because if they are achieved, the VCs know that the company will be able to raise more capital from other venture capitalists. And the venture capitalists will give you really good feedback on how real your milestones are. Are they going to be enough to raise money for the next round? And so when you come short, they know in their head a couple of things, the company has missed our numbers. They missed the target they're supposed to be hitting. And also when that happens, they're probably going to have to write another check to kinda of jump in and help save the company. 

A lot of times it's in the form of a bridge loan. And so if you're missing your milestones repeatedly, almost by definition, you're going, it means you're going back to the investors asking for more cash. And so, again, that's one of those things. And if you're missing your milestones you're just not gonna be able to get outside VCs interested in the company. And so that's another reason they might make a change. And the final, big reason is hopefully obvious these days but just harassment or tolerating a culture of harassment. I think people understand that it's not appropriate for harassment to happen in the workplace at all. 

But if you're a founder or CEO and you maybe you're not harassing people directly but you're tolerating or facilitating a culture of harassment, that's just as bad as actually doing it.

name: Why Would a Founder or CEO of a VC backed startup get fired?

snippet.title: Quick Guide to Matching Assets to Debt
snippet.description:
Quick Guide to Matching Assets to Debt

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

This is especially important for startups that are buying some type of asset and will get a payback period from their customer. So good examples would be like companies that buy tablets and load software on them or robotics companies or agricultural robotics companies. There's a lot of hard asset companies out there and they're leveraging both their technical acumen and building these robots or tablets or whatever it is, but also loading a ton of software. 

And it's really kind of a hardware plus software play. But because there is hardware involved, you do want to most likely finance that hardware. So, the idea is you take equity from venture capitalists to pay salaries and burn, all that kind of stuff. But you can take debt out to help kind of augment your cash runway, extend your cash runway, and you can do that and finance your hardware. So a good example might be like a robotics company that has to buy either the parts or they buy a robot from an OEM in Asia, and then they make some customizations and load their software on it. And once they sell it to the customer, it's a six month payback period, right? 

And so, in my example, you might start thinking about this and say like, "We just need a six month revolver." A revolver's the kind of debt that you can draw down and payback at your option as a startup. And so you go to the bank, SVB or TriplePoint or WTI, Bridge Bank, some of the big lenders that we work with and you request a revolver loan. And this makes perfect sense. You then use that, you draw down the money on the debt, you pay the person that you're buying it from and then the cash from the customer that's using the robot goes back and pays the lender. 

But that's only looking at kind of a one-time purchase of the hardware. Most of our companies, all of our companies, are hopefully growing. And so their kind of unit of growth is usually measured in those robots, in those tablets, whatever those hard assets are that they're selling to clients. And so you're gonna start assuming that month one, you buy a few robots and month two, you're gonna sell a few more, and month three, you're gonna sell even more and so on and so on because you're building a company to grow. And so you start moving your mentality from a revolver that matches that one single cash outlay to something like term debt, because term debt is gonna cover all the different outlays you have as you grow. 

And so just kind of visualize multiple schedules of paybacks out there. And the nice thing about term debt is you can typically negotiate a forward-looking commitment, which means that the lender will typically give you something like 6 months to 12 months, sometimes even 18 months to draw down and use that debt. And so, as you're making these purchases of hard assets for your company, all you do is every time, within reason, you don't wanna micromanage this, but maybe every three months or every six months, you make a new draw down on your term debt, it will match the cash outflow that's going to the OEM you're buying the robots or tablets or whatever from. 

And then you'll have your own amortization period for each draw down term debt. And the nice thing about term debt is they almost always, and you should negotiate this, have a very friendly prepayment clause. And so if your company is just kicking butt and you have a really nice bluebird inbound VC term sheet for a ton of money, and all of a sudden you're gonna have so much money that you don't even really need to use debt for awhile, then you can turn around and use that new equity you're raising and pay down all of those term debt outstanding and save a little bit of money on interest. 

And you know what, because you raised so much money and your company's doing so well, you're probably gonna get an ultra generous, aggressive offer from whoever your term lender is to do a longer interest-only period and a longer draw down period. 'Cause they're gonna wanna stay in the game. You are a company that's working and everyone wants to get money into good companies because that's how the lenders make money, that's how the VCs make money. 

And so I think just the big picture, revolvers are a really good match for those assets, if it's a one-time purchase. But again, almost all the startups we work with at Kruze are gonna be making a series of asset purchases. And so term debt actually becomes the better match for that asset. I hope that helps. I know it's a little bit of a complex concept, but we're here at Kruze to help you out if you have questions on venture debt and how you should optimize the debt you're raising to match your assets. Hope that helps, thanks, bye.

name: Quick Guide to Matching Assets to Debt

snippet.title: 3 Factors slowing VC investment into startups
snippet.description:
Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about three factors that are slowing startup investment by VCs, and we're right in the middle of the COVID-19 situation, so this is an up to date market report here. But, there's three things that are really happening. 
The first is venture capitalists have big portfolios of existing companies, and so when there's a crisis, they spend a ton of time working on their existing portfolio, helping those companies survive, so they're in a lot of board meetings doing things like maybe redoing the operating model or maybe doing headcount reductions or just strategizing on how to get into a different market, and also maybe strategizing on how to raise more money. And so, VCs are essentially distracted from doing new deals right now because they're doing their job. They're working with their existing portfolio companies. That's what you want them to do, but it does slow down the amount of new deals they can do. 
The second factor is capital calls become more difficult in tough times like now. Now, thankfully, the stock market has recovered from the March and early April reductions, and so now the asset basis for all the pension funds and endowments is back up pretty much to where it was. So, capital calls are not as painful as they were maybe two or three weeks ago. When the market goes down a lot, it's very difficult for the foundations, endowments, pension funds to fund the capital calls. They will do it. They're contractually obligated to do it, but that means they're selling stuff at the bottom. They don't like selling assets for low prices either, just like you and I, and so when VC firms submit their capital calls, that means they're selling an asset to fund that capital call, and so they're much happier funding that capital call when things are good, the stock market is up because they're liquid and they're not taking a price discount. So, in March and April, when things were really tough in the stock market, they were not super happy. Again, they were funding capital calls, but they might've had some words or maybe told the GPs to be a little more conservative. Now, venture capitalists, it's not really in their best interest to talk about that. They're not gonna publicly advertise that their LP said slow down the capital calls. But, that does happen. I've been through it. I worked at a venture capital fund. I've seen it happen. It definitely happens. The LPs are really, as a VC, your customer, and so you're gonna do what they want. You're gonna be very respectful of that relationship. 
The third thing that's slowing down venture capital investing right now is price discovery. We just don't know, no one in the legal system knows what a company is worth today versus we had a pretty good idea where the economy was six months ago, pre-COVID. The stock market was working. It was efficient. We could see that valuations for SATS companies usually traded in like a five to 10 X revenue multiple. That's kinda what the market was, for example, SATS companies. But, VCs had a pretty good idea of what a series A should go for and how much capital should be raised in a series B and a series C, and so on.
Now, with COVID, there's so much confusion and diversions in a company's performance and the stock market isn't super rational right now either that venture capitalists don't have a good feel for what the true valuation of a company would be. And so, if they get too aggressive, they may look foolish down the road. Say someone gives a super aggressive term sheet to a hot company right now, they may feel, you know, a little bit silly down the road because their LPs may really ask them what they were thinking doing such an aggressive deal in times of COVID. And so, venture capitalists are in this process along with founders of price discovery. 
Everyone is doing a lot of negotiations and trying to figure out what the new prices for series A, series B, even angel investments are, and that takes a little while to work out. It takes some stability in the stock market. It's a lot easier, if the market's lower, it's just easier if it stays a bit lower for a while for people to get used to the new reality. When it's bouncing around with thousands of points drops and increases, it's very confusing to everybody. So, venture capitalists, they're fiduciary. They're fiduciary for the funds that invested in them, and so they wanna make sure they do a good job and make sure they get in at a fair price, and so price discovery is what's holding up some of the deals too. So, just to recap, the work on existing portfolio companies is taking a lot of time. The trying to be conservative on capital calls is also slowing down investment, and the third thing is price discovery. 
Once we get to a more stable time, even if COVID is still a factor in our life, those three things will settle down and venture capitalists will start doing more deals. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: 3 Factors slowing VC investment into startups

snippet.title: What is the Stock Markets Influence on VC Funding
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about how the stock market influences the venture capital market, and this is a really important topic right now, because we're in the middle of COVID-19. 

There's a ton of volatility in the stock market, and there's a ton of fear in the venture capital and startup communities, 'cause we don't know what's gonna happen. And so I thought it'd be helpful to just walk through how funds get their money from big institutional investors, and how institutional investors like foundations are influenced by the stock market. 

Now, foundations and endowments like Stanford, MIT, Berkeley; or pension funds like Verizon; or big, old-school companies with huge pension fund really make up the bulk of the capital that goes into the venture capital market. And the reason why is: they have huge asset portfolios. They've got money in the stock market, they've gone in the bond market, and they a long time ago realized that if they put money in asset classes like private equity and venture capital, they could actually outperform to some degree. 

But, they only have so much to go into those asset classes, 'cause they're fairly risky relative to the stock market and bond market, and they're not very liquid. So typically, a foundation, endowment, pension fund will allocate something like 20 to 30% of their total assets into alternative assets.

Now, it could be more. There's a whole conversation around Yale and the way they do things, and they're way more aggressive with allocation to alternative investments. But for our work here, just kind of figure 20%, 30%. And so, let's take a really big endowment, foundation, pension fund, let's say, we're just gonna make some numbers up here. They have $100 billion in assets, and they're going to allocate 20% of that to alternative investments. That's $20 billion. Now, and that's with the stock market kind of doing what it does. 

Now, let's imagine the stock market goes down quite a bit, like we've experienced lately, and maybe it's a 20% haircut. All of a sudden, the assets that are liquid are worth a lot less for that pension fund, endowment. Maybe their total assets now are $80 billion. But they had already allocated 20% of the 100 billion to alternative assets. That means they have a $20 billion allocation but their total assets are only 80 billion now. Now their allocation is 25%. So you can fumble the math and see how, just by the stock market going down, and that means that the allocation of alternative assets has actually gone way up for that pension fund or endowment. So now they have a problem: they can't make new allocations for a while, until either the stock market goes up or they get a lot more capital back from their alternative investments. 

And right now, there's not very many IPOs happening, there's not really big buyouts happening because it's such a tough market, so they're not going to get money back from their investments in the near term, so the only lever they really have is either hope the stock market goes up again, or they can't really make new commitments for a while. And so, we saw this in 2008, 2009, 2010. The pension funds, endowments were very slow to make new commitments to venture capital funds, or private equity funds, but mostly venture capital, because they were overweighted. The people who managed those portfolios at the pension fund, endowment are just handcuffed. They can't do anything 'cause they're overweight. 

So, if you're wondering what's going to happen to the venture capital market, and really by default the startup ecosystem, watch the stock market. This may be like a total obvious observation for some people, but it really is, these machinations really matter, and so if the stock market recovers, like it has temporarily now, in April, and hopefully it sticks, then endowments and foundations will continue to make new commitments, they'll continue to fund new venture capital funds, and again, that capital will rush into the startup ecosystem. Which is great, that's how it's been for a very long time. If the stock market has a setback and goes down again, those pension funds, endowments will find themselves overallocated, potentially for the long term, and have to let their portfolio kind of run off, and wait for distributions to come back before they can make new commitments. 

So we're in a really interesting moment here, and I hope this little tutorial on how endowments, pension funds make their allocations, and how that affects the venture capital market, helps you out. Thanks! Bye. Cool.

name: What is the Stock Markets Influence on VC Funding

snippet.title: How Startups Should Maximize Amazon AWS Free Credits
snippet.description:
How Startups Should Maximize Amazon AWS Free Credits

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, "How should a startup manage its Amazon free credits?" 

This is currency. The Amazon credits are like the lifeblood of a lot of startups. Everyone loves them. It's like candy on Halloween, right? And for Amazon it actually works really well. Like companies are able to experiment on AWS, get used to it, get their applications deployed or scaling them. So, for Amazon, it's an amazing loss-leader, so they love giving out credits. But, I get this question a lot from startups, like, "How are we supposed to manage this? How do we maximize our credits?" is a big thing. So there's really kind of two paths. The first path is, if you've gone through Y Combinator or Techstars, or like a Tier 1 VC firm, you can ask and receive $100,000 worth of free credits. You will get that. 

There's one catch though, in that you only have a year to spend those credits, and the lifetime cap of AWS credits is $100,000. So you basically are getting it all up front, and you only have a year. Now the tricky part about this is a lot of early stage startups actually can't spend $100,000 a year, because they don't have the customer usage to drive the use of their Amazon credits up, and so they end up having 50, 60, $70,000 worth of credits expire, they can never get those credits back, and they didn't maximize that. 

So the way I prefer, with the $100,000 lifetime credits limit in mind, is start slow, get five or $10,000 worth of credits, and you can get this through Amazon and you get this through incubators, there's a bunch of different ways, and then once you use those, go up another 10K and then you go up another 10K, and you're at 25, and then the grants can actually start getting bigger. 

And then you can hit up the Y Combinator, Techstars, Tier 1 VC, whoever you know in that world, and get the big giant grant that will take you from maybe like 20 or 30,000 that you've already used, up to the 100K. But at that point, you're actually able to use that incremental big chunk of credits. So I'm basically saying, take it slow. It's, kind of, like ordering a pizza, you're not gonna try to eat the pizza all in one sitting, right? So order a slice, order another slice, order another slice, and you'll actually get way more usage out of it. 

That way, if you do the incremental approach, you are not going to waste a bunch of credits. So, we do a lot of work with Amazon. Always happy to introduce you to them if you're a startup that's looking for credits, but, please, just be careful, and don't go for the $100,000 credits right away, unless you are absolutely positive you can use those credits. 

Hope that helps, if you have any questions hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks!

name: How Startups Should Maximize Amazon AWS Free Credits

snippet.title: What securities do VCs use to make their investments?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts

- The first one is convertible debt, and this is kind of like the oldest approach. Convertible debt comes in as debt, but it's really designed to convert into equity when there are larger rounds. So typically, this is angel and early stage VC funds are gonna invest in this. Sometimes there's a very small interest rate attached, maybe 2, 3% interest rate, and there's typically a term of something like 18 to 24 months at which point the convertible debt is due. However in practice, almost all investors roll that over if the startup needs more time, but it is debt, it does come out first if the company's ever liquidated or sold. And so it is something that investors do like to invest in, convertible debt. 

- SAFE notes are the next iteration of how VCs invest in startups. And this is something that was popularized by Y Combinator, and they wanted something that was a little more friendly than convertible notes. So SAFE notes, they are not technically debt, they are technically equity. However, there is a new movement, probably in the last year or two, where SAFE notes do have that priority repayment feature that's basically typical in convertible notes, meaning if there's liquidation, company gets sold, the SAFE notes do get paid out first. The SAFE notes typically do not have interest rates associated with it, so there's no compounding there. And typically they do not have a term, they just kind of run on and on and on until there's a conversion event. They do have that conversion cap. So that same example where I talked about like a $10 million valuation on the convert would be the same thing for the SAFE note and then when the Series A or a bigger round comes in, they will get to convert at that favorable valuation. So that's SAFE notes. 

- Some other important terms of preferred are some of the voting rights stuff. So sometimes, voting rights around acquisitions or around financial plans or venture debt or even management appointees is made either on a as-converted basis, meaning all the shareholders vote based on their total ownership percentage as if the shares were all converted to the common or sometimes it can be on a share class vote, meaning the Series A investors, they have to approve any initiative specifically between them. And typically what this kinda does is creates like almost like a blocking right for those investors. So the nightmare scenario for a VC is they invest in a company, and two weeks later the management team wants to sell the company. 

- Some other little things around preferred stock, even participating preferred, which means, which is pretty rare these days, but it used to happen where VCs would get their liquidation preference back, that 1X back, plus they would then get to participate in all the upside alongside the common. The typical structure of preferred equity is that you either get your liquidation preference back, or you have to convert into something like common and everyone shares in the proceeds. Now the final instrument VCs use to invest is highly structured preferred, and this is typically at the very late stage kinda unicorn-style companies, and it's typically used when late stage companies do not wanna do a valuation write down. So they, maybe they raise money at a $500 million valuation. They don't wanna go below that. They need to raise more money, so they create a highly-structured instrument that late stage investors can invest in. And what this typically is, is a much higher interest, almost like a dividend rate or an interest rate associated with that preferred, and it's gonna compound at a much higher rate.

name: What securities do VCs use to make their investments?

They were a startup bank, and then recently they were acquired by a much larger bank, so their balance sheet is much bigger, and they can do much bigger deals, more creative deals, and get in there where maybe they got priced out of or couldn't quite compete in the past. So they're much more aggressive now, great bank to work with. Now, like all other banks, some of the negatives with Square 1 is they typically use an investor abandonment clause or a MAC clause, something to mitigate their risk in a downsizing situation. So, if you're working with a bank, any bank really, but Square 1 does this, be careful of the MAC, be careful of the investor abandonment clause. On the positive side, banks like Square 1 typically have a low cost of capital, low warrant coverage, and they provide other services like your banking, housing your cash, things like that. They'll pay if you need it. So in summary, Square 1's a great venture debt partner. Laurie and Jeff are terrific to work with, and they offer the same typical bank value proposition, which is low cost to capital, but there's a little downside in that you got to be careful of the MAC and investor abandonment clause. Hope that helps. Thanks.

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm talking about why do startups need their revenue by state breakdown? Super important. Also important to the mental health of your CPA firm, because we need it to do your taxes properly. 

So, when you start getting to be bigger as a startup, the states want to start charging you sales tax. Also, the states that you're selling a lot in want to start having you file a state tax return. That is because you are, you have tax nexus in those states. Tax nexus is defined by having people, assets, property, or certain thresholds of revenue in a given state. And so, it's really important when we're filling out your tax returns, and doing it correctly, by the way, not everyone does this correctly, to get a breakdown of your revenue by state. And unfortunately, this is almost like we're trying to help you help us kind of video. 

A lot of startups don't track that, and it becomes a little messy, and it's hard for them, and it ends up delaying their tax returns, which creates a little stress for everybody, and also delays our ability to capture some of their R&D Tax Credits, and things like that because, filing tax returns later in the year, it's nice to get that money earlier, right? So, please use a CRM system, or an invoicing system that includes the addresses of your clients or customers. Super-duper important. Once you put a system like that in, I know we have that at Kruze. 

We use Salesforce, thank goodness for Salesforce. But there's Pipedrive, and a lot of invoicing systems like QuickBooks Invoicing. I think Stripe has some fields for this too. Bill.com has this. Once you have that info, especially if it's flowing into your general accounting system, like QuickBooks Online, makes it so much easier to mine this data, and for us to determine the states you have nexus in. You really want to be up to date on nexus. You don't want to have to go back when you're doing venture capital due diligence, and the diligence firm that the VCs have hired, or the VC associates and principals are asking you these questions, and you can't give them a revenue by state report to validate that you were in tax compliance. 

Because remember, when you go through VC diligence, and you sign on a dotted line, and take that money, you are making some pretty serious reps and warranties in the stock purchase agreement, and things like that. So just make sure that you have this. Again, if not, I've seen this many, many times, like hundreds of times, it's not for a lack of wanting to do it, it's for startups are constantly having to reprioritize stuff, and sometimes like a CRM system, or tracking this just gets deprioritized. 

But believe me, if you can get this in, in the early days of your company, it will make everything so much easier, especially on the tax side. It'll also help you with like regional territory stuff, commission stuff, so it's a benefit in a lot of different places across your company, but it does make taxes a heck of a lot easier. 

So hope that helps. If you have any other questions on this, or any other tax issues, hit us up at Kruze Consulting, your friendly CPA for startups, thanks!

snippet.title: How to Manage Accounting Complexities When You Have a Distributed Workforce
snippet.description:
How to Manage Accounting Complexities When You Have a Distributed Workforce

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

There's been a ton of opportunity, a ton of talent unlocked. People's lifestyles are a lot better, so I'm very pro distributed workforce and remote. So I just want to give some tips here. So the first thing is always set up a expense management expense tracking system. A lot of times now they're embedded in credit cards. 

So like Brex, Ramp, Expensify, Airbase. They all are really, really good, strong expense management tools. And they come with credit cards. So you can provision virtual credit cards to your employees. You can set low limits, so they don't abuse it or not that anyone would abuse it, but just you kind of limit the risk there. But getting those set up is really, really helpful to your accountant, to visibility in the organization, and making sure big expenses get approved and just keeping your accounting nice and easy. 

So they are working for Remote's entity and then your company, your startup will have a deal with Remote where you're paying them money every month. And you're not only just paying like the salary and the benefit costs of that person, but you're also paying Remote a fee. That's how Remote makes money. So a lot of this is becoming more popular because there's sometimes there's like an emotional pull for people in other countries. They want to be "an employee". There's something emotional about it, beneficial. And so Remote is making this easy to do. And it's very, it's very cost-effective so definitely check out Remote.com. 

The next thing is you really want to use a good accounting system. Now QuickBooks Online is our favorite and we've scaled that to even companies that are even doing over a hundred million dollars in revenue. We've got some tricks in our bag on the analytics portion of QuickBooks that make that possible, especially when kind of virtually consolidating a subsidiary. Eventually you will get to the point where you'll probably want to use something like NetSuite or Intacct for those foreign subsidiaries. If you're building out an actual foreign subsidiary in another country, if it's just people spread across the world, you actually won't really need to do that. But once you graduate and if you're, you know, hiring 10, 20 people in a given country, you're going to want to have a subsidiary. 

And you're going to want to consolidate that subsidiary and NetSuite becomes the choice there. But until then, which is usually, startups don't usually start doing that until they're like, you know, 60, 70, 100 people companies, you'll be using QuickBooks. And it's really, really powerful, easy to use and delivers good financials. If you are doing this in the United States, like your distributed workforce is across many, many states, the United States, like Kruze, you're really going to want to pay attention to state tax nexus. So tax nexus can be defined as having employees, people in a state, it can have property, assets. And the one that people kind of forget, it's relatively new is a certain threshold of sales or sales transactions. A lot of this was made possible by the, by the recent Wayfair decision by the Supreme court. 

Oftentimes we have people who've been working, you know, they got, you know, God bless them. They're trying to take some shortcuts and not working with a real CPA firm or someone who's knowledgeable at startups to do their taxes. And they don't realize they're triggering 5471s and 5472s and they come to us and we have to give them the bad news that they owe $40,000 to the IRS. These can be appealed, but only appealed for the first year. So really stay on top of this, use a good CPA firm, do your taxes. I mean, this is what we do. This is what we specialize in. And we see like these unfortunate stories all the time. So just, just choose your CPA wisely. 

And then the final thing, I would really recommend having a strong budget slash financial model and doing budget to actuals, especially if your people are just completely distributed throughout the world, because you have kind of smaller windows to communicate directly with them, not everyone's on the same time zone, corporate culture, and the expense tracking is really important, but you also just need to have, you know, someone who can have expectations on what you're going to spend money on. How much you're going to spend money on, and have that kind of alarm bell in the budget to actuals every month to see if you overspent or underspent.

name: How to Manage Accounting Complexities When You Have a Distributed Workforce
