This is something that kind of went away for a while but it's back, it's back with a vengeance and basically what this is, is think of it as like almost like debt in the form of equity that sits on top of the equity capital structure. So think of it as like senior preferred like the money that gets out first out of the preferred VC equity stack. And so the way this works is there's a lot of funds that are just dedicated to doing this or usually hedge funds that smell an opportunity. And there's a startup that's having trouble raising capital at like a clean, fresh valuation. Maybe because their previous round was at too high of a valuation given the market dynamics right now. So the NASDAQ's gone down a lot. The Bessemer Cloud Index has gone down a lot. 

There's a lot of companies sitting around with like valuations that are just too high relative to where the market is now but those companies might still need money. And so the hedge funds, or kind of structured players, see an opportunity to come in, give the company money, have a senior security. Granted it's senior in terms of equity, but that's a pretty strong position still. And what they do is they have a very heavy like dividend or cash pay component. So they're getting effectively, it's like synthetic interest or getting interest out of the company to compensate them. And then also sometimes there is a paid in kind. Which means like equity component. So the equity position actually continues to increase. So instead of maybe all cash dividends it could be half cash dividends and half paid in kind dividends in the form of extra equity in that senior preferred. 

So they're increasing their position as time goes which works well for them because it's compounding, right? It's actually like the total is getting bigger. Now the main feature and reason why a lot of startups not a lot, but some startups sign up for this is that it typically does not reset the valuation of the company. It's basically done at like the old valuation. It's just a different security. And this happens, this is attractive for numerous reasons. First of all, there's definitely like an ego component to this. Like being able to say you're a unicorn, a billion dollar valuation. It's very humbling and tough to to have to do a recap and bring that valuation down. 

Also, when you do a recap there's usually a pay to play provision which means like the funds that still have reserves left. We've done a video on VC fund reserves, can, you know, basically pay and continue to play and protect their ownership. Whereas some funds, especially like the early, early stage investors are probably running funds that have very little capital in it now, when it's a late stage investment because they probably made the investment like eight years ago or seven years ago. So they can only reserve so much capital. 

And sometimes those early stage funds have a hard time protecting their ownership position in a down round or pay to play situation. So oftentimes on the capital structure, the management team really has no ability to write another check. Really like the management team is not, unless they're super wealthy and had some big exits before, is not going to have the capital fire power that a VC fund has no matter what. So you have this weird dichotomy where the management team through ego and also wanting to avoid pay to play or downward rounds, and also early stage investors sometimes do not want. They want to take the highly structured term sheet. 

The later stage funds, they're fresher funds, they're usually like only a couple years old, and they could protect their own ownership position.

name: The Return Of Structured Venture Capital Term Sheet In The late Stage!

snippet.title: How is Accounting Debt - like Technical Debt
snippet.description:
How is Accounting Debt - like Technical Debt.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Accounting debt is you're moving so fast and maybe you're only focusing on technical aspects of your product or customers. You don't really think about your accounting infrastructure. And so, by just neglecting that, you're actually incurring accounting debt. It's a pretty interesting term. But the good news about accounting debt, I think it's actually even easier to avoid than technical debt. I'm just gonna give you a few steps here, so that you can avoid accounting debt. It'll save you a bunch of money, but more important for startup founders it's gonna save you a ton of time. Time is everything for startup founders. 

And so, if you follow these rules or guidance, you'll be able to avoid spending a ton of time on stuff you don't wanna do. So, the first thing you should do to avoid accounting debt is just get a corporate bank account. Our favorites are First Republic, SVB, Mercury, but getting a corporate account and putting money into that account, and then spending money only from that account, makes your accounting so much easier down the road. Now, if you don't have time to get a corporate account just get a corporate credit card. But you know, even that may be a little bit hard for you. So start documenting all the expenses, either through Expensify, or a spreadsheet. All the stuff you're putting on your personal credit cards, because you don't have time for that company credit card or company bank account, document it, we can go back later. It's super easy to fix later. If you don't document it. It takes us a lot of time. We're kind of comin' from a needle in haystack kinda stuff. 

So that's a great example of accounting debt. So, there's a couple of other ways you can save time and money by avoiding accounting debt. So, the next one is just please set up a payroll system if you're gonna start paying employees. There is nothing worse than when we have a founder who has just written a check to an employee, without taking payroll taxes out and submitting those payroll taxes. This is probably my least favorite form of accounting debt. If you set up on Rippling, or Gusto, or Justworks, Sequoia, TriNet, any of those systems, it will be really easy to pay the person, and we will not have to go back and wade through a bunch of IRS payroll tax, angry letters and penalties. So accounting debt, please, please just pay your employees via a payroll system. 

The next one is just do your taxes. And, you know, for companies that are just formed, sometimes that's as simple as just filing an extension and moving the deadline from April 15th to October 15th. But please do not neglect your taxes. And the other important thing about doing your taxes on time, and ideally, always filing an extension, is you can get that R&D tax credit, which is a rebate on your payroll taxes. There's nothing worse for us, it's kinda sad, when founders come back to us and they waited maybe a couple months before really engaging us. And in that meantime we found out that they used like an outsourced tax person or someone who's just not very good. And they filed the tax return without filing an extension and they didn't do the R&D tax credit. And oftentimes that's a 30 or $40,000 mistake. 

So talk about accounting debt, like a missing out on 30 or $40,000 in payroll tax rebates, that's a really, really big deal. Now my final recommendation is just set up a really simple QuickBooks online account. And all you gotta do is just connect your bank accounts into the bank feed in QuickBooks. It'll probably take you five minutes max. But what that does is it starts bringing in the transactions into QuickBooks and a professional accountant once they're engaged, or hopefully you engage Kruze, we can go in there and automate a lot of the recognition, like the classification and labeling of the vendor, all that stuff. 

But, if the transactions are already syncing, we don't have a lot problem, sometimes the banks only go back a certain number of months. So just getting that data flowing to QuickBooks can really be a big help. So I hope this helps. Accounting debt it's so similar to technical debt. And I think a lot of founders can really relate to this because they live technical debt every day in their life. But again, if you just take these four or five simple steps, you'll be able to avoid it.

name: How is Accounting Debt - like Technical Debt

snippet.title: Why VC backed Startups Don’t Usually do SBA Loans
snippet.description:
Why VC backed Startups Don’t Usually do SBA Loans

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about SBA loans and why startups typically don't do SBA loans. 

And SBA loans are mostly a traditional financing source for small businesses. So your mom and pops, your cashflow-positive businesses, maybe you're acquiring a small business, and you need to finance it with some debt, and so you use an SBA loan. SBA loans typically have a guaranteed portion for the lender by the US government, and have subsidized interest rates. So they're very friendly for cashflow-positive small businesses. But for venture capital-backed startups, those companies have a different risk-return profile for everyone involved. 

And typically, VC-backed companies can raise a lot of equity capital but the investors want big outcomes, and so those investors, and the founders, push the companies to grow fast, they're not really worried about being cashflow positive in the early years, for a long time really, and they have a high chance of actually just not working, and going out of business. And so if you're a founder of a VC-backed startup, you're already typically taking a way lower salary than you could if you were working in a big company, and to personally guarantee the loan, an SBA loan, on your company could be really, really dangerous. 

Again, you're not running it to be cashflow positive or to pay back a loan, you're running it for a big outcome and running it to hopefully raise another round of venture capital in 18 to 24 months. And so it's one of those things where, be careful. I would hate for you to ruin, you're already taking a beating, probably personally and financially if your company doesn't make it as a founder, and to lose like your life savings or something like that because you personally guarantee the loan would just be a heart breaker. 

And so that's why we tell people not to do that. There are other sources of capital, debt capital for venture-backed startups. It's called venture debt, venture lending. We have a ton of information on it at the Kruze website. But basically, there are a bunch of lenders out there who love VC-backed companies, who not only underwrite the value and enterprise value of a company but they take into account the VC backers, and their willingness to write another check if things get tough, their willingness to help sell the company and park it and get the debt back if things don't go well. So there's definitely debt capital out there for you if you're a VC-backed startup. I just would not recommend doing an SBA loan. 

Now, SBA loans are a little more popular these days in the startup community because a lot of the PPP loans from COVID were actually structured as SBA loans and administered through the SBA Administration, but the traditional personally guaranteed SBA loan that's like a five-year amortizing loan, I would highly recommend you don't do that unless you're very, very sure you can be cashflow positive or are cashflow positive, and even that, I probably wouldn't do it. I'd only do that if I was a small business owner or buying a small business from someone else. So hope that helps. 

Be careful with those SBA loans, be careful with personal guarantees on your credit card, on other types of loans. It's really hard to get. You just can't out of those once you make that personal guarantee. Hope that helps, if you have any questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks.

name: Why VC backed Startups Don’t Usually do SBA Loans

snippet.title: Which States are Taxing PPP Loan Forgiveness?
snippet.description:
Which States are Taxing PPP Loan Forgiveness?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm going over which states are taxing PPP loan forgiveness? 

So PPP has actually been pretty big in the startup space, especially for a lot of seed and Series A companies that haven't raised a lot of capital. For the later stage companies, the venture capitalists encourage their companies not to take PPP loans and I think correctly those companies had another way of funding themselves, they had big institutional backers and really the PPP program wasn't really set up for them. But for the seed stage companies and Series A companies, especially that raised a lot of capital, they kinda function like small businesses, like realistically they're small businesses. 

And so a lot of those companies actually employ a lot of people. And so the PPP helped those companies stabilize when COVID hit and allowed them not to have to fire a bunch of employees which really helped stabilize our economy. So I was a pretty big fan of the PPP program. And now we have a lot of companies are actually doing forgiveness. So you took the PPP loan, you submit then submit through your bank portal, a PPP forgiveness application, you select the time period you're using either eight weeks or 24 weeks, you punch in all the right numbers, you run some reports, you provide all your bank statements, and the SBA and the banks are working together really, really well and they're actually forgiving a lot of these loans. 

And so a lot of the companies, this has been a great program for them, but there's one thing that's kind of, you don't wanna be ungrateful, but some of the states are actually taxing the PPP loan forgiveness. So the federal government who actually gave the money out is not taxing them. So if you did $100,000 PPP loan, you are not gonna have to pay federal taxes on that $100,000 but if you're in some of the big startup states are actually taxing them, so like California, Washington, Texas, North Carolina, Florida, those states are all taxing on a state level, the PPP forgiveness. 

Now there's an interesting thing happening here where a lot of startups are losing money, and so they're not typically paying taxes like most startups don't pay taxes. You still have to file a tax return, but you're not paying taxes. So, if you lost enough money to also cover the gain you would have had on a state basis on the PPP then you're still not gonna have to pay tax on that. So in my example, of like $100,000 forgiven, federally you don't pay taxes and then say your company lost $500,000 and you have this $100,000 PPP, well, you still on a state level have a $400,000 loss after you'd net those two out. 

So you're gonna be okay and not have to pay taxes on that. But for companies that are profitable or operating right around breakeven, which a lot of companies do those are the ones that are gonna get hit by the state taxes. Now it's interesting, New York is actually not taxing PPP loans and Massachusetts is doing it kinda in a weird way where they're excluding it on a taxable basis for corporate taxes, but they are doing it on individual tax return income. 

So it's a little more complicated, and again, it's intersecting with people's personal tax returns, I think that's on the S-corp LLC front. But just be aware, I want everyone to know that, especially talk to your tax provider, it's important that they're capturing this the correct way. 

I know the IRS is working overtime to get the revised tax forms out and while the software providers that do, that handle, help folks like us at Kruze with our in-house tax team actually do the taxes, are adjusting their systems to be able to handle this, but just if you're in a big startup state, that's not Massachusetts or New York, odds are you're gonna have to pay taxes or on that gain of forgiveness. 

So hope that helps, thanks.

name: Which States are Taxing PPP Loan Forgiveness?

snippet.title: Airbase and SVB offer a new integrated expense management solution
snippet.description:
Airbase and SVB offer a new integrated expense management solution

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

I think it's helpful to kind of re-trace where the industry's come from and then kind of put this new announcement into context. Before I get into that, just know, Kruze, we're one of the, probably the leading startup accounting tax firm, we have relationships with a bunch of companies I'm going to cover in this. Silicon Valley Bank, Airbase, Brex, Ramp, Bill.com. We are like, we believe in the best tools for everyone and so, we search out the best tools for all of our startups and that has led us to all of these vendors so just know we do business with all these vendors, we have conflicts, we recommend them, but I think you can trust this is coming from a really good place and we're excited about this announcement because it's actually going to open up the startup credit card/expense management market even more. 

So, lets re-trace the history of the industry real fast. Silicon Valley Bank was the dominant bank in Silicon Valley tech startups. And they kind of, frankly, the credit card business for SVB was pretty big but I've kind of gone over this before. I think the bank got, was a little resting on it's laurels with not the greatest customer service, not the great technology and that really opened up the market for Brex to come in. 

And that was about four years ago. Brex came in with a better option for startups. They didn't have personal guarantees, way better technology integration, amped up the customer support. And that was a big deal and Brex has pretty high market share in credit cards. Now, the cool thing for SVB is they actually saw what was happening and had a very strong response. They actually came out with the SVB Innovator's Card which mirrored the best features of the Brex card so no personal guarantee, they really made the perks or, you know, your points, all that kind of stuff a lot better. 

From our end as accountants they made the interface and integrations with Quickbooks and other tools so much better and they finally made customer support much better. So SVB responded, started to retake the market share. Then came along Ramp and Divvy. Who are both card-centric but expense management tools as well and in the last like, kind of year we've seen Ramp do a major push into this market and is getting a lot of market share. And, Bill.com acquired Divvy, so we had typically referred Bill.com as a bill pay solution. It was actually, Bill.com came around, what, nine, ten years ago, I think it's a $26 billion valuation company now public. Check my podcast, I interviewed Renee, like five years ago, the founder and CEO and they acquired Divvy because they saw where this market was going. 

The market is really going to an integrated approach. Cards plus expense management. And for those who don't know, you know, people think of cards as the dumb kind of Chase, Amex card that you might have or legacy had. But really, Brex, SVB's Innovator Card, Ramp, Airbase's capabilities, Divvy. They all let you do a lot more dynamic provisioning, dynamic changing of limits. It's just so much easier for everybody, it's better integration into Quickbooks which makes your accountant happy because it makes us more efficient. So this has been a really big leap in the category in the last two or three years. And one of the coolest things about the Airbase/SVB partnership is SVB had one of the leading cards but didn't quite have just as much integration as many of those tools I just noted as some of the other players. 

But now, by integrating into Airbase they get best in class expense management tools. It's really, really big, and again, it may not seem like a big thing but if you can automatically provision or just decide to provision virtually a credit card for employee, you tend to use expense management software, like build Expesify expense reports much less. The employees have a much greater sense of freedom. They can actually make purchases with a very simple approval flow or they have a lower limit, you know they're not going to abuse it and so they can just make that purchase without having to bug someone and waste someone else's time. 

So, if you're a startup your life just got a little bit easier. And if you're an accountant your life got a lot easier with this partnership and integration between Airbase and SVB, so congrats to the firms, I think there'll be a lot more going on in this market as we go forward and I'll keep doing videos to explain all the changes that happen but congrats, congrats to the players, congrats to all the startups out there and congrats to us, your friendly CPA, who just saved a lot of time because of that integration. Thanks.

name: Airbase and SVB offer a new integrated expense management solution

snippet.title: How Do I Get in Touch with Angel or Seed Funds
snippet.description:
How Do I Get in Touch with Angel or Seed Funds

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

1- First, you know, it's helpful to just think through, like most angels are high net worth individuals, like they've made money somewhere. They've had some success, and that's why they're investing in startups. Seed funds are typically like actual institutional venture capital funds, professional money managers, who look at startups all day long. 

So it's always best to go through those channels if you can, and really when you're looking to get in touch with angels and seed funds, getting introductions is really, really helpful. It really kinda cuts through the red tape. The mental overhead of whether the investor wants to meet with you or not, it's easier for them to decide. So, I would go with intros and through people you know, if possible. Now, there's a lot of people, especially outside like the Bay Area and New York and maybe Santa Monica, who are creating really cool startups these days, but don't have that direct connection to, you know, the sexy angel investors or the seed funds, and so this is where networking or cold emailing can really help you out. 

And sometimes, you know, investors, you'll see them joking that they don't answer cold emails, but they do. There's a lot of investors who will actually answer cold emails, so if you can't get that intro, don't give up. So what should your cold email say? First of all, it's got to be upbeat. It's gotta be really tight, and you don't wanna send 'em like "War and Peace," like a whole volume of text. You wanna keep it short and to the point. The first couple sentences, they really should be a short explanation of what the company's doing and why it's important and the potential. So maybe like three sentences, and I'm not joking here about keeping it short. Investors tend to have a short attention span. You're a guest in their email box. You wanna keep it short and powerful. The next thing you wanna do is express the traction and progress you've made. 

Now this could be building a product and getting it into the app store, or getting it on the web, or getting people to use it, maybe it's revenue traction, maybe you're Ramen profitable, and you're actually breaking even already, but some type of signal that people like what you're doing, that you have some traction, and they should take it seriously. Now, another thing I like to include is some type of link, or a presentation, or a one pager attached to the email that way, when they wanna learn more, they can click that and quickly skim through it. Investors look at tons of presentations and one pagers, they're very, very good at doing that efficiently, so absolutely include that. Another thing you wanna include is just the dollar ask and the dollar size of the round. Very simple, we're raising $2,000,000, and I'd love it if you'd be interested in putting in $100,000, or I'd love it if you'd be interested in leading the round. 

Some type of signal, so they know how much you're looking for, and maybe you can also include how much is already committed, and so they're just kinda feeling, like you're raising 2,000,000, but 1.5's already committed. You're hoping they can fill in the rest of that round. So those are the really, really important things. You also wanna personalize it for them, make it, you know, in some way, whether it's a distant connection, or you saw them write a great article, or you just know they ran a business that was kinda the first generation of what you're building, some personalization and saying why it's important for you to get them to invest. You want their expertise is another thing I'd always include. So again, you know, to wrap it up, it's always better to get an intro, especially if you just know an angel or seed fund or some of your colleagues or friends do, but if you have to, you can use the cold email format that I just gave you. 

And, you know, as I'm recording this, another thing just popped in my head, which is lawyers and accountants like Kruze can be an excellent conduit to angels and seed funds. Like we work with 'em all day long, we know who the good ones are. We know who might be interested in your market or what you're building, and so also look to your lawyer and accountant for intros. They're not gonna like get your company funded for you, but they can make a few intros to help you out. So, I hope that helps. Good luck, happy hunting on the investor front, and looking forward to seeing what you're building. If you have questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com.

name: How Do I Get in Touch with Angel or Seed Funds

snippet.title: How Startups are Financed
snippet.description:
How Startups are Financed

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Startups are kind of unique to like your traditional small business in that, they tend to be technology-based whether it's like biotech, or medtech, or software, or hardware. And that technology base tends to require some capital investment. And so, this video is for eventually venture backed startups. It's very possible to be a bootstrap company in the technology world. I mean Kruze is a bootstrap company in the technology world. So we're doing it. But a lot of companies will end up raising capital instead of bootstrapping their selves. 

Usually the first stage is some combination of bootstrapping and or friends and family rounds. And so this is when you're first getting the idea working and it may just be you doing the startup. Maybe you have a co-founder maybe there's a couple people on the team. But at that stage if you can find a paying customer or a couple of paying customers, you can bootstrap it for a little while. And basically bootstrapping just means like you're taking the money that your customers give you. And you're living off that. That's what funds payroll. You're probably not taking much payroll. I mean, I remember in the early days of Kruze Consulting Vanessa and I were getting paid $25,000 a year, for a couple of years, that was extremely painful. Bootstrapping is very, very hard. So the natural next step to bootstrapping is to do a friends and family round. 

And friends and family are really investing in you because they support you. They love you. They care about you. They think what you're doing is probably cool but they're not like expert investors. So I always like to remind founders to, try to give them a good deal. Sometimes founders get caught up in dilution and thinking that like, they've got to maximize everything. 

Angel investors are typically people who've done very well in their career maybe professional angel investors at this point AngelList has made doing angel funds, seed funds, really, really easy. And so they're more professional. They're really good at underwriting the potential of the market, the potential of the company, where this could go, maybe competitors. And so they are typically willing to pay up a little bit more than friends and family. 

And one thing that's really important to think about as soon as you take friends and family money and angel money you're basically signing up for, to go long, to do like the whole startup journey. No one really wants to invest in a friends and family or an angel round, to have the company get sold for like $5 million or $10 million. All of those investors, especially like the professional angels are looking at you and saying like, okay, 12 months from now, after you build something of value with the capital I'm giving you. 

So pre-seed and seed is the next step. And those are typically anywhere from 10 to $50 million institutional funds.  

As soon as they cross that $20 million fund amount they start participating at something like 20 to 30% of the profits.

A pre-seed might be $500K to a million dollars whatever it is typically the lead investor of that seed or pre-seed fund will sign up for half to two-thirds maybe three quarters of that amount. 

The series A funds are really helping. The bar is really high. Like you need to have locked in financials. You need to have, a locked in roadmap for product development. You have to have clear expectations of when you're gonna get customers and they will hold you accountable. You'll typically raise, 18 months of cash, maybe 24 months. 

Series B investors typically follow very quickly the series A investors. I always joke that series A investors have, the speed dial. Like if you have Vinod Khosla on your board he's got five series B investors who are dying to invest in all of his companies. And so they can make raising that next round a lot easier by using their network.  

And series C is really kind of a make or break it moment for most startups. You've got some traction because you wouldn't have been able to get a series B without it but now you need to really be scaling and building something super exciting to attract capital. Series C investors, they're investing in preferred, too, are going to be super financially oriented. They're gonna start thinking about time to exit, IPO. 

Finally series D, series F, these are super financially driven investors. They're gonna look at your customer acquisition cost, your LTV, and say if I give this company a dollar they're gonna turn it into five. This is the kind of company I wanna invest in. And I think I can do an IPO in a year or two years, or maybe there's a buyout in a year or two years.

name: How Startups are Financed

snippet.title: Startup Corporate Culture: Top 3 Negatives that Employees Feel About their Managers
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health/

The first thing that employees typically think about their bosses is that they don't communicate clear expectations. This is one of the largest complaints. At Kruze, we have seven core values. We talk about it on every all hands meetings, and we also go over the core values in every single one-on-one. So talking and reinforcing core values really brings clarity to the relationship, and it also helps employees help each other. Like, you can police the organization and make sure that everyone's doing the right things just by sticking to the core values. So, that's the first one. 

The second one is, employees think their bosses play favorites. Now, this is also another common thing. And so at Kruze, we do some other things to make sure there's a very even playing field. My first, and this kinda dates back to when we had an actual physical office with a very large boardroom table in our office, and then we had seats around the boardroom table. And so, we used to make a very strong attempt to encourage junior people, and especially women and minority folks, to sit at the table. There's something very symbolic about sitting at the table, getting comfortable there, and having your voice heard. And when people see you sitting at the boardroom table, they know that your voice is important, and so that's one way to mitigate playing favorites, to rotate that, to get everyone comfortable sitting at the table. 

The third item that a lot of employees complained about their employer about was that there was no clear development plan for their career. And so, this is something that we've taken a lot of effort and invested a lot of time into at Kruze, and so one of the ways we do a development plan is that every written review cycle has a section for the development plan, and the near-term goals and long-term goals for our employees. So, it's very important to write this out, because everyone can come back and reference it. Sometimes when you just do this verbally, and I've made this mistake myself, people kinda forget, it's not concrete, they don't know exactly what they need to do, so written improvement plans are very, very helpful. Also, a career progression presentation is very, very helpful. One of the things we do is we actually list out the different goals and skills you need to have to progress to certain positions in our company, this is really helpful. 

It's a lot of work, it takes a lot of energy from the folks that are running the company, but there's so much more productivity, people enjoy working at your company so much more, and they just improve and become more powerful so much faster, it's really worth the investment. I hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Startup Corporate Culture: Top 3 Negatives that Employees Feel About their Managers

snippet.title: For a seed round, are many investors or a small group better?
snippet.description:
For a seed round, are many investors or a small group better?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

My professional opinion is it depends. It's actually really the founder's choice. There's positives and negatives with both. So let's kind of roll through it. So first of all, the bottom line when you're doing a startup and you're backed by investors is, you've got to raise the money somehow, someway. So this question is more for people who have the choice really. If you don't have the choice, do not worry, there's so many legendary stories. I think Jeff Bezos had to meet with 100 venture capitalists before he got the first check for Amazon. Like stuff like that happens all the time. It is not really correlated to the success of your company. 

So don't get discouraged. If you're in the position where you've just got to raise money somehow, someway, then do both. Raise it from as many small people, and as many big people who will give you money. Now, if you do have the choice, there's a couple things that you're going to want to kind of factor in. First of all, it is easier to manage usually fewer investors. And so people kind of refer to that as your cap table, your ownership table. 

And so having a couple big ones is actually pretty nice. And once you get them over the hump and they're committed in investing in the company, then it's a lot easier. Your work's kind of done. The only negatives with that are you are really beholden to that person. The people who invested, the few people who invest in their company, especially if they're funds, they've got a lot of control. What they think really matters. There's going to be a lot of oversight. 

When you go to raise your next round of funding, a lot of people are going to actually ask about it. Ask that investor who previously invested what they think. So you've got to really keep that person happy. You need to do good reporting. You need to respect what they think about the business and take their advice. But they will write you a big check. You can get the fundraising over quickly, and especially if they're a well-regarded fund, you can often use the term sheet they sign to fill in behind them with a lot of individual investors. 

And so the mechanism for that is like, this happens with seed a lot, where a seed fund will say hey, I'm going to take $1.5 million of a $3 million seed round, which means there's another $1.5 million available to be invested but the founders' got to fill that up. And so the founders can go around to the angel networks or maybe like another seed fund that people like and say, "Hey, X, Y and Z Ventures is already committed, and they've already done the diligence and here's the term sheet they signed. Would you like to participate and piggy back on all the diligence, and really kind of buy into the opinion they have that this is going to be a big company?" And it's really effective, especially at seed stage. Seed stage, there's not a lot of traction to judge whether the company's going to be successful or not. 

A lot of it is how good is the idea, what's the vibe from the entrepreneurs? Do they have a track record of making companies successful? And so getting that stamp of approval from a bigger fund who's going to take a big portion of the investment round is really, really helpful. So that's the argument for taking money from at least a couple big investors and using them to kind of help fill out the round. If you want to go full on lots of little investors, I've seen a lot of companies do this very, very successfully at the early stage and really, they're going to friends and family, they're going to people they went to business school with or people they worked with at a prior company. And you can get a lot of 25, 50, 100K checks, depending on how successful the people in your network are. And fill up a round very quickly, and those people will often be true believers and will actually, you have kind of like the crowdfunding effect where they will spread the word and tell other people about your business. And so you get a little bit of a marketing pop out of this, which is great. 

Now, you can get a marketing pop from the couple big investors because the funds that do these investments have usually a PR team, they'll help you get press for it, they have a brand name, but the kind of quote, unquote crowdfunding approach of a lot of little investors can be just as powerful. There's a lot of voices out there talking about your company and promoting it. And especially if they're users of what you're doing because hey, those people have put their money where their mouth is. And they believe.

name: For a seed round, are many investors or a small group better?

snippet.title: How to Handle Petty Cash at Your Startup?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn "How to Handle Petty Cash at Your Startup."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xM8CIroeixE
