Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

#handlepettycash #howtohandlepettycash #kruzeconsulting

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, "How do I handle petty cash in my startup?" 

And for those who don't know, petty cash is basically a term for cash kind of lying around that is used for very small purchases. So for example, maybe pay for parking, tip a parking valet or a restaurant, something like that. And my basic advice is actually, try not to do petty cash or use petty cash at your startup. The amazing thing in the age we live in right now is that there's so many credit card options, and it's very easy to just create virtual credit cards or credit cards with dynamic limits for employees. In the old days, petty cash was used a lot more often. But nowadays, everyone on your team, including you, the founder, can have a credit card. And the reason why I'm so against petty cash is it's kind of like an accounting weakness for a couple reasons. A) people tend to not get receipts for that kinda of stuff and $300 just kind of disappears every month or something like that, right? 

And when you add that up, it's not a huge material amount of money, but it's just not doing things the right way. And there could be like a serial abuser, someone on the team who just decides to, they dip in and take a hundred bucks every month or something like that. So that's an accounting weakness. The IRS requires you to have receipts for anything over $75, so you just don't want that little accounting weakness. Secondly, it can send a really bad message to the team that cash is fungible, the company's money is fungible. It's our money, not the company's money. And you got to remember as a founder, you're a fiduciary. 

So you are responsible at a higher level than you might realize with what happens with the company's money. And we've seen times over the years where all of a sudden an office manager is paying their own credit card with the company's money. Or the founder's staying in lavish hotels and buying a lot of clothing or other kind of things. And petty cash is one of those things that can start you down that slippery slope. It's almost like a gateway drug to poor financial controls and usage. And so again, in this day and age, you can just use a credit card, give everyone a virtual one or get everyone a regular credit card, have a dynamic limit, low limits for employees. And it's also easy for your accountant to review that and see what those credit card charges are being paid for. That will protect you. 

And again, it just kind of instills a greater level of responsibility, process, controls in the company. So not a fan of petty cash. I've seen a few founders over the years abuse it. Don't go there, stay away. Use virtual credit cards. It's so much easier for everybody. I hope that helps. If you have any other questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks.

name: How to Handle Petty Cash at Your Startup?

snippet.title: Can your Startup Change its Accounting Method for PPP 2 Loan eligibility?
snippet.description:
Can your Startup Change its Accounting Method for PPP 2 Loan eligibility?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, can my startup change its accounting treatment to be eligible for PPP2 loans? 

And the background on this is when PPP2 came out, there's a clause there that says if you're a startup, if your company had a 25% reduction in gross receipts, AKA revenue, in any quarter in 2020 versus 2019, then you would be eligible for a second PPP loan. And so basically, say you had a great year in 2019 but then COVID really hurt your company in 2020 and one of your quarters you were down more than 25%, then hey, you get a second bite of the apple. 

There's another PPP loan that you can get, which is a pretty substantial amount of money. It's about 2.5 times your average monthly salaries in 2020. So there's a lot of money at stake here and so I've had a couple of founders ask me this question of like hey, we're on accrual method, which is how startups should be, what the accounting method, meaning you basically, all your revenue and costs are booked when incurred, or excuse me, when the services are provided or when the expenses are actually incurred versus cash accounting when you actually pay for those things or collect the revenue. Startups should be on accrual, that's GAAP based, that's what VCs want, that's what M&A acquirers want. It also just makes running your business a lot easier 'cause you're actually gonna see what's going on all the time. 

But a few folks have been like, hey, why don't we change our accounting treatment to cash and then it will show a more than 25% reduction. We'll be eligible for PPP2, a second bite of the apple. And so you really don't wanna mess around with this. The IRS actually has, the IRS and SBA I believe, SBA's administering all the PPP loans, have guidance out saying explicitly to not do this. Do not pick and choose or flip around for purposes of getting a second bite of the apple, a second PPP loan. It's unethical and it's against the regulations or against their guidance. So if you do that, you are setting yourself up for a very painful audit and potentially some embarrassing press. So please, don't do that. 

I know none of the Kruze clients will do that because we'll help educate them if they were even leaning towards doing that. But if you're working with another accounting firm and maybe they are not on the up and up or whatever it is, just don't do it. Don't take that chance. You're expressly violating what the IRS and SBA have prescribed on this. Don't around mess with your revenue recognition or flipping to cash accounting if you're just trying to stretch and get this loan. 

I know it's a lot of money, I know it's tempting probably but it's not best practice and you don't wanna run afoul of the IRS and SBA. So hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Can your Startup Change its Accounting Method for PPP 2 Loan eligibility?

snippet.title: Why do Big Acquirers like to buy Small Startups via Asset Sale instead of an Equity Purchase?
snippet.description:
Why do Big Acquirers like to buy Small Startups via Asset Sale instead of an Equity Purchase?

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question why do big companies like to buy smaller startups in an asset sale versus an equity purchase? 

And it's really pretty simple actually. The big companies are always super nervous about buying a company in an equity purchase meaning they bought all the equity and complete ownership of the company and unintentionally assuming a bunch of liabilities they don't know about. And so the classic examples of this are maybe there is a lease that was never disclosed to the acquirer and the acquirer's on the hook for a couple hundred thousand dollars a year for another five years. Or there's a huge sexual harassment suit that's brewing or is being filed that wasn't disclosed. Or, this doesn't happen in startups very often but like toxic waste on the startup premises. You know, things like this, these are all very, very expensive issues and the big company is really just trying to buy the startup for their technology and for their team and for their brand and the customer relationships. 

And they don't want any of these unintended liabilities that can really come back and bite them in the butt later. And so the big companies doing the right thing for them by buying the company in an asset sale. Because an asset sale you're just buying the assets, you're not assuming all the liabilities of a company. And that's why it's typically structured like this. Now a lot of startups say like, "Hey, how much leverage do I have or can I push this to an equity sale?" And the reality in an acquisition is you only have so much leverage. 

So if this company really wants to buy you and it's reflected in the purchase price, then yes, you can push for an equity sale. But if it's a 10 million, 5 million, $20 million purchase it's kind of signaling that you don't have a ton of leverage or else the purchase price will be higher, right? And so oftentimes you don't have enough leverage to push it into an equity sale instead of an asset sale. But that's not such a bad thing, like, I don't think it's that big of a deal for founders. You're gonna basically just have this entity that you started, corporate entity, that's gonna keep living and you'll probably keep it living until all the earn-out payments are actually made and then you'll shut it down and do all the distributions. 

But practically speaking it's not really gonna impact your tax basis or anything like that, so it's not that big a deal. I always recommend to founders that oftentimes when you're negotiating you can only pick a couple things you really want to negotiate. And so I always recommend to founders like, Hey, focus on the purchase price that's what really matters. The asset versus equity purchase isn't gonna really change your life that much but getting another $5 million or another $10 million of purchase price, that can help change your life. 

So focus on that and again, this is why asset sales are done with big companies and small companies. As the two, in a merger of equals or a really big acquisition maybe a 100, $200 million, $500 million acquisition, they're gonna do typically an equity purchase. Because there's just a lot of like other stuff that is beneficial for them, but for the little ones for the little acquisitions, they're gonna wanna stick to an asset purchase. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Why do Big Acquirers like to buy Small Startups via Asset Sale instead of an Equity Purchase?

snippet.title: Where do VC’s get their money?
snippet.description:
Where do VC’s get their money?

Raising venture capital? Get the finance and accounting due diligence checklist: https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-capital-finance-tax-hr-due-diligence-checklist

A lot of VC firms, especially the new ones, are always out pounding the pavement, taking meetings, pitching their fund. Very, very similar to an entrepreneur's life who's raising money. I thought I'd just kinda go through where the VCs get their capital. So, the first one is endowments, and it's one of the biggest ones. And so, this is typically the big private universities, although public university systems, like the University of California system, have a big endowment, as well. They are a major player, so Yale, Harvard, MIT, Stanford, Northwestern, those are some of the biggest endowments out there. 

Again, the University of California system is very large, as well. And in the same way that entrepreneurs are hoping to get the top VC on their board, well, guess what, funds are trying to get the top endowments on their board and to lead a fund. 

The next one is also huge, which is pension funds. Pension funds go anywhere from California teacher's pension to the big state pension funds. UTIMCO is one, the Texas pension fund is a really, really big one that's active in venture capital. And then, all the way down to local pension funds, like local police and fire departments. They actually have pension funds. They utilize consultants, so there's a whole industry out there of consulting firms that benchmark, track, and evaluate venture capital funds against each other and make recommendations, especially to the pension funds 'cause a lot of times, especially the local ones, they don't have enough money under management and the funds to hire a bunch of full time people who are evaluating all the VC funds. And also, that's kind of a full time job. It's one of those things where everyone benefits from a research group that can canvass the whole industry. 

And it's a similar asset allocation to the pension funds and endowments, but again, there's very, very large foundations that you can go and call on and raise money for a VC. And again, family offices, some people would say this is a different subset, some say this kinda mirrors or is a portion of the foundations, but family offices are generally very, very wealthy people, but it might be, wealthy is all in the eye of the beholder, it might be someone who has $100 million family office or a 200, $500 million family office. They're gonna make a lot smaller venture capital direct checks than someone who has a foundation that's $10 billion or $20 billion. Again, in the same way that the pension funds have different sizes, the same thing is happening in the family office and foundation world. And then the final group, the fifth group, would be high net worth individuals. These are people who've made some money, they're professionals. 

Typically, a lot of high net worth people that invest in venture capital funds are people in the tech industries who've made some money and oftentimes, entrepreneurs who've been backed by the very fund they're investing in. That was one of our things at Lighthouse. We had a lot of entrepreneurs who we had actually worked with who wanted to invest in our fund because they knew the value prop, they knew we knew what we were doing, and they had taken that dilutive capital from the venture capitalists, and so, they wanted to get on the other side of that and benefit from that. High net worth is typically, when you're starting out a new fund, that's usually where you first start. You're raising money from high net worth people, 50K, 100K, $250,000 at a time, maybe even $1 million, and then you slowly crawl up into the foundations, endowments, pension funds, and family offices. Those are the big four. But a lot of venture capital funds start out with high net worth individuals. 

Again, the reason why folks like to move upstream into the bigger checks, into the foundations, endowments, and pension funds, is because of the bigger checks and because of that brand, because of that reputation, and because of that kind of quiet, implicit promise that they'll invest in multiple funds. I hope this helps. It's really helpful to know, actually, where your venture capitalists get their money. The pressures they have, the need for them to perform when they are sweating you in the board meeting, hey, it's because they need your company to work out so they can return an exit or a good amount of capital to their investors and they can raise another fund. 

We're all in business here. Hope that helps, thanks, bye.

name: Where do VC’s get their money?

snippet.title: Accounting for startup financing from Pipe
snippet.description:
Accounting for startup financing from Pipe

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're answering the question how do you account for a loan from Pipe? 

And for those that don't know, Pipe.com is a new lending marketplace that allows companies with reoccurring revenue streams to actually, basically, generate cash or capital upfront by factoring or trading their future payment stream. But the interesting thing about this is factoring invoices has been around forever. That's what banks do really, really well. You have a customer, you provide a service for them, you invoice them, you're going to get your cash in 30 days, but instead, the bank will actually give you 96 cents on the dollar and then collect the money from the customer directly. That is factoring receivables. 

What's cool about Pipe is you don't even have to have a receivable. You are factoring payment streams that you probably haven't even invoiced yet way out in the future. But the investors who are on the Pipe platform who are basically buying these future payment streams don't require a pure invoice like the bank would. So super interesting financing innovation. Really, really good for reoccurring revenue businesses like SaaS companies. It's really nice. It's a great innovation, we're super excited about them, we're sending clients over to Pipe. 

And one of the things I like about the marketplace side of this with the investors who are buying the payment streams is they compete. You are actually going to get a better cost of capital than if you just go out to one or two investors and take whatever they give you. The investors are competing on the other side of the marketplace, which means your cost of capital or effective interest rate is actually being driven down by the marketplace, by competition. So super duper exciting there. Now how to treat this on an accounting basis. 

Well, the first part of it, you get a deposit from Pipe and that is going to debit your cash, meaning your cash is going to go up and you're also going to credit a short-term liability. It's kind of like short-term debt, right? You have a liability to the investor who bought your payment stream and you're going to pay them on a monthly basis. Now, the payments that go out are going to go against that short-term liability. So you're going to credit cash, meaning cash is going to go down for that payment amount every month and you're going to debit the short-term liability accounts on the liability side of the balance sheet. So hopefully for all you accountants out there, you're understanding this. But basically with every monthly payment, cash goes down and short-term liability account, the debt you owe, is going to go down, too. 

Now, there's a little twist here in that a portion of that monthly payment you're making is actually embedded interest because the investors bought it at a discount, so there's an effective interest component up to this. And so Pipe actually has thought of this and they have a really nice little report inside their marketplace that shows you the discount or component of interest. And so your accountant can split that payment amount up and book a portion of it as interest and the rest of it as the short-term liability, which means your debt balance is actually going to decrease. So there's lot going on here, but basically it's important to recognize that there is an interest component, an embedded interest component that you're paying when you use Pipe to bring cash forward and sell off your future payment stream. So I hope that helps. It's a really great tool. 

We're seeing people use it and hopefully we'll have more content on Pipe coming up. If you have any questions on this or venture debt, just hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, thanks.

name: Accounting for startup financing from Pipe

snippet.title: Who is the highest paid person at a startup?
snippet.description:
Who is the highest paid person at a startup?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Most people would think the founder or CEO, but she is usually not the highest paid person at the startup. It is usually, drum roll, one of two people, the VP of sales or the CTO. And when you kind of think about it, there's actually some good reasons for that. First of all, salespeople are notoriously and beneficially motivated by money in those ways, it's a little bit more, it's not that they're greedy people. It's more of a, I think psychologically like a score-keeping thing for salespeople. They really love achievement, they really love closing deals, they like to keep score through that, and so oftentimes VP of sales are the highest paid people at a startup because they bring in the money, eventually. 

But they are not heavy base salary people. In fact, they usually have some of the lowest base salaries in the whole company. And the reason for that is the company's incentive structure wants them to be very, very focused on bringing in new sales and not just kind of showing up to work and putting their feet on the desk. 

But I always remind them that the sales team and the VP of sales are directly aligned with the sales goals of the company, with where the company needs to go, so it's an investment and it's well worth it. The second person who might be the highest paid person at a startup would be the CTO, founding engineer, VP of engineering, someone who is very irreplaceable on the technology side and because we're working with startups so maybe at like a mom and pop small business or something not in the tech or biotech, med tech world, this could be different, like a service company, but for a technology startup, the CTO is just one of the most important people in the company. It's also really hard to find a good CTO/VP of engineering/founding engineer. 

But they're going to own, she's going to own 20 to 50% of the company. If there's two co-founders, obviously, it's probably going to be more like the 40% kind of zone, something like that. But the founders are going to have tremendous upside, but that's usually the bargain they make. They want that upside. They're willing to forgo the big salaries. Oftentimes founders could be working at Netflix, Google, Facebook, wherever, making huge salaries, but they've chosen the path of building their dream and try and change the world and getting that big equity upside. 

And the other thing, I just kind of put a quick plug in here for equal pay for, across genders, across races. We've done a lot of studies on women founders, women CEO pay, and how when COVID hit, it was interesting, women CEOs actually reduced their salaries dramatically relative to male CEOs. And we're not exactly sure why. We're not sure if it's, maybe some of those companies, just the CEOs were more tied into their companies emotionally and just really wanted to make sure the company would survive or maybe they hadn't raised as much money or maybe they're just more conscientious people. I don't know. 

A lot of the women in my life are more conscientious than me, so I think that's a very, very high possibility. But for whatever reason, we saw some real bifurcations in pay for CEOs, startups, across gender. And unfortunately we don't have enough data on pay across races or ethnicities, but that's something that we should all pay attention to. So if you're a venture capitalist and watching this video, do a pay study. You can get the data from your portfolio companies. Really, really easy. Benchmark where people are and if people are underpaid and they just happen to be not a white male and happen to be a woman or a different ethnicity, then get them up to average, at least, if not more. 

But I think only a little bit of diligence, a little bit of work on this will translate to equal pay across genders and ethnicities and I really encourage the venture capital community to take this on, do the work. You have the data or contact your friendly CPA firm, Kruze Consulting, and we'll get it for you. But let's make that change there and make the world a little bit better place for all the folks who are starting companies, no matter what their race and gender are. And just remember, bringing it all the way around, it's okay to pay your VP of sales a lot of money. It's okay to pay your sales team a lot of money. 

It's okay to pay your engineering team a lot of money. Those people have very specific skillsets, they are critical to your startup's success, and I know it may kind of tweak you a little bit or bother you a little bit on the inside, but it's an investment and it's an investment well-made. So hope that helps. Hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com if you have any questions or comments. We're here to help you, thanks.

name: Who is the highest paid person at a startup?

snippet.title: What the Plaid acquisition by Visa means for startup bookkeepers
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today, we're talking about what the Plaid acquisition by Visa means for startup bookkeepers. And at Kruze, we've been using Plaid for a while and we love it. One of the best things about it is it gives us really clean data from the banks. Sometimes when bank feeds come into Quickbooks, it's a little messy and it's hard to automate the generation of statements. Well, guess what? Plaid does all of that for us. Now, we still use the bank feed and Quickbooks because it's super important that all the transactions and Quickbooks are matched to bank transactions. That's called like a true reconciliation. You don't want anything, not match the cash.
But being able to automate the generation of statements is a huge time saver for us, and we can even do it mid-month. instead of waiting till the first of every month to get the statement. That allows us to do a cash reconciliation mid-month and limit the work towards the end of the month. That means our clients get their financials a lot faster. This is huge for the startup clients that are monitoring burn, need to give their V.C.'s the report on what the burn rate and the revenue was for the month before. So Plaid's been huge for Kruze Consulting, and with the acquisition of Visa, I think it's gonna get better. Visa's gonna be able to dedicate a lot more resources to Plaid. For instance, right now we can't get check images from Plaid. They know about it. We know about it. We ask them about it every month. That's the kind of thing that Visa will be able to spend money on and give us the actual check images so we know who the checks are written out to. So we can account for it properly instead of having to log into the pesky bank account. So plaid, I think is going to go to the moon here. It's a huge acquisition. It's a great acquisition by Visa and it's really going to help all the startup bookkeepers out there in the ecosystem. Thanks.

name: What the Plaid acquisition by Visa means for startup bookkeepers

snippet.title: Tough Times are a Good Reminder to Pick your VC’s Thoughtfully
snippet.description:
Tough Times are a Good Reminder to Pick your VC’s Thoughtfully

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about how tough times are a good reminder to pick your venture capitalists carefully. 

And I think especially over the last year, it's been just a ferocious capital market. Startups have been getting term sheets thrown at them. They've been getting preempted, valuations have gone crazy in a good way for a lot of founders. And now, I'm recording this in late May 2022, like the market's changing. The stock market's down, private valuations are coming down, market's getting a lot tougher. So a lot of people are looking back and saying like, "Hey, maybe I should have been a little more thoughtful in those decisions I made". And we all can do that in life, but what's happening is sometimes working through your existing investors and getting them to make a second commitment can be really, really tough. 

And, you know, there's been times in the past, where some people have been taking money from like hedge funds or nontraditional VCs, and it's really difficult to know how they act in tough times. So everyone's kind of finding out. Also those folks, the hedge funds and institutional investors that normally don't play in venture, are also finding out a lot about the founders they back. So it's a two-way street for sure. But I'm definitely seeing people, you know, realizing that they have to go back, they need more money, they're wondering what kind of terms they're going to get. And so you start seeing things. I haven't really seen too much of this yet, but this is probably what's on the horizon for some of the companies, which are, you know, the venture capitalist feeling like, "Hey, that last valuation was really high. You drove that up on me. You really drove it hard. Now is my chance to recapture some of the economics." 

And you see them do that through a couple things: either a down round on the next term sheet that they're offering you, or they'll start inserting you know, multiples on liquidation preferences, meaning they get their capital back, plus like a multiplier on that. Also participating preferred, which I have not seen yet, but does tend to happen in these cycles, which means basically they get their liquidation preference back and then they participate on the upside, as if they had just converted. So it's kind of like a double dip, even some of the, you know, voting as a share class, like blocking a merger, doing other kinds of operational things can start to happen. 

So I'm recording this video as a little bit of like a you know, keep your head up and make sure you're paying attention, so that these kind of things don't happen to you. Make sure you don't run so low on cash these are your only options. But it's also kind of a good reminder to everyone in the ecosystem that reputation matters. And rather than letting a valuation lead you into like a one week diligence period in signing documents, you really want to get to know your venture capitalist. It's a very, very long term relationship. It's pretty much impossible to get someone off the cap table once they're on it. 

And so take your time, pick your VCs according to the values you have. Maybe you just care about valuation, which is totally defensible. I tend to, I've worked in this, doing this, a very long time. I tend to really value relationships and people who step up when things are aren't going great. Because it's easy to be a cheerleader and a big fan when things are going really, really well. 

But you need your investors, your venture capitalists often to write a check in tough times or go to bat with you with an outside lead and help protect the valuation. So just remember, you know, pick your venture capitalist carefully. You want someone who's a long-term partner and who'll help you build the company. Hope that helps. 

If you have other questions on VC, or how to raise capital, or startup funding options, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and please subscribe to the YouTube channel. We put a lot of work in this and we'd be delighted if you subscribed. Thank you so much.

name: Tough Times are a Good Reminder to Pick your VC’s Thoughtfully

snippet.title: The IRS Opens Up Electronic Submission for Power of Attorney
snippet.description:
The IRS Opens Up Electronic Submission for Power of Attorney

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost


Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about a new IRS innovation. 

They are allowing electronic signatures and electronic power of attorney requests. This is really, really nice. They've like, getting power of attorney for a client is not the most fun thing for a tax firm like Kruze, but you got to do it if you're going to talk to the IRS about a given company's tax returns and tax history. And so there's actually a couple different forms people fill out on paper right now, 2848s or 8821s. And so typically, you know, if we have like an issue, like maybe someone missed their 5471 filing, like their foreign corporation statement, like, you know, they have a foreign subsidiary and we have to call the IRS to try to get them abated on that, like, we need a power of attorney signature. 

And so it involves like getting it signed and then mailing it in through snail mail to, you know, Kansas City or Utah. Those are typically where the IRS's, you know, West Coast people have to send their stuff to either Kansas City or Utah. But now, the IRS just came out this last week, you can actually do it through their online portal. And it's called a Tax Pro account. So it's a little bit new and maybe not the most creative name, but this is really, really nice. It's going to make it so much easier for, you know, to do a startup's, you know, to advocate for a startup on tax relief or get records, when missing records. Like sometimes founders, before they come to Kruze, use the not so great tax firm, and they don't even have a copy of their tax return, which is like, you know, it's kind of hard to believe, but that does happen. 

And so being able to get a copy of the EIN letter or past tax returns, or just advocating on behalf of the startup is actually really helpful. And so thank you IRS, for innovation here and while I'm on it, like, you know, I really recommend people be super nice to the folks at the IRS. They're under a lot of stress. If anyone has been following this during COVID, a lot of the offices were shut down. And so there's just like so much extra work for people now, after they've gone back to work for COVID, it's a very tough job. 

And in my opinion, it'd be great if the government kind of provided more resources to the folks at the IRS. So when you call and luckily you don't have to call and ask about a power of attorney anymore, but when you do call, be nice, they are very nice people, smart people that will help you out. So hope that helps. 

If you have any questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, but we look forward to doing your power of attorneys electronically from now on, thank you.

name: The IRS Opens Up Electronic Submission for Power of Attorney

snippet.title: Is angel investing tax deductible?
snippet.description:
Is angel investing tax deductible?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, is angel investing tax deductible for the investor? 

And when someone asked me this question recently, I was like, wow, wouldn't that be amazing? Sometimes it does feel like you're giving money to charity when you do angel investing, but angel investing is really the heart and soul of the startup ecosystem and the venture capital ecosystem. And it's really important. And the cool thing about angel investing is when you get into a good company early at a really low valuation, you can make crazy amounts of money, especially when the company goes IPO or gets bought for a big valuation. And guess what? That helps subsidize the companies that didn't make it. 

And so the investment in a company is not tax deductible, but guess what? There's an added bonus. Say, the companies you invest in, one or two out of 10 are big hits and you're making money there, which is great. But the other ones don't quite work out, which is kind of like the ratio for angel investing. Well, the losses on the company, when it goes, unfortunately shuts down and goes bankrupt, that is tax deductible. 

So you can take a capital gains loss on the investment when the company shuts down. Oftentimes your friendly CPA will ask you for proof the company shut down, or the Delaware franchise tax filing for basically withdrawing the Delaware franchise, Delaware corporation, whatever it is, just some type of proof that the company did go down and not make it. But all that money you put into the company that didn't make it can go to an offset on your gains for the companies that did make it. And so it's kind of like a really nice little thing about angel investing. 

Yes, some don't make it despite the founder's best efforts, but that's a tax write off when it finally doesn't make it. So hope that helps. It's again, angel investing, super-important for the startup ecosystem. We love you angel investors and keep taking big swings and making the entrepreneurial economy possible. 

And if you have any other questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, thanks.

name: Is angel investing tax deductible?

snippet.title: Should You Offer Cryptocurrency Payroll?
snippet.description:
Should You Offer Cryptocurrency Payroll?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

I always have to be the bearer of bad news on this because it's not the greatest thing to do. I know that you as someone who believes in cryptocurrency want to, you know be an early adopter and get it going. But the major payroll companies that we work with like Rippling and Gusto and Justworks and Tri-Net, Sequoia, they don't really accept cryptocurrency or don't facilitate paying via cryptocurrency. 

And so then what happens is we have companies or founders that decide just to send the payment via like Coinbase or another mechanism like Square's app, Cash app, or any other different way but they're not taking payroll taxes out of those payments. And that is a huge no-no for the IRS. The IRS really cares about payroll taxes. They are very smart. They figure out when you haven't been paying payroll taxes on something you should have. And so you can end up paying a lot of penalties and a ton of negative paperwork if you just don't use a payroll app at all to make these payments. 

The other thing that's hard about these like just direct cryptocurrency payments especially to like a contractor, say you decide that you're taking my advice. You're not gonna run payroll via cryptocurrency but you do wanna pay your contractors. Well, that's okay 'cause you're not, you know, avoiding payroll taxes but it makes the calculations and accounting for all those transactions a lot more difficult. So at Kruze, we're still waiting for like that magical moment when we can actually just get the when the crypto currency payment goes through like say you paid someone in Bitcoin or Ethereum and we actually get the exact dollar amounts in our accounting software. 

Right now the way we have to do it is treat each one of those crypto payments as basically like a foreign currency payment and do the calculations to figure out what the actual currency was on that day or the average of the day or average of the week. And so it makes the accounting for it a lot more difficult. Also, if you're using something like bill.com where you're saving the invoices for those contractors, which you should those invoices are getting synced into QuickBooks. The payment in cryptocurrency, outside of bill.com will not always match in dollar terms with the invoices inside of bill.com. 

And so we end up in this situation where we're spending a lot of time trying to match each cryptocurrency payment which often the app that was used are not really marked or itemized or labeled for the vendor very well at all. Most of the time, not labeled for the vendor. And we're trying to match those to invoices in bill.com so we can cancel out or basically offset that invoice. So there's just a lot of problems on the accounting side if you're trying to pay payroll or contractors through cryptocurrency. I totally get why you wanna do it. And this is how things go mainstream. When people are early adopters and start pressing use cases. I am excited though because there are accounting software companies starting to get funded who will be able to solve this problem. 

So, like for example, there's a company called TaxBit which was funded out of Utah which raised a hundred million dollars. And their whole goal is to do better accounting around crypto transactions. And I can envision a day where TaxBit or someone else who also is funded has some real serious software. Will be able just to send a bank feed into QuickBooks that the accountants like us will be able to use to make things really easy. And by the way, it's not just the QuickBooks that depends on those accounting feeds, or the bank feeds. Kruze Consulting depends on those bank feeds like we have a bunch of info coming in from Plaid as well. 

So having better bank feeds from those crypto payment apps will actually be the real unlocking of being able to run crypto payroll and crypto currency payments to your contractors. So, I know there's a lot to think about but please keep it simple right now as a startup. Give the time for some of these apps to get built, for them to be bulletproof. And then I will fully endorse paying people through crypto whether through payroll or whether it's through contractors. 

But right now it's really tough. And as a startup, you're building company, you wanna focus on your company and build your company. Let these other tool providers catch up to what you want. I hope that helps. Thanks so much, take care.

name: Should You Offer Cryptocurrency Payroll?

snippet.title: What is a secondary stock transaction?
snippet.description:
What is a secondary stock transaction?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, what is a secondary stock transaction? 

And, you know, we're recording this late 2020, the stock market and venture capital market are very frothy, on fire and so there are a lot of secondary transactions happening. Meaning, a lot of venture capital firms are buying basically the founder shares or previous VC investors shares in the company. So think of a secondary transaction as it's kind of, it's the opposite of a primary share which is when a venture capitalist puts money into the company immediately, directly they're buying primary shares, like they're buying those shares from the company, they're created to sell to those VCs same thing with founders when they establish the company, they're granted a bunch of stock, those are primary shares. 

When they resell those shares, that is a secondary transaction. And so you might say like, why are people doing secondaries right now with the market being so hot? Well, there's a couple of reasons. For founders or employees, it can be a really nice source of liquidity. Maybe you can, if you have a super successful company you can buy a house, put a down payment on something. For VCs they want to get into these companies, and maybe they can't buy any preferred stock because the round is oversubscribed. And so the only option is to buy secondary shares, from the founders or maybe a VC firm that wants to sell out. Although that's a lot less rare, a lot more rare, excuse me. 

The other reason is VCs will sometimes do a small secondary of the founder shares to give the founder some money in their pocket and so they're actually more risk seeking, meaning the founder feels financially secure and can take bigger risks, go for a bigger outcome. Venture capitalists really value the big outcomes, like the IPO, that's what returns their fund and makes them money. And so they want to be aligned with the founders. And so letting the founder take a little bit of money off the table, like I said maybe buy a house, do something so they feel secure, actually aligns the risk reward paradigm a lot better for the VCs and the founders. 

And so, now a lot of people think, hey I can just go in and buy some secondary shares. Well, it turns out there's something called a ROFR, or right of first refusal that most VC firms get in their stock purchase agreements and the articles of incorporation with the company, meaning, the internal venture capitalists get the first bite of the apple. They have to waive their right to buy those secondary shares before an outside VC firm or individual can come in. 

Now that's not always the case. I believe back in the day Twitter and Facebook didn't have that, right or maybe their VCs just always waived the right of first refusal, but there was a really big secondary markets in those stocks. And so remember you have to get the internal VC's permission typically, to do a secondary sale. The other thing to think about is people typically think secondary sales are always the common stock of the founders, which it could be your management team, but actually there's a lot of secondary sales of funds, especially for funds that are very old, maybe have been around for 10 to 15 years, and the fund life is winding down. There's an entire market for fund sales called secondaries where a fund just sells all their ownership positions, all their stock and then kind of cashes out. 

So there's a lot going on in secondary sales, but it's becoming more and more prevalent, I think partly because the market is so hot, but also investors and founders and managed teams are just getting more sophisticated, and they realize unlocking a little bit of a liquidity for the team can really help and align everyone for the big outcome. 

I hope that helps. If you have more questions hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks.

name: What is a secondary stock transaction?

snippet.title: Should your company reduce pay for employees who move to a geography with a cheaper cost of living?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

The first determinant I would make is whether this is a temporary move for that employee, or whether it's permanent. If it's temporary, you're in really good shape, I wouldn't do anything, I would just leave it alone. 

Now if it's permanent, that's a much bigger deal because a lot of these employees, when they move to that lower cost geography, also wanna pay lower payroll tax rates. And so we'll get into payroll tax rates in a second, but that necessitates actually making like a permanent adjustment in the payroll system, and also registering to do business in that state, pay payroll taxes, there's a lot of like work for the company. Now in terms of what to pay those employees, we are seeing a few companies make those adjustments. They're actually reducing it based on the standard of living in that geography. 

Now my advice if you're gonna do that is to make it a super clear communication with the employees and do it as soon as possible. 

So personally, I would not make salary adjustments, especially in the middle of COVID when there's so much uncertainty, and people's anxiety levels are really, really high. 

At Kruze, we're not doing that. We're letting people move wherever they want. 

But that's just another thing to consider. We've actually made another video talking about the tax ramifications, state and local. So check that out on our Kruze video site. So again, if you're gonna make a salary reduction based on a geography and a lower cost of living, communicate very clearly, make sure you are using data to make that change, and also really think twice about it because you may be opening yourself up for some of your employees to get poached.

name: Should your company reduce pay for employees who move to a geography with a cheaper cost of living?

snippet.title: What is a Right of First Refusal (ROFR)?
snippet.description:
What is a Right of First Refusal (ROFR)?

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, what is the Right of First Refusal when it comes to startup equity? 

And, you know, oftentimes this term will actually be called a ROFR, it's the initials of all Right Of First Refusal. It's kind of like the classic venture capital or legal thing where people like to throw big words around or abbreviations that the normal people like us don't actually know. But luckily you have an accounting firm, Kruze Consulting, who's willing to explain this stuff to you. So, yipee! So Right of First Refusal is something that's actually negotiated by the venture capitalists in your stock purchase agreement. 

And basically what that says is, "Hey, we the venture capitalists, if someone," you know on the inside of the executive team, common stock holders wants to or even preferred, this actually can apply to other preferred, but much less often preferred. It's mostly about common stock holders. If they wanna sell some stock, they have to come to us, the venture capitalists, because we have a Right of First Refusal, we get to make the first offer. And the reason for that is the VCs, most VCs typically in good companies always want more ownership. They're professional investors. That's all they do is have money and they buy stock. They buy stock in good companies, hopefully and so they always wanna increase their ownership. 

There's a secondary issue here in that like if the founding, the executive team or employees start selling stock to outsiders, there could be information rights transferred where all of a sudden the actual financial results of those companies get out. Now there's some other language usually in a stock purchase agreement that blocks, you know that you only have information rights if you own a certain amount of a company, but still what kind of happens is there's, this becomes like a wild secondary market in stock for private companies and I think generally speaking most companies try to do an IPO, Initial Public Offering and sell stock in a very organized way and try not to have like a lot of stock trading outside the company's control. 

This really came to a head when Facebook and Twitter, probably like 10 years ago, 11 years ago, 12 years ago when they were in their huge ramp and running towards an IPO. A lot of Twitter and Facebook folks were able to sell stock or get around ROFRs or those companies didn't have them. I'm not sure if they had them or not, but they were able to sell stock to just everyday people or funds and so there became like just a lot of outside ownership in those companies, which was great for the people who were able to buy the stock and also great for the employees who are able to sell some take some liquidity and then get to the IPO. 

So typically the venture capitalists though they wanna maximize their ownership, so it was a little problematic for them and it had a bunch of secondary consequences so companies have gotten a little tighter on ROFRs that said venture capital firms are a lot more willing to do a secondary buy, which means buying though they'll put their initial investment in which is primary shares, the company issues shares to the VC. 

That's a primary transaction, but a lot of VC firms are more willing to do secondary sales nowadays where they'll buy like a million or $2 million or $3 million of stock from the founders as part of our primary transaction. So in a way that Facebook, Twitter and all the other success, the Valley and New York and Santa Monica have had recently has kind of loosened investors up to they're more willing to buy secondary pieces but they still like to enforce the Right of First Refusal or ROFR so that they can, you know buy as much stock as possible before any employees sell it to the outsiders. 

So I hope that helps, if you are working at a venture backed startup it's very high likelihood that your company has a ROFR so you're just gonna have to work through the proper channels, The CFO, the accounting firm, the general counsel, sometimes the founder handles this stuff too but just make sure you get permission and make sure you do it in the right way. You don't want anything invalidated or anything weird happen. So hope that helps. Hope the definition of Right of First Refusal makes sense to you. Thanks. Bye.

name: What is a Right of First Refusal (ROFR)?

snippet.title: Trump Organization Tax Fraud Case - Lessons for Startups
snippet.description:
Trump Organization Tax Fraud Case - Lessons for Startups

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn of Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about the tax treatment on perks for employees that are, perks that employees receive from companies. And what brought this up is I was reading the news that the Trump organization's CFO has been indicted for tax fraud. 

And it was about, I think it was like $1.75 million of tax fraud here. And basically, what it comes down to is I started seeing that, I started reading the list, and it was all things that startup founders ask us if they can do for their own companies and themselves. And so I thought it would make, this would be a very real life example for everyone. So, you know, hopefully this comes across as well intentioned here. But basically the Trump CFO, I think his name is Allen Weisselberg. He was not reporting indirect income on his W2, which is what the federal government uses to track your income. So it was stuff like the Trump organization was paying for his apartments. And they were paying for his cars. And they were paying for private school tuition, utility expenses, garage expenses, all these things that are called perks or indirect income that was making his life a lot better. And guess what? He was not running this through payroll and paying payroll taxes. 

So it's perfectly fine for the company to pay for this stuff if it wants, but it needs to be taxed. The IRS, you know, deserves the taxes from this type of income, even though it's not in your salary. And so the correct way to do this is to add line items on the payroll every month for the employees who get these kinds of perks. And have them pay tax on it and have the company pay tax on it. But the Trump organization was not doing this. The only way the IRS caught this was, he had been keeping detailed records, like a good accountant would, of all these different expenses that he was running through the company, but not paying taxes on. 

So your startup can learn from this. Like, don't pay a rent on behalf of the founders, don't pay for the gym, don't pay for, you know, cars or other kinds of stuff. That is illegal. The IRS, you know, they're doing their best to audit this kind of stuff. They may not catch you, but you wanna do things the right way. When you're doing a startup you're trying to build a giant company. You're not trying to save a few bucks on your apartment, right? So learn from this real life example. 

And if you have any questions hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. We answer this question, I would say once a week from a founder who's well-intentioned, and is trying to figure out what's reasonable, and what they can expense, and what needs to be run through payroll taxes. So just remember if it feels too good to be true, and you're getting a bunch of stuff paid for by the company, it means you probably need to be running that through payroll taxes. You don't wanna end up working with the IRS in a hard way, or the feds knocking at your door someday. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Trump Organization Tax Fraud Case - Lessons for Startups

snippet.title: Can I retroactively apply for PPP 1?
snippet.description:
Can I retroactively apply for PPP 1?

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, can my startup apply for a PPP loan retroactively? 

And really, this is a question I'm getting quite a bit from startups who didn't apply in March, April and May last year but who were eligible and there's a variety of reasons why companies didn't apply maybe they felt some pressure or they didn't have other funding sources or whatever it is. 

If you are eligible and you were eligible at that time, the new PPP 2 laws actually let startups or other companies apply, it's called a first draw PPP and you are not subject to the rules around PPP 2 which say like you basically have to have a 25% reduction, quarterly reduction in gross receipts. And so if your company passed or just didn't do it last year in 2020 but wanna do it or wants to do it now you can actually apply. The guidance and the guidelines are exactly the same. 

Again, you are not subject if this is your first time, you are not subject to the 25% reduction in gross receipts but you do have to warrant that this is needed that your company was affected by COVID and you do have to list out all your 20% shareholders which are typically gonna be VC funds. So, the affiliation laws are still in play. There was a lot of affiliate concern around affiliation laws and basically what that means is if you're startup is owned, has a significant amount of ownership, VC fund has a significant amount of ownership in your startup and in many other startups you essentially pool those together and it can disqualify you. 

There was some movement and it made it a little bit easier for VC backed startups to do PPP despite some of the affiliation stuff but it's not like super clear, it's not like very obvious whether you qualify or not so that's something you should talk to your attorneys, talk to your accountants about, but again the headline is if you passed or just didn't do PPP 1, but would like to and you still qualify and your company was affected by COVID, you can do it in this new round of PPP 2 it's called a first draw loan. 

Tons of paperwork, tons of information online, SBA has a lot of good resources and you are eligible. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Can I retroactively apply for PPP 1?

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question; How does a startup's taxes change if it changes its state of incorporation? 

And this is kind of a creative question I gotta say. But, the first thing to remember is, a venture capital firm is always gonna want you to be a Delaware C corporation. And that's for a couple reasons. A, everyone understands case law, it's a very business friendly, place to do business, especially with VC firms, and, venture capital firms have a pretty complicated tax structure because they have all these limited partners who invest in them, and so they can't afford to have like LLCs, or S Corps, or things like that that are passed through. So they're always gonna ask you to be a Delaware C Corp. 

So, getting fancy, and maybe out thinking you're outsmarting someone by changing your incorporation state or things like that, I don't recommend that. Now, someone might say, you know, and I also wanna be specific here. This is different than being a Delaware C Corp and then just hiring someone in New York, or California, or Texas, or Florida, or wherever, where you are going to be employing people there, create tax nexus and have to register to do business in that state and pay some taxes. So the question I'm answering here is not that. 

If you are just hiring people in a state and you're gonna conduct business there, well you just register, you pay some taxes, it's pretty easy, very straightforward. You will file a state tax, income tax form every year along with your federal return. But what I'm talking about is maybe someone trying to game the system. Maybe they're like a California C Corp, or a New York C Corp, and maybe they think they can take advantage of like R&D Tax Credits for another year. There's basically like once you hit revenue you have like five years to be able to use the payroll tax offset, right? And so they might think like, "Oh my gosh, I'm gonna get really fancy here, and take my California C Corp and make it a Delaware C Corp and reset the clock on the R&D Tax Credit." 

Well, that doesn't work. And the reason why it doesn't work is the IRS follows EIN numbers. That is the tax number you are associated with in the IRS system, that doesn't change whether you're a Delaware C Corp, or a California C Corp, whatever kind of company you are, that, you are stuck with that, that's how they're gonna evaluate your tax return and any historical things like the five year limit on payroll tax offsets from R&D Tax Credit. 

So, I hope this is definitely a more complicated question but I, it's a question I actually got from a client who I think was getting a little creative. And just in startups, this kind of stuff, always keep it simple. It's so hard to build a startup. There's so many things going on, there's so many demands on your time and your people. This is an example of someone probably overthinking it a little bit and they weren't really gonna get anywhere anyways. 

Now, luckily they had, they were a Kruze client, so they had a CPA firm to ask this question for, and they didn't spend a lot of money and time on it, but, just keep it simple. Keep your Delaware C Corp, don't try to move around in corporation states or anything like that. And then, you know, as a best practice if you do hire someone in another state or have assets or property, or generating quite a bit of revenue in that state, you will have to start filing tax returns in that state and register to do business in that state. 

Hope that helps, if you have any other questions on this or other tax issues, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thank you so much, appreciate it.

name: What Changes the State of Incorporation and Its Impact on a Startup’s Taxes?

snippet.title: How do early stage VCs find the startups to invest in?
snippet.description:
How do early stage VCs find the startups to invest in?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

The first one is, you know, and this is really new, like Fred Wilson, Bill Gurley. Some of the older VCs have been doing this for a long time, is building their brand, producing content, and just general advice. And now, you see in the VC world, First Round Capital has an amazing newsletter. Andreessen Horowitz is basically kicking off like a whole kind of media company. Fred Wilson's blog is still legendary. Bill Gurley's blog is legendary when he writes it. There's a lot of VCs on Twitter. What these venture capitalists have realized is by putting out content or messaging about industries or concepts they find interesting, it's actually a great way to help startup founders find them. So, you know, the reverse of this would be like the summit model. Someone's a very, very successful VC fund, but later stage and they just cold call and do a lot of direct marketing to business owners. 

Well, what a lot of the venture capitalists realized in the startup world is it's so hard to know who to call or who to reach out. And a lot of the best ideas come from the fringes. And so by putting out content, and demonstrating the kind of advice, and how smart they are and how they can help your company, they can generate a lot of really great deal flow that way. So that's number one. 

Number two, existing portfolio company management teams aka other founders they've invested in. This is definitely the number two right here. It's a huge validation for a venture capitalist when another founder introduces them to a company or startup or founder that's doing something really interesting because oftentimes, like the founders of the portfolio companies are the most in tune with what's happening in the market. They also have these like implicit filters that allow them to see like, is this founder a good decision maker? Are they organized? Can they move quickly? Can they recruit talent? Is their idea super interesting? Is there a big market opportunity for this idea? The founder that's making this intro is typically already gone through that whole filter set. 

And if they're making the intro to the VC, which is an important relationship for them, that means it's something interesting and the venture capitalist should really pay attention. So I think there's maybe less of these than some of the other channels, but they're the highest validation. Maybe, even the most important, because I think more times than not, these are the ones that lead to an investment. And I can look at the Kruze Consulting client portfolio because we have a lot of relationships with a lot of VC firms and a lot of founders. And I can tell who made the intros to who and often ask that question. 

Number three is angel investors, especially if you're like a seed stage or series A fund, angel investors can be another great kind of "scouting system" for you because angels, oftentimes, are wealthy individuals or people who've been very successful in the corporate world. Like maybe people worked at Facebook or Uber, Google, whatever, and have some extra money. And so they're going around investing in companies that they find interesting. 

And then it was a 20, $25 million fund. Now, some seed stage funds are getting like 50, $70 million, especially for the smaller ones, you're kind of capital constrained. And you know that you need to make a lot of bets as a seed stage fund because the failure rate is really, really high. And so, what you often see with seed stage funds is they partner up with other seed stage funds. You might see like Precursor and Homebrew do a deal together, you know, to pick just a couple folks we're familiar with. Because they know, maybe one of the seed stage funds wants to do a million, but they know this company actually needs $3 million in capital at the seed stage. And so they're going to bring in one of their funds they're friendly with, but who also kind of is like-minded. 

Next up, I talked about this a little bit, but cold emails. And there's really kind of an art to cold emails. Jason Lemkin at SaaStr talks about this all the time. He has some really good posts on this. But when you're running a cold email, you do not want to overwhelm the VC with a bunch of text, like giant, giant paragraphs. You want to start off with a very simple one sentence or two sentence; what your company does. So for Kruze Consulting it's we do accounting and taxes for startups. And at this point when I'm recording the video in the middle of 2021, we have over 500 clients. Right? That would be what I would send to the VC. Like that's a very quick summary of what we do.

name: How do early stage VCs find the startups to invest in?
