snippet.title: Should your startup switch to unlimited PTO?
snippet.description:
Should your startup switch to unlimited PTO?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

There's a couple different reasons why companies do this, one of the first ones is, it's kind of flashy. It sounds really cool to new recruits, which makes the actual recruiting process a little easier, especially like hard to find engineers. People like the concept of unlimited PTO. There's also a financial benefit to the company that's probably driving a lot of this to be honest with you, which is, when someone leaves, especially like the states like California and New York, when someone leaves the company, you are technically required to pay them their outstanding PTO they never took on vacation. This is something you actually have to pay them within, different states have different requirements, but the first 24 or 48 hours usually. 

And so that's a liability the company incurs along the way, and it's real cash. Like if you have someone with two or three weeks of vacation per year, they're not taking very much vacation. You're actually going to owe them a decent amount of money. And so some companies are like, "Hey, great we get the flashiness on the recruiting side and guess what, we're not gonna have to pay people when they leave. Like how great is that? We're saving a bunch of money." And so that's what's driving the unlimited PTO trend. My opinion, I'm actually slightly negative on unlimited PTO. And I have a couple of reasons why. 

First, there's the cultural problems. So you kind of have two buckets of people. The first more obvious bucket is people who abuse it and take too much PTO. So you have the people who just decide they're going to take every Friday off, like that's 50 days or probably 40 days a year. That kind of thing. You have the people who are going to take a three or four week vacation cause they have unlimited PTO. And it's hard for the people who are managing the organization, especially the middle management layer to push back against a definitive company policy and say, "Hey, you can't take PTO." Like after all, there is an unlimited PTO policy at the company. 

So that's a problem. And it does put pressure on the management team, especially middle management, which is when you get going, you're scaling as a startup it's actually maybe your most important layer, like that middle manager layer is really transferring the culture, the process, how we do things here. And so adding another thing, especially if you're going through hyper-growth is very difficult there. The second issue I see is, and this is, I've seen this documented in a bunch of places in surveys, people who have unlimited PTO, actually most of them perversely take less PTO. In fact, they don't take enough PTO. 

And so what happens is, there's this building resentment slash burnout that can really creep into an organization and you can fight this a little bit by just encouraging and messaging people to take PTO and reminding them it's unlimited. But there's this, it's just hard mentally when they're not looking in their payroll account and seeing the number of days of vacation they have, or feel like that time is owed to them, for some people to take the time off. And so the nightmare scenario is those people burn out. They start lashing out and they actually create a very, very expensive HR problem at your company. Where you're starting to lose good people. Maybe there's some abuse or, you know, stuff like that. All because someone who normally would have been a fine actor, a nice contributor just got burned out because they weren't taking enough PTO. 

So, that's, you know, again, when you're doing unlimited PTO, you're getting rid of the liability and it's nice for a brochure for recruiting, but I really personally don't think the financial benefit of getting rid of that liability is really worth the potential burnout and HR problems you could have with people who aren't taking enough PTO. And then also you've got this middle management layer, who's really having to enforce this policy and make decisions in the field that are tough to justify sometimes. So, you know, I definitely see the benefit of it. I understand why some startups do it, but I personally just recommend people have a PTO policy. 

That's how we do it at Kruze. We have a PTL policy. People get paid out when they leave, we monitor it. We really encourage people to take vacation. It's very healthy. It's healthy for the organization long-term. So that's my 2 cents, that's what I recommend. If you have any questions or comments hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. We'd love to answer your questions. 

Happy to listen to your viewpoint as well, especially if you've worked in an organization that has unlimited PTO. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Should your startup switch to unlimited PTO?

snippet.title: How startups can modify their office leases during COVID to cut burn
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about startup office leases. And what do you do if you're in a really tough situation? 

So with COVID hitting, lots of companies are not even using their offices. Office space is one of the largest burn, like cash burn or expenses, for a startup. So a lot of people are trying to figure this out. Now, a couple of things for a background. Office leases are actually unsecured debt. Like, you cannot just like get out of an office lease. That is debt on your company. So you got to be really careful on how you handle this. 

Secondly, a little bit more background. For a very long time, startup office leases in San Francisco, New York, Austin, they've all been going up in price for a long time. And so people didn't always really worry too much about how long their lease duration was because they figured they could always sublease it out. And that was true. Because the market was always going up, subleasing out always was a better deal for someone. So someone would always take that lease. Now, with COVID hitting, prices have plummeted. And so it's really tough to get out of a lease. So we've got four different solutions for you. 

So the first solution is you can quote-unquote play hardball. Now we do not recommend this. But playing hardball would be, "Hey, Mr or Mrs. Landlord. "I'm just not gonna pay you for a few months," and see what happens. Now, sometimes people think that's a good solution. But it's really not because again, this is unsecured debt on your company. Furthermore, you've typically put down a deposit, one to three months or so, or you've signed a letter of credit with the bank that the landlord can draw down upon for collateral. So if you stop paying for a few months, they're just gonna use your deposit or they're gonna draw down to your letter of credit. 

And I know a lot of startup people have been surprised that letters of credit have been getting drawn down upon. But that's just kinda how it works. That's what letters of credit do. So the other thing to worry about if you play hardball is that in these leases there's a lot of penalties and fees that the landlords can rack up on you. They can also just take you to court for some of the like more qualitative but very dangerous terms where you're causing financial damage to them. So all of a sudden the liability gets really big if you stop paying. So we do not recommend doing that. 

Instead, we recommend working with your landlord. So there's a couple different ways. Now, the first one is working with your landlord to find a subletter. This is really tough. You've probably already tried doing that. What we are seeing is prices are down 25 to 50% in the big metros. So if you can get a subletter, you're probably gonna be subsidizing them by paying 25 to 50% rent. So you've got to figure out if that's even really worth it for you. But you do get out of that liability if you do sublet it. 

The next option, which is probably my favorite, is blend and extend. And what that means is you go to the landlord and you say, "Hey, I will sign up for another year on my lease "on the backend under the assumption that the market "will get better, we'll get through COVID and office space "will be in more demand." So you don't really mind doing that. In exchange, you will get a lower payment for the next year or two. So the landlord wins because they're extending the lease and you win as a startup because you're blending the high payment you used to pay with a much lower payment in the near term. And this is the most cashflow-friendly way because you're really reducing your payments when it matters most. 

Now the fourth option is a variation of that. But what you would do is actually go to your landlord and say, "Hey, instead of extending, "I will just buy out the lease." Now, this is again, landlords, not their favorite thing because they really like having long-term leases. But if you make it worth their while by paying six months to a year worth of payments upfront, you can usually get out of the lease. That gives the property back to the landlord. They've got a bunch of cash up front. And then they can try to lease it again. Now, the problem for a startup is the cashflow burden is really huge upfront, kinda when you don't wanna do it. You wanna push those payments out if possible. And all of a sudden you're paying six months to a year worth of lease payments right away. So it is pretty painful. But if you think there's no way that you're ever gonna use this lease and there's no way to get a subletter, and you don't wanna extend it, then doing the buyout is the best option. So I hope that helps. 

There are four options. None of them are super-fun. None of them are super-easy. But times are tough and it's time to take evasive action if the office lease is really hurting your company. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How startups can modify their office leases during COVID to cut burn

snippet.title: Startup Financial Planning
snippet.description:
Startup Financial Planning.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

1- Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), to drive their financial model, which is in my opinion, the right way to do it. So, you have certain KPIs, maybe average selling price, number of customers, on the development side there might be things like number of engineers, productivity per engineer, things like that. There's some usually three to four maybe five KPIs you wanna use to really drive your business. And typically the KPIs will, some of them at least, will drive your revenue. And so most people kind of start from the top and they go top down. So they use the KPIs to figure out what the revenue projections are gonna be. And then they start thinking about, okay, how do I need to support, or how do I need to build this organization to support that revenue? 

There's one other we really didn't talk about. We talked a lot about people, but we didn't talk about some of the more CapEx heavy companies like biotech or manufacturing or robotics, for those companies you have to plan ahead on your capital expenditures. And so you really need to know how much equipment do I need to buy? When's it gonna be delivered? Do I need any accessories with that equipment? Planning for a hardware or biotech, MedTech company, robotics company is actually a lot harder than just a pure like SaaS or consumer internet company. 

2- Fundraising. And typically startups raise money on an 18 month cycle. So, and some startups raise every 12 months, some every 24 months, but 18 months is a good average. 

3- Board Approval. Typically the boards actually sometimes even in the stock purchase agreement, investor rights agreements they will include that they have the right to approve the financial plan for the year. So you're gonna wanna present that budget to the board. Now, I like to get all this done in December if possible, maybe January. The reason for that is  if you can get everything nailed down, board approved in December, you're going right into January. You're collecting resumes already. You're gonna be interviewing and you can usually hire those people that you need by the end of January or February. If you're getting this board deck and board presentation approved in January, it puts you kind of a month delay and that's not a huge deal. 

Most recruiting doesn't really turn up until end of January. But just earlier is better. You also need to build in some buffer time because you're gonna need to have some conversations with your board. I would not just present the plan like, "Wow. Here it is." I would be having side conversations with them while you're building it, checking in, making sure you are consistent with what their assumptions are. And it's very common for board members to not approve the plan on first blush and send you back to the drawing board a little bit. And often they just wanna see a more aggressive plan. Like they've invested a lot of capital in this company. They wanna see it produce big numbers. They wanna see a big exit out of it. And so they're gonna challenge you to just be more aggressive. So just prepare for that. 

But ideally you'll have the board meeting in late December or January and it'll be ready to go and you'd be ready to start recruiting. And then the final aspect of financial planning for 2021 is really the execution aspect. And a lot of it is getting those orders in for CapEx, getting HR, getting recruiting ramped up, making the time in your schedule and team members' schedules to actually do the interviewing and attract really good people. I mean, that is just so important. One of the big reasons I see our clients miss their numbers, if they do miss is because their plan was predicated on bringing a certain number of contributors, whether it's developers or salespeople into the organization. And they're just late hiring those people. 

And so, by default, they just end up missing their numbers by a quarter. So, the faster you can execute on this plan, get those people in the door, start making positive progress in 2021. You're just gonna be better off and it's gonna show. Your valuation will go up if you're raising more money. You have more traction. You'll have happier team and you'll have a happier board. 

And most importantly, you'll have a happier you the executive team of the startup. So I hope this helps. Please don't wait. Don't procrastinate. Now's the time to start planning for 2021. Get that financial plan done. You'll sleep better. You'll enjoy the holidays more and you'll have just a great start on 2021. Thanks.

name: Startup Financial Planning

snippet.title: My employer changed to PEO mid-year, how does that affect my personal taxes and my W2s?
snippet.description:
My employer changed to PEO mid-year, how does that affect my personal taxes and my W2s?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're answering the question, My employer, my startup, that I work for, switched to a PEO mid-year, How does that affect my personal taxes and my W2s? 

And the answer is, it is actually not that complex really, you should get a W2 from your company via the payroll provider that you used to use. So, a lot of companies are on Gusto or Rippling or Intuit payroll. And maybe you switched half, Your company switched halfway through the year. So, you'll get, you know, hypothetically, a W2 from January to June, on the old payroll system. 

And then when you go to a PEO, you actually technically work for the PEO, a professional employment organization and then you kinda have like a side relationship with your startup You work at this is how PEOs are able to pool all the employees and get really great healthcare benefit costs because they can kind of pull everything and have better negotiations. So technically you work for that PEO. so you will also get a W2 for the second half of the year wages directly from the PEO and it will actually come from the PEO, not your company. 

And so you should get two W2s and W2s are basically the statement that tells you what you made what your gross wages were and all the deductions like 401k and and some of that stuff, taxes, things like that. So, if you're company switched to a PEO and you only got one W2 you need to look at that and figure out who it came from. Your old payroll provider or your new PEO and make sure you're the squeaky wheel and get a second W2. So you can fill out your taxes correctly. A lot of people think if they don't get a W2 or a 1099 they don't have to declare those wages or payments on their taxes. 

But guess what? The IRS actually gets notified in a different way and knows that you didn't declare and they will find you and audit you eventually. I hope it doesn't happen to you, but it happens quite a bit. 

So even if you don't get the W2 because of some paperwork problem or you don't get a 1099, because of some paperwork problem you still need to declare all those earnings on your personal tax return. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: My employer changed to PEO mid-year, how does that affect my personal taxes and my W2s?

snippet.title: Financial Modeling Basics for Startups
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts/ 

Video Transcript:

Hi, guys. I'm Vanessa, from Kruze Consulting. Today I wanted to go over with you guys a couple of the basics you need to think about when you're creating a financial model for your start-up. There are really five things. First of which, you do need three years worth of projections. Some folks will think, “Oh, maybe I just need one, or maybe I need five,” the answer is, keep it to three years. Next up, do make sure that you have a three statement financial model. That means a PNL, a balance sheet, and a statement of cash flows. Some folks will just go straight to the income statement and then leave it as-is. But the real answer is, make sure that you have all three of those statements, tying back together. Third, you are going to wanna make sure that you're using your KPIs as your drivers. Those are things like your number of users, your cost to acquire a customer or your MRR. Those are the things again, that should really be making your financial model move. Next up, do think about churn. Customers who wanna leave, you should account for that. It really just keeps your financial model a little bit more honest. Last but not least, do make sure that you add in waterfalls. Waterfalls help keep your financial model dynamic because as you guys all know, things don't always go to plan. So you need to make sure that your financial model isn't completely broken when you've either exceeded your goals, or you've kinda fallen a little bit behind. So again, it's a three statement financial model, three years worth of projections, KPIs should be your drivers, do account for churn, and last but not least, the waterfalls. Thanks again for listening. I'm Vanessa, and we'll see you soon.

name: Financial Modeling Basics for Startups

snippet.title: How much should I reimburse employees for a home office?
snippet.description:
How much should I reimburse employees for a home office?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, is Scott Orn, Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, how much should my startup reimburse employees for home office equipment? So, all of us have found ourselves with COVID working at home even if we don't want to. And a lot of team members have really sub-optimal equipment setups, like they don't have enough monitors or keyboards or computer or whatever it is. So you really want to take care of your  employees. 

The average amount we're seeing our startups and what we're recommending is right around $1,000. So, $1,000 will typically cover everything your employees need to have a really nice workstation at home. Now, that's the dollar amount. And we see some companies spending $500 and we see some being super generous and doing $2,000. But $1,000 is right around the right number. That's what I would go with. 

Now, the second part of this question is, how do I execute on it? Because there's a lot of logistics here and there's some payroll tax issues you don't want to mess up and some IRS issues you don't wanna mess up. So just let me go through the four ways of doing this. The first way is to have a very centralized process. Have your operations team have a list of equipment that every employee should have and just go boom. Fire away, go on Amazon and buy that stuff with the company credit card. Your operations team will do it. Send it to the employee's house, super easy, very little work for the employees and the operations team can knock this out very, very quickly. That's my favorite way of doing this. 

The second best way is to enable virtual credit cards for your team. We typically put companies on Brex or the American Express virtual startup credit card. You can set up those cards very, very quickly and easily. And set a limit and then tell your employees what the budget is and they can go and buy the equipment for themselves, have it shipped to them. And because it's on a company credit card, it comes in the company's financials very, very easily. Kruze, other accountants, are gonna be very comfortable working with this. That's the second easiest way. 

The third easiest is to have the employees use their personal credit cards and expense their purchases. Now, the danger in this is you're starting to use a lot of employee time. Like they have to buy the equipment, they have to fill out the expense report, someone has to scrutinize that expense report and make sure it came in under budget. The IRS requires you to do an expense report if you're not using the company's credit card. So, you're starting to kind of waste a lot of time here. So just be careful with this, but Expensify and then or Tallie, Emburse are actually very good platforms that can do this fairly quickly, but it's not quite as easy as the first two options. 

The fourth option which we do see some companies doing just because it's so easy is I'm just kinda say this like sending money. Like, "Basically here's a thousand bucks, go do what you want with it, buy what you need." Now, there's a couple of things you don't wanna mess up on this, because if you just give your employees money that needs to be run through payroll and be treated basically as a bonus and be taxed. So you're probably gonna have to gross it up. So if you are giving people $1,000, you probably got to give them like $1.3 thousand or something like that, right? 

The second problem with this is you actually don't know if the employees bought what they said they were gonna buy. And they may still be working in a sub-optimal work environment because they just valued having the cash more. So, I don't really like this option, but if you're looking for a very quick and easy, something you can do in 15 minutes, then send money slash pay a bonus is the way to do it. 

Please make sure this is run through payroll. Don't mess this up. You'll start getting IRS payroll tax notifications and penalties. It's just such a bummer. So those are the four ways. Again, the number is right around $1,000. And just be smart. Make sure you have a system approach to this. Don't kind of wing it. And pick one of the four options I gave you. It will be easy, it'll be quick, and most importantly your employees will be happy because they'll have all the right equipment, they'll have a comfortable work environment, and they can do their job. 

And that's what everyone wants in this day and age. Hope that helps. Thanks. Bye.

name: How much should I reimburse employees for a home office?

snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn how to raise venture capital from existing investors right now.

*******************************

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

#raiseventurecapital #startupbusiness #cashmanagement 

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

I'm taping this at the end of May, 2022. And what we're seeing is a lot of companies are either looking to fill up the tank a little bit more or going back to existing investors and really needing more capital to survive. And so it's super-important to get this right if you're a startup. First of all, one of the things you need to realize is outside investors are all busy triaging their own portfolio right now. Again, they have portfolios just like your venture capital funds have portfolios like the folks that invested in you. 

And so what you kind of see in the beginnings stages of a tough time, like I remember this from COVID, in 2008, even, I was a baby investment banker in 2000, 2001, but the venture capitalists first pay attention to their own portfolio companies and triage those, get those to a good place. And so they're not super-open for business. They will still take meetings, still look at companies. But a lot of their attention is on their existing portfolio. 

So it makes it hard for them to like lead new investments. You start seeing that when the market hits a bottom, their existing portfolio is triaged, and then they can start thinking kind of opportunistically about new deals. The portion of the cycle we're in right now is the triage existing companies. And so that's why I'm kind of coaching folks in this video on how to ask existing investors for money. Because that's going to be the fastest, the quickest, the easiest. Those people know you, they know your traction, they've been tracking you, they know what kind of person you are, they know how organized, how good of a decision-maker you are. And so and they also have already invested in the company so they have something to protect there. So they are more likely to want to invest in your company. So there's a couple things going on here. There's always going to be the rocket ship companies. 

And if you are a rocket ship watching this, it's a great time for you. You could probably even raise an up valuation. Run a process. People will pay attention. If you're doing pretty well, this is a really good time to open up the last round of financing and do some extra capital at that valuation. Now, I know that seems so painful and doesn't seem fair. And you probably made a ton of progress off of the last round valuation. Say it was like six months ago or nine months ago. You probably did a lot. The only solace I can give you is that that round was probably raised at a very aggressive valuation. So you did a great job fundraising in that round. You maximized the valuation most likely. So when you reopen that round, you're kind of giving a little bit back to the VCs. They're there when times are tough, they're supporting you, and it's not the worst thing to open up the round at the last valuation. I don't love saying that. It's not the best, my favorite advice, to give you. 

Sometimes in a tough market, acquirers will re-trade the deal. And so if you have a little bit of extra cash, you can be a little bit more forceful in your no's when they try to re-trade it. And so those are also really good opportunities to raise capital right now. There's something you can really point to that's going to move the needle for the VCs because remember, they do have their ownership position in you, they're existing investors, but this is extra capital. 

So I think the moral of the story is if you've got like 24 months of cash, you're sitting pretty. I wouldn't really do anything. I wouldn't open up the last round. I wouldn't be asking for bridges, anything like that. Maybe raise a little bit of extra venture debt.

name: How to Raise Venture Capital from Existing Investors Right Now

snippet.title: 5 Ways to Collect Cash Upfront from Customers
snippet.description:
5 Ways to Collect Cash Upfront from Customers

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

The first way is just defaulting it into your agreements and the way you do business. And this is especially a lot easier if it's smaller ticket items because people don't really, you know, freak out if they're having to pay a full year subscription upfront if it's a small item, but you'd be amazed like defaults are just so powerful in our lives, in the world. And just starting with a default pay up front is actually really, really helpful. You may have some negotiations you may have some one-off things, but by and large most people will just default to following directions, especially if they wanna use your application or your service. So default is the first one. The second technique is discount. 

And this is something that I think the startup world, especially SaaS world is getting more and more in tune with but giving a partial, you know a 5% or 10% discount for cash collections upfront can really trigger a lot of cash collections because there's a lot of vendors out there that have plenty of cash that want to use your service. And if they can save 5% or 10%, well heck, that's really great. That's actually a good return on their capital by prepaying it. 

And so discounting is probably the best tool for generating cash up front for your startup. The next one is something that's sometimes people don't think about it but incentivizing your sales team to collect cash up front especially in big enterprise deals. Salespeople are very focused on incentives. They tend to be financially oriented. They love the thrill of the sale. They love the thrill of closing a deal and they also love little extra bonuses. 

And if you can give them an incentive for a higher commission level, if they collect cash up front or cash in the first year, that is really really valuable to your startup, especially for enterprises that are selling two or three year licenses or agreements. Getting year two and year three upfront is huge. Think about that, that's money that can go be reinvested back into your sales team. Be reinvested back into customer acquisition in turn a couple more sales in the meantime whereas if you're not getting paid in advance, that's cash you'd either have to raise from investors or you just can't deploy it back into your business. 

So, giving the sales team an incentive to collect cash up front is very, very helpful. Another idea is bundling free services into an upfront payment. So the classic example would be like a software plus consulting service purchase. And if you can provide either discount on the people slash consulting time or effort or just giving that consulting time or effort away for free to incentivize cash up front, that can really work. Especially when it's a people-centric cost. I think a lot of customers realized that like software has a very low marginal cost but people time has a very high marginal cost. 

And so they know you're kind of throwing them a bone or taking a little pain or just giving them an extra good deal if you throw in some of those consulting services into the deal to get them to pay up front. So that's a really powerful lever as well. And then the fifth one is just doing an automatic auto-renew every year and collecting cash upfront on the auto-renew. Now you wanna be careful and respectful of your customers. You don't wanna surprise them. You wanna give them plenty of notice, you know a month or two out that the arrangement will auto-renew and that the cash is collected up front. Like it was the first time they signed the deal but just doing that auto-renew and doing an automatic collection, like attaching something to Stripe or Chargebee or something like that. 

And just being able to run the payment can actually be really, really helpful to your business. And you know, the customer oftentimes doesn't mind that because that's less headache. That's less things they're having to think about. As long as they signed up for the auto-renew in the first place, it's a totally kosher, cool thing to do. So I hope that helps. Again, collecting cash upfront for your business can be really powerful. You can re-deploy that cash into the business. It means that you will have to raise less capital from investors and you can actually grow a lot faster. 

So I hope these tips help. If you have any other questions, give us a shout at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks so much.

name: 5 Ways to Collect Cash Upfront from Customers

snippet.title: What Happens If Your Startup Doesn't Make Its Medical Payments?
snippet.description:
What Happens If Your Startup Doesn't Make Its Medical Payments?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm talking about what do you do when your startup didn't make its medical benefits payments? 

This is a humongous deal. It's a shame really, and it happens maybe once every couple years in the Kruze client base because a lot of times it's confusing for founders, especially if it's like the first company they've run. And they think that the payroll provider who, you know, you kind of get your benefits through the payroll provider most of the time, they think the payroll provider is gonna make those payments. And so we message this quite a bit during onboarding in that you actually have to set up a direct ACH debit with your medical benefits provider like Blue Cross Blue Shield, Kaiser, whoever you're using. 

But sometimes founders just don't do it, so what do you do? Well, first, let's talk about the downside. This is actually really important because one of the core things you need as a successful company is for the employee base to have confidence in the company. And so if the employees find out that they're not covered because the company didn't make the medical benefits payment, maybe they're in the emergency room or something like that, that can really rock the company culture. It's really, really, it's toxic. So be really careful and make sure these payments are made. I know at Kruze, we try to point out if we ever don't see these payments made on a monthly basis 'cause we want the founder to be aware of this kind of stuff. 

But there's some other things that can happen. You as a company potentially could be liable for all the medical bills, and even worse, the officers of the company, the executives and the board of directors, they can be personally liable. Not for sure, but there definitely a high likelihood of a lawsuit if the company doesn't step up and make all those payments on behalf of the employee. So just really critically important that you take care of this stuff. I know as a founder, there's a million things you gotta take care of, but making that, setting up that automatic debit ACH to the medical benefit insurance companies is really, really critical. 

Now, if you find out you haven't been doing it, especially if it's been a month or two, super easy fix. Call the benefits provider and get on the phone with them and they will actually usually reinstate you pretty quickly. Again, it's something that happens a decent amount and so they have a whole get up-to-date and get true in your account process. Now, if it's been three or four months or six months, this is a real issue. You may actually have to re-enroll. It's gonna take some real fancy footwork. I highly recommend having an HR professional who's super up-to-date and really has some friendly relationships they can call upon at the insurance companies. Someone who's kinda been there and done it like a thousand times kinda person. 

So if that happens and you need help, shoot us an email. We're happy to connect you to some people who can get it fixed and make sure your employees are covered. And again, this is just the kind of thing that, it's confusing for everyone. The payroll providers are not on the hook for this. They do not make those payments for you. Your company needs to do it. And if it goes wrong, act quickly, fix it because really the executive team and the company can be held liable. So be careful and hope this helps, thanks.

name: What Happens If Your Startup Doesn't Make Its Medical Payments?

snippet.title: How to Rebalance Ownership Between Founders
snippet.description:
How to Rebalance Ownership Between Founders

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

First of all, why do this? Well, oftentimes like a company gets going maybe it's a solo founder, maybe there's two founders and the company's going for a little bit and then Miss Amazing or Mr. Amazing walks into the picture with a key skillset or connections or whatever that would make the company so much better and so you're tempted or you want to add someone to your founding team even though the company kind of got going already and so you need to kind of balance out the founder stock, right? Another situation could be their is two founders and they split it evenly at first but one is kind of over the course of time everyone kind of realizes that one is significantly stronger than the other or has more valuable expertise and so you kind of re-cut the pie, so to speak. 

So that's why you would rebalance the ownership positions of founders. Now there's a couple different mechanisms you can try. I'll go over those and then I'm also going to give you a couple points to just be careful of. So the first and probably the easiest mechanism is to issue stock options to the new founder. This is easiest and best if the company's been kind of operating for a while and the beauty of stock options is there's a strike price established by the 409A Valuation. 

In the early days is still pretty low and because that valuation is low it's still very appetizing for the founder. Of course, it's going to be a higher valuation than what the original founders or the original cut was because at that point, when the company was started there was like nothing there and so when the company is founded and the founders do their 83(b) and buy the stock, the founder stock, they usually we're talking like tens of pennies or one hundreds of pennies per share of stock. 

But as soon as the company starts making progress or is about to raise money or does raise money you need to do a 409A Valuation to establish the fair market price of the stock and so the options are based on that but the nice thing about the options is that if they're issued at fair market value then there's nothing taxable at that moment. It's not a taxable transaction for whoever is getting that stock and so there's no like cash out of pocket in that transaction, which for these super early stage companies you just never know. A lot of people don't want to write like a 50 or $100,000 check super early, if they can kind of wait the other options. 

Now, if they chose to exercise those options and start the long term capital gains process, yes, there would be cash out of the pocket. They'd actually have to write the company a check to cover that option exercise. So, and we'll come back to that for a second on how to write that check and how to fund it but so that's options. Easy, very quick, non-taxable and the other option is to just issue more restricted stock or founder shares to this person that you want to beef up their ownership and that can work really well except restrictive stock often has like a vesting clock and you're actually getting the shares or not exercising to get the shares and so that restrictive stock is actually oftentimes taxable. 

So the founder who's getting the extra shares and rebalancing upward is going to have a tax bill in that year for all the stuff that's vested. So that's kind of the negative to restricted stock and again, if you're doing this like two weeks after the founding of the company the restricted stock is going to be, you'll probably just use the par value, but two months, six months, a year after the company and there's significant progress made. That restricted stock's going to be pretty valuable and it's going to be a pretty big tax bill. So those are the two main mechanisms. Now, in terms of funding that option exercise. Sometimes we see companies grant a loan to the founder and the founder takes that money and then actually buys shares, exercise the options. And that can work except you just got to be wary of if the company goes down and that loan is forgiven. The forgiven piece of that loan becomes taxable income for the person who had the loan forgiven. 

So like anytime a loan is forgiven in the real world that's taxable income. That's how the IRS sees it. So the person could end up paying taxes on a loan that was for stock that went to zero, right? So you got to be really, really careful with any kind of loan at the startup level. You would only really want to do that at a later stage moment when you're very, very sure the company's not going to go down. The other kind of mechanism or approach we see people do, which I want to highlight, which can be potentially dangerous. Is the company buys some shares back from one of the founders and then reissues those shares to another one of the founders.

name: How to Rebalance Ownership Between Founders

snippet.title: Is it better for startups to pay vendors via credit card or check?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about a startup question, is it better for startups to pay a vendor via a check or credit card? Now, for the startup, it's always easier to pay via credit card. 

It's super convenient. You give them the number, they run the transaction. And if you use Brex, like what we like and we put companies on, then it integrates into QuickBooks super easy. And it's very easy for us, your accountant, to characterize the transaction. It actually does it automatically most the time because of our proprietary software. So we love it when startups pay via credit card. 

Now there's a lot of times where vendors, the person you're working with, doesn't want to accept credit card. And the reason why is... Credit cards have a pretty hefty fee. Usually it's about 3%, 2.5%, 3%. And they don't want to pay that. I don't blame them because that's a lot of money. It's a lot of margin to lose. So they want to be paid via check. 

Now, for us, the accountant, the worst solution is for you to actually write a check to that vendor. The reason why is we use Plaid to pull down tons of data from bank counts and integrate into our proprietary systems. And we do not get check images from Plaid. It doesn't have them. So we have to manually go into your bank accounts. Click the check image once the check is cashed and look and see who you wrote in your chicken scratch to on that check. So that is not a great solution for us, your accountant. But luckily there's something called Bill.com which is out there. And Bill.com does all this electronically and it's super easy to pay vendors via a check or it's more like an ACH, like a direct payment because Bill.com has a payment network where it connects to your vendors, gets their bank account on the other side and actually just does like a direct deposit into their bank account. 

And guess what? We don't have to log into your bank account and read your little chicken scratch on the image. Even better, Bill.com allows you to upload the invoice into Bill.com, which syncs into QuickBooks and matches the payment when that actually goes out. So the real question you should be asking as a startup is should I pay vendors via credit card or Bill.com because Bill.com is a superior solution to just writing a check. And in that situation we're pretty agnostic. But I do think credit cards are a little bit easier for people. 

So I would always lean towards the credit cards. But of course, if your vendor is not accepting the credit card because that fee most likely, then go ahead and just use Bill.com. We put all of our clients on Bill.com. It's super easy to use and you'll have a invoice record. You'll be able to pay your vendor electronically and your accounts will be very happy with you. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Is it better for startups to pay vendors via credit card or check?

snippet.title: What does an Outside General Counsel do?
snippet.description:
What does an Outside General Counsel do?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

I've been getting this question a lot more these days. I think most startup founder's executive teams are used to working with a big startup law firm to handle all their financings, the M&A for sure, but kind of lost in the shuffle a little bit is another service that law firms can provide which is just general counsel work and so I thought it would be interesting to take a second and I think oftentimes the outside or outsource general counsel firms typically are not like the huge big startup law firms that are handling your fundraising, that charge, you know at least a thousand dollars an hour kind of place.

We're like an outside accounting firm for tons of startups but because you're working with the companies for so many years and you know all their processes, oftentimes you built their processes, you really can do this in a very effective and efficient cost and lower cost way than hiring a full-time general counsel. 

So before, if I was a startup before I hired a full-time general counsel, I'd actually work with one of these outsourced or outside general counsel services and so, so some of the things they cover, you know contracts like customer contract, vendor contracts that's actually really, really helpful to have a legal experienced person be able to roll through those and make sure you don't sign a bad contract. They are working with a lot of different companies so they see kind of what's what's market, what companies should be signing up for and what not and so you can actually just ... Just this, just by not signing one bad contract per year you could effectively pay for the general, outside general counsel service, but just, there's a lot of stuff in there and also allows you to close deals a lot faster rather than, you know, either you, the founder, trying to, you know, pretend like you're a legal scholar and reading these contracts, which, you know you're going to put off and take a week to do or sending it to one of the big law firms and they're going to charge you a ton of money and make it a low priority 'cause they're focused on fundraising and M&A. So you can close deals a lot faster by having this service alongside of you. The other thing that ... Licensing agreements are very similar. 

Like if you're going to license your technology or in-license something, you really want to have someone read through this and really be paying attention and again, continuity is really important. The fact that they know your business, work with your business all the time, they know kind of those edge cases that you really need to worry about if you're signing a contract. Some other things, you know, around IP protection, like a lot of startups for even though they're building really cool intellectual property will kind of drag their feet or not protect their IP through patents or other types of mechanisms like copyright trademark. 

That's why people hire the big outside firms but really, you know, practically speaking, the outside general counsel can close those deals for you and also guide you through M&A, which is pretty exciting 'cause again, they know the company. And then there's a whole other component of compliance around board meetings, board resolutions, board minutes, documenting all the consents. That stuff is actually really important. You want to have a paper trail for everything discussed at your board meeting, 409A evaluations, stock option issuance, key decisions, documenting that the board has approved the financial plan for the year. 

It's actually a really helpful service. We have a firm that we work with that we love that does this for us, and they, over time, they just become part of your team and it's really powerful and you know, it also as a founder, you don't have to be the only one to interface with them as your team builds trust and as you build trust with this lawyer, you can actually start having, you know, your executive team reach out to them and guess what? That takes you out of a bottleneck position. It helps you get business done quicker. 

Also lightens your load a little bit and really that continuity and institutional knowledge is just so valuable to have in a lawyer on your side. So I hope this helps. Check out the, you know ... There's a bunch of outside general counsel services out there, and if you need some recs, just hit us up: kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks!

name: What does an Outside General Counsel do?

snippet.title: Startup trend: Replacing expense reports with credit cards
snippet.description:
Startup trend: Replacing expense reports with credit cards

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about why startups are using corporate credit cards instead of expense reports. 

And this is really a trend we've been seeing happening for a while. And, you know, it's one of those things where the convenience of the corporate credit card, especially the virtual cards, how you can spin them up really, really quickly is making it, so like, there's just a lot less transactions that need to go through an expense report. And so the use case we're seeing nowadays quite often is a company will sign up with a corporate credit card company and create virtual cards for their employees. And those cards will typically have a low limit. That's kind of one of the expense control/fraud controls that the companies are doing and we're encouraging them. So that way, you know, if someone abuses the credit card, it's not gonna be a huge mistake. And so it's just a little bit easier. 

Now there's some negatives with this, right? Like, you know, expense reports do have kind of a high degree of oversight. Like someone's actually checking the expense report, approving it, but that takes time. That's not as convenient. So there's this time convenience trade-off with, you know, oversight/fraud prevention that you're trading off by going with corporate credit cards. But generally speaking, we see this happening quite a bit. The other benefits are like, the employee doesn't have to wait for the reimbursement to hit their bank account, you know. Sometimes it takes like two or three weeks to get that expense report approved and then the money's got to be moved from the company's bank account to the employee's bank account. That disappears. There's no reimbursement needed. Which is kind of nice. 

Also, like I'm sure, you know, anyone listening to this has probably lost some receipts over the years or forgot to do expense reports. And that doesn't really happen with the corporate credit card anymore. So like sometimes like the employees are kind of like taking one for the team or losing some money by having to do expense reports and so they're avoiding that. One area we really do recommend expense reports is, when a founder has been paying for things out of their own pocket, their own personal credit card, usually before the company's raised money or, you know, before they have like a real business bank. That is something they should definitely file an expense report on, document that, get that on the balance sheet, get those in the income statement at the very least, even if you're not going to get paid back right away or reimbursed right away, at least that's on the balance sheet as a loan from the founder and you can get reimbursed when you raise more money down the road, but not doing an expense report there, means there's no documentation. 

The IRS's favorite thing to audit is transactions or money going back and forth between the founder and the company. So you just, you know, it's an audit risk, a huge audit risk. So I hope that helps. I mean, I guess the other benefit of doing the corporate credit cards versus the expense reports is a lot of the expense report software requires a subscription anywhere from like 8 to 16 bucks a month. And so you're avoiding that extra cost if you're just using the corporate credit cards. That being said, some corporate credit card platforms do charge a monthly fee, but most of them are free because they're making money on the interchange. 

They're basically making, whenever you buy something with a credit card, the issuing bank, and some of the other people in the chain actually make some money on interchange. And so that's the business model for a lot of the software is actually just making money on interchange. So I hope that helps. It's a pretty exciting place right now. We have Brex and Ramp growing really, really fast. Expensify has their virtual credit card. Now bill.com bought Divvy, because they know they need the credit card functionality. 

Airbase has come out and they're integrating with a lot of the big banks and big bank credit cards. So tons of activity in the space, but the core trend that we're highlighting here is just like people are just doing expense reports a lot less and they're relying on the corporate credit card to take care of that for them. 

Hope that helps if you have any questions or comments hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and we'll be there for you, thanks.

name: Startup trend: Replacing expense reports with credit cards

snippet.title: Venture Debt Scouting Report: Bridge Bank
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott, from Kruze Consulting, and today we're doing a venture debt scouting report on Bridge Bank. Now Bridge Bank has been a venture lender for a long time, but they used to be a much smaller bank. Recently they were acquired by a large bank, so their balance sheet is really big so they can do much bigger deals. They're very aggressive and definitely someone you want to talk to. Our representatives on the West Coast is Mike. Mike’s been around venture debt for a very long time, he's a great guy, and easy to work with so I definitely recommended talking to Mike. In terms of things you should think about, pros and cons for Bridge Bank. You know they have the same low cost of capital that most banks offer. They also do low warrant coverage. So it's a very affordable, easy to work with a solution. The one negative is typically they'll use a MAC clause or investor abandonment as part of the deal. Sometimes covenants as well. But you're usually gonna get that when you're doing a bank term sheet, so there's nothing abnormal. It's not a knockoff Bridge Bank, that's just how banks lend money to startups. So again, great team. We really like working with Mike. They've been around for a very long time. They have a much bigger balance sheet now. They're very affordable, with low warrant coverage and low-interest rates. And again, you do have to keep in mind the Material Adverse Change clause or investor abandonment, if that's in the deal. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Venture Debt Scouting Report: Bridge Bank

snippet.title: When should your startup make its first operations hire?
snippet.description:
When should your startup make its first operations hire?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

I vote for somewhere around employee number eight to ten. And I like to call this person, the Jack or Jill of all trades. So they should be able to do a lot of different things. They're typically not like a VP of operations type of person. This is typically someone with like, you know, three to five years experience in the working world. Who's hungry, willing to do a lot of different things, can think on their feet. And doesn't have a huge ego. The ego stuff's kind of important. I was talking to one of my friends and she pointed out like this person is not always well-liked, when they join the startup. 

Because even by like employee 10, there's a lot of bad habits that have happened inside of a startup. There's maybe the, you know, the financial infrastructure isn't great. Unless you're working with Kruze, of course. The operations or sales ops is not very good. There might be some facility problems. There might be like recruiting. It might be the company's been hiring their friends and not actually running like a real recruiting process. There are tons of things that need to be put in place or professionalized by the first operations hire. 

Sometimes this person is called like a Chief of Staff. Sometimes they're called an Admin. I prefer to call them like an Ops person. Whatever the title is, they're gonna have to do a lot of things. And the person who typically actually, you know, the founders at most early stage startups control the purse strings and, and kind of ironically, a lot of them are the slowest to hire or slowest to see that they should hire this operations person. 

But they're the ones who benefit the most. Because as a founder, you kind of start off as a one or two person team. You're doing everything. And the whole life of the company, you are shedding jobs, tasks, and giving it to other people who are specialized along the way and who can do it better than you. And so, you know, most of the people that hire us, they start off. They're just the CEO or founder. And what I like or I notice is on the accounting finance side, when the company gets to about 10 people, the founder has a lot more responsibilities. They're communicating with investors, they're doing a ton of recruiting. They are implementing the systems. 

Oftentimes they're a subject matter expert in the category they started the company in. Why else would someone fund them? They actually know what they're doing. And so they're spending a ton of time on product. And they start being less responsive across the board. And for us, as an accounting firm and tax firm, we need those, that feedback. We need the answers and we want to be there to answer your questions. And so we start seeing like a slow degradation in quality of feedback from the client or answers to the feedback. 

And that's why I love bringing this ops person at, you know, employee 10, say. Because they're gonna be the liaison with us, your accounting and tax firm as a startup. But they're also going to help on the recruiting front, quite a bit. Again, they're going to help you put in systems. Like, they may not be the person that puts in Salesforce or Pipedrive. But they're gonna be the point contact for the contractor who puts Salesforce in, right? There's a lot of like liaising in this position. And that might not sound sexy for someone who hasn't done it yet. 

But it's a way to learn the guts and how a company runs. Like you will learn every single aspect of the company in this role. And I think it's one of the most important roles in the whole company. And you also become a standard bearer or conveyor of the corporate culture. And sometimes people think like, oh, 10 team members, like, our culture is still forming. Our culture won't be determined till we're like, a 50 person company. The culture is determined almost like day one by the founders. But the operations person is someone that other team members, those other 10, 15, 20 in the early days, people who are not the founders can go to, to get resources, get something done, communicate with a founder if needed. They are a major part of your company culture. 

It will help you as a founder, take things off your plate, be more effective. You will accelerate in product. You'll accelerate in recruiting. Your financials will be so much stronger. Your board will be so much happier. It will be easier to raise money the next time around. There's a ton of benefits that maybe aren't as quantitative as you might think, but they're definitely qualitative.

name: When should your startup make its first operations hire?

snippet.title: What is an Orphaned VC Deal?
snippet.description:
What is an Orphaned VC Deal?

Raising venture capital? Get the finance and accounting due diligence checklist: https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-capital-finance-tax-hr-due-diligence-checklist

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm talking about orphaned VC deals. 

And I don't really like the term, I don't like that term, orphaned, it's not a positive term but this is what people call it so I figured I would make the video and we can all kind of agree that we need to come up with a better term for these types of deals. So essentially what it means is, the general partner, at the VC fund that led the investment into your startup has left their fund. And they are no longer, likely no longer on the board. 

But even more important, likely no longer an advocate inside the fund for your company. And so this puts you the startup founder, in a very awkward position because you're gonna get assigned a new partner at that fund. But deep down inside that new partner knows that they are not the ones who originated this deal and if things go great for your company, there's a little bit of self-interest here at work in that they know that they're not gonna get a ton of credit. 

And so what typically happens is, it's kind of sad but companies that have, that lose their partner, typically have a much harder time getting follow-on capital inside the partnership, getting those endorsements and really just kind of generally get less of the funds time. Now of course, there's exceptions to this. Like I think Square, the Khosla investment in Square the partner ended up leaving and they did fabulously well. So it's not like your company's gonna die right away or anything like that. You just need to know as a founder, that it's gonna be a little bit tougher and that extra money or the benefit of the doubt you may not get. 

And so this is important to know going into this because you wanna pick someone who's gonna be at the fund for the long haul. One of my most fun cheats on this is just figure out who owns the management company of the fund. The management company manages multiple funds at whatever firm. And typically there's a couple partners that own the management company. Everyone else is an employee of the management company and the fund. And so the people who own the management company, they are not going anywhere. It's very difficult to get rid of them. 

So it's really dangerous if you, a couple things, maybe you've got a partner who's just not doing great in their investments and the fund is getting ready to raise another fund and they asked that partner to step away. Also, another risk for you is maybe your partner is so good but they're junior and they're gonna leave to start their own fund. And so that means, probably you're helping them do that. You're part of their track record. 

But when that partner leaves, it's just gonna be life's gonna be a little bit more difficult for you inside. And so I think I recorded this because I really want founders to understand this dynamic. Choose wisely. It's really tough these days, because we're seeing fundraising rounds happen in the matter of weeks. Like it used to be a month or two months. 

Now it's like two weeks and people are signing term sheets. And especially with COVID, you don't have as much of a chance to get to know people, on a one-on-one basis and really figure out what makes them tick, how happy they are at their firm, what the rest of their portfolio looks like. 

And so really, founders, do diligence on the partners you're gonna be working with, ask them what their long-term plans are. Maybe kind of do a little back channel and figure out who controls the purses at the fund. That'll tell you a lot about your working relationship. And again, if your partner does leave and you are an orphaned deal, it's not the end of the world but you're just gonna have to work a little bit harder. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: What is an Orphaned VC Deal?

snippet.title: How to Handle a Co-Founder Departure
snippet.description:
How to Handle a Co-Founder Departure

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

I guess there are two differences. First of all, there's the amicable. And then there's the termination, this person needs to leave immediately kind of thing. So when it's amicable, definitely a lot easier and the person in the company that is leaving will work with you and ideally work with the board to make it a smooth transition. 

If it's a termination, then you know, you need to move fast. You need to do the typical stuff, like prepare their final paycheck, consult HR, document why they're being terminated, have the meeting with them. Definitely have a second person in that meeting so there's always two people. And you know, there's some other stuff we'll talk about, but that's the big stuff. Document everything, run their final paycheck, pay them for PTO, everything like that. Now in an amicable or maybe a full-fleshed way of talking about this, the other things you really want to think about are, first, how you're going to message this to the team. Because everyone that works at the company's committed to building the vision of these co-founders. 

The next thing you want to do is work out the equity. And most co-founders are on a four-year vest for founder's share. So very similar to stock options. VCs typically require a four-year vesting period. And it usually has a one-year cliff and then vest after that, after the one-year cliff, you vest the first year or first quarter of the founder stock package. And then you start vesting monthly after that. So if the founder's leaving and it's still very early in the company's life, odds are, they probably haven't eclipsed that one-year vest yet. And so you're not really having to part with any equity. So that's always good. If the founder has been there for a while and has passed that one-year cliff and has vested on a monthly basis, odds are, they own a decent amount of stock. And so obviously, the company is going to retain everything that wasn't vested, but in an effort to retain some of the stock that was vested, oftentimes the board, if it's a really promising company, will actually offer to buy some of that stock back or all the stock back. 

And sometimes the founder, the co-founder who's leaving likes to do that because they clearly don't believe in the vision or they're burned out, or it's a nice cash windfall for them and they could go on and do their next thing or maybe even fund their next thing. So I've seen that happen quite a bit. And sometimes for the board, especially if it's not like the key person, but maybe like the second person or third person who's a co-founder, but not critically important to the company, it can be opportunistic for the VCs, because they can you know, if the person is leaving anyways, they can buy some of that stock back. And ideally, the company goes on to bigger and greater things. So that's something that actually happens quite a bit. The other things you want to make sure you do is make sure you have an IP assignment clause, especially when it's an early stage company. 

If it's a later stage company or the founder has been there for a while, that's for sure going to be in place. I'm really talking about the super early stage companies where maybe the co-founder has been working there for six months, isn't passionate and is leaving, that IP assignment is critical. Because if the company doesn't own the IP that the co-founder has created, then there could be litigation down the road. So very, very important to sign that. Typically, not always, but sometimes you'll do a severance or something like that, where you'll make the landing a little softer for the co-founder who's leaving. In exchange for that, you typically ask for non-disclosure agreements and language that basically says the company can't be litigated in exchange for that cash payment. 

Typically in kind of a legal world, if someone's signing over rights, like their willingness not to sue and things like that down the road, they do need to receive compensation for that to be kind of a contract in the law's eyes. So paying that severance and getting those signatures on the non-disclosure and no litigation stuff is actually really helpful. And then I also talked about making sure you pay vacation, any reimbursements, that's just good practice for any employee who's leaving. But make sure you do that on the last day.

name: How to Handle a Co-Founder Departure

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, "How much flexibility does a startup's board have in setting the strike price for options?" And this is a question I get quite frequently, actually, 

so I thought I'd just make a video here. So the short answer is, the board has very little flexibility. So let me explain why. First of all, boards should be very wary of incurring liability or underpricing stock options only to have to reverse those pricing later on when the company's successful and goes through an audit. If a company under-prices their options and the auditors figure that out later, there's going to be what's called cheap stock charges, so like, actually hits to your profit and loss statement. Now, they're non-cash, but they do show up on the profit and loss statement. You often see this with like, companies that are doing an IPO. But you want to try to avoid it if possible. 

So you really want to stick with what the independent valuation provider gives you for the exercise price and that is known as a 409A evaluation. And the reason why the board has to worry about liability here is, the IRS actually instituted 409A valuations, a while back, probably like, I think it's probably been like 15 years, maybe 17 years. I remember when I was working in venture capital, everyone was up in arms about this because it was expensive to do, and everyone had just been kind of used to pricing every share at a penny and calling it a day. 

But what the IRS figured out is like the boards were systematically under pricing stock options. And an example for this is, say they price at a penny a share instead of whatever the fair market value might be like a dollar a share. And so when it's a penny share all the management team, they all exercise, pay the penny a share for all their shares, and then they own it at that point. And then every incremental increase in value is taxed at the capital gains tax rate which is usually around kind of, it depends and vacillates but it's like 20% is good proxy for that. Whereas like the ordinary income tax can be all the way up to like 35, 40%, right? And so there's a huge tax difference if you exercise early and treat everything as capital gains. 

So that's what everyone in the startup community was doing. And the IRS figured out that was costing them and the treasury quite a bit of money in tax revenue. And so they instituted the 409A requirement and they require it to be done by an accredited valuation provider. So your board can't just pretend to be a valuation firm that has accreditations and just price it. So you have to use a third party. It's actually really easy to do, the price has come down quite a bit. So I highly recommend doing that. So it's best just to be safe, avoid liability avoid cheap stock charges later on and don't mess around. Don't like, get the 409A price and then haircut it by 20%. You can't do that. You need the documentation. You need to be able to show that to the IRS that you actually have that independent third party. 

So be safe, be conservative, it'll pay off in the long run. So I hope that helps. And if you have any other questions on this hit us up at the Kruze Consulting 409A Valuation page. We have a pretty nice little page there with videos and explainers and I'm sure this video will land on that page at some point so check us out. Lots of good information there and on other stuff like accounting and taxes for startups. Thanks so much.

name: How Much Price Flexibility Does The Exercise Options Startup Have?

Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, what is the Bessemer Cloud Index? 

Well, this is one of the newer, cooler, stock market indexes, and big shout out to Bessemer Venture Partners who put this together. It's been a while. I think this has been going for like five or six years. But they are one of the early investors in cloud, SaaS companies. And they were very smart. They're like, "Hey, we believe in these kind of companies. Let's create an index to track the performance," and it becomes kind of this cool, self-fulfilling prophecy where every SaaS founder knows or wants to be in this index eventually when they're publicly traded. And so, hey, it's a good thing to do to talk to Bessemer and get them involved in your company, too. So great marketing, great job, Bessemer, for getting ahead on this. And I love the index. There's actually a really good website, cloudindex.bvp.com because they have really amazing charts. They show you all the companies that make up the index. They show the performance. 

And maybe most importantly for investors and people in the startup world, they show stats like forward revenue multiple. And a revenue multiple is basically like the value public market investors are paying for every dollar of revenue. So if you have $100 million in revenue and you have a 10x multiple, well, guess what, you're a billion dollar valuation. That's how the math works. And so I think one of the reasons I wanted to do a video on the cloud index was just so that people knew there is a pure-play way to look at SaaS company performance. And frankly, it's been a little ugly the last six months. The SaaS companies had a huge run up with COVID and the index reflects that performance. And over the last six months, it's down about 40%. So there's been a lot of pain in SaaS, but this is historically a pretty volatile subsector. 

When you compare like the SaaS performance down 40%, or the cloud index performance down 40% to NASDAQ. NASDAQ's only down 15% because there's a lot of really large companies, cashflow positive, very mature tech and growth companies in the NASDAQ. So this is a better pure-play measurement stick for the startup SaaS ecosystem. And that's why I pointed it out. So by the way, you can actually buy the Bessemer Cloud Index. You can buy an index and actually have it in your portfolio. There's a couple different tickers. EMCLOUD or WCLD are two ways to buy this. And so I actually own a little bit myself because it's a great way to get broad exposure across all the SaaS companies. 

So if you're a startup in the SaaS space, in the cloud space, and you're trying to figure out, what's the market like, what are the revenue multiples like, then this is a really great tool, because at the end of the day, venture capitalists are investing in companies in the early stages and in medium stages so that they can become late-stage startups, so they become IPOs and get publicly traded. So venture capitalists are always watching the performance in the equity markets to see how comparable companies are trading and what they're doing. 

And so if you're early stage and medium stage founder, always pays to keep your eye on the Bessemer Cloud Index. Hope that helps. If you have any questions on stock multiples or the SaaS market, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks.

name: What is The Bessemer Cloud Index?
