Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, how often should my startup have a board meeting? 

And this is a question we get quite a bit, because at Kruze we work with a lot of like C, series A, series B companies, and they're always trying to figure out, am I spending the right amount of time with my board? Am I over-indexing there? Is it time well spent? And from my perspective, I'm personally a every six weeks to eight weeks kind of person on board meetings. And you see some companies do it every four weeks but that's just like, the cycle is too fast. Like it's actually too hard to do board prep and have a substantial conversation because in a way not that much has changed every month. It is good to do a update email for your board every month. I highly recommend that as a way of keeping them engaged. 

But for the board meetings, I recommend every six to eight weeks and you know you could probably err towards the eight weeks. So that basically means you're doing, kind of, six board meetings, maybe seven board meetings a year. But I think it's really important to keep your board involved. You know, like founders scrutinize the venture capital firms and the VC's they take money from on the front end when they're taking money from them. But it's really important to stay connected to those people. They are working for the company. They're a fiduciary, they've got a lot of capital at place and the more connected they are the more likely they are to help the company and more likely to be there for the founder when things get tough. Like, startups are tough, bad things happen. It's a rocky road out there. Even the best companies have tough times. 

And so you really want your venture capital investors and board members to be behind you. And if they are getting frequent updates, know exactly the issues in the business, they can be there in those tough times. You can also use them opportunistically for positive things even when times aren't tough. Like helping you reel in that big final recruit that you're trying to get to complete your management team. Venture capitalists are great sales people. That's a key skill in that job. And so they're good at recruiting and they do that for their other portfolio companies. So they should be doing it for you. 

Another thing you can use them for is just the quick check in of like, am I a fundable company right now? As in, if I needed to raise capital right now do we have enough progress. Either revenue, customers, technology progress to be able to raise our next round. That's very helpful information for the management team. And remember, the venture capitalists are in the market all day long. They're talking to new companies all day long sourcing deals. So they have a very good pulse on the milestones required for a series A or a series B or even a series C and they will be able to give you direct feedback. 

And if there's a high degree of trust and you're very aligned they will give you very honest and direct feedback. So those are kind of two of the main reasons I love having consistent board meetings. Another kind of maybe reason that people don't always think about but it's a really great way to help develop the management team at a company. Because the executive team actually gets to, and this isn't every company, but I recommend it, letting the executive team report directly to the board for like a 15 minute segment in each board meeting. That way that executive team member actually preps their own update. They're thinking very closely about it. They're thinking about what they promised last time. 

And so there becomes this additional level of scrutiny but also opportunity for those executives. They can sharpen their presentation skills, know what's important to the venture capitalist, pick up some nuggets in that part of the conversation. So it's also just a great development opportunity for the startup management team and really that's what it's all about. Like the stronger the management team the better shot the company has of being successful.

name: How Often Should an Early-Stage Startup Board Meeting Happen?

snippet.title: What is an employer of record?
snippet.description:
What is an employer of record?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze consulting. And today we're talking about a term, "employer of record", That is really important in startup world right now, specifically because PEO's which are Professional Employer Organizations are becoming much, much more popular, mostly because of COVID with employees, you know, a lot of companies are finding their employees are moving throughout the country, even world, really, and that is necessitating a different approach to payroll and benefits and all that kind of stuff. 

So the employer of record is kind of self-evident, but basically the employees of the company are in a legal way working for the employer of record, which is a PEO in the case I'm talking about. So like TriNet, Justworks, Rippling has a PEO, ADP has a PEO. You think they're working for the startup, but they're actually contractually legally working for that PEO. 

And the reason this is, this exists is because the PEO can then pool employees across many different organizations after all, they are the employer of record, and negotiate better health benefits, perks, all that kind of stuff. And so that's why the employer, I keep saying employee, that's why the employer of record is so important. 

You just want to kind of know that, you know, if you are a company that uses TriNet, the W2 that the employee gets at the end of the year will actually be from TriNet, not your company. And this structure and legal contractual approach is what unlocked, you know, a lot of the things in the PEO industry, it was really kind of a legal arbitrage that's been embraced, it works really well. 

Tons of startups work with all those companies I mentioned. And again, their employer of record is actually the PEO firm, not the startup, but no big deal. Everyone's kind of used to it. And again, it's a way to maximize the amount of money or get the most bang for your buck on benefits. The PEO also helps with some of those state and local tax compliance. 

So it's a good approach overall, and it's just become more popular with COVID. So hope that helps. If you have any other questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thank you so much.

name: What is an employer of record?

snippet.title: What is the minimum Angel check to get pro rata rights?
snippet.description:
What is the minimum Angel check to get pro rata rights?

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're answering the question, what is the minimum check size to get pro rata rights in an angel investment? 

And this is a question we actually get quite a bit. And usually, I mean, and sometimes, founders will just give everyone who participates in the early rounds pro rata rights. Now, that's super nice of them but I wouldn't really recommend that. Instead, what we see most of the time is that there is a threshold for something called a "Major investor." And this is in the fundraising documents, and all major investors get pro rata rights going forward. 

Now, typically the threshold to become a major investor is $100,000 check size in angel seed deals. Now, it can be higher, it can be like 500K. It can be lower, it could be like 50K. But a $100,000 is typically the average, it's kind of what we see most of the time. 

Now you might be asking yourself, why do pro rata rights matter so much? Well, they actually matter because it allows you in the future if you have a really great company to keep putting more money in the company to protect your ownership position. So, say you own 1%, you're an angel investor, you own 1% in a great seed stage startup, and that becomes the next Uber or Facebook or something huge like that. Being able to protect your ownership and keep 1% of that company is incredibly valuable over time. 

Instead of being diluted down, you can just keep pumping money in and whether you need to beg or borrow or do whatever you need to get that check to invest in the next Facebook or Uber along the way, you're gonna do it. So that's why people care about pro rata rights so much. 

So again, 100K is typically the threshold where founders and the other investors will let someone have pro rata rights in the future. Hope that helps, thanks!

name: What is the minimum Angel check to get pro rata rights?

snippet.title: Top tip to close a seed round
snippet.description:
Top tip to close a seed round

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm sharing with you my number one top trick for closing your seed round. 

And guess what? It's as easy as using a convertible note, or SAFE note, and just changing the discount over time. And so what you want to do is start with a bigger discount to begin with, meaning the investors get a better deal if they put money in early, and you slowly move that discount down, which is more beneficial to the company. So there's a less of a discount, which means investors don't get as good of a deal. And so there's this massive incentive to invest early. 

You can also do this with the valuation cap. The discount, typically it's kind of 15% to 20% of whatever the next round is, but the valuation cap often takes precedent in those situations when there's a big up round. You can start the valuation cap low, which means a lower valuation for the investors, and then move it up over time as more investors come in. 

This really, really helps. It helps entice investors to put money in now or early, instead of waiting. I kind of, to borrow a basketball term, call it, "hanging around the hoop," like waiting to see who comes around, right? You want them to take a stand. 

If they love your company, they should be putting money in now, not waiting to see who else invests. And so this little trick actually will really help you close the round. Sometimes, managing investors is a little bit like herding cats. And if there's a monetary incentive to act early and act forcefully for investors, they will often take that. 

So hope this little trick helps. Best of luck. If you have any other questions on convertible debt, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com Thank you so much.

name: Top tip to close a seed round

snippet.title: How do VCs spend their time?
snippet.description:
How do VCs spend their time?

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt

Everyone thinks VCs just get to run around and invest in tons of companies and have the greatest job of all time, but they only get to do that for a small, actually, a pretty small percent of their time, maybe 20, 30%. There's a lot of other stuff they have to do. And the first thing is they have to fundraise for their own funds. And so a lot of times entrepreneurs don't realize that VCs have a similar relationship that they have to their VCs. The venture capitalists are kind of beholden or need to make their limited partners happy. 

Another thing you need to do which is probably maybe the bulk of the time is working with your portfolio companies. This is really what the best VC funds do, and the best partners. So of course you've got your board meetings every four to six weeks, sometimes every two months, but plan on doing a sizeable amount of board meetings with the company that you invested in. And there was a lot of prep before that board meeting. You're going to get the board packet a couple of days early. You're going to read through that and think about the questions. Sometimes there's like sub-committees like compensation committees, audit committees, things like that. 

Another thing you're gonna need to do is review the financial plan and do approvals. That's super, super important especially in December and January, that's usually when most companies are getting their plan approved. It's a pretty hefty board meeting. It usually takes a while because everyone wants to talk through revenue projections, expense projections and really layer on the milestones where the company's going qualitatively with the quantitative financial plan. Of course, another thing that this segues into is financing plan. Basically, when are you gonna raise money? Are you gonna raise another round next year? Are you gonna do venture debt? Are you cash flow positive? Are there other alternative fundraising options you can do? So there's a lot going on there, but fundraising and making sure the financial plan is fully baked and incredible is super, super important. 

Another thing that venture capitalists do is they do a lot of diligence calls on your company's behalf. When other VCs are gonna invest in your company, they wanna talk to the venture capitalists on the board. They wanna know the inside scoop. They wanna know what's going on. They wanna know how great is the entrepreneur. Are they really... Is the CEO really smart? Is she a great salesperson? Is she great quantitatively? Is she a great engineer? What makes that CEO special and their founders special? So there's a lot of diligence calls. They also do a lot of diligence calls the venture lenders as well. 

And then one of the final things kind of operationally they do for their portfolio companies is doing a lot of recruiting. Obviously, if you're gonna bring in like a VP level person or maybe a director level person, the venture capitalist is part of kind of wooing that person oftentimes, and also VC funds. A lot of them now have recruiting arms. So they'll actually do a lot of recruiting work for your company. Not necessarily the partner that's on the deal. They will do those diligence calls with potential hires that are especially big time people. But you can also leverage the VC firm's in-house recruiting team. That's actually a really great tool. So that's all the stuff they do for their portfolio companies. 

The final bucket that venture capitalist do, spend their time on is a lot of networking, writing, press, videos, whatever is their kind of shtick. I think probably 10 years ago, venture capitalists figured out that content marketing worked for them, too. And so they would do Fred Wilson's blog or Bill Gurley's blog or Mark Suster would do Snapchat all the time when Snapchat first came out. But there's just a lot of information and content that venture capitalists put out to help communicate with the market, help teach entrepreneurs. 

They also do a lot of press because they wanna... it's helpful to be in New York Times or CNBC. And so that's another aspect of their job. So we total all this up, you can see venture capitalists have a lot of responsibility. That's why they get the big bucks, but there's a lot of responsibility and a lot of time demands. And so, again, if you're an entrepreneur who's looking to talk to VCs and try to get in front of them and pitch them, a little bit of empathy will help because talking to you, potential entrepreneurs that they're gonna invest in is probably their favorite part of the whole job. And yet you can see they have all these responsibilities that make it a little bit difficult to allocate as much time as they want. 

So be patient and have a little empathy for the VCs and it should get you somewhere. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How do VCs spend their time?

snippet.title: How to payback COVID payroll tax deferrals
snippet.description:
How to payback COVID payroll tax deferrals

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

If you remember, take yourself back to March, April 2020. The federal government was doing everything they possibly could to help startups, small businesses survive COVID, it was a very scary time, I know we were scared. And so one of the things they made available to startups and small businesses in general, is you could delay paying or defer your payroll tax payments. And so, pretty much any business that runs payroll is gonna pay payroll taxes, you should be paying payroll taxes to the government. 

And so the government, you know, they were doing the right thing, they were making more cash available to startups that needed it. But, when we kinda looked at it, it wasn't like a grant or a forgivable loan like PPP, that was kind of a pure cash injection, it was a loan, you were basically deferring these payroll taxes, but you had to pay them back. And the schedule to pay them back was 50%, that was deferred in 2020, needs to be paid back in 2021 by the end of the year. And the other 50% had to be paid back by the end of the year 2022. So, it's not bad, it was a loan, it was a zero-cost loan, not a bad thing to do. 

Our concern at Kruze was, what happens if, heaven forbid, but a startup goes out of business. They had actually done the payroll tax deferrals. And the IRS and the federal government wants their money and the company's gone out of business. And so we were pretty cautious on encouraging companies to do this, because we didn't want the government to come back after those founders' personal money if the company had crashed. So that's the context behind the payroll tax deferral. But, guess what, we are in 2021, it is time to start paying back these payroll tax deferral loans. And so a lot of companies have been asking us, how do you do it? And this isn't something handled by your payroll provider, that you did make the selection inside of your payroll provider dashboard, but, they want you to pay the federal government directly. 

And so the way you do that, there's a system called EFTPS, which is like an electronic funds transfer network that the federal government has. And so you're actually gonna use that to pay the federal government. Now remember, you only have to pay 50% of it back in 2021 and 50% in 2022. So you're gonna log in, create an account, and you're actually gonna start sending them money. Now, some companies prefer to do this on a monthly basis, right, so that's it's not all hitting at the end of 2021. But other companies are preferring to just wait 'til late in December and actually just make their 50% payment then. However you do it, it's a good best practice to establish your account and actually know how it works and be able to fund it. You don't wanna be the people trying to pay this on December 31st, and not be able to figure your account and then not get the money in, and then have a big penalty. 

So you gotta be really careful about this. And so, just remember, you can actually pay it before it's due, so you don't have to wait until December, there's companies that we work with, not that many took this, but some of the ones that we did, they're just paying on a monthly basis. Also remember that the IRS is going to send you a statement every quarter for what you owe. And they kinda do it on a quarterly basis, like Q1 2020, Q2 2020. And so you may get actually four statements in the mail saying "Hey." This is if you deferred for all four quarters in 2020, you may get four statements, so just know. Also remember that when you do make payments, the IRS is going to apply those payments to the earliest deferral. So for example, say you make a bunch of payments now, until you fully pay back the 2021 obligation every payment is gonna go against the 2021 obligation. 

So, I just wanna make sure you kinda do the accounting in your head correctly, and you're not thinking you're paying back a portion of 2021, or 2020 evenly, it's all gonna go back to the 2020 allocation first, and then the 2021 obligation. So, I mean, those are the big mechanisms to do that. Remember you do need to establish an account at EFTPS.gov. You can't just like send a check to the IRS to do this, and again, your payroll provider will not make this payment for you. You need to do this, you need to go to that website, sign up, create an account, then follow their money transfer directions there.

name: How to payback COVID payroll tax deferrals

snippet.title: Distributing advisor shares for your startup
snippet.description:
Distributing advisor shares for your startup

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

It makes sense because there's a lot of people in the world who will just help your company out without even asking for shares. And then there's the people who definitely deserve advisor shares because they're helping out a ton. And then on the other side of the spectrum are the people who almost like make a living out of either trying to get a little bit of advisor shares and doing very little work or over promising what they can actually do and asking for a ton of advisor shares. So there's some different use cases there. So let's go over that real quick. So obviously, you know, if you build a network, if you're a good citizen, if you help other people out, you can actually get a lot of help without actually giving out shares in your company. I do think it's nice if someone's going to be consistently involved and committed over a long period of time, basically as an advisor actually give them some shares. 

So what I typically see is companies picking a few core advisors and giving out anything from like, you know, something like 25 basis points, which is 0.25% of the company. You might see them give out, do that for like three or four people. If there's someone out there who is like a just amazing mentor and has the connections, the Rolodex, the ability to make a round come together, you might give them something like 1% of the company. But you'd also want to vest that over four years and make sure they're continually working with the company. So not just like someone who's like almost like an investment banker, but someone who's a true advisor. Who's going to be a consigliere with the CEO for many, many years. Those are people that you're really kind of upping the ante. You're giving them like 1% of the company is a lot. So, you know, that's, they need to earn that. 

But those are typically people who you know, you have a relationship with, you trust and they're not going to just disappear on you. The nightmare scenario, there's kind of two, which is the, hey, it's almost like visualize the getting off the bus in Hollywood, 20 years ago, wanting to be famous and not really knowing who to trust or who not to. When you're a new entrepreneur, like you don't know always who's going to be a good mentor, who's going to be a good advisor and you'll run into people who will say something like, "Give me 5% of your company and I'll take care of all of the fundraising." 

And just have your, "if it's too good to be true meter" on and if it's too good to be true, it's probably not true meter should be going crazy at that moment when someone asks for a gigantic piece of your company and just says, "I'll take care of everything, don't worry." Right, alarm bells should be going off. Beware of these people. Someone who is that well-connected and is asking for that much of the company, will just write you a check. They will actually invest in the company, right? They'll be greedy that way, not greedy on getting free shares. If it was really that easy and they could just snap their fingers and make a round come together, they would invest. 

They would help lead the round, yada yada, yada. So beware of those people. I've actually been approached by those people in my past. Where they're professional salespeople and they're good at like, kind of going around the valley and getting a few newbies to sign up for that kind of stuff. So just be careful. The other area that I know, and this may conflict with what other people think. This is just me. But I also see entrepreneurs give out advisor shares to people who look great in a PowerPoint deck or a fundraising deck, but really aren't going to do much for the company. And they think that like, oh, I've got these names attached and maybe they'll get some sales for me or due diligence for a VC. It's a fallacy. 

Like if they're not engaged and they're not actually paying attention, I don't really believe in diluting yourself like that. I believe in, you know, say you're giving out a couple percent to 10 people and they're not actually, you can just kind of tell they're not really going to do anything, you're just putting them in the PowerPoint presentation. I would actually personally rather just sell 2% of equity, get the cash and hire a couple of people full time who are going to be really dedicated to the company. You see people, entrepreneurs, buying into like the, I've got superstars on my advisory board, even though everyone kind of knows they're not going to do a whole lot. It doesn't really help you that much. 

So my core advice circling back is, be focused.

name: Distributing advisor shares for your startup

snippet.title: VC Liquidation Preferences
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

Video Transcript:

Hi. It's Scott at Kruze Consulting. Today, we're talking about how do VC liquidation preferences actually work. For those who don't know, a liquidation preference gives a venture capitalist the right to get their money back before other shareholders. An example might be they might invest $5 million into a startup. That startup, when it gets sold, the VCs have a momentary decision where they can actually say I want my $5 million back, which means the investment effectively worked as a loan. They just got their capital back. Or they can convert and participate in all the upside along with the other shareholders. The liquidation preference is a great risk mitigation tool for VCs. When the company doesn't have a big exit but actually does generate some proceeds, it means the VCs get their money back, they haven't lost their capital, and they can live to play another day. Of course, if a company has a big exit, they convert and participate alongside everybody else. So it's a way of mitigating their downside while also preserving their upside. Liquidation preferences are found in almost every single deal a VC will do. Typically, they'll ask for 1x, one time their money. Sometimes when it's a real kind of tough situation or downside situation, they might ask for two or three times their money. That's pretty rare. Typically, you're going to see a 1x liquidation preference. Remember, what that does is that means the VCs can get their money back if the company has kind of a modest exit. On a big exit, they're always going to convert and play for the big upside. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: VC Liquidation Preferences

snippet.title: What Is a Co-Employer Relationship and What Are The Benefits for Employees?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn what a co-employer relationship is and what the benefits are for employees.

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about co-employment relationships. 

And this is essentially what you're signing up for when your startup starts working with a PEO, professional employer organization. But essentially, the co-employer relationship means that you essentially both have responsibility over these employees. There is a division of responsibilities but you're basically signing a contractual agreement with the PEO that they're going to handle specific stuff for you. So, the advantage of this is, as a management team, you get to focus on your business. You don't have to worry as much about like state and local taxes, the PEO will also do a lot of benefit price negotiations for you, but you do pay a sizable fee for this. 

So, there's some trade-offs here. It's important to note that the startup, the employer, is still responsible for managing the employees on a day-to-day basis. The PEO is not like going to do that for you, nor should, would you want them to out for you. But there's a pretty clear line of responsibility that you are in charge of, determining who you're going to hire at your startup, you're going to manage them on a day-to-day basis, that kind of stuff. So, the PEO goes about as far as you want it, because again, you do want to make those decisions for your company but it's not like a complete out, it's not like an abdication of responsibility, no matter how some people might position it. 

So, the benefits are, you don't have to worry about HR as much, they will take some of the burden off of you, they will do a lot of your state and local tax filings but there can be some negatives, especially if the PEO is not certified by the IRS to submit taxes and do taxes correctly. A startup can actually get in pretty serious trouble if their PEO is not submitting the taxes properly. This is like a baseline function of a PEO but not all PEOs are certified by the IRS. In fact, I remember a couple years ago, there was a major PEO that we worked with at Kruze a lot who was going through this process. and because of that, the R&D tax credit stuff was dramatically delayed. Thankfully they were certified, made everything a lot easier. 

They could submit all that stuff electronically and still be able to process all the tax credits and all that kind of stuff for the Kruze clients. So, just super, super important. This is actually like an official designation, certified PEO. So, if you're signing up with a PEO, you can either ask us and we'll tell you if they're certified or not, the big ones that we work with are all certified, or check their website, do some Google searches but just make sure if you're taking a chance on like a new PEO or a regional PEO that maybe the rest of the startup ecosystem doesn't work with, definitely make sure they are certified. You do not want to make that mistake. Say you pay your payroll taxes to the PEO and then the PEO does not relay those payroll taxes to the IRS or state agencies, your company is still responsible. 

So, that would be a massive problem, a massive amount of money you have to pay twice and massive penalties. So, just be really, really careful about that. One other really nice thing about working with a certified PEO is that, you can leave that PEO anytime during the year. If it's not a certified PEO and you're still filing on their EIN number, there can be a lot of messiness with trying to switch to just a regular like payroll and benefits company. So, that's kind of, the certified PEO is not about just submitting all your taxes correctly and things like that, but they have a higher standard that they have to provide to give you an off-ramp off the service and make it easier for you to do electronically. 

So, the co-employer relationship is very powerful, it's super helpful for a startup. We see a lot of startups doing that, over 35% of our startup clients at Kruze now use a PEO and a co-employer relationship. But important to know that you're working with a certified PEO and also know where the line stops, where you are still required to hire, manage, do all that kind of stuff for your employees. But they do provide a lot of additional support, which is nice. So that's it, that's it on PEOs. If you have any questions on that, check us out, we have tons of videos and stuff at kruzeconsulting.com. 

And, if you get a second, please subscribe to our YouTube channel. We put a lot of time, energy, and love into these videos and we'd appreciate the subscription. Thanks.

name: What Is a Co-Employer Relationship and What Are The Benefits for Employees?

snippet.title: 83B Election - What to file and when?
snippet.description:
83B Election - What to file and when?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, what is an 83B election, and how do you do it? 

Now the 83B election is a form that you send into the IRS telling the IRS that you are electing to buy your stock immediately, even if it hasn't all vested yet. And you're locking in a low tax basis. Therefore, all appreciation after you've filed that 83B, and after you bought that stock, is gonna be taxed at a capital gains rate, which is something like 20%, give or take. And so that's a really nice place to be. 

If your company IPOs someday, you're gonna have a really huge gain, and only having to pay capital gains tax is gonna be really nice for you. The alternative is forgetting to send in your 83B election form and having to pay income tax on the delta of appreciation every year as the stock vests. So if a stock goes up in value a ton after the first year or two, you're gonna have to pay income tax on that appreciation. And income tax rates are somewhere between 30 and 40%. 

So there's a really big delta there. You're talking about a lot the money, especially if your company gets bought or IPOs. So please fill out that 83B election form, and also send it into the IRS with certified mail. I always tell people sometimes the IRS gets a lot of mail. It's easy for things to get lost. So make sure you have proof that you sent that in. And remember you only have 30 days to actually elect an 83B so do it right away. Like the day your company is incorporated. Fill out that form, that your lawyer will give you to do it, Mail it in, do the certified mail, and get it off your plate. 

So you don't forget it. There're so many times where founders forget to do this. And it's really pretty much impossible to unwind. You're just not going to be able, to get that favorable tax treatment. So I highly recommend doing it right away. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: 83B Election - What to file and when?

snippet.title: Top 8 Ways Employees Steal Money from a Startup
snippet.description:
Top 8 Ways Employees Steal Money from a Startup

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

The first one is cash advances. Never let people have cash advance access to the bank account. You'll see this like $200 or $300 at a time kind of thing. This is why having virtual cards and issuing people credit cards is the right way to do things, but occasionally we'll see someone who let an employee go to the bank and take money out. Like do not ever let that happen.  

Another one that's really scary is they put their own wire information in instead of the customer's wire information. This is wire fraud. This is a federal crime, but people do it. People do sketchy stuff. So you gotta be really, really careful. Sometimes, this is a bad one, they will collaborate with a vendor to overbill a company and then take a kickback on the backend in cash. Super important, this is why you need to look at all the invoices you're paying, approve everything, have a second set of people approving invoices so that person can't just jack up an invoice and then take a kickback on the back end. Another, I wouldn't say favorite, just something we see, this is one of the more often ones is an employee paying their personal credit card with the company's funds. This is something we see quite a bit in very early stage companies. I'd say like one in one in 50, one in 70 companies, something like that. 

Another one, another favorite that we've found a couple of times recently, which is buying dinners or paying for hotel rooms on the company card. So like, you know, especially at a bigger startup, this stuff can kind of blend in, like it's harder to catch. It's harder to know exactly who, what was warranted. Maybe there was a conference and some one books, pays for an extra hotel room or they just do it out of the blue. Same thing with dinners. This is an area of theft. We've had a couple people at clients over the years go completely rogue and have like no conscience or they're not thinking even remotely correctly and will start buying clothes, jewelry, weird stuff like that. Do not let that happen. That's why check all your statements every month. That's why you checked QuickBooks. That's why you look at the general ledger. 

And so they've got the company's credit card in their Uber or Lyft account, and come weekend time, they're taking Uber or Lyft to go out with their friends and it accidentally hits the company's credit card. And again, I'm calling this unintentional. Maybe someone malicious could take advantage of this, but this is one where you really wanna coach your employees on switching the default credit card back to their personal credit card. Same thing goes for Amazon. Like a lot of companies, you know, a lot of companies used to buy a lot of office stuff from Costco. And Costco was kind of like a, you know, it was just a different relationship than Amazon. 

B
And so we're the ones saying hey, these transactions look weird. And this video was inspired by something that happened last week. I had this call last week with a client who, you know, allegedly, probably $60,000 was stolen from this client. And so if you have someone who has a second set of eyes on it, who's actually checking the stuff and knows what regular transaction volume looks like and what it's supposed to look like, it will really prevent you from experiencing fraud. The other thing is the employees know that someone else is looking at the books. If they just think it's you, and you're strapped for time, and you're running in a bunch of different directions, and maybe you're not an ace accountant, it might embolden them. So having the second set of eyes is really, really powerful. One more way is doing regular budget to actuals. 

So, budget to actuals, you take your financial model, and it should be on a monthly basis, and every month when we send you your financials, you or we, we offer the service, we paste them into the model and can show variances and show what's way over budget and what's way under budget. And so, and it's a service we offer at Kruze, but you can do this on your own, too. You do not have to work with us. It's very easy to do this on your own as well, but that's when you start seeing like big hops in meals and entertainment or office expenses or fraudulent vendors or things like that. That's where it's gonna really show up because you're gonna look at the last couple of months and be like, wow, how did my office expenses go up $10,000 this month? And it turns out someone bought a piece of jewelry with the company credit card, right? So budget to actuals are your friend. Budget to actuals are helpful in like, five different ways. You know what you're spending money on, you can communicate with your venture capitalists. They can get confidence from you, but like budget to actuals is a very baseline fraud prevention activity.

snippet.title: What Is the Social Security Tax, and Why Do Startups Pay More of It Early in the Year?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn what the Social Security Tax is and why startups pay more of it early in the year.

*******************************
Additional Resources

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dJf95pnOws8

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2ct0qLSyL0

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

#socialsecuritytax #startupsecuritytax #kruzeconsulting 

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about why a startup pays more in social security taxes, like payroll taxes early in the year than later in the year. And there's a really good reason for that and it's related to social security taxes. 

Now, social security taxes are actually officially known as OASDI taxes, that stands for Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance. So it's definitely a mouthful but the shorthand is social security taxes. And one thing about social security taxes is they actually cap out on the maximum taxable income. So, in 2021, if someone made over $142,800 after that the next dollar after that, there's no social security taxes, basically it's capped at a certain level. Now the limit in 2022 is gonna be $147,000. So, say you make $147,000 and one dollar. 

Well, that last dollar is not gonna be taxed for social security taxes. And so what you can imagine is, as a company kinda goes through the year and has a, you know, people are kind of making relatively the same amount of money throughout the year. People who are highly paid you know, engineer, sales people, folks like that who make more than this year, $147,000, they might eclipse that late in the year maybe like November, December, they're past that limit and therefore social security taxes are not gonna be taken out of their paycheck or the company's payroll and the dollar amount goes down. 

So this throws off a lot of our clients sometimes when they're looking at their payroll line items throughout the year and especially what happens is come January, some of those employees are now paying social security taxes, the company's paying social security taxes and all of a sudden the payroll taxes look a lot higher and it weirds them out. 

So I just want everyone to know if you have a lot of people who are high earners, engineer, sales people, folks like that. And at some point in the year, they're gonna pass the cap and not gonna have social security taxes taken out. Now, that's the gist of the answer. There is one other reason why social security taxes can go down and that's, if your startup does an R&D Tax Credit and we do tons of these at Kruze Consulting, you actually get the payroll tax offset assuming you fit the criteria. 

And so you actually may see times on your profit and loss statement where you're reading across where all of a sudden you weren't paying much in payroll taxes because of the R&D Tax Credit offset. And then all of a sudden you use up that entire R&D Tax Credit, and guess what? You're paying social security taxes again. So that's the other edge case and, you know, most Kruze clients actually do the R&D Tax Credit 'cause we're in the venture financing, super intense technology, research development type of industries. 

But the bigger more prevalent issue is just that the OASDI tax that are known as social security tax has been maxed out for a lot of the employees in the company on those employees. So hope that helps if you have any questions on payroll taxes on R&D Tax Credit or just plain accounting, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks so much.

name: What Is the Social Security Tax, and Why Do Startups Pay More of It Early in the Year?

snippet.title: Paying PTO if your startup is shutting down
snippet.description:
Paying PTO if your startup is shutting down

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm talking about the importance of paying PTO, if your startup is shutting down. 

And so really I'm talking to the management teams, and the board of directors, of startups that, you know, unfortunately are struggling and aren't going to make it. And this is a way of life in startup world. Like a lot of the, a lot of great companies don't make it, but they go on, the management teams go on and start another company. So it's important to shut down your company correctly, and take care of employees and avoid liability. And so that's why I'm making this video for you. So PTO is paid time off. 

In most states, it is required to, you know, in California, in New York, most states you have to pay PTO no matter what, even when the company is going down. And the important thing for startups to know is that you, as an executive team and the board, are fiduciaries, and you can actually be personally liable for the PTO, if you don't pay it. That means a employee who gets, you know, doesn't get their PTO payment can actually sue you personally, take you to court, win money plus penalties, plus court costs, and actually you have to pay it. So that is why it is so, so important to pay PTO costs. 

And so oftentimes this is actually the last trigger for a company to shut down. Everyone, you know, the board, and the management team is looking at the cash balance, knows the runway, but that PTO liability is out there, and everyone just kind of calls it a day. So I always kind of say like, if things are not looking good, and you've exhausted all your fundraising potential, and the board or insiders don't want to do a bridge round, then three months start thinking about this stuff. Most people have, you know, at least a month's worth of, or two weeks to a month worth of built up PTO. So it's going to be a decent sized check you have to write the employees. 

Now, you know, some folks say, well, hey, my company has unlimited PTO. Is this an issue? And with unlimited PTO, you actually don't have an ongoing liability. You've basically just told everyone they can take as much time off as they want. You don't track it. You don't have this liability. It sounds really good, but there are some downsides with unlimited PTO. I've done that in another video, you can check out, but the real thing I just want to drive home here is, budget for your PTO to be paid out, pay it out aggressively. 

Do not leave the employees hanging. It's a huge amount of liability for the management, and the board. It's also going to leave like a really negative feeling with the employees. And if you're going to start another company, you probably will work with some of the people that you're working with on this startup. Always think long-term always thinking of the future. Take care of the people. Pay the PTO, avoid liability. You'll be much happier. And if you have any questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Happy to answer your questions. Thanks.

name: Paying PTO if your startup is shutting down
