snippet.title: What’s behind the huge increase in VC requests for financials
snippet.description:
What’s behind the huge increase in VC requests for financials

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, we're covering what's behind the huge increase in financials requests from venture capitalists. 

This is something that we're seeing. It's pretty crazy right now like we're getting flooded. And what we're getting is VCs asking for both historicals, and a lot of scrutiny on the financial model of a company like the go forward projections. And this has always been a part of the due diligence for VCs. But, you know, I think what we see happening right now is the deal velocity in 2020 and 2021 was so high, as in so fast, that venture capitalists were doing cursory checks on the financials, but really kind of buying in to the company's story, and the vision a lot more. And now, with the NASDAQ declining and the VC funding market getting a little tougher we see venture capitalists really just digging in, and scrutinizing both how money was spent previously, and also what the future looks like. 

Overall, I think this is really healthy. It forces tougher conversations earlier in the relationship between founders and VCs. There was just a lot of like shotgun marriages happening because founders were picking VCs based on term sheets, and venture capitalists were using price as a weapon, or a negotiating tactic instead of getting to know the founders as well. And so, I think this is really going to help folks in the future, but it does mean that if you're a startup your financials need to be in good shape, your projections need to be in good shape, and you need to be able to talk through them. And a venture capitalist is going to ask you some questions. 

Now, again, remember especially when it comes to financial projections, VCs, they're not wanting you to be like a Goldman Sachs M&A analyst or something like that, who can model anything in Excel. They're looking for a way to talk through your story, and how you're going to spend money, and what the milestones are for your company. So it's more of a map than like a precise something that, you know, needs to be exactly right. Like it's got to be directionally correct. You need to be able to defend it. And you also need to be able to use it to give a venture capitalist a sense of where the company's going. 

So also, by the way, one of the other factors driving this is that in tough times, VC funds only have so many dollars to support existing companies. And so what we're seeing also is venture capital partners they feel like they owe it to their other partners to really dig in and do that diligence because whenever a venture capital firm, you know, a top tier firm makes a commitment, there's this implicit promise of support, AKA another check down the road. 

And so all the partners in a fund know that if they're doing new investments, they need to be allocating some extra money reserves down the line. We have another video on VC reserves but basically they need to make sure that the company they're investing in is not going to like blow through the cash and come back to the partnership in nine months, or 12 months, or something crazy short, and need more money. And so they owe it to each other. Not only do they owe it to the entrepreneur to make sure that's scrutinized and make sure the best decisions are made, but they owe it to the other partners inside the funds. 

So, again, I think this is a really positive trend, and it's really going to help companies long-term and help the VC funds long-term. But it is a shift, we're seeing it, and just be prepared, know that you're going to have a lot more scrutiny on your financials, and your projections going forward. Hope that helps, if you have other questions about fundraising, or venture capital, or financial models hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. 

And, if you don't mind, please subscribe to our YouTube channel, we really appreciate it. We put a lot of work into this and we'd love it if you checked out a few more videos, thanks.

name: What’s behind the huge increase in VC requests for financials

snippet.title: What is Revenue-Based Financing?
snippet.description:
What is Revenue-Based Financing?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about revenue-based loans. 

And so these are loans that the lender is underwriting your revenue flow, and also taking payments in return. They're returning their principal back out of your revenue. So there's a bunch of companies that do this. It's been actually like a pretty new space. Lighter Capital is one of the big firms in the venture capital-backed startup space that does this but it's been around for a long time. Typically, the lenders will take something like 3 to 6% of your monthly revenue back, and these loans usually get paid back over like three years. The expected IRR is anywhere from like 10% annually to 20% annually. So that's your cost of capital. 

When I say IRR, I'm talking about the lender's return. But really if you're a startup borrower, you're paying something like 10 to 20% interest on the loans. And again, these lenders are really underwriting the health of your business, and your burn rates, and things like that. But they're also very focused on revenue, specifically reoccurring revenue. They love SaaS businesses, they love businesses that have this reoccurring revenue flow so that they know over time, with a minimized churn, they can get paid back and make good money. 

And so that's the kind of startup they're looking to lend to. When I bring up churn, it reminds me, they often will have some covenants in there, and they'll actually underwrite based on your churn. So if you're growing and have a great reoccurring revenue stream, fantastic, you have access to capital through these revenue-based loans but if you have a high churn, they're actually going to bring the amount of money, like the advanced amount or advanced rate amount way, way down. 

So just know that. Churn's actually going to be a major metric for them that they're going to focus on. And these have been popular. I kind of find that they're less popular with VC-backed companies, merely because VC-backed companies usually raise a lot of money in equity, A, don't always need debt, but when they do need debt, they'll typically go more towards a bank, like Silicon Valley Bank or Bridge Bank, Comerica, or they'll go to a fund lender like WCI, TriplePoint, Hercules, some of those folks because when they have the VC backing, those lenders will underwrite not just the enterprise value of the company, but also how willing the VCs are to stick with the business, to write another check if things get tough, and so typically, their access to debt capital is actually a lot better than a company that's like maybe a bootstrap startup that hasn't raise venture capital yet. 

So in my world, I'm seeing a lot of the revenue loans going to companies that are pre-VC funding but have a little bit of traction or bootstrap companies that made the conscious decision not to raise any equity, or bootstrap/angel-funded companies that maybe raised a million or $2 million of angel funding, don't have a big institutional VC behind them though and are building to a milestone that will allow them to raise that big VC check. So again, once you have the VC money, there's a whole group of venture lenders that are available to you that often kind of make the revenue-based loans less attractive, especially at the IRR part of that. 

But they are a really good option for companies that are bootstrapping or raised a little bit of equity but not a ton, and can see a milestone right there in front of them, and once they hit that milestone, they'll be able to raise a bunch of money from VCs. So that's where we're seeing it, and it's a good asset category for your lender. 

And if you're a startup, it can really help fill a void when you're in that like, I call it the teenager phase, when you're a tweener, you're not quite ready to be VC-backed but you've got something much more than just an idea, a piece of paper. You've actually customers that are paying you. So check out revenue-based loans. Lighter Capital, there's some other folks out there that are doing this. 

And the space has really actually exploded, so there's a lot of options in this category. Hope that helps. If you have any other questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Happy to answer your questions on venture debt, revenue-based loans or anything else that affects your startup, accounting or taxes. Thanks.

name: What is Revenue-Based Financing?

snippet.title: 5 reasons eCommerce accounting is difficult
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

- The first thing that makes it hard is revenue accounting. Now revenue, most people think, oh, cash in cash out. No big deal. But actually you should be working off in an accrual method, but even if you're not doing a cash method, you need to look at your gross revenue, which is like all your sales, total sales. 

- The next aspect we're going to talk about is inventory accounting. Inventory accounting can be pretty, relatively easy or pretty hairy. So the first thing you need to think about with inventory is whether you're buying products already manufactured, already kind of ready to go, or if you're making or manufacturing them yourself. So let's go after the ones where you're buying from the manufacturer. That's relatively easy. You're getting the invoice for all the products you purchase, and you're going to need to track that somewhere. You're going to track it either in you know, not ideal, but you can use a Google sheet or there's some tools that plug into QuickBooks online that are pretty good that you can use, but you're going to track that entire list of products and how much it costs for each one of them. So that's how you do the basics of buying from a third party manufacturer. 

- Now let's talk about cost of goods sold. As we said, your inventory like the actual units you sold are one of the largest components into your cost of goods sold. 

- Third-party logistics providers will often charge you a storage fee and a shipping fee. Both those need to go into cost of goods sold. So again, you've got the inventory cost and the inventory cost can be calculated either based on the average cost of your inventory, or what's called last in first out, meaning LIFO, which means the oldest inventory gets sold next. And so you look at your sheet or look at your system and all the oldest inventory is what, the cost of those products actually get pushed to cost of goods sold. Those are the two kind of main ways. Then you're going to have the storage and distribution fees. Then you're going to have transaction processing costs like Stripe or Shopify fees. Those are, you know, Shopify is like the dominant eCommerce software platform right now. So you're going to see all those fees loaded in the cost of goods sold as well. Now we talked about 3PLs or third party logistics providers. 

- The last thing that makes eCommerce accounting difficult is just the high transaction volume. There is a lot going on, a lot of widgets going out the door, t-shirts, candles, whatever you're thinking, people are selling. And because the transaction velocity is a lot higher, there's a lot more that can go wrong. And so you wouldn't think about it 'cause it is a fairly straightforward transaction, but there's a lot of refunds and discounts that also need to be applied. So eCommerce companies in general, have a little bit more of a complicated accounting system than just your average startup. And you know, one final bonus thing to think about, this isn't in our top five list, but it probably should be, is you really want to be able to calculate your marketing expenditure, advertising expenditure on platforms like Google and Facebook and any other thing you're using for customer acquisition and be able to calculate an ROI on that. 

A lot of times people think of it in terms of customer acquisition cost and return on customer acquisition cost. So, typically VCs like to invest in companies that have something like a 3 to 5X multiple on customer acquisition costs. So you spend 50 bucks to get a customer. Ideally you're getting $250 of basically gross profit, not even just revenue, but gross profit. That is a huge winning combination if you're an investor and if you're running eCommerce platform, that's a great deal and something that someone's going to want to invest in. If your ratio is a lot lower, it might be hard to attract investment, you might have to move a little bit slower, bootstrap, maybe take on a little bit of debt, but that's something you really want to watch out for, and it really helps if you have a financial model to track that. 

At Kruze, we have a bunch of financial models for free on our website. You can just Google Kruze financial models, and those will help you figure out your customer acquisition costs and your multiple of return on customer acquisition. So I hope that helps, a lot going on in eCommerce. It's not an easy place to do accounting, but there's just a ton of growth there. 

Congratulations to all you entrepreneurs out there who are building great eCommerce companies. And please look us up at Kruze. We'd love to help you out. Thanks.

name: 5 reasons eCommerce accounting is difficult

snippet.title: Shopify Lets you Offer different payment methods
snippet.description:
Shopify Lets you Offer different payment methods

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about the payment methods accepted by Shopify. And for everyone who doesn't know, Shopify is kinda the go-to de facto e-commerce store software. 

So I think hundreds of thousands, if not millions of e-commerce providers actually use Shopify to host their store and sell anything they want to sell. And so it's really important, at Kruze, we have a pretty big focus on Shopify and the Shopify ecosystem for e-commerce clients. And so it's worth going through just the payment methods that work inside of Shopify. And the cool thing about Shopify is it's really just this big software platform. So there's even more payment methods than I'm covering right here. 

But I'm just going to go over the big ones just to help educate you and let you know what your options are. So the first one is just the Shopify payment or sometimes people call it ShopPay. But actually that is processed through Stripe. It's kind of a quiet secret but Stripe actually, which is a big payment processor, it's a startup, late-stage startup, actually does Shopify Pay or Shopify merchant channel. So that's nice. You have both the inherent credibility of Shopify and you know Stripe does tons of volume. It really knows what they're doing so your payments are gonna get processed in an accurate way. So that's kinda the first option. 

The second option is good old PayPal, which it feels like everyone has a PayPal account these days. It's been around for 25 years. It's been to go-to for sending your friends money, sending business people money. And so Shopify enables PayPal also, which is really nice. The third one to cover is Amazon. Amazon, Shopify in a way competes with Amazon but it feels like everyone has an Amazon account and so Shopify very smartly actually lets Amazon Payments sit on their platform, 'cause it just makes it easier for the end customer, the buyer to convert. 

And at the end of the day, all these payment options are there just to make sure that if someone's gonna buy something from your store, they're not locked into one payment option. They can use whatever is convenient for them. So Amazon's a really good option. Stripe, we talked about a little bit as powering the Shopify gateway but in geographies that Shopify does not have emerging gateway, you'll usually find Stripe. Stripe has more global coverage than Shopify. And so sometimes, you'll see that little Stripe button popping up as well if you're in a different geography. 

And then the final one to cover is a relatively new one called Affirm. Affirm is kinda like being able to make payments on a purchase instead of just buying it all upfront. So for example, maybe you buy a $1,000 piece of equipment from an e-commerce provider. And you don't quite have $1,000 or you wanna delay the payments a little bit, Affirm will let you do something like four payments of $250 or slightly more, like a little bit of extra in there just to make it worth it for Affirm and for Shopify and for the whole network. But basically, Affirm is pretty nice because it's one of the first options that lets you delay paying everything upfront. 

And I recently saw Affirm is gonna file for an IPO and do a big public offering. So they're legit. They've raised a ton of money and they have a lot of volume going over their network, too. 

So I hope that helps. The big ones again, Shopify, or ShopPay, which is powered by Stripe. PayPal, Amazon, and Stripe itself and then you've got Affirm. Those are big payment options for Shopify merchants. Hope that helps.

name: Shopify Lets you Offer different payment methods

snippet.title: Shopify Sales Channel Reporting
snippet.description:
Shopify Sales Channel Reporting

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about Shopify sales channel reporting. 

And basically, the cool thing about Shopify, which for those who don't know, it's kind of the go-to e-commerce store provider for hundreds of thousands, maybe millions of people who are selling e-commerce stuff over the internet. Shopify actually has a really cool reporting system that can let you see how much you've sold by channel. 

And this is important because there's some channels that are inherently organic, like Google. And there's some that are inherently paid like Instagram, Facebook, things like that. And so knowing where your customers are coming from and what they're actually buying and how much they're buying is really important, because that cycles back into what you wanna pay on a customer acquisition cost, what you're gonna pay for advertising to get those customers to your site. 

And so this is just a partial list, but you've got the Google report, you've got Instagram, you've got Facebook, you have Facebook stores, you have Amazon, Pinterest and you even have the Walmart marketplace. So those are, if you kind of think about those are like the big traffic centers for online shopping. 

And so Shopify, by virtue of having this report can really help its e-commerce store providers really be smart about where they're gonna spend money, what kind of customers are coming to them and really just optimize their store for conversion. And so we do a ton of stuff at Kruze with e-commerce companies and pretty much all of them use Shopify. And so this is just one of our favorite parts. 

And so I wanted everyone to know about it because again, the smarter you are about your spend and the better you are about conversion, the more you can spend and you get that really nice flywheel going and you can build a really big e-commerce business. So I hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Shopify Sales Channel Reporting

snippet.title: How to Breakout Shopify Fees for Accurate Financials
snippet.description:
How to Breakout Shopify Fees for Accurate Financials

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm gonna explain how to break out your Shopify fees for accurate financials. 

So, Shopify is the e-commerce software platform of choice. Everyone's flocking to Shopify to host their store and make all their transactions really easy. In the old days, you'd hack together a website to try to sell something or have to pay a million dollars for a piece of software to do e-commerce but nowadays, Shopify have a really accessible price point. It's really easy to use and there's, I think hundreds of thousands of stores on Shopify. So it really makes a difference to know how to actually treat the information you're getting from Shopify in your accounting system. 

And so let's walk through this here. So first, the people who are buying, the end customer, they don't really see the fees. It's transparent to them. They just are happy to go to a website, find a pair of shoes or a necklace or whatever it is they like, purchase it and use one of the very easy payment options and boom, they're done. And they know that it's gonna get shipped to them and they can track that. So for the end customer, Shopify is really amazing. 

Now, for the vendor, for the person that owns the e-commerce site, it's actually really amazing too, but there are a couple fees you have to pay when you use Shopify. So the first one is called basically like a platform fee. It's just like the cost of using Shopify. But then when you're doing e-commerce and you're actually shipping things, there's a second fee. It's called a shipping fee. And so both of these actually technically should be in cost of goods sold, but the way it automatically comes into QuickBooks it's just like one big bundle of fees. You can't actually split them out natively or easily in QuickBooks. You actually need some more information. 

Now, luckily, Shopify provides an invoice, so you can actually see the itemized platform fees and shipping fees in your account for every month. And so what a good accountant would do, like us at Kruze, is we go into that invoice and we actually break out the platform fees. That's one line item in cost of goods sold. That's like the software cost to host your store. And then we break out the second line item, which is shipping fees. 

Now, those two different sets of fees are gonna go totally different ways. They're gonna be different and so that's why you want to break them out. You wanna know this because you'll actually have a better view on your gross margin. You'll know if you should be some day, somewhere start using a new shopping platform because it's cheaper or easier or if the shipping fees are just eating into your profits so badly that you're gonna have to find another shipping option. 

So having that visibility on gross margin is really important. And we're very thankful that Shopify does provide that invoice because it allows the Kruze Consulting accountants to deliver really nice accurate financials for the e-commerce customers. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How to Breakout Shopify Fees for Accurate Financials

snippet.title: How to read an Income Statement
snippet.description:
How to read an Income Statement

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

You wanna manage your company in a really smart way. This is like the barometer of your company, it's maybe one of the most important things besides just the number, which is the cash in the bank. Like that's probably number one, how to read Income Statement, number two. So you're gonna start off with revenue. 

And maybe the simplest way to say this is just, revenue is widgets times the price of the widget. So if you're selling a software license, you sell one license, you charge 100 bucks, that means you generate $100 worth of revenue. That is the top line, as a lot of people refer to it. 

The next line item in an income statement is your cost of goods sold. Now, this is all the costs associated with delivering your service or selling your widget. So for online businesses, like SaaS companies, it typically has things like your hosting costs, and your customer support costs and all the little things that go into actually developing and delivering your product. 

For E-commerce providers, typically, it's whatever you're buying your inventory for, and sometimes like shipping charges and things like that, or 3PL charges. But basically the cost of delivering your widget or your service. 

Now you're gonna subtract that from revenue. And this gives you gross margin. So you often hear venture capitalists and founders talking about how it's better to run or invest in a high gross margin business. Because that means you have a lot more cash, a lot more margin to work with from your income statement. It allows you to invest more money in the next group of expense categories, which are called your operating expenses. 

The next category is General Administrative Expenses, G&A. Now this is like the overhead, this is where your accountant goes and maybe your lawyer goes. Anything that's kind of like just typical business overhead will go in General and Administrative Expenses. So you take all three of those R&D, sales and marketing, G&A. Those are your operating expenses. You're gonna add them all together, and you're gonna subtract your operating expenses from your gross margin, or gross profit, some people call it. This will give you your operating profit. 

Now, this is all, it's almost like your net profit. This is almost what your take home is. This is a really good barometer for the company. Sometimes you'll hear the term EBITDA thrown around, which is basically just your operating profit. And you're gonna add back depreciation amortization. But this is the benchmark for most companies, especially more mature companies. Banks will look at this to make sure there's enough operating profit in the company before they wanna make a loan. 

The next line items are interest expenses or interest income. So if you have a lot of money in the bank and you're getting a good interest rate, you can generate interest income. A lot of companies that have debt, they're actually paying interest expenses here. And then other income, maybe other kind of weird things that pop in, will be here. And you're gonna subtract them or add them if it's a interest gained into the operating income. And you're gonna get to net income. This is your net profit. This is pretty much what you get to take home. We'll talk about the cash flow statement and adjustments to net income a little bit later. But this is the core barometer of your company. This is what bankers really like to look at. 'Cause you might be producing a really good operating income but have huge interest expenses, which eat up your whole operating income. 

So net profit, just think about it as like your take home, what the company is actually producing for all the work. And that's at the bottom of the income statement. So again, from all the way from the top to the bottom, you've got revenue, you subtract from revenue, your cost of goods sold. That gets you the gross margin or gross profit, Then you're gonna subtract research and development, sales and marketing, General Administrative, those are your operating expenses. You get down to operating income, and then you're to subtract interest expenses or other expenses. And you'll get to net profit. 

And your net profit is gonna feed in to both your balance sheet and your cash flow statement. We'll talk about that in other videos. But really, it's kind of the bottom line. It's what the company is really producing. 

Now, I hope this little exploration of how to read income statements has been helpful. And again, founders, entrepreneurs, it is so important that you learn how to do this. So we will produce more content and help you learn how to read these in even more depth. I hope that helps, thanks.

name: How to read an Income Statement

snippet.title: How to Finance Your Ecommerce Company
snippet.description:
How to Finance Your Ecommerce Company

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

eCommerce companies are pretty interesting because there's actually a wide range of options. If you're building like a software company or a hardware company, you're gonna kind of default to venture capital investment because it's so capital intensive. But for eCommerce companies, you can actually get up and running pretty quickly and actually produce a positive, gross margin, positive net margin. So, the first option for how to finance your eCommerce company is bootstrapping. Like, do it yourself and have your customers finance you. 

But I think bootstrapping, especially if you're just kinda coming out of the box with a new concept. I think that's a really good way of financing your eCommerce company at first. So that's number one. Number two, would be actual venture capital investment. And, you know, eCommerce was a venture capital darling for a long time. And then it went through kind of a little bit of a trough where it was actually hard to get eCommerce companies financed. And then COVID hit and everything changed. And everyone wanted to buy things through the internet, drop shipping was made available in a much easier way. And all of a sudden now eCommerce companies and brand companies that just go direct, are exploding. And venture capitalists are writing huge checks to those companies because their metrics look great. They've kind of realized that maybe eCommerce adoption was dramatically accelerated by COVID. 

So VCs will write you those checks and I think venture capitalists like eCommerce but they especially like it when it's around branded products. Like where the company isn't just the distribution channel like Amazon, eBay, you know, those kinda things. That's old, kind of old school, but has a brand that the market recognizes people, admire, want to own their products. And can use things like Shopify or big commerce to actually power the website and power the eCommerce operations. 

The third option is banks. Banks will actually lend you money. And, there's two kinds of banks. There's banks for if you're bootstrapped. And those, you know, those are more of a personal loan like the bank will loan money to your startup but they'll typically ask you to do a personal guarantee. Which means you're on the hook if the company doesn't succeed, you have to pay that loan back no matter what. The second kind of loan is, what's called venture debt for, for companies that have raised venture capital and they are making a bet on the company, a bet on the VCs. 

If you raise VC money, you're not going to need to do a personal guarantee. But you know, banks that are requiring personal guarantees they will actually fund quite a bit. Like they'll look at your assets and look at your track record and your credit scores and things like that. But they're also really going to take into account the fundamentals of the business. And so that's a great option, especially if you're bootstrapping through a big growth spurt. 

And now they're, you know, we have clients that are 5 to 10 times bigger than they were before COVID. And all of that inventory has been sold and the margin's been captured and now they've been paying back their lenders and some of them don't even have debt anymore. So, it was kind of a one-time thing. But bank debt is a good option for you. The fourth option is what I'll call kind of more aggressive debt. So that's the kind of debt that like Shopify Capital or Stripe Capital or Fundbox. Or there's, you know, 10 types of, 10 lenders like this that are doing kind of online - Kabbage is another one, online lending. They will do advances, but they are looking... If you're a small business that hasn't raised VC money, they are looking for personal guarantees. These platforms have the advantage of being able to see your exact sales. 

So just know that's more expensive debt. So that's one reason people like banks, banks tend to be cheap. They leverage that personal guarantee to give you money at 4, 5, 6%, versus that 15% from non-bank lenders. It's all about their cost of capital and these have a very, very cheap cost of capital because they rely on deposits for the cost of capital. So I hope that helps. You've got five choices. All of them are good. They're all gonna be, you know, for different scenarios or different situations your eCommerce is in, the company's in. And you know what? You may actually, you may start off bootstrapping. And then you may raise some venture capital and then you may raise some bank debt.

name: How to Finance Your Ecommerce Company

snippet.title: How do eCommerce companies manage their inventory?
snippet.description:
How do eCommerce companies manage their inventory?

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, how do eCommerce companies manage their inventory? 

And really there's kinda two key ways. The first is like the old school, been done for hundreds and hundreds of years which is, own or rent your own warehouses, handle, have all the product, all the inventory delivered there and have your own warehouse team actually managing it, tracking it, signing it out, signing it in, or these days scanning it in, scanning out when it gets shipped. That is the age-old way. And for companies that are getting pretty big that's actually a good way of doing it. 'Cause you can kind of capture economies of scale, you know what's going on. But if you think about it there's a lot of hassles inherent in that. Like you've got to actually rent or buy warehouse space which probably is not like one of the things you're the best at as a company, if you're an eCommerce company. And then you've got to hire all the staff and spend a lot of money. And you gotta buy a lot of software to manage all the inventory. 

So there's a lot of costs associated with managing your warehouse. And so third-party logistics providers, 3PLs for short, have emerged. And probably the most famous is really Amazon. Amazon has a huge amount of warehouses across the country. And a lot of eCommerce companies that sell on Amazon actually have their inventory sitting in Amazon's warehouses that also helps with Prime and One-Day Delivery and things like that. And Shopify is working on something similar. So those are... Amazon, it's probably the one that comes to mind but there are a huge amount of 3PLs out there that have emerged because eCommerce has become just a gigantic category, and Amazon charges a lot. And a lot of people who sell online don't wanna sell through Amazon or don't want Amazon to have the full picture of what's going on for fear of competitive problems or replicating the goods. 

And so there's a lot of independent third-party logistics providers out there who will charge you essentially like a markup or a fee per unit that you're actually storing with them and that they sell, they handle and they help get it into the shipping and get it out to the customer. So I'm actually a pretty big fan of third-party logistics providers because they let you as an owner or founder of an eCommerce company, focus on what you're really good at. There's very few eCommerce founders who are amazing at logistics. They'd be just in a different business. 

And again, there are a lot of capital expenditures like a lot of money up front to actually have a working warehouse on your own. So that's why this has become super valuable. And one other benefit of 3PLs is you can actually get pretty good data feeds as an accountant for what's actually going out the door and what's getting sold. And that makes the accounting so much easier for us, Kruze Consulting. We do a ton of eCommerce companies and we love those data feeds. We love easy reporting. It makes accounting for the inventory so much easier. And you know, while I'm on this topic, let's talk really quickly about like the difference between if you're assembling inventory or a bill of materials in your warehouse versus buying it directly and having a third-party logistics provider handle it. Like that's been one of the really exciting things that's happened in the last five years or so maybe 10 years is a lot of startups, eCommerce companies have been buying directly from contract manufacturers. And so in the accounting world that's like one line item per good. And it's really easy to account for on cost of goods sold. It becomes a real pain when you are buying raw materials, assembling that raw materials into a finished good. 

And you have to track all of that on a monthly basis on inventory worksheets and actually get to a cost of goods sold per unit. So again, it's the same trend as third-party logistics providers. It's so nice to work with a contract manufacturer who could prepare your stuff, have it, sent to you complete that makes the accounting way, way easier. So probably the common theme you're seeing or hearing from what I'm talking about here is focus on what you're good at, which is typically brand, typically customer acquisition, typically product. And you can outsource a lot of the inventory management and also inventory production if you're an eCommerce company. So if you have any questions on this, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and we will answer your questions. Thanks.

name: How do eCommerce companies manage their inventory?

snippet.title: How to allocate Pro-Rata correctly on Convertible Notes done in between Priced Rounds?
snippet.description:
How to allocate Pro-Rata correctly on Convertible Notes done in between Priced Rounds?

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $5.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Priced rounds are your traditional series A, series B. There's a price per share, it's a preferred price. Liquidation preferences, et cetera. Convertible notes are typically used as an interim financing tool that don't set a valuation, but typically have a cap, which is kind of a valuation that everyone agrees things will convert at if things are going well. And, so, you see convertible notes being used in between rounds as a bridge round, or a bridge note, or something just kind of quick and dirty, because an investor might come into a company and really wanna do that investment. And, the investors say like, "Hey, we're not doing a full fledged fundraising round right now, but we'll take a few million dollars 'cause that'll be helpful to us too." 

And, so, you really need to think about if you're taking this money in a convertible note, or SAFE note, this applies for SAFE notes too, you really need to think about the pro-rata allocations. And, so, pro-rata is an investor right, where investors get to always protect their investment percentage, or ownership percentage, going forward. So, if an investor owns 20% and new money's coming into the company, depending on the valuation, they actually get to put a little bit more money into the company if they have pro-rata rights, to maintain that 20% ownership going forward. And, so, founders are the ones who always experience the dilution, the venture capitalists can always put more money in to protect their ownership percentage. And, you've seen many of them doing that, especially in really great companies, like the VC's wanna protect their pro-rata ownership like crazy 'cause this is a winner, this is gonna make them a ton of money, and it's probably gonna still be a great investment for them. 

There're two things happening. The first is how much of the new convertible notes should each investor do, or get to do? And, so, this is actually a pretty simple one in that you're gonna look at the cap table, and everyone has their ownership allocations already, and, so, it's very easy to see. Like in Carta, or your lawyer spreadsheet, whatever you're using for cap table software. And, so, the company will actually split the convertible note, or safe note, up according to the percentage ownership that all the investors already hold. And, so, you can imagine if it's a $5 million convertible note, or safe note, then whoever owns 20% of the company is gonna get to put it in $1 million. 

Now, this can be a little bit complicated because often times the founders won't be able to protect their own ownership through a convertible note. So, it's typically going to default to the preferred ownership levels. But, again, this is one that's not so hard. You can actually just look at the cap table and make the allocations accordingly. 

Now, the second part of this question is what does the pro-rata on the next round look like after you factor in the participation in the convert? And, so, what's happening here is a lot of investors are happy to do that bridge round, or in between financing, or they're getting greedy and want to preemptively put money in. They're happy to do it, but a lot of them, especially in the situations that aren't like the greatest, like the company is doing okay, but not on fire, kicking butt. They will want this investment in the convert to be credited against the amount of pro-rata they would have been doing when the full round comes in. 

Now, of course, venture capitalists are very good at sensing a company doing well, and very good at talking their way into putting more money into this company and getting more ownership. So, that's a happy situation, when your VC's are demanding / asking very politely to put more money into the company. That means things are going well and they sense an opportunity. But, it's also important to plan for when things aren't going great. And, that's where this million dollars now going to convertible note, million dollars going in later when the full round closes. So, just know your venture capitalists don't, you know, they do reserve. They don't have an inexhaustible amount of money to continue to support the company. If the company's a rocket ship and gonna do an IPO, they'll find a way. If the company is doing well, but not a superstar, they're only gonna be able to allocate a certain amount of capital going forward. So, if you do have that early ask on a convertible note, or a SAFE note, asking them to do a bridge, or in between financing, just know that you're starting to deplete their reserve for your company.

name: How to allocate Pro-Rata correctly on Convertible Notes done in between Priced Rounds?

snippet.title: What Happens To a Convertible Note Term Sheet If a Startup Defaults ?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn what happens to a convertible note term sheet if a startup defaults.

00:00 Introduction
00:11 Startup convertible note
01:01 Angel investor can do
02:15 Impact of default convertible note explained
03:51 Conclusion

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts #convertiblenote #convertiblenotetermsheet

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn of Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, what happens if a startup defaults on a convertible note? 

So a lot of startup founders use convertible notes to raise money. The convertible note is basically a debt instrument where it's usually good for 18 to 24 months, then it needs to be paid back. And usually, there's a valuation cap, which kind of functions as like the conversion number, so when people put money in, that's usually their effective valuation, assuming the company raised more money later at a higher valuation. So that's convertible notes. And they are debt, and so it's interesting because this question is exactly why SAFE notes were created by Y Combinator and some of the leading Silicon Valley law firms. Basically, once in a while Y Combinator saw convertible notes being abused by angel investors and demanding their money back. 

Now, what's interesting is you can be an angel investor, you invest in a startup, in a convertible note, the company's going to spend the money. They're going to build their software, or their solution, or help the drug development, whatever they're doing, and actually spend that money. And so, say the company hasn't raised more money, so the debt doesn't automatically convert, and you, Mr. and Mrs. Angel Investor ask for your money back. Well, there's no money to pay you. The money's been spent. 

So there's kind of like the practical aspect of this, which is the company's out of money anyways, and there's not much that can happen, but there is, sometimes there's value in the company. Either it's going to get bought or sold, or it's on the verge of raising more money, but the angel investors are using the note terms to pressure and try to get more money back. And so they can do that. If you are a creditor and you can find, I think it's two or three other creditors that have not been paid back in a respectful amount of time, you can petition to try to put a company into bankruptcy, but there's a whole process with that. 

So that's like the super extreme version of what could happen if there's a bunch of notes, and maybe the lawyer's not paid, and the water person's not paid, and the gardener, and maybe some of the software developers aren't paid, then all those creditors together can petition to put a company in bankruptcy. But more practically speaking, what happens is the angel investors will kind of try to get their money back, threaten a lot, but whenever this usually happens, usually the company's kind of run out of money already and so there's nothing to give back. 

I should say that 99% of angel investors and seed funds will just extend the notes. So you get your kind of 18 to 24 month typical note time period, and if the company's making progress and it's not going to get liquidated, isn't going to go bankrupt, and good things are happening, the founders usually just go back to the investors and say, "Hey, can you extend this another year or another six months? I need a little bit more time to close a fundraising and then your notes will auto-convert." So it is a very tiny problem abused. This leverage created by notes abused by like, not even 1% probably, but it does happen, and so that was one of the main things that YC and some of the law firms were trying to address with SAFE notes. SAFE notes are not debt, they are equity. 

There are some clauses in them now where they say like, you got to pay the investors back first, but there's no kind of trigger. There's no term that says this has to be paid back on a certain date like there is in a convertible note.

name: What Happens To a Convertible Note Term Sheet If a Startup Defaults ?

snippet.title: What is the Value of Pre-seed Venture Capital Funds?
snippet.description: The first thing that pre-seed funds do is they set the terms and actually price a deal at the really early stage. This is incredibly valuable, because angel investors at that stage, feel so much more comfortable coming into the deal and following a named institutional VC fund.  And so, one of the core services a pre-seed fund is doing is just giving you a term sheet with their name on it, and they're signing their name. And so, you could take that term sheet and fill out the rest of the round. The next thing they do, is they get you thinking like a VC-backed company. It's a huge shift from being bootstrapped or just a super scrappy, three ladies in a garage type of startup. When you take professional money, you have to start doing certain things. You need to have real board meetings. You need to be metrics-driven, instead of just going with your gut so much. The pre-seed fund really helps you make that shift. And they do it kind of in a lower stakes environment than trying to do that after you've taken a 20 million dollar round and learning on the fly. So, it's a great training ground for thinking like a VC-backed company. They make recruiting so much easier for you, because you have some incredible logos. Then you can put on your website that people recognize. And when employees are taking a job at your company, they're really betting their capital, like their time. They're gonna be working for you and spending a lot of time on your company. And so, knowing that some bigger players, some institutional players are behind you really makes recruiting a lot easier. It's the same thing with customers. Now, for small deals customers don't really care who the backers are. But, when they're signing a multi hundred thousand dollar or a multimillion dollar deal with your startup, it really helps to have some institutional VCs that they can reference, that are on your website, and that they have confidence that will help get the company funded. If they're signing up to use your service, they don't want it to go away in six months 'cause you ran out of money. So, that's gonna be very important to them.  Now, another huge benefit of pre-seed funds is that, Seed and Series A funds, follow them like crazy. There's the old speed dial. And those funds all wanna see the best deals coming out of the pre-seed fund. That's kind of like their  minor leagues relative to the major leagues. They're looking for the hot prospect who's really up and coming. And that's where they find them. So, they're really gonna trust the general partners of the pre-seed fund. And when the general partners send them an email, and say, hey, you should look at this company, it's doing really well. They're gonna jump on it. You'll have a meeting within a week. That's how it works. That reputation really matters. Another thing, that pre-seed funds help with, is LPs. Now, you might think, as a startup founder, I don't really care about the LPs. But you should, because if you can get featured in the LP updates from the pre-seed fund, or even better, at the Investor Annual Meeting Day. You get an audience with all the big institutional venture seed funds. You get an audience with all the institutional these LPs that has invested in the pre-seed fund. Guess what they'll stay invest in? Other VC funds. So, it's very common for an LP to tell a Series A fund that hey, I will just act the pre-seed funds Annual Investment Day. There's three hot companies you just take a look at. That happens a lot. It also helps when they have a lot of good updates they get... Let me start with LP ones all over again.  And the final big value ad from pre-seed funds is their LP-based. Now, LPs are investors in the funds. And so, the investors in the pre-seed fund, guess what? They invest in a lot of other kinds of funds including seed and Series A funds. So, it's very common for positive word of mouth to start circulating on a company that they have seen in great updates to the LPs or even better at the Annual Investor Update Meeting. If you've get to presents to the LPs that's really really valuable. You'll have positive buzz. The LPs will probably mention your company to the Series A funds that they invest in.  And guess who else invests in pre-seed funds? Operators or people at really big companies who could potentially buy you someday. So, or sign a really big deal with you. So, there's a ton of good things that happen because of the pre-seed fund LP base. that can actually really propel your company. And it doesn't happen kind of out in the open it's a lot of like... Positive rumors or people getting a good vibe for your company. So, that LP base can be really valuable. So, just to recap. Pre-seed funds help write the first check.

name: What is the Value of Pre-seed Venture Capital Funds?

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, "Why are PEO's more expensive than Payroll Services?" This is a pretty common question we get, like, someone might look at like, you know, Gusto or heaven forbid, Intuit, QuickBooks Payroll. Please, please don't do that. 

And, or Rippling basic and say like, "Hey, why is that so much cheaper than the PEO offerings of Justworks or TriNet, or Rippling has a PEO, Sequoia. And there's actually a really good reason for that because a PEO, Professional Employer Organization, doesn't just handle payroll. They handle payroll just like a normal payroll service would, but they also supply you with medical benefits, and other kinds of benefits, plus HR Services. 

Plus they do some state and local tax help. And so, when you're comparing that to just regular payroll, you have to take, you know, you've got two sides of the equation. The regular payroll side of the equation, you have to include the cost of those benefits. Now PEO's, one of their major selling points is like, "Hey, we'll save you money on benefits because we can pool all these employees across a lot of different companies and negotiate harder." Now, the truth is they also charge a much higher fee in general, even though they're offering a bunch of these services. So your instincts are right, when you're looking at Payroll versus PEO, PEO is significantly more expensive. They are offering more services. 

It is like kind of a Premium product. So I'm old enough to say it's a Cadillac, kind of product. Maybe that needs to be like a Tesla nowadays, or something like that. But they do offer a lot more, but just know what you want. There's a lot of startups that are just getting started. They just want to be able to offer payroll because they need to hire people. They're not financially in a place where they can offer benefits yet, or they just want to run normal payroll. That's what we do, we run normal payroll and we work with an Independent Insurance Broker who finds us the best deals across all the States, because we have, we're a totally remote organization at Kruze. We have hired people all across the United States, across the world, really. 

And so I like the fact that we can work with an insurance broker and pick our own benefits. And we plugged that into Rippling and it's very easy. So we don't pay for like the PEO premium stuff. Also, one question we get a lot around, difference between payroll, and services and then the PEO services like who will do the State Tax Registrations, and that's something that your CPA firm, like Kruze, we will do that for you. So you don't have to hire a CPO if you don't want... a PEO, if you don't want to, your CPA firm can do it. It's actually very cost effective. 

So, you have some very, you have two good choices and it's more of like, do you want to go down the, you know, maybe more cost-effective more control path of payroll and then benefits, and then, you know, doing, working with the CPA firm, who will also do a lot of other stuff for you. Or do you want to do a PEO and not really have to think about it, but pay more. That's really kind of the decision you're making as a startup. 

So, a lot of times it just depends on how much money you have and how strong a fundraiser the company is and how hot the market is and that kind of stuff. So, we are seeing PEOs take market share right now. So that seems to be a trend that a lot of startups are embracing. 

So I hope that helps answer the question. Hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com if you have anything else and love to hear from you. Thanks!

name: PEO vs Payroll Service: Why Are PEOs More Expensive Than Payroll Services for Startups?

snippet.title: Rippling Automatic Employee Reimbursements
snippet.description:
Rippling Automatic Employee Reimbursements.

Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about one of my favorite new features on Rippling: it's automatic expense reimbursement for employees. 

So, the typical reimbursement flow for an employee would be, you have to manually file an Expensify expense report, then someone like the CFO of the organization needs to review that, sign off on it and manually reimburse the employee. 

With Rippling, they make that whole flow automatically, as long as there's a consistent reimbursement every month. So if you're reimbursing your employees, you know, $50 for a cell phone bill every month, or maybe a meal program or something like that, Rippling can actually do it automatically, and take all that manual labor out of it. 

When you start multiplying it by 30, 50, 100 employees, you're actually saving a lot of time. So that's why I'm really liking the new Rippling Automatic Employee Expense Reimbursement. It's a really cool feature. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Rippling Automatic Employee Reimbursements

snippet.title: What to look for in a startup payroll system
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.
Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health/

Video Transcript:

Hey it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about what to look for in a payroll system.
So the first thing is a simple, intuitive interface. You need to know actually how to work this thing and probably some of your team members need to know how to work it. So you do not want something super complicated so you don't have to spend a ton of time on the phone with support. 
The next thing is you need to be able to run payroll on autopilot. There is literally, probably nothing worse for employee morale than when payroll is missed. They start asking questions, "Does the company have enough money?" "Why was payroll missed?" So you want autopilot. You need autopilot. It also saves you a lot of time and money with your accountants. There's no real reason to be paying your accountants to run payroll. You should be using a system that runs it automatically. 
Now, you also need the payroll system to handle tax information, specifically like state payroll tax information, really nicely. Many more companies are being remote now which means employees in many other states, so getting that information into the payroll system is super important. If it doesn't get in, your payroll gets blocked, you also start racking up penalties with the states for missed payroll tax payments. So it's super important that the system can handle that information and also, it's kind of obvious, but make the payroll tax payments to those states. Next, you really wanna have great customer service. 
Now, maybe this should have been number one, but having great customer service is so important, especially when you're getting into, like, M&A or a VC funding moment because sometimes during diligence, you need, like, a bunch of state payroll tax filings to show the opposite side's lawyer. Or you just need something that comes up and if you can't get on the phone with your payroll system provider, then you could be spinning your wheels and actually delay a fundraising. I'm old school. I like to talk on the phone. So I really appreciate it when firms have good support. 
And the other thing you wanna make sure is that your accounting partner has premium support. You do not want your accountant sitting there on hold charging for that time. You want them to get through right away. So premium support, they'll get the best customer service people. They won't waste a bunch of time on the phone and, odds are, your accountant is gonna be doing the work and fixing stuff for you anyways, not you. It's usually the accountant who does that kind of stuff.
One other thing you really wanna do is make sure that payroll provider can handle R&D tax credits. This is super important. Last year, Kruze saved our clients four and a half million dollars in payroll taxes by doing these credits. But the payroll system needs to be able to intake the forms and actually handle it and send it out to the IRS. And it's even better if they have a real-time credit. So there's some payroll systems that will, charge you a small fee, but they'll stop withholding right away so you get the benefit of the credit immediately. 
Now, there is a huge difference between good payroll providers and ones that can't get their act together on the R&D credits. And the ones that can't get their act together means our startups don't get their refund for a really long time. That's money that could be in your pocket, could be paying for another engineer or a sales person, that you're not getting simply because you picked an inferior payroll system. Do not make that mistake. Pick one of the ones that we recommend on our website. 
And finally, you want really strong HR reporting. You need to know who's in your organization. You need to be able to see PTO balances, sick leave balances. You need to be able to see who reports to who. You need to be able to sort things based on their title. All that kind of stuff becomes really important. If your payroll provider invests money in their HR reporting, it can make your life so much easier, make you accountant's life so much easier and save everybody money. And the final thing that you should be looking for is a really nice integration into QuickBooks. 
When those payroll journal entries come in automatically, it actually saves us a lot of time. And we love it when they're broken out by employee. That makes doing the R&D tax credit a lot easier. So make sure they have a good, clean integration with QuickBooks and you'll be all set. 
Now these are all the things to look for in a payroll provider. It's a lot, but it's actually one of the most important system decisions you're gonna make as a startup. So hopefully this helps help you make a really good decision. Thanks. Okay.

name: What to look for in a startup payroll system

snippet.title: Biggest Payroll Mistakes by Startups
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about the biggest mistakes a startup can make when running payroll. 

Now, payroll is like one of those most sensitive things because A) Everyone likes to get paid who's working. And B) The IRS loves payroll taxes. Everyone focuses on the annual tax returns, but they really kind of make their money on payroll taxes. So they're laser focused on that. And guess what? The biggest mistake a startup makes is actually not running payroll through payroll. Meaning they just wrote the founders a check or  they wrote the first couple of employees a check without pushing it through payroll and taking out the withholding taxes. 

Now, this is a very common mistake. We have tons of companies doing this before they come to us and it creates a lot of problems. You think it's like a very easily fixable problem. But every time you have a quarter end and those payroll taxes were due or should've been paid, but the IRS didn't get them or didn't know about them, it creates a huge like just legacy of penalty notices and back taxes and paperwork for your poor accountant to figure out. So please sign up for Gusto. Sign up for Rippling. It's super easy.

It's super cheap. Run your first payroll through an actual payroll service. Withhold the taxes. It is insane the amount of paperwork and time it takes when you don't do that and you just pay someone with a check without actually submitting taxes. So that is by far the biggest mistake people make with their payroll. And we would love it if no startup ever came to us again without having done this, because it would make our life so much easier
and it would save the startup so much time and money. 

That little kind of original sin of just slipping a check to somebody without running it through payroll and withholding is a really big problem. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Biggest Payroll Mistakes by Startups

snippet.title: How should Founders pay themselves?
snippet.description:
How should Founders pay themselves?

Looking for advice setting up your startups HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, "How should a startup founder or CEO pay themselves?" 

And this is actually a question surprisingly, we get quite a bit. So the main thing you want to do as a founder is you want to make sure you're on payroll, like you are an employee of the company. And the reason for that is the IRS really doesn't like it when founders who own a big equity percentage of a company list themselves and pay themselves as contractors. The IRS feels like you're trying to avoid paying payroll taxes in that scenario. And they know you own a lot of the company, and so they feel like you should be an employee of the company. 

And so you really want to comply with the IRS, so make sure you're an employee and make sure you run it through a payroll system, because the payroll taxes will be taken out of your paycheck and sent to the federal or state authority. So that way you'll be in compliance. It's so much easier. We see a lot of nightmare scenarios where founders just honestly just didn't know better, weren't working with an accounting firm like Kruze and didn't have anyone to ask, and they just started writing themselves checks out of the company bank account. And the IRS will pick up on that and see that money was leaving the company bank account and going to someone else with no taxes paid. And so you'll start that endless parade of payroll tax problems and penalty letters. 

And it's really not easy to repair those situations. You have to spend hours on the phone, on hold with the IRS. The payroll companies, although they're great to work with, they don't want to fix things that happened before you started working with them, and so they'll refuse to fix it. And Kruze can fix it, but it's really expensive. And frankly, it's work we don't really like. And so it's kind of like a lose-lose because the founder ends up paying a lot of money to fix this stuff and we don't enjoy it either. So just make sure you're on payroll, you're taking payroll taxes out, you're in compliance with the IRS. And as just a side note, a lot of founders ask us what they should be paid. We actually did a survey. We do this every year for founders and CEOs, how much they should be paying themselves. And as you can imagine, those numbers change as a company grows up. What founders at a seed stage company should be paying themselves is less than what a founder at a series B or series C. 

So as you start raising more money and as your company starts getting a lot bigger, founders and CEOs typically pay themselves more. But we have a survey on Kruze's website. So Kruze with a K, K-R-U-Z-E, and just type in like CEO startup salary survey, something like that. This thing called Google's going to be pretty big and I think it'll help you find us. But it's a pretty informative survey, and we have over 300 clients. And so there's just a ton of data points. 

And, you know, one of the really great things we've seen on CEO and founder salaries is that women founders have actually achieved pay parity at most stages of startups. For a very long time, women founders were underpaid. And so we were very happy to report in 2020 that women founders, based on our data achieved payroll parity. Now, obviously there's a lot of challenges, other challenges being a woman CEO or someone who's an unrepresentative minority CEO, and there's things that don't show up, but we were really excited to see some of these trends going in the right direction. 

So I hope this answers your question on how should a founder CEO be paid. And again, we have a lot of resources to help you make the right decision, do it correctly, and also just know what you should be paid. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: How should Founders pay themselves?

snippet.title: Should you use an independent insurance broker?
snippet.description:
Should you use an independent insurance broker?

Looking for advice setting up your startup’s HR, finance, and payroll infrastructure? Visit Kruze’s startup health tips resource: https://kruzeconsulting.com/five_tips_for_startup_financial_health

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And have a kind of a cool announcement here. Gusto said that they are now allowing startups to use their own independent insurance brokers to help find health benefits. 

So this is a pretty big change here, actually from Gusto. So Gusto originally started off as a payroll company, and then they got into the health benefits and other kinds of benefits business, probably like three years ago. It's kind of a natural extension of the payroll product because people, when they normally sign up to pay payroll and hire employees, they're going to want to offer benefits and so that made a lot of sense. But Gusto basically kind of vertically integrated and had internal insurance brokers, picking the plans and trying to help startups decide what to do and what plans to be on and what carriers and all that kind of stuff. 

And so, there wasn't really an independent broker option, but if you've kind of been through the picking insurance traditionally, you know that insurance brokers actually can be really effective, especially when a company is remote or distributed and has people in a lot of different states. It really helps to have an expert who's really paying attention and frankly motivated to find the best plans for the startup. I know this because we went through this and we did exactly this, which we hired an independent insurance broker. 

The broker picked some very specialized, awesome plans in some states that we were just getting totally gouged in, on our old plans. And we ended up saving $30,000 for the year. And that was when we were like, I think half the size or a quarter of the size we are now. And so those insurance brokers actually do really important work and can save your company a lot of money. And so I was really just excited that Gusto's offering this now, because I think it's also going to allow companies to stay on Gusto for longer. 

And no one really loves to switch payroll and benefits providers. But this was one of the triggers that was causing people or startups to leave Gusto, not being able to use an independent insurance broker. And so, bravo Gusto. I know this probably took a lot of engineering, a lot of work in the background and a lot of process. And at Kruze we're excited to help promote this and just let the world know that you don't have to move off of Gusto anymore to use an independent insurance broker. You can stay on Gusto and they can make it happen. 

So, hope that helps. And hit us up if you have any questions or comments. Thanks. Hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Thanks.

name: Should you use an independent insurance broker?

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about re-outsourcing your startup's financials. It's kind of a interesting topic, and something I've been thinking about for a little bit. And it's helpful to kind of go back historically. 

Back in the day, startups didn't really hire a VP of finance until they had like kind of 40 or 50 people. The financials would be outsourced by a firm like Kruze, and same with the taxes. But then, and then they'd probably maybe start hiring like the accounting staff, like staff accountants, controllers, all that kind of stuff. Around 50 to 80 employees. And so it was, 'cause it's expensive, frankly, to employ a lot of accounting people. The strong accounting people are very expensive, as I know. And so what you saw in the last couple, maybe the last year mostly, was the fundraising climate got really frothy. There was a lot of capital around. And so you even saw series A companies raising like 20 million bucks. And so what happened, was we started seeing startups hiring a VP of finance at like number 20 employee, or number 25 employee, even number 30. And you're never gonna argue against bringing in financial talent in a company. 

That's actually really good for the company. There's a lot of things they can do for the company even outside of financials. I always say a good VP of finance can actually become almost like a COO, too, for a startup. So very valuable people to have. And that's very helpful to the company, but what was kind of driving it on the cost side of the equation was, it was, those companies were raising so much money at such a high valuation, that they became kind of insensitive to the cost. It was almost like, "Ah, we raised all this money. What else are we gonna do with it? Let's hire a finance person." And then the other change that started happening, was they immediately started moving pretty quickly into hiring internal accountants, like controllers and staff accountants. 

And, historically, at Kruze at least, we would always support a company for like at least a year, or we'd start reporting to that VP of finance, and then support the company for at least a year until they brought in, started hiring like one by one, those accounting hires. But we started seeing it happen a lot quicker. Again, just kind of that insensitivity to the cost, because the company had raised so much money. 

The other thing, which is a very fair rationale was, if you're gonna triple your head count in a year, which many of our clients were projecting, then you do need a lot of infrastructure, and you do need those accounting professionals. 'Cause that's a lot going on, a lot of growth, a lot of transaction growth, expense growth, a lot of operations growth. And so that made sense. But as the markets start slowing down now with the NASDAQ, we're starting to see basically, like older clients getting in touch with us, and being like, "Hey, is the shop still open? Can you pick up things?" 'Cause I think what they're finding is that VP of finance is still really valuable, because again, they can do a lot of things with the company, other things besides just purely financials, but they're kind of realizing that maybe some of those accounting hires that are full-time, and benefits, and taxes, and all that kind of stuff, maybe aren't the bang for the buck that they thought it was, or they don't need that, or they're not gonna grow quite as fast, or maybe they're just more sensitive to making sure they preserve their capital. So it's early in this trend, we're just starting to see it. 

This is being recorded in May, 2022. And the NASDAQ has just kind of, the decline in the NASDAQ's kind of hit a critical mass now, but it's been something that's been happening for the last month. And so I thought I'd just make a video on it, and put it out there.

name: How Can Outsourcing Improve Financial Services for Startups?
