We're recording this in COVID times, every company has gone totally virtual or remote.

So the first step I would say is make sure they're a contractor. So these people may need to be employees, especially if you're, you know, working with a bunch of people in one country, that country, you know, governments really love payroll taxes. And so oftentimes if you're building a big presence and they can argue that you have tax nexus, you may end up having to put them on payroll. You can use a global PEO to do that, but that's really the first test. Make sure they're actually a contractor and they pass all those tests. 

Now, if they, if you have validated them as contractors, there's a couple really, really easy ways to pay them. My favorite personally is just using bill.com. I like bill.com because it allows you to upload the invoice the contractor gave you into bill.com and you can actually have some documentation, both for your own records and for your accountant. It makes booking all these contractor payments in the correct periods so much easier. 

Also sometimes contractors are a little disorganized. They might try to double bill you or you pay them and they're complaining they never got the money, whatever it is. You can actually show the cash trail through bill.com and bill.com has international wires now so you can set all those, all that stuff up through bill.com. So that's the first option. Another option is paying your contractors just through the old fashioned bank wire. And in some countries that maybe don't have as developed banking systems, or maybe there's a high chance of fraud, then you do kind of, you do use a wire oftentimes, but that doesn't have the advantage of uploading the invoice and having that for a record, a couple other options are Rippling and Gusto. 

Now Gusto is steadily making progress on this. They've got Canadian international contractors can be paid. One thinks that they'll probably have, you know, the rest of the countries, international contractors being able to pay through there. Rippling does allow you to pay contractors globally, which is really, really nice. There's also a couple kind of contractor-centric companies like Deel which is a new company, which allows you to pay your contractors and foreign employees in one place. They kind of have like abstracted the global PEO and so it looks like one interface to you, but the payments can go through a PEO or they can go through a wire or a different channel, but it all looks the same to you, which is a pretty nice option. 

The other ways of doing it are good old fashioned, PayPal. Like people use PayPal, TransferWise, things like that. And then finally, maybe, you know, depending on how you're thinking, but like things like Bitcoin or Square's Cash app can also be an option. We are careful about Bitcoin because when you make payments with Bitcoin, that is a, it's a currency that is moving around quite a bit.
And so it makes the accounting a little bit harder, but if you only have a couple and they're the kind of people want to be paid in Bitcoin, that's an option as well. The key thing to remember is whatever way you choose the pay your contractors, you really need to have those invoices. The IRS requires you to keep three years of invoices at all times in case you're audited. And so you need it for that reason. You wanna make sure, it's gonna be impossible to track down these invoices if you're ever audited. 

And secondly, to make your accountant like Kruze, work a lot faster and keep your accounting bill down. If we have access to those invoices, we can see the period for which the expenses should be booked and therefore we do not need to bug you. We can also see if you're being double billed. We can see if there was a deposit already made. We can answer so many questions on your behalf for those contractors and save you a lot of time.

name: How to Pay International Contractors: What's the Best Way to Pay a Foreign Contractor?

snippet.title: How the right credit card helps make accounting easier
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, How does the right credit card make accounting easier? 

And as a business owner or founder of a startup, you should really care about making the accounting easy because that saves you a ton of money on your accounting. The easier the accounting is, the less your accountant has to charge. I know this from experience 'cause that's what we do. So the right credit card is really important because it can get all the data, all the transactional data like vendor, date, payment amount, even transaction description into QuickBooks so much easier. Getting that nice clean bank feed or credit card feed into QuickBooks saves your accountant a ton of time. 

Now especially us because we have set up and built a bunch of automations that plug into QuickBooks that recognize transactions automatically. So we're able to do about 70% of the transactions automatically now, which means a human accountant is not touching those transactions, which again saves you a lot of time and money. But we can only do that with some of the credit cards out there because some of them are on super antiquated systems and do not have clean bank feeds and are always needing to be reconnected into QuickBooks. 

The other important thing for a credit card to make your accountant's life easier is that they have easy read-only access and log in access in their portal. I can not tell you how many times we have been locked out of American Express. It drives me bonkers how many times. It happens constantly. And if I feel really bad about it, because I have to call and email the founders and say, "Guess what? We're locked out of American Express again." And it makes us look stupid, but really it's American Express or this happens with other credit card portals where we're getting locked out through no fault of our own. They're just built on bad technology, really kind of like 1980s, 1990 stuff, and are not built for portal access and multi-tenant access for like companies like us that serve hundreds of startups. They think you have one accountant for one company. That's how their systems are built. It's also why we love some of the newer credit card systems. 

So we love Brex. That is probably our favorite. They make the integration with QuickBooks super easy. Our transaction automation runs on top of Brex very nicely. And even Brex has some of their own automation built into the connection with QuickBooks. So that's really nice. Stripe has come a long way with their credit card offering and they continue to get better. 

In fact, we give them a lot of feedback on that. And Expensify has come out with their virtual credit card, which is really nice. So those are three that will really help solve problems for your accountants, which in turn makes your life as a founder easier. And by saving money that allows you to hire another engineer or another salesperson, maybe not pay for the whole salary of that person. 'Cause that would be a really huge saving. But every dollar counts in startups. 

And so having a really good credit card that syncs nicely with QuickBooks that plays nicely with our automation, that recognizes transactions and labels them automatically is really important, and has a good portal that can handle accountants who have hundreds of clients and not lock us out constantly. All save you time and money and they save us time and money and it keeps everybody happy. I hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How the right credit card helps make accounting easier

snippet.title: Best eCommerce Credit Cards
snippet.description:
Best eCommerce Credit Cards.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about what is the best credit card for eCommerce companies. 

Now, eCommerce companies have some very special requirements. They're not your usual startup or bootstrap company. They are buying a ton of inventory on that credit card. So it's really important. They have a high limit. The higher the limit, the more inventory they can buy at one time on the credit card. That's helpful to everybody. The other thing they really care about is having a long float. 

Now, float is measured in days. Typically it's a 30 day float, but sometimes you can get 60 day floats. That's really helpful because that means you don't have to pay the credit card down for 60 days instead of 30 days. Very, very helpful. Another thing they care about is having really nice rewards. They're pushing a ton of purchases through that credit card. And so they want to get the rewards that come with that, trips, hotels, airlines, or even cash back. Those can all be very valuable if you're spending a lot of money on your credit card. 

Now, something that's not as important for an eCommerce company is employee spending limits. Typically, of course, they're gonna want to have a credit card for the employees to have spending limits on that. But the vast majority of the credit card spend for an eCommerce company is gonna be on that inventory purchase. And so it's kind of a nice to have instead of a must have. At least that's our opinion at Kruze Consulting.

name: Best eCommerce Credit Cards

snippet.title: The Benefits of American Express' New Startup Credit Cards
snippet.description:
The Benefits of American Express' New Startup Credit Cards

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about American Express's new startup credit cards. So everyone thinks about American Express as like a big credit card company for big companies, or even like small businesses, and they haven't traditionally focused on startups, but that's changed. 

They're actually coming out with a new credit card, and there's a lot of benefits for startups. So the first one is there's no personal liability. This has always been one of the biggest issues for me with startup credit cards. I hate to see when a company is going down, it's not gonna work out, I hate it when the founders might be saddled with a bunch of credit card debt, and so this takes care of that. That's like the biggest thing for me. No personal guarantee by the founders. 

Now, the other nice things about this is that it's a lot easier to use. American Express is actually coming out with virtual cards, so you can just provision employee cards really easily. And they don't even need to actually have a physical card. They just have the credit card number, and they buy their Dropbox or Box subscriptions, stuff like that, so it makes it a lot easier. It also works globally, so it's not just limited to the United States, which is really nice because a lot of companies, I know most of our customer base, are now remote and working throughout the globe, not just the United States. So there's some really nice benefits. 

Now, the rewards are really cool 'cause they're startup oriented. So they've got like the traditional Hilton Honors, hotel rewards that everyone who uses American Express really likes, but they also have some cool stuff around Uber rewards, CLEAR membership. And they even have like trip delay and flight cancellation insurance, which in this day and age, like, flights are getting canceled constantly. So if you are traveling, it is nice to have that backup. So, the rewards have actually gotten a lot better, and I think the cool thing about it is they become startup-centric rewards. Like, when things get back to normal, everyone's taking Uber everywhere, right? 

And so, that reward is actually really gonna pay off. Until then, you can still use the flight insurance, you can still use the hotel stuff. Now, the other thing about the American Express card is they actually have a cash back feature, which is super cool. So you can save up to 1.25% cash back. Every company isn't gonna save quite that much. Those are for kinda the bigger spenders, but getting like 1% back on your total Google and Facebook ad spend or all your web service spend, or if you're paying for your WeWork via credit card, these are like big dollar amounts coming back to the startup. And so, you can start to see how using the new American Express startup credit card can actually start mitigating your burn rate a little bit. 

Now, it's not gonna change your company and change your trajectory, but like every little dollar helps. And I always like to say like every dollar you save in perks like this can actually be redeployed to marketing or engineering, and so the American Express startup credit card is actually doing that. 

So they have really good benefits, there's no personal guarantee, it's easy to use globally. I just think this is the credit card everyone should be paying attention to, especially for the cash back. Like, you put all those things together with the cash back, and all of a sudden, you have a winning credit card. So, I hope you check it out. Thanks, bye!

name: The Benefits of American Express' New Startup Credit Cards

snippet.title: SVB Innovators Card
snippet.description:
SVB Innovators Card

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn of Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about Silicon Valley Bank's Innovator credit card. And oftentimes Silicon Valley Bank goes for short SVB. And really SVB has been the banking powerhouse of Silicon Valley for many, many years, dating back I think like 40 years. 

And really they bank a lot of the great startups in startup world, and they also bank a lot of the venture capital funds. So they are everywhere and it's really great that they have a new credit card that's competitive in the market. There was a time when there was some startup credit cards that were kind of a little bit more innovative and now SVB has caught up, and I think starting to surpass those other challenger banks and credit cards. And really, the benefits of the Innovator card is a couple of things. 

Really, the most important one is there's no personal liability for founders. For many years in some of the old-school credit card companies still require you as a founder to personally guarantee the credit card. So you're making no money 'cause you're a founder. And you're also having to put kind of all your assets on the line to guarantee this credit card. And that really can hurt you if the company goes down, especially very quickly and there's not enough money to pay off that credit card, that becomes your debt. And so that's one of my favorite things about the Silicon Valley Bank Innovator card. There's just no personal guarantee for the founders. 

The other thing is there's no annual fee. We all kinda know that credit card companies love to fee you up and charge a fee every year. And that's one of the ways they make a lot of money. SVB does not do that. Now another benefit is you get kinda a single view of all your accounts. So in the SVB dashboard, they now have all your bank accounts, and they also have your Innovators credit card account, that didn't used to be like that. It used to be two separate things, almost like two software systems. Credit to SVB for investing a lot of money and a lot of time in technologically-innovative projects. They've acquired a couple of companies, but they really made their systems a lot stronger. 

And for accountants like Kruze, it just makes it a lot easier, a lot faster. And frankly, we can be more competitive on pricing when we work with an excellent bank that has good systems like SVB. So that's one of the reasons we recommend Silicon Valley Bank, they have a tremendous market share in the Kruze client base. There's a couple other little things like flexible spending limits. You can spin up someone's credit card really easily if you hire a new person. The money is taken out of your bank account to pay the credit card every month. 

So they're gonna underwrite based on a big part of that without the personal guarantee. It's just underwriting based on your cash balance. So just know that if you have a really tight cash balance you may end up having to do a personal guarantee with a different kind of credit card than SVB or maybe somewhere else. But they're really looking at your cash balance in the bank to help underwrite this credit card. 

So, really the Innovators card is just, I think it's one of the best offerings on the market and it really helps that it's coming from SVB. There's just a ton of synergies all over the place and it makes the path as you grow a heck of a lot easier. So check out the Innovators card. SVB has its own own website for that, just type in SVB Innovators card, and you'll get a ton of details. And if you wanna apply hit up SVB, or if you wanna ask some more questions about it, just hit us up at Kruze. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: SVB Innovators Card

snippet.title: Startup Financial Modeling 101
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts/ 

Video Transcript:

Startup financial modeling 101. What do you need to know before you build your startup's financial model? There are three key things to think about before you start building your startup's financial model. 

One: it's very important to know the goal of the model. Why are you doing this exercise? Are you just testing to see if your idea even makes sense? Are you getting ready to fundraise? Are you doing a budget? You want to use or customize and create the level of detail that matches with the type of model that you're trying to build. 

Two: you really want to know the KPI's for your business and not just the financial ones but things like the number of clients you expect to have at different moments when you expect to release products or MVPs. And then three: you should use an existing simple financial model template. Like one of the free ones available on the Kruze Consulting website. Don't try to reinvent the wheel. There are many free templates available. Just grab one. 

Here are a couple of tips for you as you're building your startup's financial model. One: you'll want to pay very careful attention to your headcount projections and your payroll. Most of the early-stage startups burn is in payroll and in headcount. So, knowing this and understanding it is very important. 

And two: you should have a really strong opinion on the amount of revenue and the amount of cash burn that you'll have in the coming years in your financial model. And you'll want to make sure that the burn and the size are commensurate with the opportunity of the company that you're trying to build. Head over to our website and you can download one of our free financial model templates. Hope this helps.

name: Startup Financial Modeling 101

snippet.title: The Rise of Smaller (but very meaningful) Startup Acquisitions
snippet.description:
The Rise of Smaller (but very meaningful) Startup Acquisitions

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and welcome to our YouTube channel. We'd be grateful if you'd subscribe, because we talk about tons of startup accounting, taxes, financing, VC stuff, on the channel. And today we're talking about the rise of smaller, but meaningful, startup acquisitions. And what we're seeing, this is actually like a real-time trend here. 

It's actually pretty exciting. We're seeing a lot of seed stage or companies that raised like a seed plus extension round actually getting acquisition offers. We're recording this in August of 2022 and the NASDAQ's been down quite a bit. Getting a little bit of a summer recovery here. And what we're seeing is bigger companies are doing their bargain hunting. They're going around and they're looking for companies mostly that fill a technology gap and that have some traction. Something that is very synergistic with what they do in their normal course of business but that can be an accelerator. And so we're working on, this week, we just got three of these alone which are $25 to $45 million acquisitions for startups that only raised usually like kind of $3 to maybe $8 million in capital. So they haven't done the really big Series A, the $10, $15, $20 million Series A that puts your valuation probably in like the 50 to 80 zone. 

And the reason why these startups can entertain these acquisitions is that they haven't raised that much money. And these are good deals, not great deals, these are good deals for the VC Syndicate or the angels that invest in them. They're going to get a really nice return on capital. But what's really interesting is these are life-changing deals for the founders. If you've only raised, you know, 3 to 5 million bucks, you've probably only sold about 20 or 30% of your company. Therefore the management team owns 70 to 80%. 70% of 40 million bucks that's 28 million bucks. That's $28 million split amongst the management team. And most of these companies are run by kind of younger founders who, you know, don't have huge personal lives and personal expenditures. 

Although after these deals are done, they probably will upgrade their lifestyle a little bit. So this is very, very meaningful for them. It's going to be life-changing money and for their team and they get to put a win up on the scoreboard. That's something that oftentimes people underestimate. You know, when you get a nice win, you make some money for your investors, you set yourself up for life. The next startup is a lot easier to fund. And so there's all these different trends that are conspiring to, to yield these smaller but very meaningful acquisitions. 

So I'm excited. This is all Kruze customer-base stuff and we're working on a bunch of them right now. And so I'm thrilled for these founders. They've worked super hard. Oftentimes, just because they haven't raised a lot of money, they've still been working on the company for three or four years. Oftentimes these are companies that maybe raised a million or 2 million. Got market traction then only raised like that extension round like I was talking about because they didn't quite want to raise a Series A. So still put a lot of time into the company, a lot of blood, sweat, and tears and so has the team. But it's very rewarding to see them cashing out and doing these acquisitions. And really it's really good for the acquirers, too. 

This is like bread and butter acquisition. Like extending your product capabilities, adding another vertical you can sell into, doing something very synergistic in a downturn. Very smart acquisition ideas by the business development, corporate development teams at these bigger companies. 

So kudos. And we'll leave you with that. If you have any questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. Again, please subscribe to our YouTube channel and we'll see you later. Thanks.

name: The Rise of Smaller (but very meaningful) Startup Acquisitions

snippet.title: Top 5 Quickbooks Alternatives Worth Considering for Your Business
snippet.description:
Alternatives to Quickbooks

In this video, we talk about the top 5 Quickbooks alternatives that you may consider. While we primarily work with Quickbooks, reviewing some of the alternatives is still a good idea.

00:00 Introduction
00:38 Why Quickbooks is superior
02:13 Xero
03:33 NetSuite
05:14 FreshBooks
05:46 Wave
06:14 Accounting Seed
06:40 Excel/Google Sheets
08:16 Closing Thoughts

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

There are very few startups that are still using QuickBooks Desktop. There are some companies that have inventory that do use QuickBooks Desktop, but a lot of the plugins that handle inventory are progressing pretty rapidly for the QuickBooks Online Ecosystem. So even that's starting to change. But there are a couple of people who don't want to use QuickBooks. And, you know, personally and at Kruze we think QuickBooks is the superior piece of accounting software in the industry. And there's a few reasons why. It's really kind of industrial-strength, great security, never you know, very, very rarely goes down. It also has a huge ecosystem of other pieces of software that integrate into QuickBooks. And, you know, QuickBooks has made a lot of progress on the APIs, even Kruze like we've built a bunch of software internally that automatically categorizes transactions and pulls financial reports automatically. It does just a ton of other stuff. 

Xero is probably the number one alternative for the smaller company segment. And Xero started in New Zealand it's actually a great company. I actually own stock in Xero. They are very, very strong in Australia and New Zealand, Asia, and some in the UK. And Xero was really the first cloud accounting software like truly cloud and that was a huge innovation. Actually, when Vanessa first started going to Kruze and I joined Kruze a couple of years later, we did do some Xero work. Sadly, we've never really been able to get a direct response to this, but it feels like there's different versions of Xero. And the United States version just doesn't feel like it has quite the horsepower, we've even had issues where data did disappear and that was a few years ago. I think Xero's gotten significantly better and you know, we're kind of a startup too. They've been investing in the product and making it better. They do have very good APIs. That is a strength of Xero. They have good API access. They were a real leader in that before QuickBooks kind of got their act together. 

And so we typically recommend QuickBooks up to that point. We have probably, you know 5% of our client base on NetSuite, we're very familiar with it. It is very powerful. One of the areas that NetSuite really excels for our client base is international consolidations. Like if you have a subsidiary in another country, that's kind of a pain in the butt to do with QuickBooks, you have to basically do a manual Excel, Google sheet consolidation. That means putting the two companies, the parent company and the subsidiary companies financials together. You have to do that through Excel. And that's a lot of work. It's not very easy. There's currency problems. NetSuite makes that very, very easy. So, and you know, eventually, the companies get so complicated that it's time for them to switch to NetSuite. 

Now there's a few other software companies like FreshBooks which is really great for independent contractors or super small businesses. It's basically, it's mostly, it started its life as an invoicing solution. And I actually worked with FreshBooks way back in the day before Kruze Consulting. Great company, great management team, huge commitment to customer service. They're famous for only letting the phone ring one time before someone picks it up. So if you're looking for that great customer service and you're a very small company maybe an independent contractor, FreshBooks can really work for you. Wave was another company we saw a little bit kind of back in the day, it's been kind of quiet on the Wave front now, but they actually entered the market as being free and then tried to monetize through some other avenues which actually works for them. I believe they were acquired, I have to confirm that, but they had a good exit, but it wasn't quite as powerful as QuickBooks. And, you know, once they were acquired, it made it kind of it wasn't like going to be the industry standard. 

There's another company called Accounting Seed which is based on Salesforce, which I've seen once or twice. This is kind of one of those things where if you're using Accounting Seed, it probably works but you're probably also kind of limiting your pool of exceptional accountants that you can work with. So just be aware of that. It is built on top of Salesforce. It seems like, you know, a perfectly fine alternative. I haven't used it that much.

name: Top 5 Quickbooks Alternatives Worth Considering for Your Business

snippet.title: What Is a Cap Table & Why Does Your Startup CPA Firm Need One?
snippet.description:
What Is a Cap Table? Cap tables explained in 3 minutes.

If you have been having trouble understanding cap tables, then you came to the right place. In this video, we discuss what a cap table is and why you need one every year.

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Ornat Kruze Consulting and today, I'm answering the question, why does your startup CPA need access to your cap table? 

This is a question we get from founders sometimes because it's like sometimes the cap table is very precious and people, you know, when they're running a company don't want very many people know what the cap table looks like. Cap table, for those that don't know, is like the ownership percentages, breakdowns, and invested capital per investor, and it's tracked in what's called a cap table. Typically, your lawyers will manage your cap table. And typically, they'll use something like Carta, cap table management software, or they'll use like Excel spreadsheets for the early stage companies to just manage this. And so, sometimes, you know, the founders are like a little nervous about giving your CPA, like Kruze Consulting, access to it. 

But there's actually a couple really good reasons. The first one is we actually reconcile the cap table, like the amount of money that each investor should have put in, to your equity accounts in QuickBooks, like your financial system, to make sure you actually capture all the money you were supposed to get. I did another video on this called, "Reconciling the Cap Table", but basically, the short version, and check that out, but the short version is like sometimes like wires bounce or investors don't send the money in or whatever it is, and you're short, and it's really embarrassing to just, to figure out you're short like a year later, and that investor has taken off, but that investor has also, you know, signed documents, and to go back to the board and be like, "Yeah, guess what, we didn't get $250,000." You may like laugh watching this video, but like that happens, it happens, like once or twice a year. 

So reconciling your cap table to your financial system is super important. Second one is, almost every tax agency needs us, your startup CPA firm, to actually do, provide breakdowns of ownership percentages for institutions and for specific shareholders, especially like the founders, large shareholders. And so it's not, and it's not just like your federal tax return, the people usually are like kind of comfortable with that, it's like, a lot of the state stuff, Delaware franchise tax need share counts, and then even some of the municipal stuff, you need to be able to provide share counts and who owns what, so getting access to that cap table is like actually really critical for your tax firm. 

Now, it's totally fine to do an export, you know, once a year, sometimes people do that, but Carta is actually better for us 'cause we can see the changes in real-time. Like a hypothetical problem could be like, maybe you export your cap table in October around a fundraise, but then you make a bunch of option grants or someone leaves and they weren't fully vested in December. Well, we want that December 31st year-end cap table 'cause that's what we're going to use to do all the tax filings and if we've only got the October version, that's potentially not accurate. So that's why we like Carta 'cause we can just look in real-time and see what it was on a certain date. So hope that helps, hope that answers your question. 

Again, totally get that cap tables are sensitive and people want to be careful with that, but your startup CPA firm does need that for both reconciling and making sure you collected all the money you're supposed to collect from your investors and filling out all the tax forms. Hope that helps, if you have any other questions on taxes, cap tables, 409A Valuations, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and we're happy to help. Thanks so much, and oh, please subscribe to our YouTube channel, thank you.

name: What Is a Cap Table & Why Does Your Startup CPA Firm Need One?

YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...

Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Pre-seed funding's like this super awesome new asset class in the venture capital world and funding option for startup founders, and really early stage startup founders. The interesting thing about pre-seed is like maybe like five years ago all the VC funds, maybe 10 years ago, the VC funds started going upmarket. So traditional A, series A players, like all the famous Sand Hill Road funds wanted to kind of wait a little bit longer, and make sure the company was doing well before they gave them money, but they would give them more money, which then helped the seed funds emerge. And the seed funds used to be like the first check in and get things going, but then they started waiting a little longer and doing two or three or $4 million rounds. 

And so there was this glaring opportunity in the earliest stage possible, which is like the first check into a company. And some very smart fund managers decided to pursue this, and they branded it pre-seed, and it's been super successful. There's a lot of really good pre-seed funds now. We're actually seeing the pre-seed funds raise you know, they're, like $50 million funds now when they used to be like 10. So even they're growing. But for founders, this is really awesome because really pre-seed is there to like, the smallest check possible that can kind of get you going, and help you build something that can then prove out your idea. So some people call this product market fit, but I'd say it's even not product market fit. It's probably more like minimum viable product, like a simple SaaS solution that everyone can see, oh this is actually going to be helpful, or maybe get a couple customers to sign up for it. Or for like drug development, you find that you maybe can like actually start working on a compound. Or for health tech, you build like another minimum viable product that like a health system likes. So just like the very basic stuff. 

Now interestingly, pre-seed is really for kind of like, I kind of joke, it's for the non-famous non-repeat founders. And the reason for that is if you're like a famous founder, or already done an IPO, or been successful before, you're probably just going to go right to seed, or even right to series A, and just raise a big chunk of capital. And it's real simple, just kind of market demand, like VCs, everyone, angel investors, love backing founders that have done it before. Beause you just learn a lot on that roadmap, even founders that maybe weren't successful, they have sometimes an easier time raising money than first time founders 'cause they can talk about all the things they learned, and they know how to talk to investors, and have run board meetings and built something. 

And the reason for that is the valuation is just so low. But, the goal remember is to take as little money as possible that can let you prove out your idea. So we often at Kruze see pre-seed rounds being like $500K, a million bucks, something like that. And the valuation is usually like somewhere around $5 million, a little bit less, a little bit more, but so you're still kind of selling 10 or 20% of the business, which is a lot. That's a lot of dilution for, you know, a million dollars say. But again, this is kind of like for founders that really need that shot, and the seed or series A market isn't open to them. So you take the money, and the beautiful thing about taking that money, and you do suffer the dilution, but you're in business and you control your destiny. And if you build something awesome, then you are easily going to be able to get follow-on money. 

..................................................................................................................

Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, when should an early stage startup make its first operations hire? 

This is an amazing moment in the startup's history because you are hiring someone who is not working on the product or selling the product. You're hiring someone to make the company actually function. This is, this is a beautiful moment. And a lot of people call this, like, including me, the Jack or Jill of all trades role. Like, this person is gonna have some HR background, maybe a little bookkeeping, finance background, and they're gonna be able to do a ton of different things, including recruiting, including office manager, all that stuff, some IT. You are looking for someone who is not afraid to dive in and figure something out. That's probably the most important trait for this entire job. 

And it's a really awesome moment. I typically recommend somewhere around 10 to 12 employees, is when I recommend hiring this person. I've had, you know, companies that hired this person the fifth or sixth person. In fact, one of my recent guests on my podcast, Founders and Friends, Leslie from Fleetsmith, she was a sixth employee. And I can tell you that company ran really smoothly because they had an operations hire really early. So sometimes you'll get some pushback. Oftentimes, I'm actually, or the Kruze people are actually the ones saying hire an operations person, because what tends to happen is the founder gets too busy. 

There's too many people asking the founder questions, or trying to get their time, yada yada yada, and the company kind of like grinds to a halt, and things that need to get done don't get done because everyone's waiting on the founder to answer the question. And so the power of this ops person is A, they can answer a lot of those questions themselves, and B, they get time like weekly or every couple day one-on-ones with the founder to just rapid fire through these questions and get decisions made. And so it expedites everything in the organization. 

So, the pushback I usually get is like, I don't wanna pay someone who's not gonna write software, or build a machine, or do research and biotech, or sell something and make us money. And my response is always like this person will just lubricate the inner workings of the company, and make it work so much better. It will help with company retention, like people retention. You'll get stuff done so much faster. All your service providers will be so much happier and do a better job for you, including Kruze. 

So I am a big fan of hiring this position. And again, Jack or Jill of all trades, someone who's hungry, who's willing to learn a lot. There are a lot of people who just are serial ops people, who go from startup to startup, which I always have a lot of respect and admire them, because they do like two years at one company, and two years at the next company, and two years at the next company. And they build actually, like a pretty amazing portfolio of stock options. So, kudos to the folks out there who are doing this. Ops managers, we love you. And hopefully all the founders who are watching this video will listen to my advice, and hire at the latest around 10 or 12 employees. 

Please make your company, invest in your company. Make it work a lot better, a lot smoother. And your team will be happier. Your service providers will be happier, and your customers will be happier. Hope that helps. If you have other questions on operations and startups, or financing and startups, anything that comes up with startups, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, and please subscribe to our YouTube channel. We put a lot of work into this, and we'd be very grateful if you subscribe. Thanks, bye.

snippet.title: What Is a 409A Valuation, and Could It Exceed a VC Valuation?
snippet.description:
What Is a 409A Valuation? In this video, we will explain how a 409A valuation affects a venture capital fund's valuation.

00:24 409A Valuation explained
01:16 409A valuation be higher?
02:10 Case explained

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting


Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question could a 409A Valuation exceed a venture capital fund's valuation in a given startup? So it's kind of an interesting use case here. 

Actually, I got a question from a friend when Stripe kind of reduced their 409A Valuation recently. And the 409A Valuation is there for stock option pricing, common stock. And VC investments are typically preferred stock, and preferred stock has usually like a lot of bells and whistles. They're actually pretty valuable, like liquidation preferences, where you get your money back, check out that video. There's also things where like the share class as a group can vote and block things like a sale of the company. 

And so typically, the 409A Valuation, the common stock valuation, is about 35% of what the preferred valuation is. So just very simply, if the preferred valuation was $10 million, the 409A Valuation would be like $3.5 million. So the 65% discount, it's 35% of whatever the company preferred is. And so you get these kind of interesting edge cases where like hey, could the 409A Valuation be higher? And the only two edge cases I could come up with, maybe someone will watch this video and actually correct me here, it would be kind of exciting, is two things. The first would be if the company did a preferred valuation in a down round, like the valuation went down all of a sudden, and it failed to update its 409A Valuation for a while, then I could see the 409A Valuation being higher. 

Now, technically, you only do the 409A Valuation so that you can issue stock options. So if you don't have a fresh 409A Valuation, you should not be issuing stock options. So in that case, the company that has the kind of old stale 409A Valuation that's higher than the preferred that's had a down round, they need to do a 409A Valuation pronto before they start issuing more stock options or repricing existing company options. 

So that's use case one. The other edge case was, hey, maybe this company took a VC valuation like three or four years ago, pretty low valuation because it was three or four years ago and the company's building, and they're really kicking butt and they're doing awesome. In that case, the company would continue to do stock option grants, well, in that case, they would continue to do a 409A Valuation every 12 months 'cause that's how long they're good for and eventually, it's very possible that 409A Valuation could actually be higher than the preferred. In fact, if the company's doing really well, and it's contingent on not having raised more money. 

So the last round was three or four years ago basically. Again, that can happen actually pretty easily. And so that's the use case that the normal use case, the legit use case that you might see around town if someone asks you those questions. 

So I hope that helps. Again, pretty rare and if you're working on a company that's 409A is way higher than its preferred because the company hasn't had to raise very much money, it's kicking butt, well, hey, kudos to you. That's a good company and hopefully, your accounting company is Kruze Consulting. Hopefully we're working with you, too. So that ends this video. If you have any other questions, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. 

Check out our YouTube page and if you don't mind, please subscribe. We'd really appreciate it and we have tons more information on 409A Valuations, every kind of question you could possibly ever ask about that and other things in startup accounting on our website. Thanks so much. Talk to you soon.

snippet.description:

00:00 Introduction

Kruze’s clients have raised over $10 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts #startupideas #kruzeconsulting

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're covering the difference between primary shares and secondary shares in a startup. 

Now, primary shares are the shares that a company issues to raise capital for the company. So you know, you go to the VC firm, they give you a term sheet for $10 million investment, and that $10 million investment, the transfer of that is preferred shares usually. And the VC ownership has bought $10 million worth of primary shares. And so, that's typically how companies raise money. Of course, they can raise debt, things like that, but in terms of raising equity capital, they are selling primary shares. Now, the other thing that's happened lately is, especially in Q4 2021 and Q1 2022, it was a very frothy financial market for startups, and so a lot of companies were doing secondary sales. And secondary sales are either, basically existing owners of shares. So the venture capital firms, maybe the angel investors and management teams actually selling portions of their ownership, and the capital that comes from buying those shares, guess what, goes into their bank accounts. Not the company's bank account. 

So, the company is not getting the proceeds from the secondary shares. Now, sometimes primary and secondary's are done together, especially when like a VC fund wants to get more ownership. Maybe they can only get 10% ownership in the startup through primary shares, and maybe some of the insiders say, you know, we'll sell a couple more percentages and they can buy some secondary and get like 15%. So, the combo approach is a way for VCs to optimize for more ownership, but they have to be okay with insiders like management and the other VCs taking some cash, some return off the table, and that's the trade-off. 

Now, the reason why we're covering this is the market's gotten pretty tough lately. We're recording this in late June, 2022, and a lot of companies are looking around, saying like, boy, I wish we would've raised more primary, like more capital through primary sales, like cash that can go on our company's balance sheet, instead of doing some of those secondary sales. Now, of course, there's always a conflict for management and maybe even sometimes the VC firms who are sitting on the board because they may have done a big secondary, taking some cash off the table, so they benefited personally from that. But now the company's in a weaker position. 

So, secondary sales are just a fact of life in the startup ecosystem. I think they're going to kind of slow down now, but they were, you know, in Q4 2021 and Q1 2022, a really, really big part of the fundraising market. So I just wanted to explain the difference between those because people get confused about it quite often. So if you have other questions about limited partners or VC funds or preferred stock or SAFE notes, whatever it is, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. And if you don't mind, please subscribe to our YouTube channel. 

We'd love to get you some more of this wonderful content on startup accounting and taxes. So, click that subscribe button. Thank you very much, talk to you soon.

This is going to make everyone's life easier at Kruze. This is going to make all the founders who use Carta, their life so much easier. 83B filings and forgetting to send them in, in the first 30 days is like one of the worst things that you can do as a budding entrepreneur. Sometimes I joke it's like an IQ test. But really, there's a lot of smart people who have started a kick ass company, who just maybe were a little disorganized or whatever, didn't get the message from the lawyer, and forgot to send in their 83B filing. And what that does is, it basically locks in your tax basis and the taxes that you will pay going forward in the future are taxed at the capital gains rate instead of the income tax like regular income, ordinary income rate. So very important to do when stock options are a little more complicated than founder stock. Founder stock usually comes, you buy it like at par value, which is like 0.0001. 

So almost nothing. A founder stock check to exercise early would be like a hundred dollars. Stock option checks to exercise early can be lots of money, especially if you're coming into a startup a little late, but a lot of times people want to do this. They have to be educated with all the tax consequences and all that kind of stuff, but sometimes people do this. And when you do that, you have to send the IRS, the 83B form. I believe they include two copies of it. They include a cover letter in the envelope, and they will actually give you a tracking number that you can follow online through the Carta portal. They'll give you a tracking number that you can follow online through the portal and make sure it actually gets to the IRS. So they're taking this like, very offline manual process. 

That again, is a real pain, and that people forget to do, and making it super easy to do via Carta. Again, by the way I forgot to mention that in the Carta platform, not everyone wants to early exercise all their options, because again, there can be a pretty big tax bill for that. Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, when a SaaS startup starts paying sales tax, should they add it onto their customer's bill or should they absorb the tax themselves? 

And pretty much all of us... I actually did like a straw poll on this one at Kruze, because this is a question we get a decent amount. Everyone was pretty much like yeah, add it to the customer's bill. Customers should be paying sales tax if you're going to collect it. So just add it on top. There's a bunch of great systems, like Avalara, TaxJar, which was acquired by Stripe. I think there's a couple of VC-funded ones that will actually do the calculations for you and actually even look at which state their customers are in if you collect that data. And side note, please collect that data. We, Kruze, needs to know where your customers are so we can do nexus determinations. So super important to know where your customers are located. But these sales tax software engines will actually calculate it for you and just add it on top. 

So very, very powerful, super smart to do that. We do have some companies sometimes. It's like they'll absorb it themselves for a little while, and I think it's just rooted in like hey, all of a sudden we're collecting revenue at material amounts, and we don't really know what to do, and don't know how our clients will respond and things like that but like it's one of those signs of a maturing company. You're just leaving a lot of cash, a lot of money on the table by paying for those sales taxes yourselves, and the customers are going to expect it, especially if you're like a certain size. So I would just go ahead and cut over, just start doing it, and it'll save you a lot of money 'cause you don't really want to pay your customers' taxes. It'll also help you get compliant, make sure you're doing all your stuff correctly. One warning. 

Please do not forget to remit the taxes you collect to the government, like mostly state agencies is where it's going to be. It's like a very serious crime to collect sales tax and not remit. So occasionally, we see companies like in onboarding, they've been collecting sales tax for six months and never sent the checks into the gov and that's a recipe for some serious financial penalties, and even worse potentially. So if you're collecting sales tax, send it in. Do not sit on that money. Do not co-mingle it. Just get that money out of your bank account and into the government's bank account, and they will be happy, and they will leave you alone. 

So I hope this helps. It's always an exciting moment when a SaaS company is big enough to even worry about sales tax. There's thresholds you've got to meet and I've done a video on that too. You check that out. Or you can check out the Kruze sales tax page. But yeah, this is cool. This is like your company's growing up. I'm very happy for ya. And if you have other questions about accounting or taxes, or sales tax, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com and please subscribe to our YouTube channel. Thanks so much, take care.

snippet.title: Ways To Cut Your Startup’s Cash Burn Rate On A Budget!
snippet.description:
If you are a business owner, may it be a startup or an established company, you should know by now the importance of determining the burn rate. A company’s cash burn rate, to put it simply, refers to the company’s cash consumption over time.

Does your VC-backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Basically, runway is defined as your total cash in your bank account, divided by your average monthly spend. And that's how many months you have left. And so right now, we're recording this in July, 2022. There's a lot of startups that are stretching, making changes, making sure they extend their runway, ideally out to 18 months, something like that. And so, hey, I thought I'd give you a couple quick ideas. 

Next up, cutting the snacks in the office, all that kind of stuff, if you are even working in an office, a lot of companies are working remote these days. But it's not fun to do, it's kind of unpopular, but it also has the side benefit of sending a message to the team that, hey, we don't want to do this, but it's something necessary. We all have to save a little bit and look for cost savings opportunities. So it's not just the money you save with cutting the snacks and food and all that kind of stuff. But it's actually the subconscious or conscious message you're sending to folks. Another one which I really hate to recommend, but it is something to do if you're finding yourself in trouble and really need to extend your runway, which is, either cut back or fire your PR firm. if you don't have revenue.  

Now, another thing to think about with cutting your burn rate is, about 70 percent, maybe 75 percent of most startups' costs are people costs. I'm talking salary, benefits, all that kind of stuff. And so I hate to say it, but one of the ways you can extend your runway is by either reducing head count, or you can do a 10 or 20 percent pay cut across the board.  

And so you want to be careful here because cutting 10 or 20 percent of everyone's salary might scare a lot of people, so the strongest people may actually leave. They also may feel like they're being targeted, despite all the value they create for your company. And really, at the end of the day, personnel people, that usually is the most, kind of the intellectual power and where the company's going to go. Those people are really what drive everything so you've got to be really careful. I prefer to also do, or instead of doing that, do a check-in with each VP and just talk to them about performance. 

Another thing, by the way, if you haven't taken venture debt, that's another really good way of extending your runway. Lenders love following the top-tier VCs into startups that are doing well, that have traction, who just need three to six more months of runway, so that's a really good opportunity. We have tons of content on venture debt so just Google Kruze venture debt and you'll find all of our videos and webpage on that. Something else to do, this is just an exercise I like to do every month in the Kruze financials, is, I just go through our general ledger and for any accountant worth their salt should be sending you your income statement, balance sheet, cash flow statement, supporting documentation like rev rec schedules, prepay schedule, balance sheet schedules, all that stuff, and general ledger. 

Another way of looking at things, also, you find SaaS subscriptions there that you unsubscribed a year ago, but they kept billing you, stuff like that. Another thing you can do is look at a variance analysis. In our financial package, we provide a variance analysis. You can see chart of account categories, like web services or travel or office expenses, you can see them fluctuate. And those fluctuations will often allow you to see a cost savings opportunity, so I really like that. This is something we're starting to see now at Kruze quite a bit, which is people re-outsourcing their accounting. I did another video on this, so just put into YouTube re-outsource your accounting, or something like that, with Kruze in it. 

And ideally you're walking through that with a financial advisor, at Kruze, of course, we do that, but maybe it's someone internal at your company or just a friend, someone who's very financially savvy and wants to help your startup succeed and just spends a little bit of time with you every month. So budget to actuals can be your friend, big time. 

So I hope that helps, there's a lot of ideas on how to cut burn. If you're a startup, this is a question we get a lot right now. Unfortunately it's a tougher time in the market and so hopefully these ideas help. If you have other questions on this or extending your runway, or budget to actuals, financial models, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com, and please subscribe to our YouTube video. Thank you so much.

name: Ways To Cut Your Startup’s Cash Burn Rate On A Budget!

We're recording this in August of 2022. The Fed just raised their interest rates up to 2.5%, so it's another 75 basis points. That means the prime rate has gone up to 5.5%. I can't even remember the last time prime was at 5.5. That's what banks lend at. And so for startups that have a lot of money, this is an opportunity. You're sitting on a bunch of cash. All of a sudden you can generate yield out of your cash and you can still do it, which is most important, in a safe way. That safety, if my top three criteria were different things, safety would be all three of those, frankly. You're getting money from the venture capitalists to build your company and take over the world. 

Not to speculate on interest rates or anything else, so safe. But nowadays Money Market Funds are actually starting to yield about 2%. That's meaningful. If you've got 20 million bucks in cash sitting in the bank, you can get a nice chunk of cash just by putting the money in a Money Market Fund. So what are the big things you should be doing? So, first of all, Money Market Funds, especially ones that have daily liquidity, that is a very important caveat. You don't want to be locked up in a Money Market Fund for a long time. You would like daily liquidity. That means you can just pull your money out whenever you want on a daily basis. And odds are, you would never pull all your money out at one time, but you might need to just fund the operating cash account, which is another video we've done here, for three months, which is what we recommend. But if there was an emergency you could pull your money out. That's very, very important. 

The other thing that people often do is they buy what's called bond ladders. With bond ladders, and you get a slightly higher yield on this, you basically just buy US Government bonds, Google bonds, Starbucks bonds, stuff that's really, really safe, but you go out on the maturity curve, meaning you'll buy a set of bonds that mature in three months, in six months, nine months, 12 months, 15 months, right? So you're stretching out your maturity basically to match when you're actually going to need that cash flow, and again, you can get slightly higher yields that way, but you're buying direct securities. 

Well, with interest rates going up, you want to be really careful on your bond ladders and you want to stick to shorter maturities. You don't want that money locked up for anything past probably six months. You don't want it to go out to 12 or 18 months, and the reason why is, interest rates are predicted to go up even more. The Federal Reserve was talking after this last meeting about maybe taking interest rates up another 75 basis points. Well, if that happens and you're stuck in these bonds that you bought, you have to hold them to maturity, or you're going to incur a loss when you try to sell those bonds. The reason is bonds that pay a certain interest rate, when interest rates in the market go up beyond that those bonds are actually worth less. 

They start to sell at a discount. They sell at a discount to compensate the new buyers and get them what the market interest rate is. And so you could end up putting a bunch of your money in a 12 month bond, have interest rates go up even more now, and all of a sudden you're selling those at a pretty hefty discount and you're actually losing money. No one wants you to lose money on your cash management. Again, we're talking safety here. So if you're going to do bond ladders, stick to three month bond ladders, maybe six month, at the max, bond ladders in this current environment.

name: What Changes In Cash Management Follow The FED Interest Rate?

snippet.description:

Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about what are VC fund reserves? 

And this is really important right now, because a lot of venture capital-backed startups are going back to their investors and asking for more money. Markets got a lot tougher, the NASDAQ has corrected. A lot of public tech stocks are down 50 to 60%. So it's a very tough market out there. And so, if you're a founder, one of the easiest, fastest, most convenient places to get more capital is from your existing investors, but guess what? They have to fund you out of their reserves. And so, let's walk through the mechanics of VC fund reserves. First of all, when a VC fund makes investments in a startup they almost always will reserve some percentage of capital to follow on. And there's two reasons for that. 

A, they want to support companies that are doing really well. It's really good to dollar cost average in even if it's a higher valuation in the future, because typically, if the company's raising more and more money at higher and higher valuations, it's a winner. And so, you want to keep getting as much capital into those companies as possible if you're a VC and you're maintaining your pro-rata ownership percentage, which you worked really hard to get. 

The second situation you're going to use those reserves is you are going to fund a company that's not struggling or dying, but a company that's doing okay, but needs to hit, either a funding milestone, like maybe they need a couple more customers or they need to get the product out the door, or a company that's been out there for a while that needs to be bridged to an exit. So if you're a VC and the company only needs 3 or 4 more months of capital to get bought you get either make some money or get your capital back, that's actually a pretty good situation to put more money into the company. It's not optimal. 

Again, they always want to be putting more and more capital into the winners. But if you're bridging to an exit, that's another place where VCs will pony up and give you some of the reserves. So most VC funds kind of there's no hard and fast rule, but most maintain 30 to 40% of the fund to be reserved. So if you think about that, 60 to 70% of the capital say they raise a $500 million fund, 60 to 70% of that is going to new capital, new companies. 

So that's 300 to 350 million of the 500. And then you've got another couple hundred million give or take, that will go in and support those portfolio companies. So that's how VC funds work. Now, there's a lot more scrutiny the next time you come back for more capital, if you're not like a rocket ship and kicking butt. So it's super-important to treat this almost like a new investment when you're asking the VCs. You very likely will have to pitch the partnership again, you'll very likely have to, you'll kind of have to realize that you're using one of your chips. 

This may be, if it's a bridge situation, the last time you can ask the VC fund for more capital. After this, you're on your own. It's very hard to continue to fund a company 3 or 4 times, if good things aren't happening and new capital isn't coming into the company. So VC fund reserves are very precious. The partners, they don't get to do it usually in every one of their companies. So they are having to pick and choose how many companies out of their own portfolio they can support, how many of the general partnership they can support.

name: What Are VC Fund Reserves and How Are They Used?

snippet.description:

Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/

Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze consulting, and today I'm answering a question about startup cash management. 

And it is, what is a certificate of deposit? CDs, for the humans out there who can remember high interest rates. So certificates of deposits are a savings vehicle where you actually give the bank your money, and then you get a certificate of deposit. You get like a claim ticket basically. The bank has your money for a set period of time. Typically a fixed interest rate, although they can float, but most banks always want to do fixed. And oftentimes, this was like a major investment vehicle in like the eighties and seventies, when interest rates were like way higher, because hey, it's like super safe. It's insured up to $250,000 at the bank. And so, all of a sudden you're getting like, you know, if interest rates are high, you're getting like 10% just by sitting there in a riskless investment. 

That's actually really, really good. And so for a long time, or the last like 5-10 years, interest rates have been really low. Banks have paid very low interest rates. Certificates of deposits weren't that interesting, except for people who really really wanted super-secure cash. Well, guess what? Startups actually want super-secure cash. Like, the VCs gave you the money not to like go speculating on, you know, interest rates, but to build your company, change the world, hire a lot of people, et cetera. And so certificate of deposits actually, and the fact that there can be variable times, like you set the time depending on what works for you, you know, three months, six months, a year, two years. They're actually like a pretty decent match for startup cash management. What you'll see for a lot of startup cash management is either money goes in like a money market fund that essentially holds certificate of deposits and bonds. 

Or if companies have like a lot of cash, they will start buying these things directly. And that's what I'm starting to see now is companies, and that's why we're doing this video, companies that have a lot of cash are starting to see like, hey, you know, I can put this money, excess money that I'm not going to need for like a year, I can put it in a six month CD, and actually earn a decent amount of yield. I know it's safe. I don't have to worry. I'm not going to get fired by the board for putting it into something risky. And I'm getting a higher yield because I'm agreeing to lock that money up for six months. 

And so that's why we're recording this. 'Cause we are seeing startups put money into certificate of deposits, like decent, like happening a decent amount nowadays, way more than it used to happen even like a year ago, when interest rates were way lower. 'Cause back then, the yield was like so minimal. It didn't really make any sense to lock up. But as interest rates have gone up in the economy, I think prime, when I'm recording this, is like 4.75 now. And I think it's due to go up like another 75 basis points. Like we're talking real cash if you lock up the money in a safe instrument at a bank, like a certificate of deposit. So, check around, shop around, your bank that you bank with, startup bank, will probably have a certificate of deposit. 

Again, a lot of the startup banks interestingly, are still swimming in cash, and are paying very low yields, because those banks, because they hold the cash for the whole startup ecosystem, like SVB, First Republic, et cetera, Bridge Bank, Comerica, Mercury. They are not going to pay very much yield because they don't really need to attract more deposits to facilitate their lending.

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're covering the absolute first few things your startup should do when it closes a seed round. This is important stuff, seed rounds are usually like the first material amount of money into a company, and you want to do things right when you raise that institutional investor money. 

So the first thing you should do is develop a cash management policy. Like super important, be very clear about where you're keeping the excess cash, because you're going to keep some of the money in an operating account, some of the money in like a money market savings investment account. 

Just do a quick cash management policy that the board can ratify. There's templates all around the internet, just Google for that. The next thing you want to do is set up a corporate credit card, if you've been using your personal card. Now it is not okay to use your personal card. Obviously sometimes you're going to do this a little bit and submit an expense report, but you want to be professional, you don't want to be tempted by fraud, so set up a corporate credit card program. Next thing up, get a good accountant. Yes, of course the fine folks at Kruze Consulting CPA are available to do this. But actually having an accountant allows you to buy back some of your own time. You're not going to have to do the accounting yourself anymore. 

Also important, you have a second set of eyes. So there's a little bit of like separation of duties, which again reduces the threat of fraud. Just make sure your financials are accurate so that you can report good burn rate statistics to your board. You also want to get on QuickBooks, like that's what all the best accounting firms use. And the great thing about QuickBooks is it integrates with all the new SaaS financial tools. So you kind of get the best of both worlds using QuickBooks. Another thing you are going to want to do is tune up your financial model. You probably had some sort of financial model when you're raising, if not, now's the time to build one. But just spend a little bit extra time projecting out next couple years in your financial model. Another thing you're going to want to do is have budget to actuals. I love budget to actuals, it tells me exactly where we're overspending and underspending, great for communication with the board. Super, super powerful. So budget to actuals are your friend. 

Another thing that a lot of companies just don't do is send your investors a monthly update. Prefer to be early in the month, like maybe the 15th of the month, something like that, but just give them an update on what's going on with the company. This is really important because I see companies that have been silent for a long time, all of a sudden they're in a crisis or maybe they're short on money, and they go back to their investors asking for more money quickly, and the investors don't have any context. Also the investors can't help you, like these people all invested in your company so they can help you out. And if they're not part of the journey, they're not going to be able to help you out as easily as they could have if they were just part of the journey and knew exactly what was going on. Final little tip, hire a recruiter/contract with a recruiter, get someone in place who could start helping you build your team. We see something like 70, 75% of all venture capital raised goes to salaries and contractors.

name: Things You Should Do After Closing a Seed Round!

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, why do venture capital limited partners hate it when they get capital call requests in a down market? 

And for a little bit of a refresher, the funds, the groups, the people that invest in venture capital funds are typically like, you know, foundations, endowments, pension funds, big, big LPs. Of course there's like individuals, but the bulk of the money are the big LPs. And those groups, the funds, institutions, pension funds, keep their money in the stock market, in bond markets, and other alternative investments. And so anytime they get a capital call, meaning they get a request to fund the venture capital partnership, well, they have to usually sell something. And so they're selling their stocks, or they're selling their bonds, or doing whatever. They don't keep like a ton of cash on hand, they want to be as invested as possible. 

And so when the market has corrected and it's a really huge down market in the stock market and the bond market like it is right now, well guess what? Those institutions are selling at what they think is an undervalued price to fund the venture capital fund. And so they're kind of like, hmm, they don't really like doing that. Now part of being a good LP is always hitting your capital calls. And there's also like a lot of legal and financial incentives for them to never miss a capital call, especially reputationally. 

So they're going to do it, but that doesn't mean they necessarily like it. And the other thing they really hate is when you do rapid fire capital calls in a tough market, and I'll never forget, I was working at Lighthouse back in the day in 2008, 2009, it was a venture capital fund, and we did something like three capital calls in five months or six months. And 2008, 2009 was when Lehman was going down and the stock market got crushed. 

And boy, did we get some grief from our limited partners? Now they all hit the capital calls, everything was fine, and we actually invested that money in some really amazing startups. So it was a great time to do investments, because the market was down, and that fund returned really, really well. So in the end, the limited partners are happy they did it, but they're definitely going to give you some grief and not be happy about it. 

So you want to be smart about your capital calls, you want to be strategic about them, don't overwhelm them with rapid fire capital calls. Sometimes that just means a VC fund has to pass on some of the investments they want to do or be a little bit more judicious about it. That said, you know, VC funds make all their money in tough markets. Like when you can invest at a much lower valuation, that means your return expectations are going to be much higher when things normalize. 

So don't be shy, you know, do those capital calls, I get some personal ones. I'm a very, very small investor in a couple funds, and I always make sure to send that money in to make sure I'm satisfying my legal obligations, my financial obligations, and of course, my reputational obligations. So hope that helps. And if you have other questions on VC funds or limited partners and how they invest in VC funds, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. 

And if you don't mind, please subscribe to our YouTube channel, too. We put a lot of energy into that and would really appreciate you clicking that subscribe button, thanks.

name: Why VC Limited Partners Hate Capital Calls When The Market Is Down Huge?

snippet.description:

02:13 Notes
