Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsul...
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, I'm answering the question, what is a VC fund capital call? 

And so, as a refresher, VC funds raise money from big endowments, foundations, pension funds, and they essentially like draw down the capital, almost like a bank line, you just make a request of your LPs to send money into the funds bank accounts, and that money is then used to invest in startups. So everyone's got a boss and everyone's got someone they are raising money from in the ecosystem. And for VC funds, they're raising it from these big institutions. And so, when they essentially close the fund, like all the paperwork assigned, oftentimes VC funds will do something like, do a 10% draw down on the total commitment. 

So maybe a pension fund commits a hundred million dollars to a new VC fund and, at closing, the VC fund will send a capital call notice to that pension fund for 10%, $10 million of that $100 million dollars. And they'll do that for all their limited partners. And so, they'll amass a decent size amount of money in their bank account, the funds bank account, and then over the next six months or so, they will proceed to invest that money in startups. This is what they do, they invest money, they buy ownership, and they hope that company gets more valuable over time. And so, the VC capital calls tend to be kind of like 10%, 15% increments. 

So using my example before, once that 10% initial capital call is almost all used up, they'll issue another capital call notice and that capital call notice will have the bank wiring information for the fund, it'll say how much they're calling. Oftentimes, it'll also say how much of the commitment by that individual investor institution has already been called. So the investor institution kind of knows like, okay, I've already funded like 20% or 50% of my total commitment this fund so I can do some cash planning. So that's how it works. 

And then the VC fund will just continually invest the money and then do more capital calls. Now note, there's typically like you have like a 10 day or 30 day window to hit the capital call, like once you get the notice to fund the investment, that's all explained in the fund documents that all the LPs agree to. And the VC funds, again, want to be strategic, they don't want to do like rapid fire capital calls, like every two months or every month, they're doing a capital call. So they'll tend to spread it out. They do want to minimize what is called cash drag, which is doing too big of a capital call, having that money sitting in the bank account, earning very little interest, very little return, and then deploying it too slowly. 

And so, that can actually hurt a fund's returns because all venture capital funds are judged on both a multiple of capital they return and the IRR like the return interest rate, basically the internal rate return of the proceeds they generate. So a VC fund doesn't really want to have a ton of cash sitting on the balance sheet in their bank account. They want to have enough where they can comfortably make investments, where the LPs have good planning and have good visibility, know exactly when those capital calls are going to come, and then they want to have a smooth mechanical process, typically run by the fund accountants who are going to message all the LPs and ask for the commitments or the percentage of commitments that they should be getting. 

So I hope that helps, we also have some really good videos around like LP behavior and why LPs hate capital calls in a tough market.

name: What Is A VC Fund Capital Call, And How Do Capital Calls Work?

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, what is state tax nexus? This is a question we get a lot. 

A lot of our clients have people, employees, going through all out the country, and they're selling throughout the country. So this is a really important issue for people. So the basic of tax nexus is the relationship between a taxing authority and a business. And the way it goes is a business has to have tax nexus before it can be taxed. And so there's a couple different types of thresholds to establishing tax nexus. But the basic idea is you must have a prominent presence in a state. And so there's a couple ways for you to check and see if your company has tax nexus in a state. Kind of the simplest way is just to see if you have a state registration to do business in a given state. And the reason for that is, you will actually, when you start conducting business in a state, typically you have to register. And so that's kind of a nice little shortcut. 

And by the way, the state knows you registered with them. So they're more likely to check on you and make sure you're filing the right sales tax and tax returns, things like that. So that's the first really kind of shortcut way. The more established way is to evaluate whether you have employees, or assets or property in a state. That's basically like anyone who's really working in a state, you're gonna start triggering tax nexus. So for example, if you're a startup, and you have a W2 employee working in a state, and that W2 employee is renting office space, you are definitely gonna start triggering tax nexus in that state. That is, that's pretty clear cut. It's a little tougher to determine sometimes if there's just like a computer or some very small amount of assets in a state. But generally speaking, most of our clients are really kind of people businesses.  

Now, in the modern day, there's a lot of, you know, business conducted over the internet in the form of ecommerce sales, or software sales or service sales. And so the states a few years ago, felt like they're missing out. And so they brought, there was a big Supreme Court case called Wayfair versus South Dakota, and the Supreme Court ruled in favor of South Dakota. And that gave states the ability to tax businesses, even if they didn't have a physical presence in the state. So all sudden, online sales, online software sales, online diagnostic or some forms of biotech stuff, all of a sudden became taxable, if they pass a certain threshold. A lot of times that threshold is right around $100,000. And not all states are collecting this type of sales tax. 

But if you're doing business across the United States, and you have some states where you're getting close to that $100,000 threshold, it's getting very, very likely that you've actually created tax nexus, you'll have to file sales tax returns, and you'll probably have to file a state tax return. So I hope that helps. The big picture on tax nexus is that if you're doing business in a state
physically with employees, property, assets things like that you're pretty sure you've triggered tax nexus. And if you're doing business in the sense that you're selling a lot of goods or services over $100,000 usually. You've also probably triggered tax nexus. But we can do a study for you. We can help you out. We can parse this figure out if you really have triggered nexus and we can take care of all the forms you need to file. Thanks so much, bye.

name: What Is State Tax Nexus? Online Sales Tax Explained

snippet.title: Pro Rata Participation Rights In Future Financing For Angel And Seed Investors!
snippet.description:
In this video, you’ll learn if pro rata participation is a good strategy for angel and seed investors in future financing.

00:00 Introduction
00:21 Two major strategies
01:38 Second strategy
02:06 One of the key awesome terms
04:06 Benefit of very low cost basis in your first bite
04:25 Conclusion

***********************************
Additional Resources

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FBNe19SdRMA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qnTG6xizHaI

***********************************

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

#prorata #prorataparticipation #seedinvestors

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, "Should angel and seed investors buy all the shares they can, upfront, or should they save some of their capital for pro-rata participation in the future?" 

These are like the two major strategies in very early-stage investing, and I'll kind of go through them. So the first strategy is just like, "Hey, don't overthink it." You've got a certain amount of money you invest in each startup. Maybe you're an angel investor that does 25K or 50K, or you're a seed fund that does a million bucks. Some people think you should buy as many shares, aka, put all your money in, to the company, as early as possible. That gives you the lowest possible cost basis and the most shares possible, kind of going forward. 

So you look really, really smart in the big winners, because you just like backed up the truck and bought as much as possible at the earliest stage. You often see this in IPO prospectuses, where the VC firm will have an 11 cents cost basis, or 20-cent cost basis, and the company's IPOing at 50 bucks. These are huge winners, and you maximized your ownership at the earliest stage. Super-duper smart. This is actually the strategy I subscribe to. Like I do a little tiny bit of angel investing, and I actually believe in it this way, because just getting the benefit of those less expensive rounds, and doubling or tripling up on ownership, to me, is the right way to go. However, there is another strategy, which is, put a good chunk of money in early, you have conviction, you're gonna buy a bunch of shares, but save a percentage of your capital. 

Sometimes they're called reserves. We have another video on VC reserves, which you can check out, but save some of your money, usually it's kind of like 30% of whatever you were gonna invest in total, for future participations. And one of the key awesome terms that venture capitalists get are future pro-rata, meaning they can protect their ownership position by participating in future rounds. This is a contractual benefit they get. Now, there are times where seed investors or angels don't get this. There's often times where they're promised this, but then the big funds kind of elbow them out, and the founders request they don't exercise pro-rata. 

But generally speaking, pro-rata is an incredible option, because you only do your pro-ratas in the best companies. So if you think about the distribution of a angel or seed-stage portfolio, there's a lot of companies that don't make it, and a few big winners. And so being able to maximize the amount of capital and the number of participations you get in the winners is actually like crazy powerful optionality. So instead of, you know, for all those companies that you maximize your ownership in strategy one, that I subscribe to, you might be wasting like 30% of the capital that went into those companies, because you didn't save some for pro-rata, and some of those are gonna be losers, right? 

So the idea on strategy two, which is saving some reserves and participating along the way, is, "Heck, who cares if you're paying 5x or 10x more than your original cost basis in the huge winners", because you are concentrating your capital in those huge winners, you have the benefit of information and knowledge and track record, and can see exactly what's happening at that future point. And so that money is an incredible investment. So again, there's really, in angel and seed-stage investing, there's no real definitive method. 

Again, I like to get it all in at first, because sometimes you are at the risk where you actually don't get to do your pro-rata, even though you were promised it, or you're never promised it and you don't get to participate. And again, the benefit of that very, very low cost basis in your first bite of the apple can be very powerful, but hey, there's plenty of very successful angel and seed investors who do reserve 20, 30, 40% of their total capital committed for each company, and they play the pro-rata game, and they play it very effectively, and they have great returns, too.

name: Pro Rata Participation Rights In Future Financing For Angel And Seed Investors!

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question what is gross burn rate? 

And it's important to talk about this because gross burn rate is when you only look at your expenses. You are completely disregarding revenue, and I'll come back to that in a second. But gross burn rate is basically your operating expenses, any taxes, registrations and that kind of stuff. Some people also like to add in CapEx expenditures, which is a completely valid way of looking at it. But basically the amount of money going out the company's doors without factoring revenue in. And the reason to do this is it's the most conservative version of your burn rate. It's the highest, right? Because revenue would offset or reduce your burn rate. 

And it's important because it gives you the most conservative cash out date, AKA we're going to run out of cash sooner than if you factor in revenue. And the reason is in startups, revenue can really be volatile, can be up and down. You can have some traction, then traction can go away but you're still cranking as a company. So I personally like to look at it both ways. The first thing I do is look at regular burn rate that includes revenue and some generally hopefully conservative projections on revenue. But just to sanity check what I'm seeing there, I will then look at gross burn rate because I want to know the absolute worst case scenario. 

So again, gross burn rate is the worst case scenario for your cash out date, and it's good to know. You don't want to kid yourself. You really want to have that honest look. I always start again with factoring revenue projections in that are conservative, but right before you're done looking at your cash out date and what your burn is, always take a look at the gross burn rate. It'll be a really helpful sanity check. If you have other questions on burn rates or how to raise venture capital or seed stage companies or series A, series B, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. 

And if you don't mind, please click subscribe to our video channel. We put a lot of work and energy into this and we'll be very appreciative if you check out a few more of our videos. Thanks so much.

Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

It's a phrase I have found myself repeating quite a bit to a lot of the startup clients that Kruze works with, and even just people in the startup ecosystem. And the reason for that is we're recording this in late June, 2022, and the stock market has really corrected, like valuations have come way down. And yet there's a bunch of companies that frankly just need to raise money. And so it's really tough emotionally and kind of analytically to go to the venture capital market if you're a startup founder and just hear that like the valuation nowadays is half the size or two thirds the size of what you could have gotten six months ago. 

And when that valuation has been cut in half, so to speak, well, the dilution you're experiencing when you're selling stock in the company is really dramatic. It's a lot more than you would've experienced previously if you sold at a much higher valuation. And so there's this really painful kind of realization that the founders have to go through, and that's why I've been kind of telling them this phrase, like dilution never killed a company. Because really, they have a couple of options. They can cut expenses so deeply, but sometimes that's really kind of almost like self-inflicting, sometimes that just means you're not going to be able to hit your milestones and the company's actually going to be dead in the water anyways. 

So oftentimes the right move is to raise a little bit more of capital. And oftentimes, the only way you can kind of get that done in a tough market is to open up the last round valuation. And that might be six months ago, that might be a year ago. And the founder looks at it and says like, "I've made so much progress since I last raised money," but the investors are looking at it and saying like, "The market has changed. You know, that old valuation is actually higher than what it would be today, but I'm a believer in the company and so I'll write that extra check." And again, it's a huge emotional hurdle, analytically it's tough, but oftentimes it's the right thing for the company to do. And the company can raise a little bit of extra money, not cut to the bone, management has a very clear head, you can hit your future milestones. 

And oftentimes, in my experience, these really deep market troughs like we're experiencing right now, they're very rapid. Often, there's a pretty good bounce. And if you raised that additional capital and you kept your momentum up, you are going to benefit on the other side, like when the valuations swing back to a really positive area, you will benefit. Furthermore, I always encourage the founders to just do the dilution calculation on their own ownership, because a lot of times it's a lot smaller than you might think. 

And oftentimes, like two co-founders running a company, maybe take and raise at least one round, maybe two rounds, they'll own something like 25 to 35%, something like that. And say they do like a cheap and dilutive, you know, slash painful round, like I'm advocating for, taking just a little bit extra money. And maybe they sell 10% of the company for that, you know, again, just to keep the lights on, keep the momentum up and running. Well, if you own 30% in a company and you take 10% dilution, we really only lost three percentage points. 

Now you're down to 27%. And when you kind of do the math that way, it's easier to see that this isn't like a haircut in ownership that's going to like change your life or destroy your future financial upside. Really, what you're doing is giving the company the oxygen, the cash that it needs so that you have a much better chance of getting to an exit and actually getting a better realization on that remaining ownership you have.

name: What Is Dilution In a Company Value?

Seed stage companies, the size of rounds has been steadily creeping up over the years and now a lot of times seed stage companies are raising, you know, 3-5 million bucks. That used to be like a million and a half, two, but inflation and the frothier venture capital climate, are yielding bigger rounds. Even with the NASDAQ correcting, we're still seeing companies raise very, very healthy seed stage rounds. And by the way, the music has not stopped in that market, still lots of seed activity. Which is really good for entrepreneurs. 

One thing I always like to tell folks that asked me like, what's happening in the venture capital market. Guess what, startup founders never stop creating companies, they will, there will be the worst depression in the history of the United States, someday, and startup founders will still be creating new ventures and going and trying to change the world. So, the fundraising climate, of course, matters because it depends on, or factors into how much cash they're going to have to build their dream. But these people are committed, they're super smart, I feel very fortunate to get to work with them every single day at Kruze, and they will just keep going. So, in light of the new environment, though, and maybe you know, the $3 million seed is kind of back, that's probably more standard nowadays than like maybe the five or 4 million. How do you manage your cash, because guess what? Interest rates have been going up, that's part of the reason why the rounds are, you know, getting a little smaller, because people are getting more conservative in the startup market, or the tech market has corrected a little bit. Well, yields are climbing up, especially in money market funds, in short-term bond markets. 

And so, my advice to startup founders in the seed stage is still take advantage of smart cash management procedures. But safety is like of the most important thing possible for you, because most seed stage companies will raise like 18 months of cash, not 12, that's usually not enough time, sometimes they'll get it out to 24 months, which is great. But 18 months is usually what a seed stage round will get you and you have that amount of time to build, you know, a prototype or build a working product, get some customers and convince either a seed extension round or a Series A firm to come in and fund you going forward. So, you really can't afford to lose any of this money. Like you can't afford to buy like a 12-month bond and have interest rates keep going up and having to sell that at a discount and taking a haircut on your cash. 

So, keep the money very liquid, very safe. If you're going to, I personally recommend like, putting it into a money market fund with daily liquidity. That means you can pull the money out on a daily basis. So, whenever you need it, you pull it out, if there's an emergency, if the markets melting down, you can pull it out. The other option is buying bond ladders of very short maturity, like three months, maybe six months. But again, interest rates are going up. If interest rates go up, and you own a bunch of bonds and you need to sell those bonds, you're going to have to sell them at a discount, because whoever's buying them is going to want like, kind of the market rate of return, the market interest rate. 

So, be very, very careful with that. You can also keep the money in, you know, a portion of the money in a certificate of deposit at a bank, you again want to keep the maturity on that pretty light, probably like three months, the max you want to do there.

name: What Is The Seed Stage In Business Cash Management?

snippet.title: What is the Backsolve Method for 409A Valuation?
snippet.description:
What is the Backsolve Method for 409A Valuation?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about the Back-Solve Method for 409A valuations. 

And for those that don't know, there's a couple of different ways you get to a 409A evaluation, which is a, basically what a company uses to price its stock options, like the price per share of its common stock options. And so you've got the Back-Solve Method. You've got the cost to recreate. You've got a cashflow analysis. You have comparable company in M&A comps. Those are like kind of the big ways, but the Back-Solve Method is actually one of the most popular. And partially because it's, it's actually fairly simple. And it's actually one of the things that have allowed 409A valuations to come down in price. Like 15 years ago, 409A evaluations costs, you know, like 20 grand something crazy. 

Nowadays it's, you know, $2,000 to $5,000 basically, is the price. So the Back-Solve Method basically looks at the last round a startup has completed, assuming it's fairly recent, kind of 12 to 18 months is really like that zone that you want to be looking at. If it's an older valuation than that, the Back-Solve Method may not be appropriate because the valuation isn't that fresh. And essentially the Back-Solve Method assumes that very smart professional investors have priced that last round at a respectable price with the market clearing prices, and therefore, valuation professionals can rely on that price. However, the previous valuation is typically a preferred stock valuation because you know, like investors, VCs, they want liquidation preferences and redemption rights and other kinds of, of terms that go in preferred. 

While, you know, again, the common stock doesn't have that kind of stuff. And so people actually apply a discount against the preferred to get the common stock. So the Back-Solve Method would take the previous valuation, and then it's typically going to be the sum of a couple of different discounts, like marketability and some other things. You're typically going to get something like 25 to 35% of the preferred price is going to be common. So let's just take $10 a share for the preferred price. And we're going to apply our discounts. We're going to back-solve to the common price and it's going to end up being, you know, something like $2.50 to $3.50 per share. So again, you're relying on the professional investors, who've priced the previous round, but because that previous round is typically in preferred stock, you're going to apply a couple different discounts. 

And you're usually going to get to about kind of the ratio of 25 to 35% common to preferred. So I hope that helps. I know it's a little complicated, but really when you see it applied a couple of times and you read a few 409A evaluations, it's pretty clear. And again, that is one of the things that has made 409A valuations, so much cheaper, so much affordable, and really every company should get one when they're issuing stock options. I hope that helps.

name: What is the Backsolve Method for 409A Valuation?

snippet.title: How to account for seed or venture capital raises on your balance sheet?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Raising venture debt? Research key terms and negotiating strategies at https://kruzeconsulting.com/venture-debt/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, I'm answering the question, how do you account for seed investment in your startup? Now, there are four main ways. Convertible debt, safe notes, preferred equity, and common stock. So, let's go through them in order. 

Convertible debt is debt just like it says. It typically converts into equity at a set valuation down the road. But when the money comes into the company, you wanna book that as debt and only convert it once actually documentation is signed for the conversion. Next, is safe notes. 

Now, safe notes are equity. Now, sometimes lawyers will disagree on this, but we're very confident it's equity. That goes in the equity section of your balance sheet. Eventually, that too will convert into preferred stock, but for the time being, when the money comes in, book it as its own line item on the balance sheet in the equity section. 

Next, is preferred equity. This is typically what big VCs like institutions like to invest in, because as a liquidation preference and other perks, that will be preferred equity and that will be on the equity component of your balance sheet. And you want to make sure that's its own line item as well. And typically, what we like to do is book series A, series B, series C, as their own line items so it's really easy to keep track and make sure you don't get confused. It makes reconciling against the CAP table so much easier. 

Finally is common stock. Now common stock is equity. It's typically what the founders own. It's very rare for an investor to come in in common stock, but it does happen once in a while, so I wanted you to be aware of it. But most of the time, that's gonna reflect the founders and management team ownership in the company. Not real professional investment. Now, I hope this helps. 

The four ways that you can book your equity or seed investment into your company. So, we've got convertible debt, safe notes, equity, preferred equity, and common equity. Hope that helps. Thanks, bye.

name: How to account for seed or venture capital raises on your balance sheet?

We're here to talk about deferred revenue and why it's important to a lot of different startups. What is deferred revenue? Deferred revenue, otherwise known as unearned revenue, is really important to startups that receive payments or prepayments upfront for their service. Deferred revenue is technically a liability that will show up on your balance sheet. 

A side note, since balance sheets balance, the asset that goes on the balance sheet to make the balance sheet balance would generally be cash. And obviously, startups appreciate cash. Now I'm going to ignore the fact that there could be receivables which might complicate the balance sheet a little bit and just stick with talking about deferred revenue. 

So, why is deferred revenue a liability? Deferred revenue is a liability because you've gotten cash or payment, and in exchange, you owe your client a future service you have not yet delivered the service that they've paid you for. So it's a liability because you owe that to them. Let's do a pretty simple deferred revenue example. Let's say you're a software as a service startup.  A SAAS startup Your service is one hundred dollars a month and a client prepays for the full year. 

So, they give the startup twelve hundred dollars. In that very first month startup is able to recognize 100 dollars’ worth of revenue so they deliver one hundred dollars’ worth of their service to that client. Now the deferred revenue balance was that full cash amount that they received the twelve hundred dollars. And then minus the one hundred dollars, that's recognized. So, at the end of that first month, there is an eleven hundred dollar deferred revenue balance for this client. The next month the startup delivers another one hundred dollars’ worth of service, recognizes another one hundred dollars’ worth of revenue and the deferred revenue balance again goes down one hundred dollars from eleven hundred dollars to one thousand dollars. And this will continue over the life of the contract until the last month when the last one hundred dollars is recognized and this startup has a zero-dollar balance in their deferred revenue account. 

So, the cash impacts of this can be confusing. Let's assume that you only sell that single contract. So, your revenue looks like over the course of the 12 months that you have one hundred dollars in revenue every month but you only got your cash up front. You got the twelve hundred dollars up front and you did not receive any other cash during the lifetime of that customer relationship. 

So, if your startup has expenses like most do you'll see your cash balance going down. Your bank account will be decreasing even though you're recognizing the same amount of revenue every month. And that's because all the cash came in upfront and then you're delivering the service over time. 

So that's a very high-level explanation of deferred revenue. And I hope that's helpful.

name: Startups Deferred Revenue

snippet.title: How Good Bookkeeping Pays for Itself
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, how can good bookkeeping pay for itself? 

Now, a lot of people try to save money by hiring a bad bookkeeper or the Craigslist Special, or maybe someone who claims to be automated but they really just have a giant team in the Philippines or something like that. So those are examples of bad bookkeeping, and believe me, that is super costly. But a lot of people know that good bookkeeping can actually pay for itself. So here's a couple reasons. 

The first way is you actually know what you're spending money on. You could actually look at your financials, they're accurate, and you can quickly cut your burn, especially in times like COVID because you know where the pockets of extra spend are just through having accurate financials. So that's one way. The second way is you fly through VC or M&A due diligence. I can't tell you how many times and how pleased that makes me when a founder calls me and says, "Hey, I just got a term sheet." Or, "Hey, I just got a verbal offer "from an M&A company that's gonna buy us." And they say, "What do we need to do? "We probably need to scramble "and fix a bunch of stuff in our financials." And I get to say, "Actually, they're done. "They're perfect, we're good. "Send 'em the financials." 

So that signal and ability to move fast, really makes VC and M&A due diligence so much faster. Your financials do not become an issue. They do not slow down a deal. They do not make the investors think that you might be disorganized or don't have a good feel for your business and therefore give you a lower valuation. 

So that's another way that bookkeeping can really pay for itself. And then the other thing that people don't always think about, but this happens a lot with some of the automated accountants, is that we constantly are coming in and finding missed invoices or missed payments. So a very simple example is, maybe someone at the automated place, but probably has a big staff in the Philippines or somewhere else, just marked the invoice paid that was never paid, and is never caught. And we've found so many 20, 25, $30,000 invoices that were never collected or the invoice was deleted by a poor accountant, and so the management team didn't know about it. So that happens all the time. 

The other thing that happens is that vendors are double paid. But because it's poor accounting, you actually don't know you double paid the vendor because the accountant couldn't figure it out. And so those are two examples where it's pretty big dollar amounts that are either missing or going out twice that a good accountant would catch, and it'd really pay for like their whole annual fee, just one time. And then the fourth reason why I think good bookkeeping pays for itself, is when we have good bookkeeping, it's very easy to do an R&D tax credit, and you can get your rebate on your payroll taxes very quickly. 

Now a lot of startups don't know about this, but you actually have to submit highly detailed audits or an actual plan of what R&D happened, who was doing it, you know, time logs, estimates, all that stuff, but it all starts with good bookkeeping with the salary breakouts and knowing what other tools were used for that R&D.

So a good bookkeeper makes your R&D credit a heck of a lot easier, which can be really big dollars. Last year we saved our clients $4 1/2 million, an average about $40,000 per R&D credit. 

So having a good bookkeeper, it's good financial hygiene, it makes your life easier, it's way less stressful. It makes your VC diligence so much easier, but it also pays for itself. Hope that helps. Thanks.

name: How Good Bookkeeping Pays for Itself

snippet.title: How to structure Ownership in the Cap Table Between Founders
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

The first one is you're always gonna take common stock, everyone on the management team is gonna take common stock. You don't wanna have one of the founders having preferred and a liquidation preference over everyone. That's just weird, that's not gonna happen. 

The second thing is you really wanna have a vesting period on everyone's shares and what this does is it protects the founders that end up staying with the company for many years from some of the other founders who might leave after a year or two. By having a vesting period, typically it's a four-year or a five-year vesting period, where you vest, if it's a five-year vesting period you vest 20% of your stock every year and usually there's a one-year cliff, so you vest 20% after the first year and then you do the rest of it on a monthly basis. 

Now there's another thing that gets discussed, it's kind of a tough topic, but sometimes you do not wanna have equal ownership between the founders. Now this is the case when one of the founders is gonna make a more significant contribution than the others. A typical founding pair might be one kind of business or sales or strategy person and a technical founder. That's kind of the combo we see quite a bit at Kruze Consulting, but maybe the technical person was recruited late to the idea and they weren't the person that really took the germ of the idea and really built it out. 

I have one other pro tip for all the founders out there. This isn't about the ownership split but please, for the love of God, file your 83b filing with the IRS within 30 days of founding the company and buying your founder shares, it is so important. Make sure that it is certified mail, keep that receipt for the rest of your life. You do not wanna screw up the 83b. This happens occasionally, it is really hard to reverse. The 83b basically gives you a really low cost basis and you can get capital gains on all your appreciation after that. 

So have the tough conversation with the ownership split, have the tough conversation around the vesting period, and then after you have that conversation shake hands, hug, and then fill out that 83b form and walk over to the post office and mail it together. You will be covered, you will not have to worry about that kind of stuff. I hope that helps, thanks.

name: How to structure Ownership in the Cap Table Between Founders

snippet.title: Vesting Period Explained in Under 2 Minutes
snippet.description:
What is a vesting period?

In this video, we explain to you what a vesting period is and how it plays a role with vested stock options at a startup.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts 

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, what is a vesting period at a startup? 

And basically a vesting period talks about how you get your stock options. And so when you join a startup, you typically get some stock options, like a little bit of ownership in the company, but you vest those shares over, typically, four years. And the basic idea is they're giving you stock options to try to help retain you. They recognize that you're working in the company, you're putting your blood, sweat, and hopefully no tears, but maybe some tears, into the company. 

And so you get a little bit of equity in the company. But instead of giving that equity to you all at once and saying, "Thank you very much," if they did that, you might just leave and have all the stock. And so what they do is they vest it over, typically, four years. So the first 12 months are typically called a cliff, meaning you don't vest anything until you complete those full 12 months. 

Then after that, you start vesting on a monthly basis. All the way up till typically that 48 month period, you know, four years times 12 months in a year. But again, you're just gonna get a little sliver of stock every month, essentially, and the employer, the startup is hoping that helps keep you at the startup because you start seeing a lot of upside. And sometimes you even get like a second or third equity grant that will have its own vesting schedule for those equity grants. So I hope that helps. 

The kind of moral of the story is you're not gonna get all the stock right up front. It's gonna come over time, which frankly helps align you and the startup because the startup wants you there and it needs you to create value over time. But hopefully that value is pretty huge and the stock price goes up and you can make some money on that. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Vesting Period Explained in Under 2 Minutes

snippet.title: Startup Budgeting
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Does your VC backed startup need help to manage your books, burn, and projections? Kruze’s clients have raised over $3.5 billion in venture funding - find out how we help companies fly through diligence and raise the next round: https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-venture-capital-finance-experts/ 

Video Transcript:

Let's talk about startup budgeting. Having a solid budget helps your startup hit its goals without prematurely running out of cash. A number of us here at Kruze Consulting have worked in fast-growing startups and we've compiled our tips on how to make this budgeting process work. The most important thing is you need to understand or have a vision of what your long-term strategy is and what you need to do to achieve those goals. You'll want to bake your budget around what your strategy is, and the budget is actually the financial representation of that strategy. You got to make sure your team knows what the strategy is - what your financial goals are in terms of the revenue that you need to hit and the cash need to burn. Or what features need to be built and then you'll want to start to pay careful attention to the key parts of the budget. So, for most early-stage startups, the biggest part of burn is headcount. So, you want to pay careful attention to your headcount projections over the coming year and because you'll put this together with your team and your team will have their headcount projections. It will really help them manage their team in a particular know when they need to start recruiting so they'll know when they

should be able to bring on additional heads. You should have a very strong opinion on what the revenue should be over the next year. So for example, if you're a SAAS company you should know what your next milestone needs to be in terms of recurring revenue so that you can successfully raise your next round. And then you'll want to build your plan and your budget around what it takes to get there. You want to be very careful around your burn rate. So you want to know how much money you're burning so that you don't prematurely run out of money. And then you'll want to know what your monthly burn is at the end of the year like the burn of the exit with at the end of the year so that you can project your cash out date. 

You want to make sure you're not...  You want to make sure that you run out of cash when you expect to run out of cash which hopefully aligns with you being worth more and raising more capital. Once you've got all this put together you can make sure that it's carefully shared with your department leaders so they can come back and build their detailed budgeting plans with you.  And also, they can very clearly understand what their goals are. I hope this helps you with your startup's budgeting.

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about what does a good startup CFO do? 

And the first thing a CFO does for startups is to manage the financial reporting. That means making sure the books are closed and closed correctly every month. 

Typically, that's Quick Books management. So, when a startup CFO at Kruze is working with a client, of course, they are managing the internal Kruze team. The staff accountants, the controllers, making sure that the financials are delivered quickly, making sure delivered accurately, and also making sure all the questions get answered. 

A lot of times there's questions for the CEO. How do you spend money on this? What vendors that? What time period does this cover? Those are all questions that a good startup CFO can solve or answer very, very quickly. 

The second thing is the financial projections. Managing the actual financial model, building the financial model, in most cases. Also doing the budget actuals. It's great to have a financial model with the beauty of that is you can actually track see how you're doing. That way you can give reports to the board, to the CEOs, so the CEO knows how they're tracking against all of the other metrics. 

Also, helping manage a financial or capital raise. So, a lot of times we're doing this in the context of venture debt for our clients, but also our clients are always raising Series A, Series B, Series C. So, managing that process, making sure the PowerPoint's updated, making sure the most recent financial model is ready to go. Those are all super important things and also just getting back to investors diligence requests. Investors and lenders ask for tons of information and so having a CFO who can actually get that back to the investor is very, very helpful. And 

finally, there's a bunch of legal things that happen in startups: there's insurance, there are leases, there are loan documents; there's tons of stuff that the CFO can actually manage for the CEO. And again, when you're hiring a startup CFO, which are really trying to do as a CEO of a startup, is extend your time and make sure you have someone who's really strong, solving problems that you could probably solve, but don't really want to because you want to build product and get more customers and build your company. 

And so, the things that a good startup CFO does is own financial reporting, own financial model projections, and also own legal and all the documentation that goes along with it. Hope that helps. Thanks.

snippet.title: Why Do Startups Need a 409 Evaluation
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

If you’re a startup issuing equity compensation (Options/NQSO/ISO), you’ll need a 409A for startup purposes. Get started now at https://kruzeconsulting.com/409a_valuation/

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today we're talking about why these startups need a 409A valuation. Well, the quick part of that is the IRS requires it. The IRS wants you to have a 409A valuation so they can make sure that your common stock options have the appropriate strike price. Now, back in the day, in the good, old days, the board of directors used to just make up a number for the strike price for options, and oftentimes that was usually one penny because it's the simplest thing to do, but the IRS realized that that usually wasn't representative of the real value or price per share of those options, and so they started mandating 409A valuations. Now, the good news is, we do 409A valuations. We have a great page on our website that explains how much that costs starting at $1,500, all the documentation you need to actually do one, and we can do it in 10 days, so that's fantastic, but you just know that what you're really doing is buying audit protection. You're making sure that you have an independent, third-party value your company, value the common stock, and document that, document why the value is actually what it is. Typically, there are ways of doing it like the back-solve method or cost to recreate. Sometimes people use a discounted cash flow or comparable company costs. Those are the ways people do evaluations to get to this price per share that the common stock should be issued at. Again, what you're really doing is making sure the IRS is happy and that if you ever get audited you're protected because you used a valid third-party. Hope that helps on 409A valuations. Thanks.

name: Why Do Startups Need a 409 Evaluation

snippet.title: Do Venture Capitalists Use a 409A Valuation to Value a Startup?
snippet.description:
Do Venture Capitalists Use a 409A Valuation to Value a Startup?

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today I'm answering the question, do venture capitalists use a 409A valuation to value a startup? 

And this is a very common question from founders, and basically, let's define a 409A first. The IRS requires startups to do a 409A valuation process from an accredited valuation provider to price the common stock price, which is used as the exercise price for employee stock options. So you gotta keep the IRS happy. They don't want you issuing stock options at too low of a valuation, and so you do a 409A. 

But, everyone around the table at the company typically wants the 409A price to be pretty low. The reason for that is it helps with employee retention. If the employees have a lower valuation, they have more incentive with the stock price rising, and it's also cheaper for them to exercise those options. We've all heard of those horrible stories of employees not having enough money when they leave a company to exercise, and so they have to just forfeit those options. 

So, pretty much everyone, the board, the management team, and the employees want that stock option price to be low, within reason and within fairness. Now, the problem that founders feel is they're worried that the venture capitalist will take that low valuation and then effectively low ball them on the price of their next round. They're saying, "Hey, this is documentation. This is what the company is worth. Why don't we pay this low price instead of the normal high price?" And it's a totally understandable concern. 

However, you do not have to worry about that. Investors will almost never even talk about the 409A price except to approve it in a board meeting. They know that they are buying preferred stock, and not common stock. And preferred has liquidation preferences, it has redemption provisions, it has share class vote, which gives them a really strong ability to control the company. There's dividends, there's just a lot of things in preferred stock that are much better terms than common stock. And so, they know that they are always gonna pay up and pay a higher valuation for the preferred stock. And that's really what the round gets priced on. 

Now, if you do have a venture capitalist who's using a 409A price, you need to get a new venture capitalist, so don't sign that term sheet. Go find someone else. But again, VCs are very savvy. They know that the 409A is not to be used against a founder, and that the company effectively wants those prices to be low. So, don't worry about it. Get the 409A valuation. Send your conservative financials in to your valuation provider. Make sure you pick the comparable companies that are good matches, but also conservative. And you may even do a cost to recreate for the valuation provider. That will set you up, you'll get your accurate price. 

And you're not gonna have to worry about your VC negotiating against you using that 409A price. Hope that helps, thanks.

name: Do Venture Capitalists Use a 409A Valuation to Value a Startup?

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm talking about how startup CFOs charge for their services. 

A startup CFO can be a terrific advisor to a startup. They help them with financial modeling, budget to actuals, they help with board prep. They can do a lot of operational things, like insurance, leases. There's a million things a startup CFO can do. Obviously they're going to review the financials every month and make sure everything's accurate, tighten that stuff up, get feedback or info from the management team. 

And so it's a really great tool. We typically see startup CFOs. The average startup CFO typically has three or four clients and they charge one of two ways. The first one is they just bill an hourly rate, like $250 an hour to $350 an hour. And that's pretty standard. It ranges, obviously, it's always negotiable, of course. But startup CFOs are in pretty high demand right now so the kind of negotiation leverage is on their side. I tend to see that in the market. But also some of them will just do a fixed monthly fee and allocate one full day per week to you. 

So like, every Tuesday they're going to work with your company, and they carry those three or four clients, so they have, theoretically, Friday is a flux day that they can spend more time with a certain client or really get in the weeds with and provide more advisory. But it's usually that monthly fixed fee, or they bill on an hourly rate. You do have to worry, or one thing to kind of validate is make sure the CFO is not getting overextended. I have a lot of friends who, unfortunately, sometimes they end up having to take more clients than they want, whether it's a mandate from the firm they're working for or what, and they kind of complain to me privately that they end up only being able to spend like two hours or one hour a month on a given client, especially the small clients. 

And at that point, they're not really adding value and they actually feel bad they're not adding value. The whole reason they got into this business was to be helpful and help startups grow. And so it becomes a sub-optimal relationship for them. So you want to really make sure they're not taking on too many clients, and the good ones will tell you. The good ones will also say, "You know what, I'm too busy right now," and, "Let me check in with you in six months." I hear that constantly, especially in the market we're in right now. So I hope that helps on kind of the ways they charge and what to look for. The one other little way of approaching this problem is, you break up the kind of services you need in the sense that, say you just need a model and budget to actuals, well, you could work with someone like Kruze who does our, we have CFOs but we also have just an FP&A group that does the financial model and monthly budget to actuals. 

And I find sometimes when clients or prospects actually talk to me and they say like, "I need a CFO," what they're actually really asking for is that month, is the financial model to share with their investors or raise capital off of, and then that monthly budget to actual cadence. It's actually very popular and it's a great way to manage your company. Seeing where you're kind of overextended or spent too much money in a given category or under-invested in a given category on a monthly basis, is very, very valuable. And so I really recommend that service. 

So hopefully this helps. CFOs, very, very helpful, great resource. I think every startup should consider this, or at the very least the monthly budget to actuals. And if you have any other questions hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. We do have some free models on our website, so you can check that out too, if you want to build your own and we look forward talking to you, thank you.

Hi, guys, I'm Vanessa with Kruze Consulting, and today I wanted to take a little bit more time to talk to you about the R&D tax credit. Specifically, is my startup eligible for the R&D tax credit payroll offset? 

And the answer is... Most likely but there are a few qualifications. So, first, your startup must be new. Only startups that have generated revenue for five years or less can claim the new tax credit. That means that if you had receipts prior to 2012 then you're ineligible. 

And second, your startup must have made less than 5 million in revenue in 2018. and each subsequent year that you actually claim the payroll offset in the future.

snippet.title: Tips for Setting up Gusto
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting and today we're talking about three tips for Gusto users after you've signed up. So now you've made your big payroll decision. You're working with Gusto. And the first little thing that comes up sometimes is that people don't know Gusto has two-day payroll and four-day payroll. Meaning they take the money out of your account four days before payroll or two days. Now, we all like having more money in our account. We can make an interest that way. So most people like two-day payroll. But to get to two-day payroll, you have to go through Gusto's assurance teams because they need to make sure you have enough money in your account for them to take that little bit of risk that you are worth it and they can float you the money for those two days. So the big kind of mess up sometimes comes when people don't realize your two-day payroll has a dollar limit. So sometimes when companies grow really fast, they start exceeding that dollar limit of payroll. Sometimes it's fifty thousand, sometimes seventy-five thousand. So you need to remember if you are on two-day payroll to keep pushing your maximum payroll amount up with Gusto. That means you need to check-in probably once a quarter given your size, your company, and your hiring needs, and just make sure you're still eligible for two-day payroll. And to see if you need to push up your limit just a little bit more. A second thing that people sometimes make a little mess up on is they don't know that when they hire a new employee in a different state, Gusto wants you to sign up to do business in that state. And also sign up for payroll taxes in that state. Things like unemployment tax, that kind of stuff. Well, when you hire that new employee in another state, it puts an immediate block on your payroll. People don't know that. Founders don't know that. So usually we're giving them the heads up. We'll register you in those other states and register for payroll taxes but just know your payroll on autopilot is blocked. Now a really easy way to solve this... Just let us know at Kruze and we'll send Gusto a quick little note asking for an extension on the block. Usually, they give us like a 30-day block extension. That way you can run payroll normally for two weeks or four weeks and while you're processing that registration in the state it's really easy, but it's something that sometimes people just forget about. And the third thing to remember is when you have a big accounting partner like Kruze Consulting that does a ton of business with Gusto, we actually get premium support. So Gusto answers our emails and phone calls before they answer the founder's emails and phone calls. This is not something they advertise, but they're used to doing business with us. They know that we're super knowledgeable. We know that we're very efficient and we're not going to waste our time. So they prioritize us. So if you're working with someone like Kruze, ask them to send Gusto a support message. They'll get the question answered a lot faster. Instead of sitting there for a couple of days waiting for Gusto to get back to you because you're lower in the queue. The Kruze Consulting team will get answered probably within the day. So those are three little tips for Gusto users for startups after you sign up for Gusto. So now you're using the product. I hope that helps. Thanks.

name: Tips for Setting up Gusto

snippet.title: Trinet Review for Startups
snippet.description:
Trinet Review for Startups

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping, finance, or taxes? Visit Kruze to see if our team can help you! https://kruzeconsulting.com

TriNet basically works as your payroll, your HR solution, they do some tax compliance and they also handle all your benefits and they also handle R&D tax credits for you. So it's an all-in-one big bundled solution. And it's pretty effective. And there's a little wrinkle in TriNet and other PEOs in that when they work with a client, like a startup, the startup's employees actually have a direct employment relationship with TriNet and kinda like a secondary employment relationship with the startup. 

And because of this, that's where the professional employer organization title comes in, because of that, TriNet is able to pool all of its different clients' employees and because they can do that, they can actually negotiate better terms with all the medical insurance companies. And so you can imagine, a small startup with 20 employees is not gonna get the same type of rates, I'm making a gross generalization here, but as someone like TriNet who has probably hundreds of thousands of employees under their umbrella. So it's really attractive in that aspect. 

The other attractive aspect is that TriNet will do all your payroll and they're also gonna handle your HR. And so when you have an issue, TriNet is very, very responsive on the HR front because guess what? They're sharing some of the liability with you. So they wanna make sure that things get done correctly, they get done quickly and both the employee and the employer is protected. So that's a really nice feature. 

Now, one of the other things that TriNet will handle for you is your state tax compliance. They don't every state, they don't handle everything but in a lot of states, they will help register you in that state and help register you for payroll taxes. Now, this is really nice, especially in the COVID era that we're in right now because we're seeing a lot of employees moving throughout the country and it's happening at Kruze, it's happening at our clients and so having a PEO solution who will actually handle that for you and again, share some of the liabilities so they're motivated to do it correctly is actually really nice. It's a nice value-add, simplifies the founder's life. 

Now, the alternative is our clients usually just have us do it and we're happy to do it. It's very inexpensive but hey, that's not our favorite thing to do either. So if TriNet's gonna do it, that's great. Now, there is one little negative with TriNet in that they do charge a pretty healthy subscription fee. So when you compare them against other payroll and benefits providers, those other providers typically are not as full service as TriNet. So they're significantly cheaper. 

TriNet is again, you're kinda like paying for, I think I'll date myself here, but the Cadillac Package. You're paying for the premium bundle and again, you can see how it's saving you a lot of time and money but they're gonna charge for that. So just know that TriNet's gonna be a little bit more expensive than a traditional payroll and HR firm. There's one other small downside and it's pretty much been handled now but TriNet, because they pool all of their clients, they have some pretty complicated IRS tax forms they have to file with the government and in terms of R&D tax credits, the R&D tax credits kind of get pooled as well. 

So in the early days, three years ago, when R&D tax credits were first emerging, this was a little bit of an issue but TriNet did get certified by the IRS and they are good to go now. We're not having any issues with them on our new tax credits. In fact, they've very responsive and easy to work with on that. So that's something that they've actually improved over the last few years, which is really, really nice. 

So I think there's a lot of positives with TriNet, again, they're gonna handle all your payroll, they're gonna handle your benefits, they're gonna handle those hot HR issues that no one really wants to deal with. They're gonna handle your state tax compliance, which is really nice. Again, they're not gonna do it all but they're gonna do a lot of it so it's gonna save you time. 

And you just have to realize you're gonna pay a little bit more than what a traditional payroll and benefits provider asks for because they are giving you a really premium service. So check out TriNet. We really recommend it. We like working with them a lot. Super nice people. And I think the final thing is they've invested a lot in their customer support in the last couple of years. 

In the past, it was okay but now it's gotten a lot better and so we're very happy to recommend TriNet to our clients. Thanks.

name: Trinet Review for Startups

snippet.title: What is a PEO? Professional Employer Organization Pros and Cons
snippet.description:
In this video, we'll discuss what a professional employer organization (PEO) is, how they work, and what the benefits, pros, and cons are.

*************************************
Additional Resources

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VVOkjo7uwWw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OxkeKha3ptQ&t=35s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nBhDdf-NMWw&t=2s

*************************************

#PEO #ProfessionalEmployerOrganization #PEOBusiness #PEOProsandCons

Be sure to subscribe for more accounting, HR, and finance tips for your startup.
https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting?sub_confirmation=1

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting?sub_confirmation=1
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting


Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today, we're talking about PEOs, professional employer organizations. 

And so what PEOs do is they basically handle your startup's HR services. So payroll, benefits, HR policy, HR counseling. They also do a lot of tax stuff, like they help with state and local taxes in some instances. Not always, you kinda have to check it out state by state. And they usually don't do much on the municipality front. But PEOs are actually a really interesting approach to solving your HR problems. 

Now the interesting about PEOs is that instead of your employees working for the startup directly, the PEO is actually the employer of record, which means like the employees of the company actually sign a contract with the PEO, and they have kind of like a third relationship, kinda off to the side a little bit with the startup. So it sounds a little weird. But what it does is allows the PEO to pool all of their employees across all their clients, and actually negotiate better benefit rates. 

So typically PEOs, they're kind of like negotiating like they're a Fortune 500 company you know. They have a lot of power when they're talking to BlueCross, or Anthem, or Kaiser, those kinda folks. And so that's actually one of the big benefits of PEOs is that you can often get lower benefit costs if you work through a PEO. The other benefit of a PEO is they will handle some of that state and local tax compliance, which is really nice. And because your employees are basically employees of the PEO, they have a super vested interest in making sure your HR policies are correct, HR problems are handled correctly so there's no liability. So those are the positives. 

Sometimes on the negative side, PEOs tend to be a lot more expensive. They actually charge like a monthly fee per employee. That's much, much higher than Gusto or Rippling. So you're getting a benefit on one side with lower benefits cost and some of the extra services. But you're also paying more. That's kinda why I call it like, it's kinda like a Cadillac policy. It's taking the luxury approach. 

However in times of COVID, this can actually be really smart because as employees are spreading out throughout the country, I know this is happening at Kruze, you're starting to have to worry about more local and state tax, like payroll taxes and registrations. 

So the PEO can really help you out there. And you have to worry about benefits in all these other states if the employees are gonna be there permanently. So COVID is actually driving a lot more interest in PEOs, which I find pretty interesting. Now a couple other downsides of PEOs. We've kinda noticed that the PEOs are not as effective or as fast at filing R&D tax credits and getting those rebate checks. And there's this thing called a certified, like the IRS basically certifies the PEO to be able to handle this stuff. So if your PEO that you're working with has not been certified, then that's not good. Your R&D tax credit's gonna have some real problems we've had this experience with kinda some lesser PEOs. Our favorites are Sequoia, TriNet, and Justworks. Those are kinda the "big three" in our world and the Kruze world. 

So if you're working with someone else, odds are they're probably not doing the R&D tax credit correctly or quickly enough, and you might have some problems. And it's a little tricky for the PEOs because again, that benefit they get from pooling employees on the insurance benefit side, that actually kinda works against them on the R&D tax credit side, because a lot of  times, they're having to pool all these R&D tax credit filings underneath their own EIN number, which makes that super complicated and if there's a hangup somewhere, then a lot of companies' R&D tax credits are hung up. So you just need to investigate that.

name: What is a PEO? Professional Employer Organization Pros and Cons

snippet.title: What are the advantages of using a Global PEO to pay foreign employees?
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping/ 

Video Transcript:

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today we're talking about what are the advantages of using a global PEO to pay for employees? 

Now, almost every company we work with has some type of team member, or many team members, distributed globally. It's just like how the world's going these days. So you need to be able to pay those team members. Now, what a global PEO is, is basically they're groups or companies that have set up foreign entities across the globe. So, they've done all the paperwork, all the hard compliance work, set up payroll relationships, and can run payroll and pay your employees in a bunch of different companies. So it really simplifies your life. If you're gonna have employees throughout the world. 

And the importance of actually running payroll and making sure those employees are paid is important because, A., hey, everyone likes to be an employee. You get some perks that you probably wouldn't get as a contractor, but more importantly, you're in compliance in those countries. You are giving those countries their payroll taxes and every government across the world loves payroll taxes. So you don't wanna be avoiding payroll taxes. You wanna make sure you're in compliance, especially as you start building a really big presence in that country. 

And so typically, there's two options. You can either do the global PEO or you can start a whole legal entity called a subsidiary and operate that subsidiary in the foreign country. But of course, doing that subsidiary actually creates a lot of legal costs, a lot of compliance headaches. And frankly, it's just distracting. It's not something like a startup should really be doing until they have like a 10 or 20 person presence in a country. And so that's where the global PEO comes in. You don't have to worry about getting that subsidiary going. You don't have to worry about filing tax returns for that subsidiary. It just works. 

Now, you do pay a premium and it's expensive. It's not cheap, but they're just saving you so much money. So that's typically what we do. We recommend that a company, when they start hiring in another country, start with a global PEO, and then once they've built a big presence, usually we kinda say 10 people is where the break even point is. 

Then you should look at starting a subsidiary, but global PEOs can be very cost-effective and most important, they're easy. And when you're running a startup, focus is super important. You need to build your product, you need to get customers. You don't wanna be dealing with foreign payroll and foreign subsidiaries. Now, I hope that helps. Thanks so much!

name: What are the advantages of using a Global PEO to pay foreign employees?

snippet.description:

MORE FROM KRUZE CONSULTING:
Website ► https://kruzeconsulting.com/
YouTube ► https://www.youtube.com/c/KruzeConsulting?sub_confirmation=1
Facebook ► https://www.facebook.com/KruzeConsulting
Twitter ►https://twitter.com/KruzeConsulting

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting, and today I'm answering the question, what does the VP of Ops or COO at a startup do? 

And really the answer is a little bit of everything. I like to think of the COO or VP of Ops as like, if you're in a rock band, the Founder or CEO is typically like the lead singer, and you, COO, I'm a COO, so I can say this, you are like the bassist, or you're the drummer. You're very necessary for the company to make beautiful music, but you're kinda not the person that's out front and center for the company, that's typically the Founder or CEO. But that's okay, if your personality is suited to that and you enjoy the work, it's an incredible job. I enjoy my job thoroughly. So let's go through some of the functional things that a COO does. 

Almost always the COO at a startup will be, or a VP of Ops will manage the finances. They'll work with an accounting team like Kruze to make sure all the monthly financials happen, the financials get closed, all questions are answered. Revenue Rec, expenses are all done correctly. All tax compliance is done correctly, like the tax return gets filed, your R&D Tax Credit gets done. Often, you'll be interviewed as part of the R&D Tax Credit process to make sure all the employee engineer allocations are done correctly, and the projects are documented. 

But finance is gonna be something you do spend a lot of time on. Now, when you hire a VP of Finance or a CFO, this'll be much less part of your day. And that's kind of the rule for the VP of Ops or COO, you kinda have a lot of responsibility in the early days, and most startups kind of constantly are hiring like a functional expert to take things off your plate and the CEO's plate. That's just the name of the game, and really, it's always very refreshing when a company brings in someone to take a functional aspect of the company off your plate. It's very, very nice. 

So you're gonna do finance. You will probably run, or have recruiting and HR reporting to you, but, you know, recruiting and HR kinda get lumped in together quite a bit, but they are two different functions, especially if you're growing fast and recruiting a lot of people. But HR and recruiting are typically an operations type of role. You wanna make sure that you're in compliance on things like your HR handbook, and that you're doing all the best practices for hiring. You wanna make sure that you have the right recruiting mechanisms in place, or you're working with recruiters on the outside, or you maybe have a dedicated team internally, so that's really important. Also, there's just kind of, this kind of straddles HR and operations, but there's gonna be a lot of insurance and nitty gritty things that you're gonna need to handle. 

Like this comes to mind, because you're always gonna wanna have employment liability insurance, and maybe you're gonna wanna have your, you know, your general liability insurance and all, errors and emissions and all these kinds of things. This is something that, because you're the COO or VP of Ops, you kinda sit across a lot of different functional aspects of the business. You need to remember to do these things and have these things in place. The next group you're gonna have reporting to you is typically like the technology group. 

Now, this is not like the rockstar developers, if you're a software company or a med tech company, or the scientists, you know, if you're a healthcare biotech company, because those usually report up to like the CTO or the Chief Medical Officer or the CEO. But like your technology group, your technology stack, the people who manage all of your technology, especially the IT services group, they're definitely gonna report up to you. That's just, that is an area of high risk for a VP of Ops or COO, you wanna make sure all this stuff is done correctly.

name: What is the Role of the Chief Operating Officer? COO vs CEO Explained

snippet.title: Startup Tax Return
snippet.description:
Accounting, Bookkeeping, Finance, HR, and Tax for Startups.

Kruze’s tax team helps hundreds of startups cumulatively save millions on their taxes every year - even unprofitable startups can benefit from tax credits. See how much a tax return might cost your company at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup_calculators/how-much-does-a-startup-tax-return-cost/

Video Transcript:

Hi guys, my name is Vanessa Kruze from Kruze Consulting, and today I wanted to go over with you how much should be a startup tax return cost. Here at Kruze Consulting we analyzed thousands of tax returns across many different types of business lines and we actually came up with a calculator that we published to our website at kruzeconsulting.com, so go ahead and check that out. But there are four main things that go into that calculator that I wanted to discuss with you, guys, today. The first thing that we took into consideration is your fundraising realm, are you a seed, series A, or series B company? That definitely folds into the cost. The second thing that we wanted to take into consideration is your industry, are you a marketplace, SASS company, or Fin-tech company? Depending on your industry, so if you're Fin-tech or marketplace, that can be more expensive than just say a plain vanilla SASS or text company. Next thing that we took into consideration is where you have Nexus, that translates into which states are we going to have to file a tax return for you. Where do you have payroll, where do you have rent, where do you have sales, all of that is going to fold of course into your tax return cost. The last thing that we took into consideration is your volume and complexity, do you have a lot of transactions or just a few? And then how complex are you, do you have international components or do you have a parent or subsidiary companies? That can definitely make the workload a little bit more extensive and hence the price go up a little bit more. Just to give you a sense of what a tax return should cost, a plain vanilla series A tech company can expect to spend around $2,000 for their annual tax return. I'm Vanessa Kruze, feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions, and check us out at kruzeconsulting.com, thanks.
