snippet.title: Cooking the Books: What Every Accountant Should Know About Fraud?
snippet.description:
In this video, you'll learn cooking the books, what every accountant should know about fraud.

Need help with your startup’s bookkeeping? Kruze Consulting is a leader in providing low-cost, high-quality financials to funded startups. Learn more at https://kruzeconsulting.com/startup-bookkeeping

Hey, it's Scott Orn at Kruze Consulting. And today I'm answering the question, what is cooking your books? 

This is a slang term for committing financial fraud. So cooking your books is really cute, but you want to stay very, very far away from this. This is one of those things that will follow you through your whole career if you're involved in it. So integrity first, do not commit financial fraud. Now most people who are going to commit financial fraud are probably not going to be watching this or probably have already somehow justified it in their mind. So this is more for the people who are around those people or who may detect financial fraud is happening at their venture capital backed startup. 

And what do you do in that situation? It's kind of nerve-wracking 'cause what if you blow the whistle and people don't take you seriously and you get fired? Or what if the person retaliates against you and does something really, really nasty or threatens you or things like that? So my two cents is, first of all, a startup should always have an independent accounting firm working with them until there's quite a few people in the finance and accounting organization. So that's one way of reducing how financial fraud can be committed, is having checks and balances, having an outside firm, so one person does not control the books. 

We've actually seen this before. We had a company that tried to onboard with us that ended up getting sued by the SEC and turns out they were committing financial fraud. And sure enough, I think the founder and the founder's uncle or something like that were doing the books. So always look for independents, and a second set of eyes is very, very important. 

Now if you are the person at the startup that sees financial fraud being committed, you really need to speak up, go talk to CEO, go talk to the CFO. If it's one of those people and you're very nervous about retaliation, of course you can check in with your independent accounting firm like us at Kruze, but you may have to go straight to a director to like one of the VCs who sits on the board. And they will be very appreciative, let me tell you. This happens sometimes. We've had a couple instances at Kruze where maybe someone in a position of power was buying a lot of stuff for themselves personally with the company's credit card. And we've had to confront them, and we've had to call the board and tell the board what's going on. 

So it's a really, it's a kind of situation no one wants to be in. It really sucks. It's the classic, you know, "Hey, life would be easier if you didn't have to worry about this." So you don't want to be seen as an accomplice, and you really do have the responsibility to speak out. So please do something about it if you see this, even if it's small, even if it's like $5,000, $10,000. Usually, when something like that's happening in a small amount, it's actually happening elsewhere in an organization or that person's committing something even worse, just bigger numbers. You're just not seeing it. 

So speak up to the CEO, CFO, your direct boss. If those people might be in on it, then speak up to the board. The venture capitalist will be very, very appreciative. They want to know the stuff. They're fiduciaries of the business because they're on the board, and they're also fiduciaries of their fund and have a very, very strong obligation to find this stuff out, disclose it, and take care of it, get it fixed. So I hope that helps. 

And again, hopefully, you don't come into contact with anyone cooking their books. If you have any questions on accounting or tax for startups, hit us up at kruzeconsulting.com. And please hit the subscribe button to our channel if you don't mind, thanks.

name: Cooking the Books: What Every Accountant Should Know About Fraud?
